fields.headline: Prince's Trust victimised black footballer
fields.standfirst:
Trust's "impeccable record on race" soiled by unfair dismissal of former Manchester City striker, Darren Beckford

Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Trust's "impeccable record on race" soiled by unfair dismissal of former Manchester City striker, Darren Beckford.
fields.body:
A former Manchester City striker who was victimised by staff of the Prince of Wales's charity because he was black was offered an unreserved apology yesterday.

Darren Beckford was made redundant by the Prince's Trust 14 months after he joined the charity, which aims to help disadvantaged young people, many of them from ethnic minorities.

An industrial tribunal ruled that he had been unfairly dismissed and found that John Scott, divisional director, and Janet Gardner, assistant regional director, had discriminated against him and victimised him. Details of compensation will be announced soon.

A spokeswoman for Prince Charles, who was in Yorkshire yesterday surveying flood damage, said: "Obviously, we are very disappointed. The trust has an impeccable record going back 25 years on racial issues."

In a letter sent yesterday to Mr Beckford, Tom Shebbeare, the trust's chief executive, said the trust was rightly proud of what it had done to encourage young people from ethnic minorities. "But none of that can excuse the discrimination which you have obviously suffered. I hope that we can meet next week so that I can shake your hand and deliver these words face to face."

The trust has launched an inquiry and its findings will be reviewed by an external body. Decisions on disciplinary procedures will not be taken until the review is complete.

Sir Herman Ouseley, former chairman of the commission for racial equality and chairman of the trust's ethnic minority advisory group, will join discussions next week to ensure the trust is not judge and jury on its own case.

Mr Shebbeare said last night that the trust had always prided itself on being good on racial awareness.

He added: "An organisation such as ours puts a huge amount of effort into race awareness training. It may be that this is not a most serious incident, a small thing which is a one-off and to be explained; or it may be something larger that we haven't got right. My responsibility is to put it right."

In a statement issued by his solicitor, Mr Beckford said: "The trust does a wonderful job and I love working with underprivileged young people. The last few months have been a nightmare for me and I am just glad it is over and that my name has been cleared. I feel I can hold my head up again."

Mr Beckford joined the Prince's Trust in September 1998 to lead a project in Manchester for black and Asian young people under the title Don't Let Us be a Minority. He also worked with unemployed young people aged 16 to 21.

"Over a period of several months, Darren felt that he was being picked on," said his solicitor, John Hewison. "A process was started to get rid of him by unfair allegations and interviews. He was also suspended for no real reason.

"He was told that his job was redundant and asked if he wanted to resign."

webTitle: Inquiry to examine racism in prisons

fields.headline: Inquiry to examine racism in prisons
fields.standfirst:
Special report: race issues in the UK
Special report: Prisons
fields.trailText: The commission for racial equality launched a formal investigation yesterday into allegations that the prison service is riddled with racism.
fields.body:
The commission for racial equality launched a formal investigation yesterday into allegations that the prison service is riddled with racism.

The CRE's chairman, Gurbux Singh, promised a "no holds barred" inquiry and predicted it would be as far-reaching as the inquiry into the murder of black teenager Stephen Lawrence, which found widespread racism among the police.

The investigation follows the murder of Zahid Mubarak by his racist cellmate at Feltham young offenders institution in south-west London last March. It will look at Feltham, Brixton prison in south London, where a black officer, Claude Johnson, suffered bullying, and privately-run Parc prison in Bridgend, south Wales, where the chief inspector of prisons, Sir David Ramsbotham, reported "tangible" racism between Welsh and English prisoners and between white inmates and those from ethnic minorities.

Paul Boateng, the prisons minister, and Martin Narey, the prison service director, asked the CRE to look into racism in the service earlier this year. Following a damning internal report this month on conditions at Brixton prison, both admitted the service was institutionally racist.

Mr Singh said the investigation would examine the "worrying gap" between the prison service's policy and practice. "It is simply unacceptable that racial bullying, harassment, violence and indeed murder takes place in the prison service today," he said. "We have considerable powers of investigation and can force individuals to give evidence, and have a right to see any documentation." The inquiry is expected to take eight months and its recommendations will be made public.

If it finds evidence of unlawful racial discrimination, the CRE can force the prison service to comply with a legally binding notice requiring action to stop discriminatory practices and behaviour.

Mr Mubarek, 19, was beaten to death by his cellmate, Robert Stewart, 20, hours before he was to be released. An internal investigation by the prison service found evidence of multiple failings, including a lack of checks on racist letters sent by Stewart.

Mr Johnson, a black prison officer, returned to work at Brixton after winning damages for race discrimination only to be subjected to more bullying. The Brixton report, which was passed to the CRE, found that a small number of staff "sustained and promoted overtly racist behaviour".

Mr Narey said: "I have publicly acknowledged that the service is not only institutionally racist but that pockets of malicious racism exist."

fields.headline: The art of the heist
fields.standfirst: The armed raid on a select Boston museum went without a hitch. The haul was $300 million-worth of old masters. Yet it is unlikely the thieves will ever profit from their crime: a potential ransom deal went sour, the paintings are too famous to be sold. Will they ever be seen again? Ed Butler investigates
fields.trailText: The armed raid on a select Boston museum went without a hitch. The haul was $300 million-worth of old masters. Yet it is unlikely the thieves will ever profit from their crime: a potential ransom deal went sour, the paintings are too famous to be sold. Will they ever be seen again? Ed Butler investigates.
fields.body:
On a frosty October morning in 1997, a small-time criminal named William Youngworth III spoke to reporters outside a Boston gallery. In tones suggesting fatigue and frustration, he warned them that time was running out to resolve one of the most serious art crimes of the century: "They have an opportunity to recover this stuff, a serious opportunity. You know this isn't a joke. The door is closing."

The "stuff" to which he referred was the world's most prized haul of stolen artworks - artworks described as priceless and irreplaceable by their one-time proud owners, the Isabella Stewart Gardner museum in Boston. But the deal Youngworth was offering was never reached. And within weeks he found himself beginning a three-year jail term. His role in the fraught negotiations to retrieve the Gardner's collection went to the heart of the moral dilemmas facing law enforcers pursuing high-value stolen art; it also offered a telling insight into the modus operandi of a criminal go-between

The armed raid that took place just after midnight on Sunday, March 18, 1990, was dazzlingly simple. Two men dressed as police officers approached a side door of the Boston museum. There had been a nearby disturbance, they told the guard inside, and they needed to ensure that everything was all right inside the building. Ignoring official guidelines, the guard agreed to open the door, and within minutes he and another colleague found themselves bound and gagged on the floor.

The primitive security system did not include alarms on the individual artworks, so the thieves could work at their leisure, in an 80-minute spree relieving the museum of 13 pieces in total: 11 paintings and sketches, including works by Rembrandt, Vermeer, Manet and Degas; a 3,000-year-old Chinese beaker; and the bronzed top of a Napoleonic flagstaff. Strangely, they failed to take the museum's most prized work, Titian's Rape Of Europa, which was left untouched, even though it has been described by experts as arguably the greatest painting in America. Nonetheless, the loss was devastating enough. Estimates vary, but they all easily outstrip the valuations of any other theft since the second world war. Most experts price the value of the stolen works at well over $300 million (around £210 million).

For the fine arts community, it was a seismic blow. The head office of the Art Loss Register in London catalogues two of the stolen canvases - Rembrandt's Storm On The Sea Of Galilee and Vermeer's The Concert, one of only 35 by the painter in existence - as the most prized individual artworks currently missing anywhere in the world. And staff at the Gardner museum still lament the theft in emotive terms. "It's been like a death in the family," said Anne Hawley, who had been the museum's director for just five months when the crime occurred. "I've never really recovered from the loss or stopped mourning. This has been a real tragedy, not just for Boston, but for the world. Art exists for the beholder, and to believe that it would be forever lost, hidden in a warehouse someplace, never again to be appreciated, is unspeakably sad."

The crime scene itself produced very little evidence for the police to go on. The two male thieves had been masked and gloved, and said little, according to the guards, except for this tantalising parting shot: "You'll be hearing from us." That promise prompted speculation that the crooks believed that the paintings were insured (they were not), and were banking on a ransom deal. Such deals, though prohibited under most legal systems, are not unheard of in the art world, with thieves usually offering the paintings' return for a small fraction of their market value. "I know of plenty of cases of such deals happening," says one of Britain's leading art loss-adjusters, Charles Hill. "I think it's outrageous, but it happens."

However, in the decade since the theft, neither the authorities nor the museum say they have received any formal ransom demand. More than 2,000 leads have been pursued, taking investigators as far afield as Japan, Latin America and Europe. One suspicion tied the theft to the IRA, which has strong links within Boston's large Irish community, not least because, at around the time of the Gardner heist, IRA operatives were known to be dabbling in the laundering of stolen art as a means of raising funds.

For all the theories, the missing works of art did not resurface. Paintings of such value could scarcely be traded publicly anywhere in the world without the alarm being raised, according to Tom Cassano, the FBI officer who has been in charge of the investigation throughout. He expresses bemusement: "It's the biggest whodunnit I've ever worked on, as well as the most frustrating. We haven't got a clue as to who is responsible."

Some would say that such statements should not be taken entirely at face value, given the FBI's role in the later events of 1997. The situation developed quietly enough. William Youngworth, a small-time antiques dealer from the Boston area with a not-inconsiderable criminal record, found himself the subject of increasing police attention. He cut an unlikely figure as a supposed criminal mastermind: a shambling, overweight man in his late 30s, Youngworth lived unpretentiously in a Boston suburb, his lifestyle providing nothing to indicate a man who had profited from the art heist of the century - in fact, he had been in jail when the robbery took place.

Even so, police informants were still naming him as a possible link. "They raided my house," says Youngworth. "They turned everything over." In a large garage packed full of antiques, the police failed to find anything incriminating, except the butt of a marijuana joint, three antique firearms and a stolen van, on which basis they immediately charged him. It was, according to Youngworth, the first of numerous attempts to pursuade him to co-operate.

At first, he denied he could be of any help. "I tried to push this away from me," he said. "I tried to explain that I really didn't know anything." In return for the police dropping the charges against him, he says, he engineered the return of a royal seal dating back to the 17th century, one that had been stolen some years earlier. But this tactic backfired, seeming only to whet the FBI's appetite. State attorney Marty Leppo said that the authorities were now convinced they had a lead: "When he returned the seal, somebody said, 'What else can you do? How about the Gardner?' And then, all of a sudden, Youngworth is in the newspaper."

Police sources were rumoured to have been behind the leak to the Boston press of his suspected link to the Gardner collection. Tom Mashberg of the Boston Herald was one of the first to sniff a story. Indeed, he takes much of the credit for persuading Youngworth to go public at this stage. "What we did, in the grand tradition of tabloid newspapers, is that we smoked him out," says Mashberg. "We put some heat on him. And it took about three articles with his name in it before he said, 'Maybe you want to talk to me before you write your next story.'" Youngworth concedes that the Herald's approach worked. "Basically, Mashberg extorted me," he says. "He said the pressure in the newspapers was going to become much worse if I didn't agree to help him with his story." The heavy pressure may have forced Youngworth's hand, but involving the media may also have been a tactic that the authorities later came to regret. Youngworth would deal, but only on his terms.

The Gardner museum had already raised a reward, by way of private donors, for the return of the collection. This at first totalled $1 million. But in 1997, it went up to $5 million, by far the largest reward ever known in connection with an art theft. Rewards are not, of course, unusual in themselves - insurers regard cash incentives as by far the most effective way to uncover art crooks, although, publicly at least, there are strict rules governing their payment. Above all, for obvious reasons, the money should not go to anyone implicated in the theft itself, and typically the reward should lead to at least one prosecution. On the other hand, it's common knowledge that those who receive such rewards are unlikely to be paragons of virtue. Added to which, it is not always easy to sift out who finally ends up with the money once it has been paid. Mashberg puts it succinctly: "When you put $5 million on the table, you hope that it's Mother Teresa who returns the artwork. More than likely, it'll be somebody in the criminal underworld."

For Youngworth, the $5 million was only his first demand. He also asked federal negotiators for immunity from prosecution. Believing that they'd tricked him over the return of the seal, he also asked for cast-iron legal guarantees. He says it was only when he started talking about putting things in writing that they started to prevaricate. "All of a sudden, they wanted me to turn the stuff in first, and then they would discuss a reward afterwards. I said no way. I wasn't going to fall on my sword for them."

The state prosecutor, Donald Stern, denies that any verbal offers were made. But he does concede opening talks with Youngworth, who by this stage had decided to use the media to his advantage. He appeared on local television saying that he had definite access to the art haul. But now he was upping his demands. He wanted not just the money and immunity, but also the release of his long-term friend and associate, Myles Connor. Connor, at that time serving an 11-year jail term for armed robbery in Pennsylvania, was already a byword for art crime in New England - according to one Boston investigator, when any art went missing in Boston, the first question was always: "Where was Myles?"

With Connor's sudden entry into the whole equation, law enforcers may well have felt a cold shudder down their collective spines. For one thing, he far more clearly matched the profile of the Mr Big they had been seeking than Youngworth. A sometime lead singer in a club rock'n'roll band, Myles And The Wild Ones, Connor displays all the qualities of a flamboyant, even arrogant, criminal operator. He admits to more than 30 art thefts in a 20-year career dating back to the 60s, and recently boasted that the museum security hadn't yet been invented that could keep him out.

For much of his criminal life, he appears to have succeeded where most have failed - he makes art theft pay. Usually, it is impossible to yield more than a tiny fraction of the market value of well-known artwork once it is stolen; at best, it becomes collateral for drugs or other stolen goods, circulating among criminals until someone can find a low-risk way of recycling it on to the legitimate market several years later. But in Connor's hands, stolen art seems to have become a major bargaining chip, either to extort secret ransoms from insurers or to secure immunity from prosecution. Most famously, in 1975, he apparently negotiated the drastic reduction of one art theft charge against him by returning the proceeds of another, a Rembrandt, which at the time was the most precious artwork ever to have been stolen in the US.

Extraordinarily, Connor now admits to having stolen the Dutch master himself from the Boston Museum of Fine Arts while on bail for the other thefts. "He's beaten the system before and he's got away with it," says private investigator Charlie Moore. "I don't know anyone who's been as successful as he has."

Like Youngworth, Connor was in jail at the time of the Gardner heist and was therefore not a direct suspect, but few could now dismiss the suspicion that he had masterminded the operation from behind bars, and was attempting one of his trademark scams to extort police concessions. Connor was summoned to participate in the now less-than-secret talks between Youngworth and the federal prosecutor's office. But the Boston authorities wanted evidence that these con men were for real. The evidence arrived in dramatic style.

Mashberg had been Youngworth's main contact with the media from the start. Now Mashberg found himself talking to mysterious figures who were offering to take him for a drive downtown for the scoop of a lifetime. "I was out on a limb on this," he says. "It was late, it was dark. Nobody knew. Not even my editor." One night in mid-August 1997, at around 2am, he was taken by some decidedly nervous and furtive-looking figures to a disused warehouse in central Boston. He describes a woman with dreadlocks coming to the car. "Billy sent us," the driver told her. Mashberg says she and other men took him up some stairs to a storage locker, where they pulled out a rolled-up canvas. By torchlight he saw what he believes was Rembrandt's Storm On The Sea Of Galilee.

Mashberg was pledged to remain silent for a week until his underworld contacts could clear the site. Then, on August 27, he splashed the story across the Herald's front page. "We've seen it!" proclaimed the headline. Based on his description of a number of usually hidden features on the rear of the canvas, Mashberg says the Gardner museum confirmed that what he'd seen must have been either the original or a remarkably good forgery.

The Herald's revelations put the spotlight firmly on the prosecuting attorney, in this case Stern. Hounded by reporters, Stern announced curtly that "no good purpose was being served by competing press conferences and competing press statements". His response to the sighting of Rembrandt's Storm was to declare that Mashberg was not an expert, and therefore more conclusive proof had to be found. But now Youngworth was being taken seriously, at least by the museum, a trustee of which advanced him $10,000 to escape the media pressures of Boston and move to New York. It was from New York that the next piece of evidence arrived in the mail.

An envelope, containing photographs and tiny samples, allegedly scratched from the surface of one of the paintings, landed on Mashberg's desk. The Herald sent for one of the highest authorities in the land, Professor Walter McCrone, who had been instrumental in the forensic analysis of the Turin Shroud and had advised on the restoration of the Sistine Chapel. He quickly concluded that the paint chips bore all the hallmarks of vintage Rembrandt.

"They were perfect," said McCrone. "They looked exactly like the pigments and paint layers of 17th-century Holland." Unfortunately for McCrone, he had missed something - the absence of one layer of varnish used by Rembrandt in his work of that period. The museum contradicted the professor's findings, a point eagerly pounced on by the federal authorities. "Despite giving them every opportunity," says the FBI's Cassano, "Youngworth and Connor could never produce adequate proof that they had access to the Gardner collection." Connor was sent back to his cell in Pennsylvania and Youngworth found himself back in the dock.

But the point the authorities refused to address is that the analysis showed that the samples were equally consistent with that other 17th-century Dutch master on the missing list, Vermeer's The Concert. "No one other than Professor McCrone ever said the paint chips came from the Rembrandt," says Youngworth pointedly. It's a statement endorsed by Mashberg, who says that the police were looking for a way out of the negotiations. "Youngworth was behaving like a sleazy con man," he says. "He made everybody nervous. He was the kind of person who made inflammatory remarks, and the feds decided to take it personally. They didn't want a deal with men like these." "If they can't kick in a door and hold a press conference, then they don't want to deal with it."

Many officials at the Gardner museum, and also some officers at the FBI, did favour some form of compromise, but those higher up in the legal establishment had no desire to send such a message to the criminal fraternity at large. The attorney general's office in Washington warned against pandering to "cultural terrorism". Alan Dershowitz, the celebrated Boston defence lawyer and himself a keen art collector, spells it out: "It's a very short-sighted policy. If, in the end, we pay for these pictures, there will be 10 more pieces of art stolen in the next decade by people who say, 'Look, they stole the Rembrandt, they got rich, why not us?'"

For Youngworth, imprisonment was not necessarily the worst aspect of late 1997. He started receiving messages from unnamed criminals threatening the kidnap of his six-year-old son if he didn't hand over the paintings to them. And then, soon after that, his wife was found dead at home, apparently after taking an accidental drugs overdose. His son has since been taken into state care.

Since then, Youngworth has devoted much of his time to pursuing an exhaustive appeal claim and writing angry letters threatening vengeance on all those whom he believes have conspired to destroy him. He says the federal authorities have not let up trying to pitch deals at him, even though he's in jail, offering him early release in return for relevant information.

"He doesn't respond well to pressure tactics," says Mashberg, who has come to know Youngworth as well as most. "He gets very angry. He'll sit in jail for 15 years out of spite, rather than tell them anything."

Thankfully for Youngworth, he has not had to sit behind bars for quite that long. Despite a hard-fought attempt by state prosecutors to attach a so-called "habitual offender" tag to his sentence, he walked free from the Massachusetts' South-Eastern Correctional Centre in September this year. He still maintains that he has access to those holding the Gardner collection, but adds that he would be reluctant to cut a deal now. "I just want to walk away from this whole thing," he says. "The prerequisite for my co-operation is that somebody is going to have to admit what they did to me, and why." No one seems likely to do that, even if Youngworth's claims of victimisation were to be judicially upheld.

Unofficially, many believe that Youngworth, despite his claims, no longer holds the key to the missing treasure. One theory goes that Connor may have inherited the collection from fellow thieves while he was in jail and that Youngworth took custody of them on a temporary basis only. "Youngworth went through all of Connor's belongings after he went to jail," suggests one source. "He might easily have stumbled across these paintings in the false bottom of some kind of case." It's a theory that Connor has tacitly encouraged.

Hardly shy of the media himself, Connor has admitted in one interview to devising a plan to rob the Gardner museum, a scheme that he claims two other criminals copied without his knowledge. fields.bodyText: On a frosty October morning in 1997, a small-time criminal named William Youngworth III spoke to reporters outside a Boston gallery. In tones suggesting fatigue and frustration, he warned them that time was running out to resolve one of the most serious art crimes of the century: "They have an opportunity to recover this stuff, a serious opportunity. You know this isn't a joke. The door is closing." The "stuff" to which he referred was the world's most prized haul of stolen artworks - artworks described as priceless and irreplaceable by their one-time proud owners, the Isabella Stewart Gardner museum in Boston. But the deal Youngworth was offering was never reached. And within weeks he found himself beginning a three-year jail term. His role in the fraught negotiations to retrieve the Gardner's collection went to the heart of the moral dilemmas facing law enforcers pursuing high-value stolen art; it also offered a telling insight into the modus operandi of a criminal go-between The armed raid that took place just after midnight on Sunday, March 18, 1990, was dazzlingly simple. Two men dressed as police officers approached a side door of the Boston museum. There had been a nearby disturbance, they told the guard inside, and they needed to ensure that everything was all right inside the building. Ignoring official guidelines, the guard agreed to open the door, and within minutes he and another colleague found themselves bound and gagged on the floor. The primitive security system did not include alarms on the individual artworks, so the thieves could work at their leisure, in an 80-minute spree relieving the museum of 13 pieces in total: 11 paintings and sketches, including works by Rembrandt, Vermeer, Manet and Degas; a 3,000-year-old Chinese beaker; and the bronzed top of a Napoleonic flagstaff. Strangely, they failed to take the museum's most prized work, Titian's Rape Of Europa, which was left untouched, even though it has been described by experts as arguably the greatest painting in America. Nonetheless, the loss was devastating enough. Estimates vary, but they all easily outstrip the valuations of any other theft since the second world war. Most experts price the value of the stolen works at well over $300 million (around £210 million). For the fine arts community, it was a seismic blow. The head office of the Art Loss Register in London catalogues two of the stolen canvases - Rembrandt's Storm On The Sea Of Galilee and Vermeer's The Concert, one of only 35 by the painter in existence - as the most prized individual artworks currently missing anywhere in the world. And staff at the Gardner museum still lament the theft in emotive terms. "It's been like a death in the family," said Anne Hawley, who had been the museum's director for just five months when the crime occurred. "I've never really recovered from the loss or stopped mourning. This has been a real tragedy, not just for Boston, but for the world. Art exists for the beholder, and to believe that it would be forever lost, hidden in a warehouse someplace, never again to be appreciated, is unspeakably sad." The crime scene itself produced very little evidence for the police to go on. The two male thieves had been masked and gloved, and said little, according to the guards, except for this tantalising parting shot: "You'll be hearing from us." That promise prompted speculation that the crooks believed that the paintings were insured (they were not), and were banking on a ransom deal. Such deals, though prohibited under most legal systems, are not unheard of in the art world, with thieves usually offering the paintings' return for a small fraction of their market value. "I know of plenty of cases of such deals happening," says one of Britain's leading art loss-adjusters, Charles Hill. "I think it's outrageous, but it happens." However, in the decade since the theft, neither the authorities nor the museum say they have received any formal ransom demand. More than 2,000 leads have been pursued, taking investigators as far afield as Japan, Latin America and Europe. One suspicion tied the theft to the IRA, which has strong links within Boston's large Irish community, not least because, at around the time of the Gardner heist, IRA operatives were known to be dabbling in the laundering of stolen art as a means of raising funds. For all the theories, the missing works of art did not resurface. Paintings of such value could scarcely be traded publicly anywhere in the world without the alarm being raised, according to Tom Cassano, the FBI officer who has been in charge of the investigation throughout. He expresses bemusement: "It's the biggest whodunnit I've ever worked on, as well as the most frustrating. We haven't got a clue as to who is responsible." Some would say that such statements should not be taken entirely at face value, given the FBI's role in the later events of 1997. The situation developed quietly enough. William Youngworth, a small-time antiques dealer from the Boston area with a not-inconsiderable criminal record, found himself the subject of increasing police attention. He cut an unlikely figure as a supposed criminal mastermind: a shambling, overweight man in his late 30s, Youngworth lived unpretentiously in a Boston suburb, his lifestyle providing nothing to indicate a man who had profited from the art heist of the century - in fact, he had been in jail when the robbery took place. Even so, police informants were still naming him as a possible link. "They raided my house," says Youngworth. "They turned everything over." In a large garage packed full of antiques, the police failed to find anything incriminating, except the butt of a marijuana joint, three antique firearms and a stolen van, on which basis they immediately charged him. It was, according to Youngworth, the first of numerous attempts to pursuade him to co-operate. At first, he denied he could be of any help. "I tried to push this away from me," he said. "I tried to explain that I really didn't know anything." In return for the police dropping the charges against him, he says, he engineered the return of a royal seal dating back to the 17th century, one that had been stolen some years earlier. But this tactic backfired, seeming only to whet the FBI's appetite. State attorney Marty Leppo said that the authorities were now convinced they had a lead: "When he returned the seal, somebody said, 'What else can you do? How about the Gardner?' fields.headline: Cohen plays it cool
fields.trailText: Abby Joseph Cohen, the Wall Street guru at investment bank Goldman Sachs, gave an upbeat assessment of US markets yesterday, despite the uncertainty caused by the chaotic presidential election.
fields.body:
Abby Joseph Cohen, the Wall Street guru at investment bank Goldman Sachs, gave an upbeat assessment of US markets yesterday, despite the uncertainty caused by the chaotic presidential election.

Speaking in London at a Goldman conference, she said she was more bullish about the coming 12 months than she had been earlier this year.

"We believe the US economy and the US financial market are in far better condition than they were in the period of March 2000," Ms Cohen said.

She reiterated her target for the benchmark S&P 500 index was 1,575, from around 1,375 now, and said her target for mid-year 2001 was 1,650.

At the end of a European tour of Goldman clients, she tried to play down the jitters linked to the US poll and declared the nation unconcerned about the level of the euro.

She said oil prices, also contributing to stock market caution this year, will be "notably" lower in 12 months after peaking this winter. But Ms Cohen also noted that the chance of supply being disrupted was greater as a result of any violence in the Middle East.

In contrast to March 2000, when she was concerned about unsustainable growth in the US economy, she forecast yesterday that economic growth would be a more sustainable 3% and the S&P 500 companies' profits would increase by an average 7%.

But she made few changes to the advice offered in March, just after the major stock markets slumped on jitters about"new" economy stocks.

webTitle: Renting mobile phones for use abroad

fields.headline: Renting mobile phones for use abroad
fields.standfirst:
I want to know of a phone company that rents mobile phones by the week to be used on the continent during holidays.
 M Neery
fields.trailText: I want to know of a phone company that rents mobile phones by the week to be used on the continent during holidays.
fields.body:
• As far as I know, there are two ways for non-mobile owners to use a mobile abroad.

Firstly, the country you are visiting will almost certainly have a mobile company willing to rent you a phone during your stay. Mobiles are so prolific these days you can even do it in Cuba. Cubacel (tel 00 53 7802222/555511, www.cubacel.com) charges US$10 a day for the phone, plus 90 cents a minute for calls.

Alternatively, a new company called Mint (0800 00 33 55, www.mint-tele.com) sells pre-pay SIM cards that fit into most mobiles, and can be used in just about any country.

Considering you can buy a mobile second-hand these days for next to nothing, this latter option is possibly the best.
S.C.O.

• Try Carphone Warehouse (0800 125000, cpw.hire@adamphones.com or www.carphonewarehouse.com). Hire is £1 per day or free if you spend enough on calls. They are a friendly, helpful independent company.
Barbara Cummins

• Independent Phone Rentals (020-8878 6000, e-mail: enquiries@phone-rentals.co.uk) specialises in the short-term hire of mobile phones. GSM phones can be rented by the day (minimum rental period three days) for use in over 100 countries throughout the world. Nextel Digital mobile phones offering coverage in 9,000 towns and cities across the US are also available for rental.

For travel to more remote places, satellite phones the size of a laptop computer, can be rented by the week. A next-day delivery service is available throughout the UK, Monday to Friday.
David Tomley
Managing director

fields.headline: Face to Faith
fields.trailText: As a pantheist, my beliefs do not include a personal afterlife for my soul.
fields.body:
As a pantheist, my beliefs do not include a personal afterlife for my soul. I often get asked: "How can you face up to total extinction? How can pantheism compete with religions that offer immortality?"

First of all, religion can offer something only if that something exists. If immortality for the soul does not in fact exist, no religion is in any position to "offer" it to anybody, any more than they can offer free pots of gold at the end of rainbows.

As far as we can see from external evidence, there is no individual afterlife. As Job says - and as most Jews believed till the second century BC - "Man lies down and rises not again, till the heavens are no more he will not awake." Near-death experiences are not death experiences.

Religions offer the hope of immortality. They give a promissory note to clutch as you tread life's path. Yet however blissful the promise of an afterlife, almost everyone clings to this life for as long as possible.

Those religions that offer the hope of bliss also suggest a terrible fear. If you are not judged good enough, your afterlife will be spent in torment. These days most people conveniently take only heaven and try to forget the hell bit. But is heaven actually desirable? The Catholic catechism tells us it will be a state of supreme, definitive happiness, a communion of life and love with the Trinity, Mary, the angels and saints. Dante portrays us all sitting around in concentric circles like the petals of a gigantic flower, gazing adoringly at God.

Probably most folk see heaven like the Elysian fields, a leafy place where they will be reunited with their loved - and not-so-loved - ones. And how old will they be up there? My wife's mother died aged 26 - my wife is now old enough to be her mother's mother. Will she revert to being a child in heaven? And if she does, how will our children or I feel when they are reunited with her?

I would rather be reincarnated. Buddhists believe reincarnation is something to be avoided. Most modern reincarnationists find the idea of coming back to earth again appealing. I must admit I do. But I don't believe it happens. Even if it did, it would involve a total erasure of all memories of this life. There would be no continuity: the sense of self that the hope of immortality aims to preserve would vanish once you drank the waters of Lethe. Surely then that draught is just the same as individual extinction, and just as much to be feared?

I view death simply. When I die, my personal consciousness will cease. But this is the only sense in which I will be extinguished. In many other ways I will carry on. My genes will live on in my children. Memories of me will persist in the living. Actions I have done and things I have made will go on leaving their small ripples through time.

All of us know that we live on in these ways. If we believed this was the only way we lived on, would we not strive harder to leave happy memories behind?

My body, I hope, will have a natural funeral. Despite all efforts at cycling and recycling, I have done enough damage to nature while alive; I would not want to add to it when dead, pumped full of formaldehyde, encased in lead and hardwood. If I am cremated in a linen shroud or wicker basket, as I plan to be, most of my carbon and nitrogen and water will rise into the atmosphere and ride around the globe on the winds. My ashes will be scattered in my favourite copse on Hampstead Heath. I will be one with nature. For me, this idea is pure bliss. I could not dream of better.

 Dr Paul Harrison is President of the World Pantheist Movement (www.pantheism.net). His book Elements of Pantheism is published by Element Books.

fields.headline: Nature trail
fields.standfirst: Rob Penn gets on his bike to see the animals that he is raising money to save
fields.trailText: Rob Penn gets on his bike to see the animals that he is raising money to save.
fields.body:
We were an unlikely cast for an African adventure - a secretary, two insurance brokers, a schoolgirl, a couple of mature students, a mum and a management consultant. Yet in five days, we cycled a 200-mile circuit on dirt roads around Laikipia, a beautiful plateau the size of Wales five hours' drive north of Nairobi in the central Kenyan highlands.

The region is well known for its wildlife conservation and we were raising money that will be invested back into local projects, via Save the Rhino, the charity that organised our trip.

How was the cycling?

On paper, the challenge sounded like a Herculean task. In reality, it was tough but never arduous - 40 miles a day is not a huge distance to travel. Our belongings were transported, along with the "tented camp" each day.

And, although the bumpy roads and the midday sun ensured that we were happy to reach each day's destination, nobody was ever reluctant to begin the following morning.

In terms of cycling experience, the nine-person team could not have been more diverse: one person had ridden across continents, another around Solihull. In age, we ranged from 18 to 37.

In fitness, we covered the spectrum from marathon runners to busy housewives. However, we all kept the same pace and nobody complained. Regular stops for water, punctures and photographic opportunities ironed out the differences.

No one used the support vehicle to hitch a ride, but we had all done some training. Sharon, a secretary from Birmingham, was probably the least experienced cyclist. Her training regime was 30 miles twice a week for three months - the minimum you could get away with and enjoy the challenge.

The bike

I took the bike that I use to commute across London every day - a solid, no frills mountain bike worth £350. You could not get away with anything less, but more - namely a bike with front suspension forks - would improve life in the saddle. Out of the nine riders, five of us brought bikes from the UK. The rest hired from Bike Treks, the ground operator based in Nairobi, for $50.

Charles, the mechanic, fixed emergency repairs by the roadside and major problems in the evenings. We kept him busy oiling gears and repairing punctures: though people tried gel-filled tyres and reinforced tubes, they were still no match for the thorns of the African bush.

Was there much wildlife in the bush?

A huge amount - Laikipia is one of the few areas in East Africa where game numbers have risen in the last 20 years. The ride was across a number of vast, privately-owned "ranches", where the game roamed freely. On one occasion, giraffe, eland, gazelle, zebra, buffalo and baboons swept across the road in front of us beneath the Loldaiga hills.

The whole point of being on a bike was that there were countless opportunities to see the wildlife at very close quarters. Herds of elephant rumbled past us as well as kudu, impala, warthog and dik-dik.

One evening, we saw four young male cheetahs skulking in the yellow grass. Nigel, our guide, was able to settle any anxiety we had about the proximity of the big game, as well as help to identify many of the great African birds - Goliath herons, Marshall eagles, hammerkops and vultures to name a few. We also had impromptu lessons on the medicinal qualities of various acacia trees and in identifying animal spoors.

On the last day, and without bikes, we visited the Lewa Wildlife Conservancy to track rhino, endangered beasts that some of the money raised will specifically benefit.

The daily routine

Each morning, Kip, the camp cook, woke us at 6am with a bowl of hot water delivered to our tents. By 7.30am, we had packed, breakfasted, braved the mobile loo - a hole in the ground with a canvas awning - applied factor 15 and filled our bottles with boiled water.

By 1pm, we would be at the next campsite, ready for a swim and lunch. The afternoons were spent lazing in the shade, reading and writing diaries. By 6pm, washed and brushed, we were sipping "sundowners" around huge campfires.

On a couple of evenings we had some arbitrary entertainment - two Maasai tribesmen talked to us about their customs and the director of a local wildlife research centre told us about the Laikipia ecosystem.

Dinner was taken at 8pm and by 10pm, we were all zipped up in our sleeping bags, listening to the trill of the bush and the distant hooting of hyenas.

Camping and food

We slept in small, single tents which we erected each night and ate under a canvas mess. All the campsites were in wonderful locations - by rivers and waterfalls, on sandy luggas (dry riverbeds) and in deep bush. I chose to wash in the rivers (crocodile free, I was assured), but there were hot showers on request.

For city-dwellers, the brilliance of the stars and the serenity of the bush took some getting used to. For Brummie Sharon, night one was a trauma. This was her maiden trip to Africa and her first time in a tent. After campfire stories about man-eating lions, she had a sleepless night, clutching her torch. But, by the end of the week, she was relishing the wilderness almost as much as the Maasai.

Head chef MC and Kip marshalled a team of men who constructed the remainder of the camp and prepared the food. Meals were not epicurean, but borstal fare would have appealed after six hours of pedalling. Breakfast was fresh fruit and porridge followed by eggs and bacon, washed down with campfire coffee that moved my insides faster than a charging rhino. We ate packed lunches by the side of the road. Dinner was three courses - soup, meat and a sweet.

Drinking water was boiled and cooled. We paid for our own beer and drank plenty of it. There was nearly a mutiny one night when we ran out. The alternative was Safari Cane, a mean local hooch, which had us all, well, caned on safari.

A vehicle followed us every day, carrying water, drinks and bananas. We all had our own energy snacks - everything from dextrose to Kendal mint cake - and these little luxuries counted for a great deal when we were exhausted at the start of a hill.

Would I do it again?

On the final day of our ride, we were chased into the campsite by thrashing rain. As we came roaring down the last hill to reach the Ngare Ndare River, a herd of impala exploded in every direction, leaping over rocks and fallen trees - a dramatic end to our challenge. Under the dripping mess tent, slugging Tusker beer, the bold talk was not if we would all do it together again next year, but where.

· For more information on the Rhino Cycle Kenya 2001, to be run next September, and other Rhino Adventures, contact: Save the Rhino at adventures@rhinos.demon.co.uk or check the website at www.savetherhino.com. Alternatively, phone for an information pack on 020 7357 7474.

The point of the exercise

Who can apply?
Rhino Adventures are open to anyone over 18 years of age who is capable of getting fit before departure and willing to raise funds on behalf of Save the Rhino (SRI) and wildlife conservation projects in Kenya.

What is the cause?

SRI's aim is to provide a protected habitat for rhinos and other endangered wildlife through support for game rangers, anti-poaching initiatives and through community conservation programmes.

What is the deal?

You pay a £250 registration fee and commit to raising a minimum of £2,400 in sponsorship.

Where does the money go?

The registration fee covers all organisational and promotional costs of the challenge. Of the £2,400 sponsorship, half covers the cost of the challenge package. The remaining 50% (£1,200) is donated to projects. All funds raised over £2,400 are donated directly to projects.

Funds from Rhino Cycle Kenya will be used for:

· a rhino protection programme in the Lewa Downs Conservancy, home to a growing population of black and white rhino;

· an environmental education programme in schools throughout the Laikipia region. This involves the development of an environmental curriculum for teachers and a sponsored bus, which will tour schools supporting the new curriculum.

How fit do you have to be?

A person of average fitness can manage, given a few months' preparation.

What to take?

· a decent mountain bike, preferably with front suspension;

· cycling shorts and a hat;

· a bum bag to carry day kit;

· heavy sun block and lip salve;

· sunglasses with string;

· a torch;

· a light sleeping bag;

· binoculars;

· swimwear;

· energy bars and glucose sweets - enough for a couple of sugar hits each day.

fields.headline: Leigh Bowery (Seated), Lucian Freud (1990)
fields.trailText: · View Freud painting the work online
fields.body:
· View Freud painting the work online

Artist: Lucian Freud, born in Berlin in 1922. His parents left for Britain in 1933 and Freud became a British citizen in 1939. He is unique as a 20th-century painter in his dedication to the portrait he has expanded the portrait's territory from faces to naked knees, nipples, feet and genitals.

Freud has no living rivals as a painter of portraits.

Subject: Leigh Bowery (1961- 94), a man of gargantuan scale physically and culturally, a transvestite performance artist, fetishist designer, leader of the band Minty and theatrical giver of birth.

Distinguishing features: Bowery is a character out of Renaissance art - perhaps Silenus, the companion of Dionysus. His flesh is a magnificent ruin, at once damaged and riotously alive. Who knew skin was so particoloured? To count the hues of even one of his feet is impossible: purple, grey, yellow, brown, the paint creamy, calloused, bulging. In a velvet chair tilted down towards us on the raked stage of the wooden studio floor, his mass looms up and dwarfs us. Walk close your eyes are probably the height of his penis. Bowery's violet-domed, wrinkly tube hangs between thighs marked with sinister spots or cuts his knees are massive. Bowery is a painted monument who quietly contemplates his existence inside this flesh.

This is the first portrait in a series that Freud began after seeing the performer strut his stuff at the Anthony d'Offay Gallery in 1988. Bowery regularly appeared on high heels, wearing latex body stockings and masks his vocals for his art band Minty were mainly orgiastic screams over rasping feedback. "I found him perfectly beautiful," Freud said when Bowery came to his studio and posed nude. What was planned as one portrait became a sequence. Bowery's presence in the studio is another performance, a self-revealing act of theatre. Bowery was a man who liked to wear disguises - a masked reveller, here unmasked. Freud is sometimes accused of sadism toward his models. But Bowery was a subject able to answer back, someone with enough charisma and courage to face the artist's inquiry head on.

Some of the paintings in this series are named for Leigh Bowery others are called more impersonal things such as Naked Man, Back View (1991-92). That painting treats Bowery as sublime spectacle: his body's hugeness is examined in a decoratively grotesque way.

This painting, by contrast, is noble, lyrical and loving. There's a comedy to the squareness of Bowery's torso and the sagging second face of his nipples and belly. But look at the grace of his left hand draped over the chair, the colossal scale of his feet. Those are a Roman emperor's feet. After a career of more than half a century, Freud can legitimate be compared to the supreme masters of the portrait, even to Rembrandt and Velazquez.

Inspirations and influences: The ambition of Freud's portraiture demands comparison with the Old Masters. Freud has even done a series of self-portraits over the years, charting his progress from handsome young man to naked old artist waving his brush like a weapon in Painter Working, Reflection (1993). Where Rembrandt painted people in elaborate costumes, Freud is a painter of nakedness his antecedents are the great French painters of the body - Gericault, Courbet, Manet and Degas. This monumental portrait most of all evokes the grand political portraits of Jacques Louis David.

Where is it? In Painting the Century at the National Portrait Gallery, St Martin's Place, London WC2 (020-7306 0055), until February 4.

First Impressions: A peaceful, luxurious haven amid the buzz of central London. The eclectic mix of furnishings and decor gives the feeling of a splendid private residence where you immediately feel at home.

What are the rooms like: The Grand Suite is grand without being intimidating, perfect for entertaining or just relaxing on your own.

The bed test: Four-poster luxury. Just pull the drapes around the bed, sink your head into the feather pillows and London could be a million miles away.

The bathroom test: Marble tiled with powerful shower and generous supply of oils and salts. A second cloakroom is a useful addition for those seeking a place for contemplation.

The restaurant: No formal restaurant, but the café bar serves breakfast (continental £12.50 or full English £17) and light meals in comfortable surroundings. Room service is 24 hours.

What is there to see within walking distance? Oxford Street, Bond Street and Mayfair are minutes away. Hotel guests also have access to the private gardens of Portman Square. Fashionable bars and restaurants are a short stroll away at St Christopher's Place.

What is there to see within a 10-minute drive? Traffic permitting, everything that London's West End has to offer.

How much for a night? A one-bedroom Grand Suite costs £390, a Deluxe double/ twin £190, a one-bedroom suite £225 and a two-bedroom Deluxe Suite from £420-£480, plus VAT. Special weekend rates with breakfast, half a bottle of champagne and a box of handmade fudge included in the price.

Would you go back? If I could afford it, I would spend a week in a Grand Suite here at least once a year to enjoy the relaxed luxury and space of the hotel while taking advantage of its central location.

fields.headline: True to type
fields.standfirst: The readers' editor on... the Guardian's catalogue of errors
fields.trailText: The readers' editor on... the Guardian's catalogue of errors
fields.body:
The book of corrections and clarifications that many of you have been asking for comes out next week (details below). To be clear about it, it contains a selection of only the more humorous entries from the daily corrections column, in practically all of which the joke is on us. You may be forgiven for laughing - in fact, I challenge you not to laugh. The more serious lapses, dealing with which remains the main purpose of the corrections column, you will not find in the book, for obvious reasons.

To be even clearer about it, only about one-third of the book is made up of corrections and clarifications. The rest comprises 50 or so of these Open Door columns in which a wide variety of subjects concerning the Guardian, raised by readers, is discussed.

Several of the columns deal with Guardian English, including its (continuing) tolerance of expletives, although one effect of reader interest in this area was the introduction of guidelines by the editor. These are now incorporated in the style guide, which those of you with website access may consult for yourselves. Those of you who read the Guardian only on the website may be less interested than our terrestrial readers in the piece explaining why the ink rubs off on your hands, which is also included.

A good number of the columns I have chosen to reprint deal with ethical questions: for instance, to do with our use of pictures of people killed in wars and atrocities around the world, where we gradually appear to have extended the boundaries of what is thought to be permissible in terms of photography. Or they discuss the terminology we use when referring to various forms of illness or disability, or consider how we should define freedom in relation to the internet. These discussions with readers now seem perfectly normal, and stimulate or revive discussion within the office, reminding us to keep checking our motives.

The editor of the paper, whose idea it was to introduce the role to the Guardian, hazards the prediction in a foreword to the book, that within five years every broadsheet national paper (in the United Kingdom) that wishes to retain the trust of its readers will have some sort of regular corrections column. Within 10 years, he suggests, such a column will be commonplace in tabloids.

One of the things that the daily, inexorable revelation of the paper's errors has done is concentrate minds inside the paper on efforts to reduce their number. The deputy editor (news) says there is a real will to do this, and that the column has reinforced this by heightening everyone's awareness of pitfalls.

The question asked in exasperation at the revelation of so many errors, even on occasion by those who welcome the frankness of the corrections, is: yes, but what are you actually doing about it?

In the first place, more frequent investigations are being carried out to trace the sources of mistakes, not for punitive purposes but to try to understand what went wrong and avoid a similar thing happening again. The electronic technology makes it comparatively easy to do that now, with successive versions of a story or page retrievable with the names of the editors who handled them at each stage.

The setup for revising material before publication is being looked at again, with the aim of making sure that each department has an adequate system and that responsibility for ensuring that corrections are made is clearly defined.

Efforts are also being made to make sure that the personal alarm systems - the warning bells that should go off when the reporter ventures on to legally dangerous ground - are in place and working. It is hoped to run, before Christmas if possible, two "master classes" open to all staff, on libel and contempt; and three half-day seminars on general law for journalists, designed to help the Guardian's trainees in particular.

The Guardian has a very good two-strand legal system: it has a team of barristers, one of whom comes into the paper every evening to read for libel, and it has an excellent team of in-house lawyers whose advice can be sought at any time. The question for the journalist is: do you know when to seek the lawyer's advice? After publication is too late.

Every staff journalist on the Guardian is about to receive a copy of the corrections book as a gift from the editor of the paper. Happy Christmas. Any royalties that would have come to me, by the way, I have directed to the Newspaper Press Fund, a charity which helps journalists and their dependants in need. I like the idea of someone deriving modest benefit from the errors of our ways.

 Corrections and Clarifications, published by Guardian Newspapers Limited, priced £6.99, is available in all good bookshops; or you can buy direct by calling Guardian Books on 0870 727 4155 (free p&p).
Readers may contact the office of the readers' editor by telephoning 020-7239 9589 between 11am and 5pm, Monday to Friday. Surface mail to: Readers' editor, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Fax 020-7239 9897. Email: reader@theguardian.com

fields.headline: 18 diamante encrusted sunglasses and 72 silk shirts, please
fields.trailText: The amazing thing to most men isn't that Elton John could spend £20m in a year, but that he took time out to do it.
fields.body:
The amazing thing to most men isn't that Elton John could spend £20m in a year, but that he took time out to do it. The great majority of men hate shopping. I dislike it so much that I conduct even the purchase of socks like a guerrilla raid; I will stand at the door of the shop, work out where they are, dive for them, pay cash if possible, and be out in less time than it takes Paddy Ashdown to make love (see below). The sound we shopophobics dread most is the assistant saying: "May I help you, sir?" or "Are you looking for anything in particular?" If I were Elton John I would say: "No, no, just give me 18 diamante encrusted sunglasses, 72 silk shirts, collar size 16, doesn't matter what colour, throw in a solid gold turtle, and let me out!"

Women by contrast love the whole process of shopping. The other day my daughter and her friend set off for the pictures three hours early in order, they explained, to do a little shopping on the way. "But you've only got £5," I said, "you'll have spent that in 10 minutes." My reward was the look which translates as the pitying cry of "D-a-a-a-d." To them shopping doesn't mean buying anything; it means hanging around in shops. To most men, apart from Sir Elton, it means staying at home in front of the TV while someone else does it.

Rory Bremner has a gag in which he says that he gave an after-dinner speech to a convention of mobile phone salesmen. "It was the first time I've ever been in a room full of men claiming theirs is the smallest." Now, it turns out that Sir Paddy Ashdown's former mistress Tricia Howard is furious at seeing their affair exhumed in his diaries. She got her revenge this week by claiming the two of them had once made love in a total of 9 seconds. The Sun, our new paper of record, was so impressed that it made a breakthrough in political reporting by recreating the event through the use of computer graphics. In frame two, the couple's clothes fall off as they run upstairs, and frame three (wittily labelled "6.87 seconds") shows Paddy in the grip of ecstacy.

I don't believe any of this. For one thing nobody could run upstairs, get undressed, do the deed, and return to the ground floor in less than one minute. Or even two. The late Vincent Hanna was the fastest operator I ever met. He once claimed to have gone from hotel lobby to bedroom and back downstairs in a total of 20 minutes, though admittedly he had only just met his partner before the clock started. I presume these days young men boast about their lack of staying power. Social change does happen at bewildering speed.

At the risk of sounding like a New Labour toady, the book I've enjoyed most this week has been the Guardian's own Corrections and Clarifications, a sort of greatest hits compendium from the column which appears daily on the letters page. I can't think of any other paper which would publish an anthology of its mistakes (though I expect reviewers on other papers will be tempted to sniff: "Coming soon - a slimmer volume of the things the Guardian got right"). When I lived in America, I used to hate the New York Times equivalent; they were frightfully pompous about being sorry for a wrong age, or a misspelled "Phillip", but never said: "In our recent editorials, we may have given the impression that the government of Israel has been almost blameless in the present crisis. It has since been brought to our attention..." But our own Ian Mayes has a dry sense of humour, which makes the corrections chapter a delight. "We spelt Morecambe, Lancs, wrong again. We often do." Or "A country diary, p16, Feb 17, was headed Heald Green, Cheshire. Heald Green is in Greater Manchester. The error was caused by nostalgia."

Or the way the show Grab me a Gondola became Grab me a Gondolier. The recipe in which 85 grams of sugar appeared as "85 tbsp". The entry on page 10, about the spectacular mistakes in an article about deaths in soap operas, is almost worth the £6.99 alone. And who can forget the interview with the black Tory-voting chanteuse, Patti Boulaye, in which she was quoted as supporting "apartheid... you can't stop supporting apartheid just because it's unpopular". She actually said "a party". Mel Torme, whose voice has been called "velvet fog" appeared in the Guardian as "the velvet frog". And it was hard to know whether to laugh or cry about the native American "unjustly lunched for rape".

Unlike most of the people who hammer on about the Millennium Dome, I went back to it this week. It was far from empty, though uncrowded, and most of the customers were happy school parties enjoying themselves hugely. With a family ticket now only £40, it's the perfect time to go.

Loyd Grossman is to oversee NHS hospital food, but has promised not to serve up the recipes from Masterchef. Thank goodness; who, after waiting eight hours on a trolley for an operation delayed a year, could face confit of squab with gooseberry, sage and savoy cabbage, served on a fig coulis with hasselback potatoes?

But all TV chef food is basically pornographic, as unlike the real world as the women in Playboy. Take a dinner which Delia Smith is offering Radio Times readers at her restaurant in the Norwich City football ground. For £79 the diners will get canapes and champagne, followed by "cream of stilton soup with parmesan croutons with home-baked caramelised onion bread; souffléed arbroath smokie creams served with foaming hollandaise sauce; a roulade of Kelly bronze turkey wrapped in smoked Suffolk bacon with a stuffing of apples, sage, onion and pork, caramelised button sprouts and shallots, roast potatoes, purée of parsnips with crème frache and nutmeg, home-made cranberry relish..." It goes on.

The first three courses involve cream. The very thought of it all would make most of us want to dash into hospital and subsist on cold shepherd's pie.

webTitle: Money: buy over the net or through mail order

fields.headline: Mouse mat to doormat
fields.standfirst: Whether you buy over the net or through mail order, you can make savings and charities see big profits from direct sales, reports Jill Papworth
fields.trailText: Whether you buy over the net or through mail order, you can make savings and charities see big profits from direct sales, reports Jill Papworth.
fields.body:
For consumers who want to combine giving to friends and family with giving to good causes this Christmas, the internet now offers the convenience of being able to buy charity cards and gifts from home.

All the major charities have their own websites, most with the facility to order their Christmas catalogues online. And many now offer full-blown internet shopping sites where you can order and pay for goods online.

A large number of charity catalogues with online buying facilities, including those of Save the Children, Mencap, NSPCC, The Cancer Research Campaign, British Heart Foundation, RSPCA and British Red Cross, can be accessed through one generic site, www.charitygifts.com.

This is run by Webb Ivory, the biggest fulfilment agency, which produces and runs the catalogue operations on behalf of many charities in return for a straight percentage of sales. Webb Ivory typically does all the work for larger charities covering costs associated with the design, production, printing and distribution of their catalogue as well as the purchase, storage and fulfilment of all the products and cards and the provision of telephone and online ordering services.

What this means for the charity is a riskless deal where they are guaranteed a royalty percentage of the retail value plus all unsolicited donations their catalogues raise. With such deals, 25% of the sales price is a reasonable estimate of the clear profit passed on to the charity. This means that £5 of every £20 you spend on cards and gifts goes directly to benefit the cause in question.

If, however, you buy direct from one of the big charities which produce and run their own catalogues, such as Oxfam, Imperial Cancer Research Fund, Barnardo's and the RNLI, chances are that a larger slice of the price you pay will be clear profit used to further the cause. This "net revenue" figure - the final profit after all trading costs have been deducted - varies from charity to charity depending on its size and commerical acuity.

Oxfam, for example, says that once all costs are paid around 35% of the sales price of cards sold through its catalogue (by mail order or via its internet shopping site) is clear profit used to forward its work around the world.

One drawback of buying charity products via mail order, whether online or not, is that you pay for postage and packaging. This makes it costly to buy products from several different charities and more economic to place a large order with just one or two favourite causes.

For smaller orders with standard delivery, where you would expect to receive your goods within 14 days, p&p varies between £2 and £3.75, depending on the charity, and some charities offer free p&p for larger orders.

One way around this is to order from collaborative websites which sell cards on behalf of a range of charities. One contender is www.charitycards.co.uk run by Newcastle-based The Greetings Card Company, a commercial operation which sells 200 different designs of cards from 25 participating charities including Age Concern, Shelter, Breakthrough Breast Cancer and Amnesty International. Pack prices vary from £1.75 up to £4.99 for 10 cards and customers pay the postage rate of their choice.

The company buys cards from the charities to sell online, giving them back 66% of the ex-VAT selling price. On a £3 pack, for example, VAT is first taken off, leaving a £2.55 ex-VAT value of which 66% (£1.69) goes to the charity.

This does not, of course, mean that the entire 66% represents clear profit for each charity. The "net revenue" figure will vary depending on each charity's card production costs, which have to be deducted first. And it is hard for consumers to compare which charities actually benefit the most from their card sales because not only do charities tend to calculate net revenue in different ways but they rarely, if ever, publicise this figure, which they view as commercially sensitive.

A smaller, non-profit making online venture, www.christmas-cards.org.uk, is run voluntarily by the Combined Charities Christmas Shops, which also runs temporary seasonal card shops in the Cheshire area. Selling cards online, it returns 100% of the sales price to 57 national and local charities from which, again, they each have to pay for card produc tion and costs. Delivery costs are a flat £1.95 per order.

Charity supporters who like sending flowers as Christmas gifts might be interested to know that they can make a £1 donation to Macmillan Cancer Relief each time they place an order via internet same-day flower delivery site www.flowergram.co.uk.

For traditional shoppers who prefer to do their charity card buying offline, charities which run their own high street shops will benefit the most if you buy their cards direct from them. Imperial Cancer Research Fund, for example, says that if people buy a £2.99 pack of its cards at one of its own 440 shops, approximately £1.50 (just under 50%) is convenanted to the cause.

If your favourite charities have no shops, your next best bet is to buy from temporary card shops run by non-profit making organisations. Cards for Good Causes is this year running nearly 300 tempo rary shops in donated spaces around the country selling cards produced by its 25 member charities, plus a few guest charities, in return for a maximum 19p in the £1 levy on sales to cover operating costs. This means that it returns 81p in the £1 to charities, out of which each has to pay its production and distribution costs.

Under a similar arrangement, Card Aid is running 45 temporary card shops on donated spaces mainly in London and the south-east where it is selling cards on behalf of up to 150 charities.

Finally, commercial retailers including WH Smith, Boots, Marks & Spencer and various supermarkets have licensing agreements with a number of charities to sell cards overprinted with their name in return for a royalty payment - typically 10% of the pack price.

While 10% may not sound much - and retailers have been regularly criticised for not passing on a bigger slice - it is worth remembering that these returns are risk-free to charities. The retailers not only sell the cards but also bear all the production costs and take the risk on any leftover sales. Charities tend to view such royalties as a source of welcome extra income they would not otherwise get and benefit from the high turnover of sales in the major stores.
