One contender is www.charitycards.co.uk run by Newcastle-based The Greetings Card Company, a commercial operation which sells 200 different designs of cards from 25 participating charities including Age Concern, Shelter, Breakthrough Breast Cancer and Amnesty International. Pack prices vary from £1.75 up to £4.99 for 10 cards and customers pay the postage rate of their choice. The company buys cards from the charities to sell online, giving them back 66% of the ex-VAT selling price. On a £3 pack, for example, VAT is first taken off, leaving a £2.55 ex-VAT value of which 66% (£1.69) goes to the charity. This does not, of course, mean that the entire 66% represents clear profit for each charity. The "net revenue" figure will vary depending on each charity's card production costs, which have to be deducted first. And it is hard for consumers to compare which charities actually benefit the most from their card sales because not only do charities tend to calculate net revenue in different ways but they rarely, if ever, publicise this figure, which they view as commercially sensitive. A smaller, non-profit making online venture, www.christmas-cards.org.uk, is run voluntarily by the Combined Charities Christmas Shops, which also runs temporary seasonal card shops in the Cheshire area. Selling cards online, it returns 100% of the sales price to 57 national and local charities from which, again, they each have to pay for card produc tion and costs. Delivery costs are a flat £1.95 per order. Charity supporters who like sending flowers as Christmas gifts might be interested to know that they can make a £1 donation to Macmillan Cancer Relief each time they place an order via internet same-day flower delivery site www.flowergram.co.uk. For traditional shoppers who prefer to do their charity card buying offline, charities which run their own high street shops will benefit the most if you buy their cards direct from them. Imperial Cancer Research Fund, for example, says that if people buy a £2.99 pack of its cards at one of its own 440 shops, approximately £1.50 (just under 50%) is convenanted to the cause. If your favourite charities have no shops, your next best bet is to buy from temporary card shops run by non-profit making organisations. Cards for Good Causes is this year running nearly 300 tempo rary shops in donated spaces around the country selling cards produced by its 25 member charities, plus a few guest charities, in return for a maximum 19p in the £1 levy on sales to cover operating costs. This means that it returns 81p in the £1 to charities, out of which each has to pay its production and distribution costs. Under a similar arrangement, Card Aid is running 45 temporary card shops on donated spaces mainly in London and the south-east where it is selling cards on behalf of up to 150 charities. Finally, commercial retailers including WH Smith, Boots, Marks & Spencer and various supermarkets have licensing agreements with a number of charities to sell cards overprinted with their name in return for a royalty payment - typically 10% of the pack price. While 10% may not sound much - and retailers have been regularly criticised for not passing on a bigger slice - it is worth remembering that these returns are risk-free to charities. The retailers not only sell the cards but also bear all the production costs and take the risk on any leftover sales. Charities tend to view such royalties as a source of welcome extra income they would not otherwise get and benefit from the high turnover of sales in the major stores.

fields.headline: Cassia Oriental
fields.standfirst: Some people just don't seem to realise that a successful restaurant is about more than a flash idea and fancy decor, says Matthew Fort
fields.trailText: Some people just don't seem to realise that a successful restaurant is about more than a flash idea and fancy decor, says Matthew Fort.
fields.body:
Heard of the Cassia Oriental? Perhaps not. Have you heard of China Jazz, then? No to that one, too. Ah well, never mind. I mention China Jazz because that was the former name of Cassia Oriental.

China Jazz opened last year with a good deal of hype and at a cost of at least £3 million. At least, we were told it was £3 million, although apparently the then owners couldn't get an air-conditioning system that worked, which was something of a disadvantage in a restaurant that was supposed to be ushering in a new era of glamorous Chinese fine dining and dancing. Sadly, the fine diners and dancers didn't cotton on to this splendid concept, and China Jazz went down the Swanee. A few months later, Cassia Oriental arose from the ashes of receivership with a different owner, different concept and different food. And, having missed China Jazz's brief meteoric course across the horizon, it was to the Cassia Oriental that I went with Madame Feng Shui for dinner.

I'm not sure how much of the original is left, but the whole thing is a sizeable operation, with a large bar for drinking, a sushi bar for raw fish and a dining room that will take around 100-plus, all quite flash in a dun-coloured kind of way. It has something of an upmarket spankers' den about it.

I'm not sure who was in charge or, indeed, if there was anyone in charge given the headless nature of the service. Even so it takes a peculiar kind of genius to place a table of two next to a table of eight in a room where there were scarcely any other diners. Actually, the table of eight weren't diners in the strict sense of the word, because they didn't eat. They drank and talked - loudly and incessantly. I have nothing against other people having a good time. I have nothing against people with voices that you could hear with absolute clarity from the other side of Wembley on Cup Final day. I just don't want to sit next to them. Madame Feng Shui or I would get halfway through a sentence and then lose the thread as the vocal equivalent of a chainsaw sliced into our thought processes. That kind of thing tends to put me on edge, and makes me look with a beadier eye at the fuller experience.

The menu has something of the bazaar about it. Bizarre as well as bazaar, I should say. There is a bit of China, a bit of Vietnam, a bit of Thailand and a bit of Japan. The bits weren't fused together. They were pretty much unreconstructed and pretty much a disgusting mess. It didn't help that I ordered the Vegetarian Oriental Combination and got the Cassia Oriental Combination of Thai fishcakes (greasy rubber), agedashi tofu (slime), mashed prawns on sugar cane (a taste-free zone) and crispy smoked chicken (chewy chips of stale fat).

That set me up for a second course of Tom Yam Goong - "THE REAL THING! Thai prawn soup with prawns, squid, mussels flavoured with lemon grass and fresh basil", as the menu had it. It made me question the nature of reality at Cassia Oriental. It was the nearest thing to industrial effluent that I have attempted to eat in years. Although there was a generous number of prawns, scallops instead of mussels and a piece of old flannel that might have been squid once upon a time, this dish left my mouth seared as if by cleansing fluid.

Madame Feng Shui didn't do much better with Peking duck. She is something of an expert on Chinese cookery, and by the time she had run through the deficiencies of this version - cooked wrongly, cut up wrongly, cold, leatherette pancakes - there didn't appear to be anything right with it, except that it was undeniably duck. Actually, she didn't get much to eat at all, because her beef teppanyaki wrap ("pan-fried thin slices of sirloin beef rolled with garlic and enoki mushrooms garnished with asparagus and served in a teryaki sauce") that came next proved to be nigh on inedible: the slices of beef were thin all right, and fibrous like damp linen, and they were wrapped around bundles of rubbery enokis, but that wisp, that hint, that vestigial shadow of taste defied analysis. Then I remembered the skin on a pan of hot milk. That was it. But it wasn't enough for poor Madame Feng Shui. After poking at this travesty for a few minutes, she gave up the struggle and waited for me to finish my slow-roasted oxtail with white radish mouli in a sesame, bean and soya sauce.

Well, I don't know about the sesame. The sauce tasted pretty strongly of star anise to me, not that that's a bad thing. The oxtail had been cooked to a point that it was almost edible, although the overall notion of long cooking was slightly undone by the chunks of virtually raw pepper. But considering what else we had had to contend with, this was positively a triumph.

By this time the raucous braying from the next table was being given stiff opposition by what appeared to be a karaoke session at the bar, unseen figures serenading each other in sounds not unlike those of mating seals. By this time, we'd had enough. I paid £65.30, which included a bottle of something red and American at £19 from a curiously likeable list, and we left with what dignity we could muster. I'd have paid five times the sum not to have endured the evening in the first place. But after a few weeks of living pretty high on the hog, it's as well to be reminded that there is another world out there. I would avoid it, if I were you.

webTitle: Restaurant: Old Manor House, Zaika, Marwicks, Mesclun and The Glasshouse

fields.headline: Old Manor House, Zaika, Marwicks, Mesclun and The Glasshouse
fields.standfirst: Matthew Fort goes back for more at some old favourites in the south
fields.trailText: Matthew Fort goes back for more at some old favourites in the south
fields.body:
Old Manor House 17/20
Telephone: 01794 517353.
Address: 21 Palmerston Street, Romsey, Hants.
Food: Italo/French.
Price: £20-£35 a head without wine.

The Bregolis have been at the Old Manor House for 20 years, and there aren't many restaurants in the regions that can make that kind of boast. Mauro's cooking is highly evolved, but its roots are very much in his native northern Italy, and he is in the tradition of the great hunter/gatherer chefs - he shoots his own game, catches his own fish, picks his own mushrooms and supervises the raising of the pigs that go into the salamis and hams he makes. The inherent gutsiness is brought to heal by technical sophistication. Cosy, fire-warmed dining room. Serious money if you get stuck into the spectacular wine list.

Zaika 17/20
Telephone: 020-7351 7823.
Address: 257-259, Fulham Road, London SW3.
Food: Indian.
Price: £10-£35 a head without wine.

Perhaps slavish traditionalists might take issue with some of Vineet Bhatia's dishes, but anyone with an open mind and mouth who is interested in superlative cooking should toddle along and get stuck in. Intelligent, subtle, freshly spiced, technically deft, his food is a model of delicacy and taste. The effects are beautifully modulated rather than dashingly colourful. This is some of the most interesting and distinctive food in London, irrespective of nationality. Decor is in restrained good taste, blending Indian detailing with contemporary metropolitan restaurant design. Lunch a snip of snips.

Marwicks 16/20
Telephone: 0117 926 2658.
Address: 43 Corn Street, Bristol.
Food: Intelligent European.
Price: £15-£30 a head.
Bristol is enjoying a tremendous renaissance (or even naissance?) in restaurant eating. New places seem to be opening weekly. Amid all this Stephen Markwick, beavering away in a converted bank vault, may be termed something of veteran. Year after year, he goes on producing marvellous modern European cooking of unerring taste and intelligence. It begins with first-class ingredients, many of them organic, treated with careful, instinctive skill, and served with real pride and friendliness. The wine list is marked with quality wines, and a fine back catalogue. Set menus are extraordinarily good value.

Mesclun 15/20
Telephone: 020-7249 5029.
Address: 24 Stoke Newington Church Street, London N16.
Food: Modern global.
Price: £12-£24 a head without wine.
Neighbourhood restaurant of class and charm. Small, Med-flavoured dining room with rather vivid modern pictures. The kitchen roams the world for inspiration, and on the whole finds it: cod, couscous and capers all have their moments. Mesclun knows what flavour is and how to bring it out, even if the occasional tendency to over-complication gets in the way. But the generosity of the place wins over doubters, not that there are many - the place is packed most of the time. Not open for lunch.

The Glasshouse 16.5/20
Telephone: 020-8940 6777.
Address: 14 Station Parade, Kew, Surrey.
Food: Modern European.
Price: £13-£25 a head without wine.
The team of Nigel Platts-Martin (proprietor, also of The Square and Chez Bruce) and Bruce Poole (chef, also of Chez Bruce) has produced a contemporary classic on the site of the old and much-loved (though really not very good) Le Provence. Tucked away in the leafy backwater that constitutes the environs of Kew station, the Glasshouse lives up to its name with big windows and a sharp, laid-back, buzzy, modern style. The food is admirably conceived and executed, pleasing without being actually exciting or even mildly challenging, thank heavens - instead, it's a happy canter through the modern European mainstream that is both satisfying and fun. Occasional lapses in taste by the service take the edge off civilised dining every now and then - but it is only now and then.

fields.headline: Tories risk losing subsidy
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: The Conservative party is poised to lose nearly £4m of public money used to finance its war room and party propaganda in Central Office after a committee of MPs discovered that a senior Commons official had relaxed the rules for state subsidy to the opposition without consulting parliament.
fields.body:
The Conservative party is poised to lose nearly £4m of public money used to finance its war room and party propaganda in Central Office after a committee of MPs discovered that a senior Commons official had relaxed the rules for state subsidy to the opposition without consulting parliament.

William Hague has been using some of the money given to opposition parties to finance his party propaganda machine at Tory HQ - thanks to a decision by the Commons fees office to sanction its use beyond the traditional "fulfillment of parliamentary duties".

The new definition, which has prompted Margaret Beckett, leader of the Commons, to decide that the rules may have to be re-tightened, included "developing and communicating alternative policies to those of the government".

Mr Hague's decision to spend much of his own working day at party HQ rather than at Westminster has caused speculation - officially denied - that he has been using so-called "Short money" to fund his war room.

During an investigation into Short money by the Labour-controlled public administration committee the Tory chief executive, David Prior MP, confirmed such use. The clerk to the Commons, Bill Mackay, admitted Short money was not subject to independent scrutiny by parliament.

Anthony King, a member of the committee on standards in public life, said the Tories' use of their £4m annual public subsidy breached the ban on activities outside parliament.

webTitle: Garden: Love in  a cold climate

fields.headline: Love in  a cold climate
fields.standfirst: How to see your tender plants through the chill of winter? Christopher Lloyd offers advice
fields.trailText: How to see your tender plants through the chill of winter? Christopher Lloyd offers advice
fields.body:
My friend Frank Ronan is at last living in the country with a garden to get his teeth into, instead of no more than a roof in London. He is crazy about tender plants and succulents (especially aloes), and likes to have them outside during the summer. I asked about winter storage. "What about the car?" I asked, when he mentioned a garage.

"A car's never been in there. Cars aren't tender, anyway." I call that getting your priorities right. Succulents, if they are kept dry and unheated, will tolerate very low light levels for months on end. Dahlias and cannas need none, as they are dormant. We don't usually lift them until their tops have been frosted; then box them up in damp, old potting compost.

If a frost refuses to materialise, we cut them down anyway and proceed as usual. But allowing the tubers of dahlias to go on withdrawing nutrients from the foliage until as late as there is some there does encourage them to plump up as much as is possible. Thin, spindly tubers are all too apt to shrivel and disappear in the course of the winter, so it is as well to water them from time to time without ever allowing them to become soaking wet (as can easily happen if the container is lined with plastic).

The fleshy-rooted Colocasia esculenta (of the big elephant's ears foliage) and its relatives can be treated like dahlias. Begonias are of varying habits. The fibrous-rooted kinds so widely used for bedding are generally raised afresh from seed each year, sowing under heated glass in February. Tuberous-rooted begonias have their own in-built method of overwintering and are very little trouble. Their tubers can be completely dried off and stored in the dark, somewhere cool. Don't forget about them in the spring, or they'll start to sprout at all sorts of weird angles before you've dealt with their needs. Set them in damp peat in a warm spot, right side up - that is the slightly hollow side where shoots will be produced.

But then there are all the other kinds of begonias that are never dormant; we bed masses of them out, too, although many owners keep them permanently as pot plants in house or conservatory. They may not need much winter heat and light - just enough to keep them ticking over. If they lose much foliage when we're bringing them in, it sets them back rather seriously the next spring, so we handle them gently and any necessary pruning is delayed until they are on the move come the spring. Dead or dying leaves must always be removed, as necessary, to prevent any rots from spreading. Some of them, such as Begonia fuchsioides and B. scharffii, never present the slightest problem.

One of our favourites, the Egyptian papyrus, Cyperus papyrus, is distinctly tricky to overwinter. It is easy enough to raise afresh from seed in the spring, but that year's plants will be small. So we keep some of them in a greenhouse throughout the summer, and they are then no trouble to bring through the winter and can be bedded out in their second spring. The easiest thing with old plants, unless you can give them high winter temperatures, is to discard them.

Some plants make a large proportion of their annual growth in the winter months. Geranium maderense and the shrubby Echium fastuosum are notable among these. They are just not hardy in our climate, except in warm seaside localities, and must have plenty of light and root room, although generous feeding will, in part, compensate for some of this. To have them flowering really well from March to May, or even June, is quite a triumph.

The beautiful, lacy, grey-leaved Euryops pectinatus can make quite a large and spectacular shrub if well treated, and that will be covered with bright yellow daisies through a long spring season (but needs deadheading). It would go well with the blue spikes of the echium. Tender or near-tender ferns should generally be lifted and potted. They might have survived outside, but the winter will have acted as a severe check to their progress in the following spring. One of my favourites is the gun-metal-blue Polypodium aureum, and I have a pot of that on my dining room windowsill for six months.

Impatiens tinctoria is a giant. The plant we left out last winter grew a couple of metres tall by July. Its roots are tuberous and we merely protected them with fern fronds. But you can't trust to luck. We also took cuttings from its young shoots in the spring - just as you would dahlias - and they will overwinter under frost-free glass. The charming mat-forming I. pseudoviola, with masses of cheeky little white, violet-like flowers, is utterly tender, so we have rooted plants of that for overwintering in small pots.

The tall, herbaceous lobelias, such as 'Queen Victoria' and the F1 Fan series, die back to basal, leafy rosettes and they cannot be kept in the dark. We box them up and overwinter them in a snug, solid-walled cold frame. Tender shrubs, such as Grevillea robusta (initially seed-raised), we lift and pot more or less intact, not cutting them back for shape until there is enough light and warmth from the sun in February, to encourage them to make new growth.

Set them in damp peat in a warm spot, right side up - that is the slightly hollow side where shoots will be produced. But then there are all the other kinds of begonias that are never dormant; we bed masses of them out, too, although many owners keep them permanently as pot plants in house or conservatory. They may not need much winter heat and light - just enough to keep them ticking over. If they lose much foliage when we're bringing them in, it sets them back rather seriously the next spring, so we handle them gently and any necessary pruning is delayed until they are on the move come the spring. Dead or dying leaves must always be removed, as necessary, to prevent any rots from spreading. Some of them, such as Begonia fuchsioides and B. scharffii, never present the slightest problem. One of our favourites, the Egyptian papyrus, Cyperus papyrus, is distinctly tricky to overwinter. It is easy enough to raise afresh from seed in the spring, but that year's plants will be small. So we keep some of them in a greenhouse throughout the summer, and they are then no trouble to bring through the winter and can be bedded out in their second spring. The easiest thing with old plants, unless you can give them high winter temperatures, is to discard them. Some plants make a large proportion of their annual growth in the winter months. Geranium maderense and the shrubby Echium fastuosum are notable among these. They are just not hardy in our climate, except in warm seaside localities, and must have plenty of light and root room, although generous feeding will, in part, compensate for some of this. To have them flowering really well from March to May, or even June, is quite a triumph. The beautiful, lacy, grey-leaved Euryops pectinatus can make quite a large and spectacular shrub if well treated, and that will be covered with bright yellow daisies through a long spring season (but needs deadheading). It would go well with the blue spikes of the echium. Tender or near-tender ferns should generally be lifted and potted. They might have survived outside, but the winter will have acted as a severe check to their progress in the following spring. One of my favourites is the gun-metal-blue Polypodium aureum, and I have a pot of that on my dining room windowsill for six months. Impatiens tinctoria is a giant. The plant we left out last winter grew a couple of metres tall by July. Its roots are tuberous and we merely protected them with fern fronds. But you can't trust to luck. We also took cuttings from its young shoots in the spring - just as you would dahlias - and they will overwinter under frost-free glass. The charming mat-forming I. pseudoviola, with masses of cheeky little white, violet-like flowers, is utterly tender, so we have rooted plants of that for overwintering in small pots. The tall, herbaceous lobelias, such as 'Queen Victoria' and the F1 Fan series, die back to basal, leafy rosettes and they cannot be kept in the dark. We box them up and overwinter them in a snug, solid-walled cold frame. Tender shrubs, such as Grevillea robusta (initially seed-raised), we lift and pot more or less intact, not cutting them back for shape until there is enough light and warmth from the sun in February, to encourage them to make new growth.

webTitle: Schools chief says Hackney is worst council

fields.headline: Schools chief says Hackney is worst council
fields.trailText: The government has accepted the case for further privatisation of the education service in the beleaguered London borough of Hackney after Chris Woodhead, the outgoing chief inspector of schools in England, described it as the worst council in the country
fields.body:
The government yesterday accepted the case for further privatisation of the education service in the beleaguered London borough of Hackney after Chris Woodhead, the outgoing chief inspector of schools in England, described it as the worst council in the country.

Mr Woodhead, launching his third scathing report on the running of the local education authority since 1997, also criticised David Blunkett, the education secretary, for failing to take radical action earlier.

He urged Mr Blunkett to look "hard and quickly" at wholesale privatisation of Hackney school services, even though the report said that Nord Anglia, a private contractor already brought in to run some services, had a patchy record.

Schools in Hackney "were making very good progress, but they are making progress in spite of, and not because of, the authority," Mr Woodhead said. "I urge the government to act, and act now, to rescue the education of some of Britain's most deprived children from the malign influence of Hackney council."

In interviews, Mr Woodhead said: "I have to say that I feel a sense of failure myself that I haven't persuaded the government that radical intervention was needed in the past." Such veiled attacks on Mr Blunkett are likely to become more explicit when he leaves Ofsted at the end of the month. He joins the Daily Telegraph as a commentator in the spring.

The report said a third of the services for which Hackney council was responsible were still unsatisfactory, including implementation of the school improvement strategy, support for children, support for school management, corporate planning and financial management, financial support for schools, and property management.

The recent resignation of the "highly effective" education director Elizabeth Reid was "a disaster", Ofsted said. Mrs Reid, whose notice period ended yesterday, said she was "absolutely 100% with the findings of the Ofsted report".

Mr Blunkett said he was considering giving schools, or groups of schools, opportunities to buy in services, and involving private or public bodies in the provision of further services. But he would be consulting head teachers first.

"Hackney schools and heads deserve better than drift and uncertainty. We will work with them to ensure that they get the support services they need and want," he said.

A source close to the education secretary said Hackney was the first authority to have some services contracted out after the 1998 act had given ministers power to do so. They had acted on the basis of an Ofsted report. But because of the risk of a court challenge Mr Blunkett had always ensured that he had strong evidence before he took services away from local councils.

Mark Lushington from the Hackney branch of the National Union of Teachers said: "The Ofsted report is critical of Nord Anglia for doing too little, too slowly - and then Chris Woodhead says the answer is privatisation. We are fed up with being a political football."

Ministers yesterday effectively put the near-bankrupt council on trial by allowing it to borrow an extra £14m to head off a financial meltdown over the next few months. But the government has insisted it will send a team of outside consultants to monitor the work.

Hilary Armstrong, the local government minister, said: "We will not stand by and leave the people of Hackney, and the council's loyal staff, at risk from ... failing services."

She warned that "radical options" were being considered to take other services away from the council if it failed to meet its commitments and satisfy inspectors from the audit commission early next year.

webTitle: Hospital hit squad stands by after surgery health alert

fields.headline: Hospital hit squad stands by after surgery health alert
fields.trailText: The Department of Health has threatened to send in a hit squad of managers to take over a hospital in Portsmouth
fields.body:
The Department of Health yesterday threatened to send in a hit squad of managers to take over a major hospital in Portsmouth after surgeons called for all emergency operations to be stopped saying that patients' lives are being put at risk.

Ten orthopaedic consultants at the Queen Alexandra hospital say the lack of sterile instruments means that they consider it is becoming more dangerous to continue the operations on accident victims than to send them to other centres in the south of England.

Contingency plans are being prepared to send emergency cases to other hospitals in Winchester, Southampton or Chichester. Routine orthopaedic surgery was suspended in September because of long-standing problems in the hospital's sterilisation and disinfection unit so that there would at least be sufficient sterile equipment to deal with trauma patients.

The Department of Health called the situation at the hospital "completely unacceptable" and threatened either to send in a hit squad or introduce controls over its funding decisions. The Cosham area hospital has the biggest accident and emergency unit in the south with a catchment area covering 600,000 people.

This crisis follows reports this week which have criticised the running of the Oxford heart centre, condemned the treatment of elderly mental patients in Carlisle and warned of risk to patients from the failure to share procedures in two hospitals' operating theatres run by the Carmarthenshire health trust.

The Portsmouth problems were revealed in a letter written by the surgeons on Monday to hospital management recommending that all admission of trauma victims should cease from November 27, by which time neighbouring units should be prepared to take extra patients.

It said: "Despite stopping elective surgery we have not seen any improvement in the supply of sterile instruments for trauma. Indeed the situation has become worse. We have previously taken the view that cancellation of trauma takes would put the patients at greater risk than continuing the service."

But the doctors said the situation had changed in the previous two weeks and "we now feel that patients' lives and well-being are at serious risk and this situation cannot be allowed to continue".

It is understood that last week staff took six hours to find suitable equipment to treat an elderly woman with a multiple fracture to her leg that needed surgery.

Consultants might also have to reduce or stop seeing new patients.

The surgeons' letter said they were "extremely disappointed" that concerns first raised in June had not been addressed. "Our decision has not been taken lightly ... Morale in the orthopaedic department is at an all-time low."

The Portsmouth Hospitals Trust acknowledged "very slow progress" in addressing problems but said it was "working very hard to ensure that orthopaedic surgery continues at the Queen Alexandra Hospital." More instruments had been ordered.

The suspension of elective surgery meant that about 200 operations were cancelled or postponed but some operations have been conducted since early this month at the military Royal Hospital, Haslar, in Gosport.

Michael Mates, Conservative MP for Hampshire East, said he had raised concerns with health minister Gisela Stuart on three occasions in the last two months.

The health department said: "The hospital should not have let this situation develop. We expect them to take very swift action to sort out their sterilisation department, to make sure patients are safe and to deal with those who have had to wait for their operations. If they do not, we will consider action against the hospital managers involved."

webTitle: Equitable finds life ever more difficult

fields.headline: Equitable finds life ever more difficult
fields.standfirst:
Defeat over policy guarantees has been followed problems finding a buyer. Patrick Collinson on an insurer that seems to have lost its way

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Defeat over policy guarantees has been followed problems finding a buyer. Patrick Collinson on an insurer that seems to have lost its way.
fields.body:
The once-proud Equitable Life insurance company, darling of Britain's professional classes for its top-performing and low-charging pensions, is staggering from one embarassment to another.

Four months ago it lost a £1.5bn House of Lords court case on policy guarantees, after a year-long battle with a group of policyholders, including David Hyman.

After the ruling, Equitable, Britain's oldest mutual, immediately declared that it would have to find a buyer to inject new capital into the company and stunned policyholders by withdrawing annual bonuses for the first seven months of the year to help pay the costs of the ruling.

Now it is emerging that despite early hopes of a £5bn sale - enough to pay big windfalls to Equitable's 600,000 policyholders - the list of potential buyers is peeling away amid concerns about Equitable's liabilities.

Equitable set a deadline for bids for this Monday, but only Prudential and Eureko, a European consortium, are believed to remain in the fray, and the deadline is now expected to be extended.

One analyst this week said that Equitable's liabilities may even exceed its sale value, ruling out any windfalls and raising a question mark over how it will fund the return of the "lost" bonus that it has promised.

Ned Cazalet, an independent insurance analyst, said: "Adding together all its liabilities, the figure could be £4bn. If, say, it has a sale value of £3bn, then in that scenario there is a negative windfall. In one way or another the money would have to come out of policyholders' pockets."

Mr Cazalet believes that Prudential is "the only logical buyer", able to use its £9bn reserves to support Equitable. But if Prudential pulls out (and he believes Eureko is not a serious contender), no one is quite sure how Equitable will be nursed back to health.

Equitable is now taking drastic action to ensure that policyholders are not tempted to jump ship and transfer to other pension companies. In a move usually taken only when pension companies are in the midst of a stockmarket crash, it is applying a "market value adjuster" to transfers.

In other words, it is imposing a penalty that will wipe out 20% of the bonuses on the policy, reducing the total fund value by around 4%.

So what action should policyholders take? Jobs & Money this week canvassed independent financial advisers, all of whom have clients with Equitable Life policies. The biggest concern is for people who are about to retire who hold either a personal pension or additional voluntary contributions (AVC) policy.

Amanda Davidson, director of Holden Meehan, says: "AVC holders are in an incredibly tricky position. Unless you can defer the date at which you can take the AVC benefits - something which most schemes do not allow - you have no alternative but to take what's offered by Equitable, even though it does not include this year's bonus."

Equitable says it promises to restore the lost bonus in an, as yet, undecided form once the sale process is complete - unlikely before next summer. But some advisers say that relying on the restoration of the bonus is foolhardy, as no-one can be sure what conditions a buyer may impose.

Personal pension holders retiring now are also promised the restoration of the bonus, but have the option (if they can afford it) to defer taking their pension, until the age of 75. In the meantime the pension value will roll up, although policyholders will have to take a view as to what sort of bonuses are likely in future.

What if you are five or ten years away from retiring? Should you take the 4% hit and switch to another provider? Alan Stevens at fee-based adviser Portfolio and Pensions Management in Glasgow advises against such a move - for now.

He says: "Stick with it for the time being. If you come out, you are going to get a penalty applied. What's more, no-one really knows what the cost of the repair job at Equitable will be, and there may still be a chance of a windfall. And now is not the time to do a pension transfer; you should wait until stakeholders become available next year."

Equitable's term insurance policies are highly unlikely to be affected. They are contracts with fixed payments that should not be at any risk.

What if someone tries to sell you an Equitable long-term policy? Ms Davidson says you would be "crazy" to purchase until the buyer is known. And when it's over, the advisers argue that Equitable will have lost its unique selling proposition - it will no longer be a low-cost mutual, and the rivals will, in any case, be offering stakeholder pension plans at charges of 1% or under.

webTitle: Early bidder will be booking a bargain ticket

fields.headline: Early bidder will be booking a bargain ticket
fields.standfirst:
Lastminute has fulfilled its business promise but not its mooted potential for investors

Net news
fields.trailText: Lastminute has fulfilled its business promise but not its mooted potential for investors.
fields.body:
A broken clock is always right twice a day. This is a truism market pundits should always keep in mind. However, when our more outrageously flamboyant predictions come to pass, you must grant us just a little room for self-indulgence. One of my long shots has just romped home in the shape of Lastminute.com. Luck or judgment? Not sure, but it is a good time to re-examine my strident bearishness on the fallen angel of the dotcom firmament.

This time last year I was caught off-guard by a journalist who asked my view of Lastminute's proposed £400m stockmarket flotation. My off-the-cuff response was that I doubted the company was worth even as much as £40m. Come March Lastminute roared onto the market, raining £125m in cash to give it an overall valuation of £570m. Issued at 380p a share, demand massively outstripped supply. Within days the shares reached a peak of 550p.

Eight months later it is a very different story. Lastminute has fulfilled all of its business promise, but none of its mooted potential as an investment proposition. Revenues have topped analysts' forecasts. Product and service agreements have been signed with high profile corporations of genuine substance. International expansion is in train, most obviously in Europe but as far afield as Australia. A chairman of deeply blue chip hue has been appointed in Allan Leighton, former chief executive officer of food retailing iconoclast Asda. And, as if to demonstrate management's rounded skill set, France's leading e-travel company, Degriftour, has been purchased for £51.5m.

A visitor from Planet Zog might be forgiven for assuming that this carefully assembled package of good news would have been well received by investors. Unfortunately for Lastminute's management, and in particular its celebrity co-founders, Brent Hoberman and Martha Lane Fox, its news pearls have been cast into the pigsty that is the market for technology stocks. Earlier this week Lastminute shares reached a low of 72p, valuing the company at £122m. Strip out the £90m cash on its balance sheet and you have a business valued at £32m. Just sometimes flamboyant punditry comes up trumps.

Occupational hazard

Upbeat research notes from some of the world's largest investment banks have failed to reverse the slide in Lastminute's share price. Perhaps in part this is because many of these banks were parties to the company's flotation. This is an occupational hazard from which no broking firm is immune. Nevertheless, it is clear from these documents that, in a particular set of favourable circumstances, the company's cash pile will see it through to profitability without the need for further recourse to equity investors.

The internet chat rooms tell a very different story. Cut through the vitriol - Brent is a failed businessman and Martha is a former Burger King assistant were two of the kinder quips I found - and you will unearth a highly pertinent debate about the Lastminute business model. The charge laid by the sceptics is that Lastminute is a middleman, and that the internet squeezes out middlemen by facilitating direct contact between producers and the public.

Online customers do not fit neatly into a single category. Some will value one-stop convenience shopping from an aggregator such as Lastminute. Others will search with a frontier spirit for the lowest prices and best service themselves. The proof of the Lastminute model will lie in its conversion rate of registered customers into commercial transactions.

The numbers are so small - 90,500 items sold in the most recently reported three months - that all forecasts must be treated with great circumspection. Evidence of a recent waning of home internet usage by the public has raised the risks a notch further still.

Loyalty contaminated

My own feeling is that Lastminute will never generate anything more than modest profits. The net present value of all future profits - using a suitably cautious discount rate - is probably less than £100m. Add in the inescapable fact that the company's cash pile must diminish as it continues its build-out, and you have little upside to the current share price. And there is always the very real risk that it never even reaches modest profitability.

This does not mean that Lastminute is wholly without value. Although the bungled flotation process and subsequent share price collapse will have contaminated customer loyalty, there is no denying that Lastminute scores highly for brand awareness. Also, although its website already has an out-dated front-end feel, Lastminute is investing heavily in intelligent databases and internet-to-mobile capability. Brand and technology are both costly to sustain, but would have value to the right corporate buyer.

Lastminute makes much of the coming v-commerce revolution, based on voice-recognition technology. In the cut-throat world of mobile telephony it is easy to conceive of one of the pan-European service providers owning Lastminute in order to provide exclusive services to its customer network. £100m, say, for Lastminute (ex its cash) would be small beer for Vodafone by comparison with its outlay on third generation licences, or the costs of a price war across Europe.

It is hard to envisage an uncontroversial end to Lastminute's quoted life. Brand protection should be the management's over-riding priority, for the good of all concerned. This points to an early takeover rather than a later rescue. And just forget about the original flotation price.

Nevertheless, it is clear from these documents that, in a particular set of favourable circumstances, the company's cash pile will see it through to profitability without the need for further recourse to equity investors. The internet chat rooms tell a very different story. Cut through the vitriol - Brent is a failed businessman and Martha is a former Burger King assistant were two of the kinder quips I found - and you will unearth a highly pertinent debate about the Lastminute business model. The charge laid by the sceptics is that Lastminute is a middleman, and that the internet squeezes out middlemen by facilitating direct contact between producers and the public. Online customers do not fit neatly into a single category. Some will value one-stop convenience shopping from an aggregator such as Lastminute. Others will search with a frontier spirit for the lowest prices and best service themselves. The proof of the Lastminute model will lie in its conversion rate of registered customers into commercial transactions. The numbers are so small - 90,500 items sold in the most recently reported three months - that all forecasts must be treated with great circumspection. Evidence of a recent waning of home internet usage by the public has raised the risks a notch further still. Loyalty contaminated My own feeling is that Lastminute will never generate anything more than modest profits. The net present value of all future profits - using a suitably cautious discount rate - is probably less than £100m. Add in the inescapable fact that the company's cash pile must diminish as it continues its build-out, and you have little upside to the current share price. And there is always the very real risk that it never even reaches modest profitability. This does not mean that Lastminute is wholly without value. Although the bungled flotation process and subsequent share price collapse will have contaminated customer loyalty, there is no denying that Lastminute scores highly for brand awareness. Also, although its website already has an out-dated front-end feel, Lastminute is investing heavily in intelligent databases and internet-to-mobile capability. Brand and technology are both costly to sustain, but would have value to the right corporate buyer. Lastminute makes much of the coming v-commerce revolution, based on voice-recognition technology. In the cut-throat world of mobile telephony it is easy to conceive of one of the pan-European service providers owning Lastminute in order to provide exclusive services to its customer network. £100m, say, for Lastminute (ex its cash) would be small beer for Vodafone by comparison with its outlay on third generation licences, or the costs of a price war across Europe. It is hard to envisage an uncontroversial end to Lastminute's quoted life. Brand protection should be the management's over-riding priority, for the good of all concerned. This points to an early takeover rather than a later rescue. And just forget about the original flotation price.

webTitle: Arafat tries to stop the shooting

fields.headline: Arafat tries to stop the shooting
fields.standfirst:
Palestinian call for restraint and hopeful poll news for Israel's leader could signal peace effort

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, called on Fatah militiamen yesterday to hold their fire, one of several tentative signs that Israel and the Palestinians are seeking an escape route from nearly two months of confrontation.
fields.body:
The Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, called on Fatah militiamen yesterday to hold their fire, one of several tentative signs that Israel and the Palestinians are seeking an escape route from nearly two months of confrontation.

Mr Arafat stopped short of banning the activities of the Fatah tanzim (militiamen) whose shooting at the Jewish settlement of Gilo, south of Jerusalem, has caused hysteria in Israel and provoked the ferocious retribution that has reduced many houses in the Christian town of Beit Jalla to smouldering wrecks.

"We are trying our best to get our people to stop shooting from Palestinian-controlled areas," he told reporters in Gaza after Friday afternoon prayers. "There are orders from the Palestinian security council to stop shooting."

But before that will happen Mr Arafat must persuade tanzim leaders such as Mike, the burly commander of a cell of gunmen in Beit Jalla.

"We are all working under Yasser Arafat's command, but unless he feels we are totally satisfied he is not going to ask us to stop shooting," he said, looking out over a valley of olive trees to his target, the multi-storey flats of Gilo along the spine of the opposite hill.

"We are all victims and economic losers, and he can not tell us to stop and go back home unless we are convinced that something has changed."

Such determination is common among tanzim, from Mike, who has six gunmen under his charge, to Hussain Sheikh, their commander in the West Bank.

During these weeks Mr Sheikh has not gone out without six guards dressed in black and armed with M-16 rifles with sniper scopes, for fear of an Israeli assassination attempt.

Earlier this week he too said it was premature to end the guerrilla-style attacks on Israeli troops and Jewish settlers in the West Bank.

"In my opinion the Palestinian people are still the victims and are still paying a heavy price. The Palestinian people are not going to raise the white flag to the settlers and the army."

Such attitudes could make it hard to call off the tanzim should Mr Arafat so decide. So too could the organisational structure of the tanzim, divided into small cells the length of the West Bank.

From Jenin in the north to Hebron in the south, each cell operates as an autonomous unit. Most of their leaders are said not to know each other.

"The intifada has many leaders, and each can decide on his own what to do," said Abdullah Abu Hadid, who commands the tanzim in Bethlehem.

Mr Arafat's call for restraint does not apply to tanzim operating in those parts of the West Bank under only partial Palestinian control or complete Israeli control. But it was one of several small encouraging signals that - for all the public assertions by the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, that now is not the time to talk peace - Israel and the Palestinians are working behind the scenes to re-open negotiations.

Such efforts had no effect on the ground yesterday. Two Palestinian policemen were shot dead overnight near Jericho. Another man was killed by an Israeli bullet through the chest in the West Bank town of Qalqiliya.

But there was a flicker of hope when newspapers reported that Israeli and Palestinian diplomats had held secret meetings at the UN to discuss the Palestinian demand for an international protection force in the West Bank.

Mr Barak has, with Washington's backing, opposed such a force. But on Thursday night his office said Israel would not object to international supervision of a peace agreement.

There has also been, in the 10 days since Mr Arafat and Mr Barak met President Clinton separately in Washington, renewed speculation about a final peace summit before Mr Clinton leaves office.

To Fatah leaders there is no contradiction between the intifada, and negotiations. They argue that the two go together, while Fatah's presence on the ground helps to repair the gross inequality between the Palestinians and Israel's political, economic and military strength.

To Mr Barak that is simply unacceptable, running counter to the mantra that the Palestinians must "stop the violence" before there can be talks. He is under constant pressure from the Israeli right and the army to strike ever harder against the Palestinians.

But the Israeli left is also beginning to awake from its slumber. Two dozen prominent writers and academics published a large newspaper ad yesterday calling on Mr Barak to disband Jewish settlements in the West Bank and affirming support for a Palestinian state.

Earlier this week Israeli non-governmental organisations resumed contacts with their Palestinian counterparts, broken off when the violence erupted.

Opinion poll results published yesterday showed that the steep decline in popular support for Mr Barak could be reversed if he reaches a final peace settlement with the Palestinians.

The findings are the first to challenge the accepted wisdom in Israel that Mr Barak would be forced out if he resumed negotiations.

For now, however, "there is total confusion in the Israeli government, it is like pilot's vertigo", said Menachem Friedman, an academic who was among the ads' signatories.

"The leadership is embarrassed and needs reorientation to find out where the skyline is, and where to move the aircraft.

"They move from one extreme to the other, not satisfying anyone, neither the peace camp, nor the right wing."

webTitle: Judges put Gore back in the race

fields.headline: Judges put Gore back in the race
fields.standfirst:
Election stand-off set to last into next week

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Seven Florida judges rode dramatically to the rescue of Al Gore's presidential hopes last night, prohibiting the state's election officials from declaring a result in the disputed election there until further notice and setting a new timetable which takes the 11-day White House standoff with George W Bush well into next week.
fields.byline: Martin Kettle  in Washington and Julian Borger in West Palm Beach
fields.body:
Seven Florida judges rode dramatically to the rescue of Al Gore's presidential hopes last night, prohibiting the state's election officials from declaring a result in the disputed election there until further notice and setting a new timetable which takes the 11-day White House standoff with George W Bush well into next week.

To audible cheers inside Mr Gore's home in Washington, the Florida supreme court ruled in Tallahassee that the local secretary of state, Katherine Harris, could not certify the Florida election results today as she had intended. The court said recounting in the election could continue and set a hearing for oral argument between lawyers for the two sides for Monday.

The court instructed Ms Harris not to certify any votes in Florida "until further order of this court". "It is not the intent of this order to stop the counting," the court said.

Mr Gore had been on the point of making a statement on the doorstep of his official residence at 4pm local time yesterday, which had seemed likely to be a rallying call at the end of a difficult day. But just as Mr Gore was about to emerge, the news came through from Tallahassee. Suddenly, Mr Gore had a new spring in his step.

"The will of the people" should decide the outcome, a buoyant Mr Gore said. "Neither Governor Bush, nor the Florida secretary of state nor I will be the arbiter of the process.

"The citizens of Florida surely want the candidate who received the most votes in Florida to be determined the winner of that state," he added.

The court move came as Mr Bush seemed to stand on the very threshold of the White House. Ms Harris had been expected to declare the Texas governor as the winner of the disputed count at noon today. Now those plans are on hold for several days and Mr Gore is back in the contest.

At the start of a day that was spectacular even by the standards of the extraordinary post-election battle, Mr Bush captured a crucial legal and psychological advantage that left Mr Gore against the ropes. A judge in Tallahassee refused to order Ms Harris to accept late election results from hand recounts that are still continuing in selected counties favourable to Mr Gore.

That cleared the way for Ms Harris, a Republican, to complete the certification of the Florida results today. But Mr Gore's lawyers remained defiant, immediately lodging an appeal that helped to swing the advantage back his way less than seven hours later.

Judge Terry Lewis's ruling had sent the Bush campaign officials in Austin cheering and hugging one another and Gore supporters looking gloomier than they had been all week.

The counting of Florida's estimated 2,500 overseas postal votes was due to begin at midnight last night, the final deadline for them to be received by the state's 67 counties.

Results from these counts - generally assumed likely to produce a Republican majority - are expected to be tabulated by midday and to be added to the existing statewide figures, which show Mr Bush with a 300-vote lead in an electorate of 6m voters.

By noon yesterday, two of the 67 counties had already reported their overseas ballot results, which gave a net gain of two votes to Mr Bush.

There were more overseas ballots left to count in pro-Bush counties such as Duval (with 500 uncounted yesterday) and Escambia (239) than in pro-Gore counties such as Palm Beach (44) and Broward (100).

Judge Lewis's ruling yesterday afternoon had not stopped manual recounts in Palm Beach and Broward counties, which were beginning to produce small incremental gains for Mr Gore. Broward reported a net gain of 34 votes for the vice-president by lunchtime. He was up six votes in Palm Beach after the first few hours of the count, which is expected to take at least five days.

Inside the West Palm Beach counting hall - improvised in the county's Emergency Operations Centre, normally used during hurricanes - word of Judge Lewis's decision had gone unnoticed by the 52 local government employees who had been co-opted as counters. They are not allowed to talk to each other.

At one point, a Republican observer had approached the head of the county election committee, Charles Burton, to try to persuade him to stop the count, but Mr Burton had rejected the appeal.

Meanwhile, Broward county fought off a legal challenge from lawyers representing four Republican voters claiming the recount was illegal. The lawyers had subpoenaed the members of the county electoral board, whose departure would have required the vote tally to stop.

webTitle: Labour confident of winning on economy

fields.headline: Labour confident of winning on economy
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Labour can win the coming general election on the strength of its management of the economy - and the voters' still-strong memory of the Conservatives' "boom and bust" legacy, the cabinet's strategy meeting at Chequers was told yesterday.
fields.body:
Labour can win the coming general election on the strength of its management of the economy - and the voters' still-strong memory of the Conservatives' "boom and bust" legacy, the cabinet's strategy meeting at Chequers was told yesterday.

The party's evidently confident election planners will also deploy a strong emphasis on crime prevention - including a "yob bill" in the Queen's Speech - investment in public services and a balance of rights and responsibilities which citizens should honour.

But much of Labour's energies will be directed at William Hague in person - the Tories' biggest problem, pollsters claim - and the continuing reluctance of voters to trust him or his lieutenants, whose best hope is a "backdoor strategy" for victory via public disillusionment and cynicism.

Labour has been hit by polling setbacks since the fuel protests, as party planners admit. But they are brushing aside shadow ministers' claims that they have lost fundamental public confidence.

"It would be fair to admit that people are impatient for change. They want more change and they want it faster," Tony Blair's spokesman admitted last night.

But, far from being on the backfoot, the government may be the first in 100 years to win a second term because the voters, whatever their impatience, trust Labour with the economy better than they do the Tory alternative.

"Voters have a very clear memory of the Tory legacy, the railways, BSE, negative equity, boom and bust," an insider said. It reinforces the Labour message that voters agree that Britain is not so much an overtaxed country as an underinvested one.

That memory, coupled with what is likely to be Labour's ruthless use of the Tory "£16bn black hole" on tax-and-spending plans, will assure victory in what Downing Street refuses to say will be a May 3 or 10 election.

Yesterday's upbeat scenario given to Mr Blair and his senior colleagues came from focus group and polling data provided by Labour party HQ and the pollster Philip Gould, which - if upheld by a second full term - will vindicate Mr Blair's long-term aim to make the centre left the natural party of government.

"There was a lengthy discussion about this whole problem of cynicism, that what the prime minister feels about this is that the Conservatives do not feel confident enough to put up the people they have in the leadership of the Conservative party and say 'this is what you want as the next government'. They do not want to give a sense of going through the front door of No 10, but hope for a back door strategy," Mr Blair's spokesman, Alastair Campbell, told journalists.

As a civil servant, albeit with a special politicised contract, Mr Campbell will have to resign when the election is called - to help Gordon Brown and Peter Mandelson mastermind the Labour campaign.

Last night he stressed the importance of addressing manifestations of yob culture - drunkenness, graffiti, intimidation on the streets.

But a populist line on crime will be coupled with the now-familiar stress on economic stability which allows investment to start making a difference in schools and - more slowly, ministers were warned - in the NHS.

 The shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, said yesterday she would rethink her "zero tolerance" policy on cannabis. Her decision comes after being ridiculed for her Tory party conference call for police to act against anybody caught in possession of the drug.

Ms Widdecombe told BBC News 24: "Once you've got a policy that has been through those sort of rough waters you would be a very great fool if you didn't say: 'Right, let's see if we can do it in a slightly different way'."

webTitle: French families sue Britain over vCJD

fields.headline: French families sue Britain over vCJD
fields.standfirst: Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: The families of two French victims of CJD, the fatal human variant of mad cow disease or BSE, filed a lawsuit in Paris yesterday against French, British and European authorities, alleging poisoning and involuntary manslaughter.
fields.body:
The families of two French victims of CJD, the fatal human variant of mad cow disease or BSE, filed a lawsuit in Paris yesterday against French, British and European authorities, alleging poisoning and involuntary manslaughter.

As Italy announced a partial ban on French beef, the parents of Laurence Duhamel, 39, who died of new variant CJD in February, and Arnaud Eboli, 19, a suspected sufferer, said Britain, France and the EU had failed to adequately protect their citizens.

"People who smoke and drink do so by their own choice. All my son did was eat meat, and he is going to die," said Dominique Eboli outside the court. "What we want now is for measures to prevent this from happening again."

The 100-page suit, the first of its kind related to CJD in France, was lodged "against persons unknown", a legal procedure that requires judicial experts to establish whether there is a case to answer, and if so, who should appear in court as defendants.

Lawyers said Britain was targeted because of claims that it had effectively exported BSE, and hence nvCJD, to France. French farmers claim at least 14,000 tonnes of meat-and-bone meal banned in Britain were imported into France in the early 1990s. A spokesman for Tony Blair said there had been no formal notification of any action against the government.

The French government this week banned T-bone steak and other cuts of beef on the bone, and suspended the use of meat-and-bone meal in all animal feed. Sales have fallen 40% since three supermarket chains admitted last month that they had unknowingly sold potentially contaminated beef.

A hospital in Paris said yesterday that it had detected a fourth possible CJD case, a woman of 40. At least 80 cases have been diagnosed in Britain.

Three French ministers stood trial last year after allowing the transfusion service to use blood that eventually infected some 4,000 people with HIV.

webTitle: Railtrack chief to get £400,000 after quitting

fields.headline: Railtrack chief to get £400,000 after quitting
fields.standfirst:
More about transport
Special report: the Hatfield train crash
fields.trailText: Gerald Corbett, the beleaguered chief executive of Railtrack, will walk away with a   £400,000 golden handshake after the company finally accepted his resignation yesterday, a month after the Hatfield rail crash.
fields.byline: Julia Finch, Jamie Wilson  and  Michael White
fields.body:
Gerald Corbett, the beleaguered chief executive of Railtrack, will walk away with a £400,000 golden handshake after the company finally accepted his resignation yesterday, a month after the Hatfield rail crash.

Mr Corbett, whose depar ture came less than 24 hours after a meeting with Tony Blair to discuss the chaos on the rail network, will be paid his full contractual entitlement of one year's salary even though he resigned, a source inside the company confirmed last night.

The extent of the payout is bound to spark controversy at a time when millions of passengers continue to face long delays because of track repairs and speed restrictions.

It was announced that Steven Marshall, Railtrack's fi nancial director, will take over. Until last year he was chief executive of the television rental company Thorn. His appointment was criticised by rail safety campaigners yesterday.

"More people who know about railways are needed on the board at Railtrack," said Louise Christian, a solicitor for the victims of the Paddington and Southall train crashes.

Railtrack also announced its chairman, Sir Philip Beck, will stand down next summer.

Mr Corbett, 49, initially of fered his resignation from the £377,000-a-year post on October 18, the day after four people were killed in the Hatfield derailment caused by a cracked rail on a section of the East Coast line. It later emerged the defect had been known about but not repaired.

The Railtrack directors refused the offer saying Mr Corbett was the best man to oversee a major programme of track repairs.

It emerged yesterday that many routes will continue to face severe disruption until well into the new year.

Mr Corbett said: "In the last few weeks my own profile has been far too high for my own good, my family's good and also for the company's good."

Last night the prime minister's spokesman, Alastair Campbell, denied that Mr Blair or his ministers knew of Mr Corbett's imminent resignation when they met at No 10.

webTitle: How the Real IRA recruits boys into a life of terrorism

fields.headline: How the Real IRA recruits boys into a life of terrorism
fields.standfirst:
Unearthed - Paramilitary training camp where teenagers learned the deadly art of handling and firing weapons

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: It was just after 8.30pm when the teenage boys were led up the muddy track in single file. Moving as silently as possible they and the eight men who accompanied them climbed over a barbed wire fence and made their way along a crumbling stone wall towards what looked like a pile of discarded red bricks.
fields.body:
It was just after 8.30pm when the teenage boys were led up the muddy track in single file. Moving as silently as possible they and the eight men who accompanied them climbed over a barbed wire fence and made their way along a crumbling stone wall towards what looked like a pile of discarded red bricks.

Bending down to remove two sheets of rusting corrugated iron, the first man eased himself through a hole he had uncovered in the ground. He was followed by the rest of the group, and within minutes there was no visible sign of life above the surface.

For the two boys from Dublin, aged 14 and 16, it was their first visit to a paramilitary training camp; but the path they trod that day in October last year was one that has been followed by hundreds, if not thousands, of young Irishmen from both sides of the political divide over the last 30 years as they took their first steps into the murky world of the terrorist.

Despite being in one of the more remote spots in rural Ireland, the group was not alone that night in the fields sur rounding Herbertstown House, a once grand dwelling for minor aristocracy that has been reduced to a few stone walls and a couple of cowsheds on the border between County Dublin and County Meath. A squad from the Garda's elite emergency response unit (ERU), the Irish republic's version of the SAS, had been staking out the underground bunker in the derelict wine cellar of the old mansion.

According to evidence given at the trial of John McDonaugh, 34, who pleaded guilty this year to training with and possessing weapons at a Real IRA training camp, he had collected five young men outside a McDonald's restaurant in Dublin. The 14-year-old told police that he had been approached two days before his arrest at the training camp and told he would learn about Irish history, be shown guns and be allowed to fire blanks. The 17-year-old explained to Garda officers that he had been approached and told he was going to an Oglaigh na hEireann training camp. He said he knew a splinter group was involved but did not know it was the Real IRA.

The boys were taken to a farm in Drogheda in a van. From there they had been transferred to a jeep and a horsebox which brought them to within walking distance of Herbertstown House.

At 9.30pm, as McDonaugh stood guard outside, the ERU decided to move in. Wearing black boiler suits, bullet-proof vests and masks, and carrying pump-action shotguns, Uzi machine pistols and smoke grenades, the officers surrounded the entrance to the cellar and arrested McDonaugh. Two men tried to escape but were arrested by police. A smoke grenade was thrown inside and the remaining suspects gave themselves up.

According to previous court hearings, when the police entered the cellar, which was lit by a portable generator, they found a Zastava 7.62mm assault rifle, a CZ model 70.9mm pistol, a CZ model 9mm submachine gun and three magazines. Police also found sandbags that contained bullets matching the pistol.

One of the older men, according to a statement read out in court, was wearing a white boiler suit and gloves and had been giving a demonstration in how to strip down, re-assemble and fire the weapons.

In follow-up searches of the area, police found bomb components including detonators, and a RPG 18mm rocket launcher, with an explosive warhead capable of piercing armour. The weapon had never been seen in the Irish republic before. Nobody has been charged over the later find, but it signalled a worrying development for the security forces on both sides of the border. The weapons, which are believed to have come from a senior Croatian army officer who has been cited as a war criminal by the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia, showed the Real IRA had set up a supply line to some serious weaponry.

But equally worrying to the security forces was the age of two of the recruits who were being trained at the camp. The 14-year-old schoolboy, who cannot be named for legal reasons, was led crying and shaking from the bunker. "Emotionally overcome," was how one special branch officer described it in court.

This month the youth, now 16, was given a three-year suspended sentence at the special criminal court in Dublin after pleading guilty to offences connected with the discovery of the training camp.

At the same hearing, sentencing was adjourned on his friend, who was 16 at the time of his arrest. He was ordered to sign on three times a week at Coolock Garda station after detectives giving evidence said the youth still had very strong leanings towards extremist republican organisations and had been seen in the company of leading dissidents since his arrest.

The Real IRA is the largest in a coalition of dissident groups, which, security services estimate, number between 120 and 200 people, although it is unclear how many are "active" terrorists. It formed in the autumn of 1997 when the IRA's quartermaster quit the IRA with his partner and a dozen others. But since then the group has failed to attract the number of disaffected provisionals it had hoped, apart from a senior bomb maker who defected to the Real IRA in May last year.

Although many who took part in the Provisional IRA's terror campaigns may be broadly in agreement with the Real IRA's aims to fight on, the Omagh atrocity, when 29 people and unborn twins died after a car bomb exploded in the centre on a busy Saturday afternoon in Co Tyrone town in October 1998, has resulted in many steering clear of the dissident organisation.

Fears of a feud between the rival republican groups has also hardened positions. Last month Joe O'Connor, the Belfast Commander of the Real IRA, was shot seven times in the head outside his home in Ballymurphy. It was the most serious of several clashes between the two groups.

As a result, the Real IRA has been forced to look elsewhere to try to bolster its membership and carry out attacks. In the spring, security forces in the Republic questioned members of a Real IRA colour party near the border. "They were people we've never seen before, they were very young, little more than kids," a senior security source was quoted as saying in the magazine Magill.

According to Professor Paul Wilkinson at the centre for the study of terrorism and political violence at St Andrew's University, such recruits are known as "lilywhites" because they have unblemished records. "They have no record with the Garda or any other security services, and are therefore less likely to be observed. Dublin is particularly attractive for this type of recruitment, as security is likely to be less tight than in the north," he said.

The two teenagers arrested at the Real IRA training camp fit the profile perfectly. The family of the 14-year-old had no known republican connections, although he joined the Fianna - which has been described as a republican version of the scouts - at the age of 12. The older teenager had a similarly unblemished record.

For the Real IRA the use of "cleanskins" - as they are known by the intelligence services - has become increasingly important as the security net has tightened around many of the dissident organisation's more established figures. "There has been an emergence of a policy to use clean operatives which does make the work more difficult," said one security source. "These clean volunteers have to be identified before they can be watched."

The tactic was illustrated in May last year when three members of the Real IRA were jailed for planning a firebombing campaign in London. Anthony Hyland, took a four-year arts degree at University College Dublin, Liam Grogan had just graduated from the same university where he had met Hyland, while the third member of the group, Darren Mulholland, was in the second year of a theoretical physics degree at Queens university, Belfast.

The trio, who were arrested in July 1998 following a surveillance operation mounted by the Garda, MI5 and the Metropolitan Police, planned to target a senior politician with 2lb of Semtex and to bomb shops in London before escaping to Ireland. Significantly, the men had not been involved in terrorism before. At their trial, police were unclear whether they had instigated the bombing plan or were acting as agents for more experienced members of the Real IRA. The fact that all three were either students or former students is also significant, as the security services also have evidence of attempts to set up cells within universities and among students in both the north and the south.

Intelligence has suggested the Real IRA is planning a "spectacular" over the Christmas period, with London being the most likely target. In response, Scotland Yard will next week launch a publicity campaign urging the public to be vigilant over the Christmas period.

Three years of terror

Formed in 1997 when the IRA's quartermaster general left in protest at the Provisionals' backing for the Mitchell principles on non-violence, the group is believed to number between 120 and 200. The security services also suspect a high level of co-operation between the Real IRA and the Continuity IRA, a smaller dissident group.

Although it has been denied, the Real IRA's political wing is the 32-county sovereignity committee led by Michael McKevitt and his partner Bernadette Sands-McKevitt, sister of hunger striker Bobby Sands.

Its main powerbase is in the border region between the north and the Irish Republic. Although the quartermaster general is thought to have brought some weapons with him, the group managed to open an arms route from eastern Europe, smuggling in modern shoulder-held rockets and industrial explosive.

The Real IRA has either claimed or been held responsible for numerous terrorist attacks, including the bombing of Hammersmith bridge, an attempt to bomb a railway line in Acton, west London, and the missile attack on MI6 HQ this year. The attack for which the group is most widely known was the Omagh bomb in August 1998 which killed 29 people and unborn twins.
