webTitle: Hospital hit squad stands by after surgery health alert

fields.headline: Hospital hit squad stands by after surgery health alert
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the future of the NHS
Special report: NHS shortages
fields.trailText: The Department of Health yesterday threatened to send in a hit squad of managers to take over a major hospital in Portsmouth after surgeons called for all emergency operations to be stopped saying that patients' lives are being put at risk.
fields.body:
The Department of Health yesterday threatened to send in a hit squad of managers to take over a major hospital in Portsmouth after surgeons called for all emergency operations to be stopped saying that patients' lives are being put at risk.

Ten orthopaedic consultants at the Queen Alexandra hospital say the lack of sterile instruments means that they consider it is becoming more dangerous to continue the operations on accident victims than to send them to other centres in the south of England.

Contingency plans are being prepared to send emergency cases to other hospitals in Winchester, Southampton or Chichester. Routine orthopaedic surgery was suspended in September because of long-standing problems in the hospital's sterilisation and disinfection unit so that there would at least be sufficient sterile equipment to deal with trauma patients.

The Department of Health called the situation at the hospital "completely unacceptable" and threatened either to send in a hit squad or introduce controls over its funding decisions. The Cosham area hospital has the biggest accident and emergency unit in the south with a catchment area covering 600,000 people.

This crisis follows reports this week which have criticised the running of the Oxford heart centre, condemned the treatment of elderly mental patients in Carlisle and warned of risk to patients from the failure to share procedures in two hospitals' operating theatres run by the Carmarthenshire health trust.

The Portsmouth problems were revealed in a letter written by the surgeons on Monday to hospital management recommending that all admission of trauma victims should cease from November 27, by which time neighbouring units should be prepared to take extra patients.

It said: "Despite stopping elective surgery we have not seen any improvement in the supply of sterile instruments for trauma. Indeed the situation has become worse. We have previously taken the view that cancellation of trauma takes would put the patients at greater risk than continuing the service."

But the doctors said the situation had changed in the previous two weeks and "we now feel that patients' lives and well-being are at serious risk and this situation cannot be allowed to continue".

It is understood that last week staff took six hours to find suitable equipment to treat an elderly woman with a multiple fracture to her leg that needed surgery.

Consultants might also have to reduce or stop seeing new patients.

The surgeons' letter said they were "extremely disappointed" that concerns first raised in June had not been addressed. "Our decision has not been taken lightly ... Morale in the orthopaedic department is at an all-time low."

The Portsmouth Hospitals Trust acknowledged "very slow progress" in addressing problems but said it was "working very hard to ensure that orthopaedic surgery continues at the Queen Alexandra Hospital." More instruments had been ordered.

The suspension of elective surgery meant that about 200 operations were cancelled or postponed but some operations have been conducted since early this month at the military Royal Hospital, Haslar, in Gosport.

Michael Mates, Conservative MP for Hampshire East, said he had raised concerns with health minister Gisela Stuart on three occasions in the last two months.

The health department said: "The hospital should not have let this situation develop. We expect them to take very swift action to sort out their sterilisation department, to make sure patients are safe and to deal with those who have had to wait for their operations. If they do not, we will consider action against the hospital managers involved."

fields.headline: Saudi car explosion kills Briton
fields.standfirst: Blast follows warnings of threat to British interests
fields.trailText: Blast follows warnings of threat to British interests.
fields.body:
One Briton died and another was injured when their car exploded at a crossroads in the centre of the Saudi capital, Riyadh, yesterday.

In a statement, the Riyadh police chief, Abdullah al-Shahrani, said the car, thought to have been booby-trapped, exploded while it was being driven.

Other Saudi sources said earlier that explosives had been thrown through the window of the car. A Foreign Office spokeswoman in London said she could not confirm the cause of the blast.

The dead Briton was named as Christopher Rodway. His wife Jane, who was in the car with him, was treated at Al-Hammadi hospital for superficial injuries.

The Foreign Office said the couple had been living in Saudi Arabia for six or seven years and that Mr Rodway worked in a hospital in Riyadh.

Security forces sealed off two main streets in the Saudi capital's commercial district where the blast occurred before removing the four-wheel-drive vehicle.

The attack came immediately after Friday prayers and a few hours before Crown Prince Abdullah was due to open an international energy conference in the city attended by officials from more than 40 oil producing and consuming countries.

Last August, a Briton was injured when a man opened fire on two cars carrying employees of BAE Systems, which provides support services for the King Faisal air base. That attack was said not to have been politically motivated.

Current Foreign Office advice is that "Saudi Arabia is one of a number of countries where there is an increased threat to British interests from global terrorism". Britons should "exercise particular caution", it says.

Between 25,000 and 30,000 Britons work in the kingdom.

The explosion comes at a time of widespread Arab and Muslim anger over American support for Israel. Britain, in turn, is perceived as a close ally of the US and is still remembered for the 1917 Balfour Declaration which led to the creation of Israel.

Some of the more extreme Islamist groups in the Middle East also resent the presence of westerners, which they see as a corrupting influence. These feelings are fuelled by the stationing of American and British forces in the Gulf to patrol the no-fly zone over southern Iraq.

In 1995, five Americans were killed by a car bomb at a US military headquarters in Riyadh. The following year, a truck bomb near Dhahran killed 19 US Air Force personnel and injured more than 500 Americans and Saudis.

Last month, 17 people died and 39 were injured in a suicide attack on the American guided missile destroyer USS Cole, in Aden harbour, Yemen. The next day, a bomb caused serious damage at the British embassy in the Yemeni capital, Sana'a.

Yemeni authorities believe the Aden attack was carried out by Jihad - a local organisation started by Arab veterans of the Afghan war - possibly with outside help.

Security in Kuwait was stepped up last week following the discovery of a suspected plot to attack American and British forces in the country. Six Kuwaitis are under arrest. A Moroccan, thought to be the group's explosives expert, is still at large.

According to the Kuwaiti authorities, the suspects had buried 293lb of explosives in the desert and planned to use it to bomb a US army camp and western military personnel in their homes and vehicles.

The explosion comes at a time of widespread Arab and Muslim anger over American support for Israel. Britain, in turn, is perceived as a close ally of the US and is still remembered for the 1917 Balfour Declaration which led to the creation of Israel. Some of the more extreme Islamist groups in the Middle East also resent the presence of westerners, which they see as a corrupting influence. These feelings are fuelled by the stationing of American and British forces in the Gulf to patrol the no-fly zone over southern Iraq. In 1995, five Americans were killed by a car bomb at a US military headquarters in Riyadh. The following year, a truck bomb near Dhahran killed 19 US Air Force personnel and injured more than 500 Americans and Saudis. Last month, 17 people died and 39 were injured in a suicide attack on the American guided missile destroyer USS Cole, in Aden harbour, Yemen. The next day, a bomb caused serious damage at the British embassy in the Yemeni capital, Sana'a. Yemeni authorities believe the Aden attack was carried out by Jihad - a local organisation started by Arab veterans of the Afghan war - possibly with outside help. Security in Kuwait was stepped up last week following the discovery of a suspected plot to attack American and British forces in the country. Six Kuwaitis are under arrest. A Moroccan, thought to be the group's explosives expert, is still at large. According to the Kuwaiti authorities, the suspects had buried 293lb of explosives in the desert and planned to use it to bomb a US army camp and western military personnel in their homes and vehicles.

webTitle: Humble Clinton makes whole of Hanoi swoon

fields.headline: Humble Clinton makes whole of Hanoi swoon
fields.trailText: Hanoi, a city which has had minimal contact with US officialdom since the people last heard American bombers overhead almost three decades ago, went into a collective swoon yesterday over Bill Clinton.
fields.body:
Hanoi, a city which has had minimal contact with US officialdom since the people last heard American bombers overhead almost three decades ago, went into a collective swoon yesterday over Bill Clinton.

Thousands gathered just to catch a glimpse of his limo as the president drove round at the start of his three-day official visit to Vietnam. He shook hands with all-comers while visiting the Temple of Literature (930 years old) and a Hanoi cappuccino cafe called Know One Teach One (a few months old). "Hi! How you doing?" he called. Everywhere the response was the same: "Hey, Bill! Hey, Bill!" they shouted. "He's very handsome," sighed one female student.

Old Hanoi hands said nothing had been seen on this scale since Fidel Castro hit town in the 1970s. But the Clinton fans belonged almost wholly to the generation born after what the Vietnamese call "the American war" ended in 1975. That's a majority of the population.

The politicians here make Al Gore look charismatic, and this is a city still short on popular diversions. It was not necessarily an indication of incipient rebellion. But, equally, there were no banners or flags, or any indication that the crowds were orchestrated - Vietnam has moved on.

The country has not, however, moved away from old-style political control, and its leaders had to endure a public lecture from Clinton - representing the side that supposedly lost the war - on the virtues of democracy. He listed the benefits of western-style freedoms in a speech delivered at the National University and broadcast on national TV, a risky departure for the Vietnamese.

"America's record is not perfect," he said, but added: "We've learned some lessons. We have seen that economies work better where newspapers are free to expose corruption, and independent courts can ensure that contracts are honoured, that competition is robust and fair, that public officials honour the rule of law." Political and religious freedoms strengthen a society, he insisted, before adding: "We do not seek to impose these ideals, nor could we. You have proved to the world you will make your own decisions." America, he might have added, learned that lesson the hard way.

Ear-bashing

Amid the careful nuances of modern US-Vietnam relations, it was not clear whether the president had gone further than his hosts thought was seemly or whether they regard this ear-bashing as a price they must pay for having these powerful new friends.

But the speech drew a tart response from the university president, who announced: "Vietnam is on a steady march to socialism - a strong, equitable and democratic society."

Actually, the whole country is steadily marching away from socialism, at least as anyone has previously understood the term. Behind Air Force One will be planeloads of American businessmen desperate to cash in on the Vietnamese government's growing commitment to laissez-faire. But it remains committed to the old methods of political control. In his private meeting with the country's president, Tran Duc Luong, Clinton touched on human rights, to be told: "We may have different meanings of human rights."

Most of the time, Clinton was complimentary, with a leavening of humility appropriate in the country that gave the Americans their greatest ever humiliation. He praised the intellectual achievements of the Vietnamese, both here and in exile, noting that a Vietnamese-American had just passed out first in his class at the US Air Force Academy, and that Vietnam had won three gold medals at the International Mathematics Olympiad.

The president also referred, with some awe, to the people's "staggering sacrifice" and said the shared suffering of the war had given Vietnam and the US "a relationship unlike any other". He urged that two countries which valued their independence should now recognise their inter-dependence. Borrowing a phrase from Pete Peterson, the US Ambassador and former PoW, he said: "We cannot change the past. We can change the future."

The air of cautious amity that preceded the visit seems intact. No one has made any apology for what happened in the war. But officials on both sides are working together on dealing with the effects of Agent Orange and other toxins, and on trying to find the remains of those still missing - 1,400 on the American side, an estimated 300,000 Vietnamese.

Compromises are being made all round. Clinton had to make his speech on a stage decorated with a bust of Vietnam's founding father, Ho Chi Minh, the last Communist patriarch anywhere whose reputation has retained its lustre. Fortunately, the mausoleum where Ho's body is on display, Lenin-style, is currently closed while embalming experts give him his annual wash-and-brush-up. A pilgrimage there, normally obligatory for foreign dignitaries, was thus avoided with no loss of face.

Nor did he visit Hoa Lo prison, where Pe terson and the former Republican presidential contender John McCain were among the captives. A small part of the site is now a museum, full of gruesome models of heroic Vietnamese prisoners being held in leg-irons when Indochina was under French control. One room is devoted to pictures of happy US prisoners receiving Red Cross parcels and cheerfully cooking. "Though having committed untold crimes on our people," says the caption, "American pilots suffered no revenge."

The prisoners, whose view of their experience is a little different, derisively called their jail the Hanoi Hilton. Now there is a real Hanoi Hilton - the White House press corps is currently camped there. History plays strange tricks.

fields.headline: Rush to become people's peers
fields.standfirst:
Basketball player, ex-scientist and Tory writer among 2,000 applying for 10 seats in Lords

Special report: Lords reform
fields.trailText: A last-minute deluge of wannabe peers emerged yesterday as candidates rushed to become the newest recruits in the House of Lords - with up to 400 applying in the 24 hours before the midnight deadline.
fields.body:
A last-minute deluge of wannabe peers emerged yesterday as candidates rushed to become the newest recruits in the House of Lords - with up to 400 applying in the 24 hours before the midnight deadline.

The phone lines to the Lords were white hot as would-be "people's peers" suddenly realised they could make a difference or, at least, gain a title.

A fifth of all the 2,000 applications arrived yesterday - while 700 have come in since Monday alone. Just a month ago, only 191 of the six-page forms had been returned.

The applications are in response to Tony Blair's decision to find a new way of appointing peers in the wake of accusations that the House had been stuffed with "Tony's cronies" since the ejection of hereditary peers. Lord Stevenson, the media tycoon, has been asked to vet applications and propose up to 10 "ordinary peers". The Tories are curious but sceptical about the exercise. "I can't believe they'll find 10 suitable people," one said yesterday.

To illustrate the dangers, it emerged that one applicant is Peter Hitchens, the former Trotskyite activist who is now a militant Conservative and columnist on the Daily Express. Other applicants were said to be more earnest.

The recruitment drive - which saw late applications arriving by hand or via the internet - is also part of Labour's campaign to modernise the second chamber by including more women and people from ethnic minority groups, both categories woefully under-represented in parliament, and, in particular, the Lords. Any UK or Commonwealth citizen over 21 can apply for one of the eight to 10 places which will be announced early next year.

Former convicts will not be ruled out - but, to be in with a chance, applicants will have to prove their "independence and personal integrity, highest standards of propriety, and their ability to contribute to the work of the House". They will also be expected to demonstrate that they possess seven qualities perceived as essential for a peer: selflessness, integrity, objectivity, accountability, openness, honesty and leadership.

With just six hours to go before the deadline, a spokeswoman for the appointments commission refused to reveal any details of who had applied, though, in addition to Mr Hitchens, candidates are believed to include a 25-year-old basketball player and a 78-year-old retired agricultural scientist from Sussex. There has been further speculation that candidates include Oxford University academics and a former firearms officer at Buckingham palace.

To encourage applicants from all areas, 10,000 letters were sent to companies, charities, businesses and trade unions asking for nominations. But the final rush for posts first advertised eight weeks ago is believed to have been sparked by a broadcast on the BBC's Breakfast News yesterday morning. "We've had hundreds come in in the last few days, but a sudden rush after that," added the spokeswoman.

The successful applicants - who will gain a title, an allowance of £81.50 a day and benefit from subsidised restaurants and bars, exquisite surroundings and erudite company - are expected to be announced by March after a "stringent" vetting process.

They will also enjoy all the trappings of power together with the kudos of having reached the elevated position of member of the House of Lords through their own merits rather than ancestors' aristocratic blood.

The successful applicants, who will be non-political and sit on the crossbenches, will join a House that is becoming increasingly assertive, with members defeating the government on two important issues - the lowering of the gay age of consent and the sale of air traffic control - in the last three weeks.

Principles for holders of public office

Selflessness They should take decisions solely in terms of the public interest. They should not do so in order to gain financial or other material benefits for themselves, their family, or their friends.

Integrity They should not place themselves under any financial or other obligation to outside individuals or organisations that might seek to influence them in the performance of their official duties.

Objectivity In carrying out public business, including making public appointments, awarding contracts, or recommending individuals for awards and benefits, they should make choices on merit.

Accountability They are accountable for their decisions and actions to the public, and must submit themselves to whatever scrutiny is appropriate to their office.

Openness They should be as open as possible about all the decisions and actions they take. They should give reasons for their decisions, and restrict information only when the wider public interest clearly demands.

Honesty They should have a duty to declare any private interests relating to their public duties, and to take steps to resolve any conflicts arising in a way that protects the public interest.

Leadership They should promote and support these principles by leadership and example.

fields.headline: Tallahassee's other big face-off
fields.standfirst:
Politics is relegated as football fever sweeps city

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: This is a transcendent occasion in Tallahassee, so much so that they are calling it "The Big Face-off". Thousands of people have infiltrated the city for the moment today that surpasses all others.
fields.body:
This is a transcendent occasion in Tallahassee, so much so that they are calling it "The Big Face-off". Thousands of people have infiltrated the city for the moment today that surpasses all others.

Indeed, the state capitol complex is where Katherine Harris, Florida's contentious secretary of state, will probably announce that, now the overseas ballots have been counted, George W Bush is still ahead of Al Gore and has therefore won the state.

But this is not what exercises the people of Tallahassee so greatly. Their concerns are closer to home: the annual football game between Florida State University and its neighbour the University of Florida.

The T-shirt industry has its own perspective on the relative values of politics and playing games. Near the state senate building there is a stall selling shirts that carry the words: "Who will win the other big game in Florida?", above football helmets marked Al and George.

The convergence of a local institution with the place where the presidency might be won and lost has brought together thousands of football fans, political strategists, support staffs and media workers.

Sporting fixtures are better organised than political crises and so the football fans are in charge, having booked their rooms months, and in some cases a year, in advance. So serious is the situation, that even some journalists are being required to leave their rooms.

In truth, most are simply departing well-appointed billets for the merely average but some, including those from the Boston Globe and the worthy C-Span cable channel, have had to accept rooms from students at $150 a night.

"People don't understand that every hotel room in a five-county area has been booked for six months in advance," said Lee Cornman, the technical co-ordinator for the department of hotels and restaurants division. Fortunately for Mr Cornman, he has the law on his side (subject, of course, to challenge in the courts). This allows hotels to have the police evict guests who do not hold reservations.

Relief, of a sort, is at hand in the environs of the capitol building. Railings, trees and "walk-don't walk" signs are decked with slips of paper offering rooms. "Need a place to stay for the weekend? Open bedroom with full-sized bed and plenty of room," followed by a contact number for Brian B is typical; another, demanding $500 a night, is less so.

But college football is more than a pastime in the south. "Around here, college football's a religion," said Tim Perry, 40, an airline pilot and veteran of the Gulf war who served for four years in Suffolk. "These universities have been home town rivals for so long."

His home is a three-mile drive away and he is here, in Andrew's bar and grill, because his employer has a block booking at a good hotel across the street. "I knew it would be a goatrope here but I had no idea that it would be such a circus."

He is supporting Florida State University and George W Bush, in that order, and has not forgotten entirely about the politics. "We have a flawed system and a lot of stupid people. Show some of them a ballot paper and it's like a pig looking at a wristwatch."

While the University of Florida fancies itself as the home of the elite, taking in future doctors, lawyers, politicians and journalists, Florida State University caters to artists, actors - Burt Reynolds played for them in 1957 - and business people.

Fittingly, perhaps, the show at FSU's school of theatre last night was a production of The Comedy of Errors.

webTitle: A life less ordinary amid the wastes of Planet Wet

fields.headline: A life less ordinary amid the wastes of Planet Wet
fields.standfirst: Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: Retired teacher Rosie Hick, 50, has finally rejoined the rest of Britain after 10 days marooned by floods in the North Yorkshire hamlet of Ryther, near York. Her daughter Kathryn, in the neighbouring village of Naburn, has rediscovered her cottage's inundated ground floor. Rosie's partner David, 44, has garaged the canoe - for now.
fields.body:
Retired teacher Rosie Hick, 50, has finally rejoined the rest of Britain after 10 days marooned by floods in the North Yorkshire hamlet of Ryther, near York. Her daughter Kathryn, in the neighbouring village of Naburn, has rediscovered her cottage's inundated ground floor. Rosie's partner David, 44, has garaged the canoe - for now.

Sat Nov 11 Water still all around us. Should be in Budapest today on a cruise with David's colleagues. Feel isolated and frustrated. News spreads quickly that Button Hill now passable - road to village flooded since Nov 1. Started car to venture out for provisions; it's been stood for nearly a week, brakes have ceased, won't move. Finally escape through eight inches of water to supermarket, via long detour. Feels strange driving again, cars hurtle towards us at unbelievable speeds. Feel like a couple of aliens just arrived from Planet Wet. Kathryn rings. She's been living upstairs all week in her cottage in Naburn with a large mirror across her landing to stop the newborn kittens venturing downstairs. She's distraught, the mirror fell over in the night and one is dead.

Sun Nov 12 Remembrance Day. A day of heartbreak for Barlby and Selby to remember as people go back to their homes for the first time since being evacuated. Top of five bar gate now visible, must still be 4ft deep, murky and still. David drives for papers, usually four-mile trip, this time thanks to water it's a 20.4-mile journey.

Mon Nov 13 Radio York chirpily announces road closures due to flooding. Is everything nearly back to normal? One quick look tells me it's not! - water still stubbornly at the top of the gate and road impassable. Left David's car parked at neighbours for now. All emergency pumps ceremoniously disconnected. A silence falls on the village. Go to see environment agency guys who say: "High pressure on the way midweek, water will recede very slowly." Honestly? How much longer I wonder?

Tues Nov 14 Wake to silence, calm, no rain, no pumps, no cars tearing by. Just peace. Birdsong very noticeable. Must have been like this 100 years ago. Magical. Interrupted by phone, David's Dad."Why don't you lock up and clear off?" he asks.

Realised with some surprise that we don't feel like that, at the beginning of all this we wanted to escape, but now don't feel that at all.

With some effort we head for York via detours. Racecourse is stunning: a lakeland home to hundreds of snowy gulls. York prepared for Christmas. Trees stood waiting to be lit, while at home our bonfire stands wet and untouched. We've been in a time warp.

Wed Nov 15 Wake to frosty, misty landscape. Gas finally runs out! Shivering. Make a cuppa, light fire. Within minutes hear the tanker coming. What a wonderful,welcome sight, ploughing through water to us. Radio tells of snow this weekend. Oh really! Check gate - three bars visible, that's progress! David declares all clear. Water can now be flushed down drains. Head off to art class - water laps the tyres where once it would submerge the car. Unusual wearing shoes once again, feel tight. I miss my wellies. Pm: Inspector Morse dies.

Thurs Nov 16 School bus here again. Life returns to normal. Road to village opens and is cleaned. Now can see the total gate. Pm: radio gives out weekend forecast of frost and snow. They don't sound surprised. Don't get carried away Rose, No need for a snow plough just yet. Or is there? Perhaps we will have many more extremes of weather and have to be flexible to cope? Canoe, snow ploughs, hurricane lamps and sunblock. Will this be the pattern of things to come? Watch forecasts avidly now.

Fri Nov 17 That huge unwelcome visitor is slowly trickling its way back to the river bed. Life has returned to some sort of normality. Other villages and towns were not so lucky. Detours still persist, children play in the street as roads remain closed. Is it really over?

She's distraught, the mirror fell over in the night and one is dead. Sun Nov 12 Remembrance Day. A day of heartbreak for Barlby and Selby to remember as people go back to their homes for the first time since being evacuated. Top of five bar gate now visible, must still be 4ft deep, murky and still. David drives for papers, usually four-mile trip, this time thanks to water it's a 20.4-mile journey. Mon Nov 13 Radio York chirpily announces road closures due to flooding. Is everything nearly back to normal? One quick look tells me it's not! - water still stubbornly at the top of the gate and road impassable. Left David's car parked at neighbours for now. All emergency pumps ceremoniously disconnected. A silence falls on the village. Go to see environment agency guys who say: "High pressure on the way midweek, water will recede very slowly." Honestly? How much longer I wonder? Tues Nov 14 Wake to silence, calm, no rain, no pumps, no cars tearing by. Just peace. Birdsong very noticeable. Must have been like this 100 years ago. Magical. Interrupted by phone, David's Dad."Why don't you lock up and clear off?" he asks. Realised with some surprise that we don't feel like that, at the beginning of all this we wanted to escape, but now don't feel that at all. With some effort we head for York via detours. Racecourse is stunning: a lakeland home to hundreds of snowy gulls. York prepared for Christmas. Trees stood waiting to be lit, while at home our bonfire stands wet and untouched. We've been in a time warp. Wed Nov 15 Wake to frosty, misty landscape. Gas finally runs out! Shivering. Make a cuppa, light fire. Within minutes hear the tanker coming. What a wonderful,welcome sight, ploughing through water to us. Radio tells of snow this weekend. Oh really! Check gate - three bars visible, that's progress! David declares all clear. Water can now be flushed down drains. Head off to art class - water laps the tyres where once it would submerge the car. Unusual wearing shoes once again, feel tight. I miss my wellies. Pm: Inspector Morse dies. Thurs Nov 16 School bus here again. Life returns to normal. Road to village opens and is cleaned. Now can see the total gate. Pm: radio gives out weekend forecast of frost and snow. They don't sound surprised. Don't get carried away Rose, No need for a snow plough just yet. Or is there? Perhaps we will have many more extremes of weather and have to be flexible to cope? Canoe, snow ploughs, hurricane lamps and sunblock. Will this be the pattern of things to come? Watch forecasts avidly now. Fri Nov 17 That huge unwelcome visitor is slowly trickling its way back to the river bed. Life has returned to some sort of normality. Other villages and towns were not so lucky. Detours still persist, children play in the street as roads remain closed. Is it really over?

webTitle: Switch that signals a different approach

fields.headline: Switch that signals a different approach
fields.standfirst:
Special report: transport in Britain
Special report: the Hatfield train crash
fields.trailText: Gerald Corbett's departure is a new start for an organisation that over the past year has earned the sobriquet of Britain's most hated company.
fields.body:
Gerald Corbett's departure is a new start for an organisation that over the past year has earned the sobriquet of Britain's most hated company.

His replacement as Railtrack's chief executive is Steven Marshall, an accountant who worked alongside Mr Corbett five years ago at the Grand Metropolitan pubs and drinks group. But he has a quieter, more measured style than his predecessor, who was a tough and occasionally abrasive leader.

When Mr Corbett first tendered his resignation last month, in the wake of the Hatfield crash, there was a widespread feeling he ought to stay on. By yesterday, with the network still suffering appallingly from cancellations, delays and speed restrictions, there were suggestions that some of the more influential voices in the industry believed he was not really the man for the job.

A source inside one of the regulators said: "We all admired Gerald after Ladbroke Grove. He took a lot of responsibility, and that took a lot of courage. But there is a view the business needs to do better in its day-to-day running. Someone has got to get a grip. We need a new approach, a new team and a new start."

In just the last week Mr Corbett is viewed as having made two serious misjudgments. The first was when he compared the pursuit of rail safety to a journey in which "you never arrive at your destination". This tactless comment at Lord Cullen's inquiry into the Paddington disaster drew tears from some relatives of the 31 dead in the public gallery, and Mr Corbett apologised.

Three days later he provoked fury by raising the company's dividend to shareholders. He said the increase, which will siphon off £2m that Railtrack might have used for investment, was a signal to investors of better times ahead.

A spokesman for Railtrack denied Mr Corbett had been put under any pressure to resign, either by the government or by Railtrack's chairman, Sir Philip Beck. "It really was a purely personal decision," he said. But the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, had repeatedly declined to give Mr Corbett his personal support, saying only: "I have full confidence in the company and I want them to get on with the job."

Last night the prime minister's spokesman, Alastair Campbell, insisted the government had had no idea Mr Corbett was about to resign - even though on Thursday he had been inside Downing Street to present his national recovery plan. But Mr Campbell admitted: "We are on their backs pretty permanently at the moment."

Now he has time, Mr Corbett plans a long holiday in India and a skiing trip over Christmas. In his absence his successor will take up one of the toughest jobs in business.

Mr Marshall's first priority will be to get the network out of chaos by ensuring the present spate of work on the track is done on time. About 75 miles have been relaid, but many more remain and passengers are facing delays well into the new year.

He must focus on the issue of signals passed at danger, or Spads, primary cause of the Paddington disaster.

He faces tough negotiations with the train operating companies over compensation for the current delays. Railtrack has offered £150m, but the operators are believed to want at least double so they can offer generous terms to delayed customers; however, a big payout would anger Railtrack shareholders.

He also faces the prospect of a highly critical report from Lord Cullen, and probably a second one arising from the Hatfield enquiry.

And he will not have support from all quarters. Supporters will point to his having overseen a huge £2bn investment in the railways over the past year; detractors will focus on the fact that, like his predecessor, he is not a railman but an accountant.

Relaxed style for decidedly tough job

Steven Marshall will bring his own "unassuming and relaxed" style to the toughest corporate job in the country, his former colleagues said yesterday.

Mr Marshall, 43, may be a relative newcomer to the rail industry, but his new job will not be the first time he has taken the helm in the middle of a corporate storm.

At Thorn, the electrical and TV rental company, he was called upon to make a similar move from financial director to chief executive in 1995 when it was demerged from EMI.

Mr Marshall has been groomed to be Gerald Corbett's successor, and presents himself as the passengers' friend. Yesterday he said that he intended to examine Railtrack's whole agenda, to ensure that more emphasis was put on consumer benefits.

But whether Mr Marshall will be able to keep a cool head in his new position remains to be seen. "I have not seen him work in areas where there are political or diplomatic considerations - something he will have a lot of at Railtrack," a friend said.

webTitle: Emails set up day of dissent

fields.headline: Emails set up day of dissent
fields.standfirst:
Rallies calling for electoral reform planned in 130 cities

Special report: the US elections
Net news
fields.trailText: Demonstrations organised by email are planned in more than 130 American cities today in protest against the way the election has been conducted and to call for a full recount in Florida and a reform of the voting process. The grassroots organisation hopes to turn itself into a movement that will change the election system
fields.body:
Demonstrations organised by email are planned in more than 130 American cities today in protest against the way the election has been conducted and to call for a full recount in Florida and a reform of the voting process. The grassroots organisation hopes to turn itself into a movement that will change the election system

The demonstrations started as an idea floated on the internet in Los Angeles last week and has snowballed since then as friends have sent details of the organisations, Countercoup and Trust the People, that are coordinating the protests. The former is the overall organisation and each city has its own Trust the People group. The sites of the rallies, which will all take place at 1pm, have been posted on web-sites and emailed forward by friends and groups. People have been asked to organise their own protests if there is not one taking place near them.

"It really is a grassroots organisation," said Lorrie Sparrow, a business analyst who is helping to coordinate the Chicago protest. "I have never been involved in something like this before." Rallies last weekend in a number of cities were attended, she said, by everyone from students to businessmen and included many who had never been involved politically before.

"We want a fair and clear election," said Ms Sparrow. "Every vote matters. This is a non-partisan organisation and we have no party agenda. Part of the lovely thing about it is that people are non-partisan, it is a lovely mix of America in ages and ethnicities. We believe that people are willing to wait for an honest election."

She said that the initial emails had come out of Los Angeles but that it was unclear exactly how the whole network had become operational.

The twin demands of the organisation are for a full recount in Florida and for a change in the electoral system so that in future a president is elected by popular vote alone. If this system operated, Al Gore would have won comfortably but such a change would require a constitutional amendment likely to be opposed by many smaller states who fear that it would diminish their importance.

Ms Sparrow said that while the main efforts were now being directed into getting people onto the streets today, there were plans to organise a pressure group that would ensure that a situation like Florida never happened again.

It is hoped that the film-maker Michael Moore, a Ralph Nader supporter, will address the Chicago rally. Martin Sheen, the actor, has been asked to address the Los Angeles gathering. The hope is to get as many as 100,000 on the streets nationwide.

Demonstrations are planned in cities from Anchorage in Alaska to Birmingham in Alabama, from San Francisco to Boston and Ann Arbor in Michigan to New Orleans in Louisiana. California and Florida are both hosting large numbers of protests with the aim in Florida to make the events non-partisan; there have been many protests in Florida over the past ten days but they have been organised by the supporters of Al Gore or George W Bush.

webTitle: Prime suspect in mole hunt laughs off link to leak

fields.headline: Prime suspect in mole hunt laughs off link to leak
fields.standfirst:
Former Downing St civil servant refuses to deny being source of Sunday newspaper report

Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: A former Downing Street civil servant said yesterday that he was flattered to be considered "the prime suspect" in the Whitehall inquiry into how detailed conversations about the cabinet's 1997 decision to back the Millennium Dome were leaked to a Sunday newspaper.
fields.body:
A former Downing Street civil servant said yesterday that he was flattered to be considered "the prime suspect" in the Whitehall inquiry into how detailed conversations about the cabinet's 1997 decision to back the Millennium Dome were leaked to a Sunday newspaper.

Mark Adams, who remained a high-flying private secretary at No 10 for three months after Tony Blair's landslide victory over John Major, refused to confirm or deny the substance of rumours in government circles that he may have been the person who briefed journalist Simon Walters.

Told that he is under suspicion in Downing Street, Mr Adams replied: "So I am the prime suspect?" He later joked: "It's nice to have advance warning. I'll decide what to say if and when the leak inquiry catches up with me. I will have no problem, as an ex-public servant, if they do come my way to chat with me."

He joked that such notoriety "might be good for business" in his work as a lobbyist seeking to influence government. "One of my clients might easily ask 'Are you the mole in No 10?'. I can tap my nose and do not have to break any confidences, the client can go away and say 'I just met the mole at No 10'."

The circumstantial reason why Mr Adams's name is circulating in Whitehall as a possible source of the detailed account published by the Mail on Sunday is twofold.

Though Alastair Campbell, Mr Blair's spokesman, denies that any official cabinet minute or notes appeared in the paper, the verbatim account of how 12 ministers attacked the dome project is, ministers present admit, broadly accurate despite some errors.

"The Mail on Sunday didn't publish an official document, but it wasn't bonkers either. It got the drift right," said one official. "There's quite a bit of head-scratching going on about what to do."

Some sources claim that Mr Adams left Whitehall shortly after the election because he was disappointed at the lack of promotion. Such a career profile would fit the timing of the dome leak and an earlier one to the same newspaper about alleged cabinet discussions in July.

He told the Guardian: "I used to sit in occasionally on cabinet, when it was prime minister's question's day, to get the line right. Whether or not I was there on that particular day [of the dome discussion] I don't remember. I sort of stopped doing anything very active in the summer recess [after the 1997 leaks] and was hanging around as a sort of consultant to my successor."

But Whitehall officials also spotted that he was one of 32 friends (including Lord Archer) to be thanked for help in the foreword of Simon Walters' first novel - Second Term, "a story of spin, sabotage and seduction" - published in September. "We think he may be the man," said one official.

Pressed to say categorically whether he was the source, Mr Adams, who got an OBE for his civil service work in John Major's years, said: "I am quite excited that it might be me. It seems a shame to categorically deny it."

Officials who worked with him then call him "very smooth". Some say he was apolitical, others a Tory and a third source called him Blairite.

In a telephone interview, Mr Adams, now managing director of the political unit for the Westminster-based Communications Group, confirmed that he had been present in his capacity as one of Mr Blair's private office staff during some cabinet meetings in the early months of Labour's new government.

"I cannot remember what bits I was present for," he said, adding later: "I do not know how to check whether I was there at the crucial moment [when the dome was discussed on June 19 1997]. I am not inclined to do so to make some public comment." He added last night: "I rang No 10 to seek advice on what was happening. I was assured there was no leak inquiry and that no such official [leaked] documents existed."

Mr Adams was Mr Major's private secretary (parliamentary affairs) for nearly four years, the Tory prime minister rewarding him with an OBE in his resignation honours' list. He joined his present consultancy from the Apco group, also lobbyists.

Mr Adams was said to have supplied much of the colour for the Simon Walters novel, especially for scenes set in Downing Street, such as the colour of wallpaper and details of paintings hanging in various rooms. His own explanation is that Mr Walters "came to me two days before the proof deadline after suddenly realising there was not enough colour about No 10. 'Will you have a quick read?' he asked. On a train to Newcastle I gave it a quick skim and told him about the timing of things, the fact that the people who bring the tea to prime ministers are the messengers, harmless descriptions like that."

One former colleague described him as "chippy" and claimed Mr Adams quit Downing Street when Mr Blair failed to promote him. "He was not politically minded at all, very much a career civil servant," said the former colleague. "He did not get the promotion he was looking for, so decided to leave."

Mr Adams had a fairly low public profile in government but in 1993 was drawn into the row over allegations made under parliamentary privilege that Roger Windsor, former chief executive of the National Union of Mineworkers, had been an undercover MI5 agent.

Mr Windsor, now living and working in France, denied the allegation and wrote to Mr Major asking him to make a public statement clearing his name.

On July 21 that year, Mr Windsor received a reply from Mr Adams referring him to a parliamentary answer given by the prime minister in June 1991.

Asked by Labour MP George Galloway whether Mr Windsor had "ever been employed by her majesty's government", Mr Major had simply replied: "No."

Mr Adams told the Guardian he had refused TV opportunities as a pundit after leaving No 10, preferring to work behind the scenes.

He said he had last met Mr Walters in the street at Brighton during the Labour conference in September. He added that he knew many political journalists.

webTitle: Schools chief says Hackney is worst council

fields.headline: Schools chief says Hackney is worst council
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government yesterday accepted the case for further privatisation of the education service in the beleaguered London borough of Hackney after Chris Woodhead, the outgoing chief inspector of schools in England, described it as the worst council in the country.
fields.body:
The government yesterday accepted the case for further privatisation of the education service in the beleaguered London borough of Hackney after Chris Woodhead, the outgoing chief inspector of schools in England, described it as the worst council in the country.

Mr Woodhead, launching his third scathing report on the running of the local education authority since 1997, also criticised David Blunkett, the education secretary, for failing to take radical action earlier.

He urged Mr Blunkett to look "hard and quickly" at wholesale privatisation of Hackney school services, even though the report said that Nord Anglia, a private contractor already brought in to run some services, had a patchy record.

Schools in Hackney "were making very good progress, but they are making progress in spite of, and not because of, the authority," Mr Woodhead said. "I urge the government to act, and act now, to rescue the education of some of Britain's most deprived children from the malign influence of Hackney council."

In interviews, Mr Woodhead said: "I have to say that I feel a sense of failure myself that I haven't persuaded the government that radical intervention was needed in the past." Such veiled attacks on Mr Blunkett are likely to become more explicit when he leaves Ofsted at the end of the month. He joins the Daily Telegraph as a commentator in the spring.

The report said a third of the services for which Hackney council was responsible were still unsatisfactory, including implementation of the school improvement strategy, support for children, support for school management, corporate planning and financial management, financial support for schools, and property management.

The recent resignation of the "highly effective" education director Elizabeth Reid was "a disaster", Ofsted said. Mrs Reid, whose notice period ended yesterday, said she was "absolutely 100% with the findings of the Ofsted report".

Mr Blunkett said he was considering giving schools, or groups of schools, opportunities to buy in services, and involving private or public bodies in the provision of further services. But he would be consulting head teachers first.

"Hackney schools and heads deserve better than drift and uncertainty. We will work with them to ensure that they get the support services they need and want," he said.

A source close to the education secretary said Hackney was the first authority to have some services contracted out after the 1998 act had given ministers power to do so. They had acted on the basis of an Ofsted report. But because of the risk of a court challenge Mr Blunkett had always ensured that he had strong evidence before he took services away from local councils.

Mark Lushington from the Hackney branch of the National Union of Teachers said: "The Ofsted report is critical of Nord Anglia for doing too little, too slowly - and then Chris Woodhead says the answer is privatisation. We are fed up with being a political football."

Ministers yesterday effectively put the near-bankrupt council on trial by allowing it to borrow an extra £14m to head off a financial meltdown over the next few months. But the government has insisted it will send a team of outside consultants to monitor the work.

Hilary Armstrong, the local government minister, said: "We will not stand by and leave the people of Hackney, and the council's loyal staff, at risk from ... failing services."

She warned that "radical options" were being considered to take other services away from the council if it failed to meet its commitments and satisfy inspectors from the audit commission early next year.
fields.bodyText: The government yesterday accepted the case for further privatisation of the education service in the beleaguered London borough of Hackney after Chris Woodhead, the outgoing chief inspector of schools in England, described it as the worst council in the country. Mr Woodhead, launching his third scathing report on the running of the local education authority since 1997, also criticised David Blunkett, the education secretary, for failing to take radical action earlier. He urged Mr Blunkett to look "hard and quickly" at wholesale privatisation of Hackney school services, even though the report said that Nord Anglia, a private contractor already brought in to run some services, had a patchy record. Schools in Hackney "were making very good progress, but they are making progress in spite of, and not because of, the authority," Mr Woodhead said. "I urge the government to act, and act now, to rescue the education of some of Britain's most deprived children from the malign influence of Hackney council." In interviews, Mr Woodhead said: "I have to say that I feel a sense of failure myself that I haven't persuaded the government that radical intervention was needed in the past." Such veiled attacks on Mr Blunkett are likely to become more explicit when he leaves Ofsted at the end of the month. He joins the Daily Telegraph as a commentator in the spring. The report said a third of the services for which Hackney council was responsible were still unsatisfactory, including implementation of the school improvement strategy, support for children, support for school management, corporate planning and financial management, financial support for schools, and property management. The recent resignation of the "highly effective" education director Elizabeth Reid was "a disaster", Ofsted said. Mrs Reid, whose notice period ended yesterday, said she was "absolutely 100% with the findings of the Ofsted report". Mr Blunkett said he was considering giving schools, or groups of schools, opportunities to buy in services, and involving private or public bodies in the provision of further services. But he would be consulting head teachers first. "Hackney schools and heads deserve better than drift and uncertainty. We will work with them to ensure that they get the support services they need and want," he said. A source close to the education secretary said Hackney was the first authority to have some services contracted out after the 1998 act had given ministers power to do so. They had acted on the basis of an Ofsted report. But because of the risk of a court challenge Mr Blunkett had always ensured that he had strong evidence before he took services away from local councils. Mark Lushington from the Hackney branch of the National Union of Teachers said: "The Ofsted report is critical of Nord Anglia for doing too little, too slowly - and then Chris Woodhead says the answer is privatisation. We are fed up with being a political football." Ministers yesterday effectively put the near-bankrupt council on trial by allowing it to borrow an extra £14m to head off a financial meltdown over the next few months. But the government has insisted it will send a team of outside consultants to monitor the work. Hilary Armstrong, the local government minister, said: "We will not stand by and leave the people of Hackney, and the council's loyal staff, at risk from ... failing services." She warned that "radical options" were being considered to take other services away from the council if it failed to meet its commitments and satisfy inspectors from the audit commission early next year.

fields.headline: Prince tours flood-ravaged North Yorkshire
fields.standfirst:
Huge job of repairing defences gets under way

Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: Britain is down to its last severe flood warning today, three weeks after rivers across the country were trebled in size by torrential rain.
fields.body:
Britain is down to its last severe flood warning today, three weeks after rivers across the country were trebled in size by torrential rain.

Only the village of Gowdall in North Yorkshire remains in danger from weak points in the river Aire defence dykes, which have seen floodwater seep through in spite of intensive sandbagging.

The Prince of Wales toured the area yesterday, inspecting swamped homes and praising the resilience of flood victims and emergency staff. He called in on victims of the river Ouse, which rose nearly six metres at the height of the flood, including retired headteacher Margaret Walker, who had to perch upstairs in York when the river engulfed her ground floor.

"I can hardly believe how deep the water had got. I do feel very much for everyone trying to struggle on like Margaret," said the prince, who walked past pavements and gardens lined with sodden furniture, books and toys. "It will take such a long time to dry anything out. I think this is the worst time of all."

He also praised the army, council staff and others involved in coping with the floods for "the marvellous way" they pulled together. He added: "I was determined to see how everyone has managed to cope. Everyone is battling to get back to normal again. These disasters bring the best out of people."

Mrs Walker, who had to salvage all her ground floor possessions just a day after leaving hospital following a gall-bladder operation, said: "I can't begin to tell you what this has done to me. I no longer have a home. When I come back I will be scared of it happening again and would like some reassurance that it won't."

Houses remain flooded in parts of Malton, Norton, and other towns and villages close to the river Derwent, also in North Yorkshire, where drenched water meadows are draining only slowly. Twelve ordinary flood warnings are expected to be lifted by the weekend on low-lying land b y the river Severn, the Lavant in West Sussex and other points on the Yorkshire Aire.

"It looks like the end for now, but a huge job is under way on inspecting and repairing flood defences," said Adam Leavy of the environment agency, which has recorded 6,600 properties flooded nationwide. "We are really only starting on what can be the flooding season and the defences have had an extremely severe testing."

Staff in Yorkshire and the north-east, which took the worst battering, are checking more than 1,500 miles of earthen dykes and concrete walls, which faced relentless pressure for nearly three weeks. In York, where the river Foss mobile barrier was lifted after a largely successful, 17-day defence of the city, structural engineers are checking every yard of wall for cracks or other damage.

Frost is not expected to make any structural problems worse in the defences, but cold weather added to the misery of householders clearing ruined possessions from flooded homes in Barlby, Selby and the Derwent towns. There was also resentment in Gowdall after the environment agency warned that staff would not be able to attend meetings organised by the local council because they were too busy checking flood defences.

An agency regional spokesman said staff were keen to liaise with local people but defence work had to take priority. Although rivers are close to normal, general flood watches remain in place for almost the whole of Yorkshire because of the waterlogged ground.

Huge lakes remain in farming areas close to the Ouse between Tadcaster and the Humber, with a return to normal unlikely for several weeks. But weather forecasters remain optimistic that fresh rainfall, which could trigger flooding rapidly, particularly if concentrated in hill catchment areas, is unlikely in the short-term.

webTitle: Bulger's mother pleads for killers to be denied anonymity

fields.headline: Bulger's mother pleads for killers to be denied anonymity
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Bulger case
fields.trailText: The mother of James Bulger made an impassioned plea last night for his killers to be denied anonymity on release.
fields.body:
The mother of James Bulger made an impassioned plea last night for his killers to be denied anonymity on release.

Denise Fergus said she felt "let down and betrayed" by the justice system, after the high court finished hearing an application by Robert Thompson and Jon Venables for a lifelong ban on publicity after they leave custody next year. Dame Elizabeth Butler-Sloss, president of the high court's family division, said she hoped to decide before Christmas whether to grant the ban.

The pair, who killed James, two, in Liverpool in 1993 when aged 10, sought an unprecedented injunction preventing publication of details of the new identities they will assume on release. Four newspaper groups oppose the ban. Yesterday Mark Shaw, for the Home Office, told the court the public might never know when or if the pair, now 18, had been released.

He said there had been no decision yet on a date for release. When it came, it was normal practice for neither the prison service nor the parole board to make an announcement. But if the press or a member of the public put a specific question to the authorities after release, an answer would normally be given but even then the time or day would not usually be volunteered. "There may be reasons in this case to be even more circumspect that that."

In a statement, Mrs Fergus said: "I feel let down and betrayed by the system. The only shred of hope I have is that Dame Elizabeth turns down the application for Robert Thompson and Jon Venables to be given anonymity for the rest of their lives..

"As children one can understand them being given some protection but what right have they got to be given special treatment as adults as well?"

She added: "For seven years the system persuaded me to rely on the criminal justice procedures and to remain silent although all this time I feared the worst.

"Venables and Thompson have dragged me, my family, and the name of James through every court possible in this country and Europe for which unlimited funds have been made available to them.

"This is in complete contrast to the help made available to victims of crime. The European court of human rights has become a friend of criminals and enemies of their victims".

Thompson and Venables say their lives would be at risk on their release if their whereabouts were made public.

Arguing that a ban would not open the floodgates for adult murderers such as Myra Hindley, Mr Shaw said the boys had spent their adolescence in detention and their appearance had obviously changed since 1993. Injunctions had barred publication of any new photographs of them and their whereabouts were not publicly known.

webTitle: Britain ahead in greenhouse gas cuts

fields.headline: Britain ahead in greenhouse gas cuts
fields.standfirst:
Environmental measures applauded as international wrangling continues to bring US into line on harmful emissions

Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: Environmental measures applauded as international wrangling continues to bring US into line on harmful emissions.
fields.body:
The UK will have the largest reductions of greenhouse gases of any country if the latest estimates proved correct, the environment minister, Michael Meacher, said yesterday as he launched the government's new climate strategy.

The programme to reach 23% reductions on 1990 levels by 2010 is almost double the legally binding target of 12.5% to which the UK is committed under the Kyoto protocol being negotiated by 180 nations meeting in the Hague.

Mr Meacher and John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, will spend next week at those climate talks attempting to broker a deal with the United States which is at loggerheads with the EU over the details of the protocol.

The US is committed to 7% cuts but, because of a booming economy, says it cannot reach the target by cutting fossil fuel burning and instead must buy carbon credits from other countries and plant forests.

Mr Meacher said the EU remained determined that the US must take domestic action and not buy its way out of its commitments.

"The extreme weather of the last few weeks...can leave us in no doubt of the urgency of tack- ling global warming," he said.

"The US with 5% of the world population and 25% of emissions must be brought on board."

The UK programme is already well ahead of most countries because it substitutes gas-fired electricity stations for coal but Mr Meacher said the cuts being made in emissions in the next 10 years were "real".

Among the carbon savings is an increase in renewable energies from 1% to 10% of electricity production including wind power, wood and bio-fuelled power stations, wave energy and solar power. The government will provide £89m in capital grants for offshore wind and energy crops. There will also be a boost of combined heat and power with district and factory heating schemes.

New regulations to make electrical goods more efficient are already in place and revised building rules will improve insulation in homes. Businesses will pay a climate change levy on carbon based fuels and £130m of that money will be recycled into low carbon technologies to stimulate their growth.

From next year electricity companies will be obliged to help pensioners and the poor insulate homes to reduce their power bills.

One of the most controversial aspects of the UK's policy is transport - where energy-efficient engines and cleaner technologies are voluntary agreements. There is also criticism from the green lobby of the lowering of petrol taxes and of a report yesterday that the ultra low sulphur diesel produces 20% more carbon dioxide than ordinary fuel.

Mr Meacher said that the price of oil had soared so much that the tax cut made no difference to the fuel strategy. He also refuted claims that the new diesel was more polluting. It produced far less particulate matter and nitrogen dioxide, two serious air pollutants. As far as carbon dioxide was concerned the increase was about 2% per gallon but this was offset by the fact it was a lighter fuel and contained less carbon that ordinary diesel.

The new Traffic Act would also give local authorities the power to curb traffic with road pricing. "If the strategy is not enough to curb traffic we will take further measures," Mr Meacher said.

Charles Secrett, director of Friends of the Earth, said: "There are too many voluntary measures and not enough mandatory ones. There should be tax breaks for industry to bring in low carbon or no carbon fuels and much more support for renewables."

Lifestyle changes in the UK by 2010

• Houses will be better insulated and energy rated, so fuel bills will go down

• Electrical goods will be energy efficient

• Park and ride schemes will be common, as city roads are given tolls

• Public transport will be better in town and country

• Trains may run on time.

• Cars will be smaller and more fuel efficient

• Many cars will run on clean fuels

• Rubbish will be recycled

• Wellington boots will be more than a fashion item

• Solar panels will be available in supermarkets

webTitle: In the tracks of a streetcar named Desire

fields.headline: In the tracks of a streetcar named Desire
fields.standfirst: Richard Eyre: director's diary
fields.trailText: Richard Eyre: director's diary
fields.body:
November 5 1999

New York. To the Public Theater to interview George Wolfe, who is its director. He had to follow Joe Papp - a producer with a gargantuan enthusiasm for not-for-profit theatre and a matching ego: he substituted his own face for Shakespeare's on the posters for Shakespeare in the Park. George, despite a kidney transplant and running the Public Theater, has limitless energy and has discovered the secret of circular breathing: he talks without stopping about social responsibility, the Group Theater, Odets, Miller, Federal Theater Project and - he's black - racism, the fault-line in American society. We talk about "cultural strip-mining": "I think that there are very few things that happen in this country that I don't see as some kind of Minstrel show," says George.

November 6

Interview with Kim Hunter, the original Stella in the play and movie of Streetcar. She talks of Marlon Brando with great affection as a thoughtful, responsible, hard-working and thoroughly engaged actor. When we asked him if he'd be interviewed for this series, he said that the last thing in the world he wanted to talk about was acting; he'd only talk about the plight of the American Indian. Reasonable enough, but Stan, our van driver, says of him: "His elevator doesn't go to the top."

Broadway by night: a piece to camera about what the American theatre has given to the British. When we finish filming, three small girls ask for my autograph. I tell them that my signature is worthless, but they meekly persist: the presence of the camera has convinced them that I'm a catch, so strong is the national religion of celebrity. So I write: "Kira, with best wishes", wishing that I could make her day by adding the words "Clint" and "Eastwood".

November 7

Irene Worth interview, then off to New Orleans. Irene talks (and does impersonations) of Noël Coward, TS Eliot and John Gielgud, from whom she says she had the best piece of advice on acting, which he'd learned painfully: "Acting is half shame, half glory. Shame when you're aware of yourself, and glory when you can forget yourself."

It's a two-hour journey (and a different time zone) to New Orleans. We arrive after dark, happy to be wrapped in humid, semi-tropical night. We're staying in the French Quarter - elegant two - or three-storey houses, a louche and lively street life, live oaks dripping with Spanish moss in the square, small courtyards with fountains and greenery, and balconies with lacy ironwork. We have dinner sitting on one of them, directly opposite the room where Tennessee Williams lived - the justification for our visit.

November 8

Driving out of town to rendezvous with a steamboat (as in Showboat, the first real Broadway musical). I grew up in Hardy country in Dorset, so I'm used to people decoding landscape familiar to them from literature. For me, Louisiana is familiar from Huckleberry Finn, the plays of Tennessee Williams, the novels of James Lee Burke, and the life of Huey Long, the demagogue governor, assassinated in 1935, chronicled brilliantly in Robert Penn Warren's All The King's Men. I tell Warren, our New Orleans van driver, about my interest in Huey Long. "He was a big BS-er," he says.

The steamboat - the American Queen - is moored on the Mississippi beside a levee, the steep man-made flood-barriers that line the river. The scale of the boat matches the river: it's like a white Gothic aircraft carrier with a huge red paddle wheel at its stern, a floating hotel.

Opposite the levee is a beautiful white-columned "Greek revival" house, situated at the end of an arcade of 250-year-old live oaks, surrounded - at a distance - by sugar fields and small thin- roofed clap-board houses. It doesn't take much imagination to picture the slave plantation, and we're reminded that the Old South isn't dead when our camera assistant, Andy, who is part Malaysian, asks a tourist if he minds waiting till we've finished the shot. "Move, Boy!" shouts the no-neck. Later I spot Little Black Sambo for sale in the tourist shop.

November 9

The French Quarter is swarming with tourists, the objects of veneration being the ubiquitous T-shirt, Tabasco, souvenirs and cajun music CDs. In contrast, the Louisiana museum is almost empty; it's next to the St Louis cathedral, whose bells Blanche Dubois refers to as the only pure thing in New Orleans. Just to see the chronicle of slavery, the forced migration, the auctions, the division of families, the systematised brutality, is to feel that here is a crime as great as the Holocaust, and possibly less well digested by the perpetrators and the victims.

Plaques all over the French Quarter describie the dates of houses and their ownership. There is nothing, however, to record the residence of Tennessee Williams, who put New Orleans on the map as much as Louis Armstrong and Sidney Bechet did. At night we film on the balcony where we had dinner two nights ago, opposite the house where Williams worked on a play set in Chicago called The Poker Night, as the streetcars rattled below his window. They came from a district called Cemetery and ended in Desire: the setting of his play became New Orleans - a street called Elysian Fields (it exists but not in the French Quarter) - and the streetcar became celebrated in its title.

Later we film on a streetcar (well, a bus) heading for Desire. It seems a cruel irony for its inhabitants that Desire is all embers rather than all promise. It's the end of the line: shacks, tenements, urban wasteland, the expense of spirit in a waste of shame. We spend two hours filming on the bus - Desire twice consummated - and feel that segregation, at least by poverty, still persists: we're the only white people who travel on the bus.

 Richard Eyre's Changing Stages continues on BBC2 on Sunday at 7.30pm.

Plaques all over the French Quarter describie the dates of houses and their ownership. There is nothing, however, to record the residence of Tennessee Williams, who put New Orleans on the map as much as Louis Armstrong and Sidney Bechet did. At night we film on the balcony where we had dinner two nights ago, opposite the house where Williams worked on a play set in Chicago called The Poker Night, as the streetcars rattled below his window. They came from a district called Cemetery and ended in Desire: the setting of his play became New Orleans - a street called Elysian Fields (it exists but not in the French Quarter) - and the streetcar became celebrated in its title. Later we film on a streetcar (well, a bus) heading for Desire. It seems a cruel irony for its inhabitants that Desire is all embers rather than all promise. It's the end of the line: shacks, tenements, urban wasteland, the expense of spirit in a waste of shame. We spend two hours filming on the bus - Desire twice consummated - and feel that segregation, at least by poverty, still persists: we're the only white people who travel on the bus.  Richard Eyre's Changing Stages continues on BBC2 on Sunday at 7.30pm.

fields.headline: Charlie Dimmock: the shocking truth
fields.standfirst: Charlie's Wildlife Gardens | The Beautiful South: Paul's Gang |  Children in Need
fields.trailText: Last night's TV
fields.body:
Right from the titles of Charlie's Wildlife Gardens (BBC2), Charlie Dimmock is presented as some winsome disciple of mother nature, a fertility goddess spreading her wild oats and bringing life to dreary lawns. She flies hither and thither with her elfen helper, Chris Baines ("a man with a passion for meadows"), spreading the joyous news that nature is nice. Strawberry blonde tresses dancing in the breeze, Charlie wouldn't look out of place wandering about the woods in A Midsummer Night's Dream.

As it was, she was in the back garden of a cottage in Ross-on-Wye creating a meadow garden for some woman who couldn't be bothered doing it herself. Instead of getting on and doing the job - and thus producing a neat 15-minute programme - Charlie and Chris had a whole half-hour to fill. That meant padding out the digging and planting with some day trips away.

Consequently, Charlie nipped off to another garden that had flowers (oooh!) and to a genuine meadow with Nick the wildlife expert (aaah!). And some expert Nick was. When the pair saw a creepy spider carrying its babies in a sac under its body, instead of stamping on it and laughing, Nick picked it up and called it "special". It would be even more "special", he continued, when the sac burst open and the babies rode around on mummy spider's back. Special? Is that in a totally disgusting, too-many-legs-for-one-creature kind of way? I fear not, at least not as far as Nick is concerned. Cuddling grasshoppers I can just about deal with, but spiders are just plain wrong.

Back in the garden, after an interlude devoted entirely to reminding us how pretty butterflies are, Charlie was whooping enthusiastically: "I've got a red admiral on my bum." Where the rest of the fleet were, we weren't told (though they may have been forming an orderly queue somewhere). Naturally, no Dimmock programme would be complete without a little sexual frisson - and we were treated to it in spades as she and Chris the Mad Meadows Man threw grass at each other in a devil-may-care rural style.

Charlie Dimmock isn't a real person, of course. She's actually a robot created by some shadowy military-industrial-gardening organisation to encourage us to get on with horticultural shenanigans while they spray us with sedatives from weather balloons. And those aren't nipples, you know - they're control buttons.

Even her name has the whiff of simulacrum about it. "Charlie" is very jolly hockeysticks, homemade lemonade and frolics in cornfields, while "Dimmock" has connotations of the countryside with a hint of hammock, and implications she's a harmless, non-threatening rural gal. Well, just you wait.

The Beautiful South: Paul's Gang (BBC2) was a mildly interesting look at the band who brought the world such delights as A Little Time, Song for Whoever and Prettiest Eyes. Like the band itself, the documentary wasn't slick, pretentious and grandiose. Style never overtook substance as the camera followed Paul Heaton and the rest through the processes of songwriting and recording their latest album, Painting It Red.

Were this another band, the travelogue from Hull to Utrecht to Seville and back again could have been construed as nothing more than a cynical marketing ploy but with The Beautiful South, it felt genuine and worth something more than bog standard "behind-the-scenes" documentary tacked onto some DVD.

Should newsreaders make fools of themselves, albeit for charity and only once a year? That is the question that occupies the mind whenever Children in Need (BBC1) raises its Pudsey Bear head. Admittedly, it is jolly to see Jennie Bond and Nicholas Witchell giving their all to some big musical number, but it undoubtedly affects one's opinion of them the next time they read the news (mind you, considering Bond does royal things and Witchell spent far too long searching for Nessie, perhaps their dancing doesn't matter too much).

In one respect, I suspect that's why Mariella Frostrup presenting Panorama was criticised - she isn't highbrow enough and lacks journalistic training. That, of course, is entirely the wrong reason to criticise her elevation. The right reason is that she does the voiceover for a Boots advert.
