fields.headline: Help! I'm having an art attack
fields.standfirst: The trouble with culture these days, says  Mark Ravenhill, is that there's just too much of it
fields.trailText: The trouble with culture these days, says Mark Ravenhill, is that there's just too much of it
fields.body:
There's a lot of art about at the moment. It's everywhere. It's really stressing me out. It's making me feel guilty. And I wish it would stop. For starters, there's all those books on the Booker shortlist. I ought to read them. Well, at least the Margaret Atwood. But if I read that one, I know I'll want to read more Atwood. I mean, I haven't even read The Handmaid's Tale, and everybody's read that. And there's a film of it that I ought to see, a TV adaptation I missed, and a fantastic opera version that opened in Copenhagen last year.

And there's all those exhibitions. I want to have an opinion about Apocalypse. I mean, I've got an opinion because I've seen countless pieces in newspapers and magazines. I've witnessed Tracey Emin being repellent in various media. But I'd like to see the real thing at some point so that I don't go round feeling my opinion is a bit... well, second-hand. And that library in Peckham - that sounds fascinating. I need to work out where Peckham is, find the library, and see what I think of it for myself.

And I've got to stop being so metropolitan. I've got to go to the Lowry Centre, the Tate in... oh God, is it Cornwall or Devon or...? And Smoking with Lulu at the West Yorkshire Playhouse. I would say that's a must-see.

It's not just art I want to be aware of. There's culture, too. I mean, I'm not an elitist. I understand that the new Charlie's Angels movie embraces a fascinating range of discourses on gender politics. Can this really be true? I have to see it for myself. And I have to compare and contrast the new Westlife single and the new Tweenies single and...

Look. Isn't there too much art around at the moment? Isn't there too much culture? Isn't it making us all unhappy? Clearly there's a big problem. And we've got to find a solution.

Various moratoria have been suggested recently: no more Shakespeare plays produced for five years; nothing but new plays produced for 10 years. Well, I wonder whether we shouldn't go for the big one: nothing produced for a year. No images, no narratives, no "experiences", no performances. Nothing that could be considered, even by the most dogged commentator, as art or culture. Just a year to give us a chance to calm down, take stock and see whether we really want all this stuff.

All of this would have to be firmly managed, of course. A cultural moratorium tsar would have to be appointed to ensure that the performance indicator - zero - was met. But then think of the various cultural commentators who would be freed up for a year to do the job. I would suggest Mark Lawson. Lawson, I think, has the breadth of understanding and the weight - culturally speaking - to do the job. But if Lawson declines, there's a rich array of choices: Richard Eyre, Mariella Frostrup, Lord Bragg. Any of them would do a splendid job.

But then, when the year is over, what happens next? The artists, relieved for a whole year from the burden of promoting and explaining their current book/play/album/ exhibition, might produce far more in the year that followed than in any previous year. Which means that once the moratorium is over, there'll be more art around than ever and the whole merry-go-round will spin around faster than ever.

How did we get here? Are there really more stories, more images about than ever before? Or does it just seem like that? There is a long tradition of distrust, or even panic, in the face of cultural overload.

In the early 18th century Pope wrote, in The Dunciad, of a London drowning under a great tidal wave of words pouring out from Grub Street. The thousands of new novels produced every year during the 19th century, mostly consumed by female readers, were mocked in other publications, from Northanger Abbey's depiction of the dangerous effects of Gothic fiction on young women's sensibility, to the disdain shown by Lady Bracknell for Miss Prism's three-volume novel of "more than usually revolting sentimentality" in The Importance of Being Earnest.

There has always been an ongoing battle between the Leavis Gang - those who, broadly speaking, want to rescue art from the crude world of the masses and the marketplace - and the Walter Benjamin gang, who have embraced the new possibilities for readers and audiences offered by new technologies, from the printing press to the internet.

Year on year, decade on decade, century on century, since the Renaissance, western culture has accelerated. There are always more narratives and more images than the year before, and new technologies are constantly discovered that allow them to be distributed to a wider constituency and at a greater speed. And this has been a good thing: the lives of men and women have been enriched by being able to choose the narratives or images that allow them to define themselves, to make sense of their relationship with their community, to gain an insight into lives very different from their own. And more and more people every century have the opportunity to become producers as well as consumers. No longer are a few wise old men with private incomes justifying the ways of God - or Marx - to men.

But is this an ever-widening virtuous circle? Can it keep on expanding infinitely and still be making our lives richer and better? There's still a lot to do. There are great sections of our society whose voices are only faintly heard in our art and culture. We need to expand artistic production to embrace them. Perhaps we can use the revolution in TV technology or internet publishing.

Or have we reached a crunch point? If the Renaissance was a Big Bang that created the universe of narratives and images that we now inhabit, maybe we've reached the point where we've overstretched ourselves. Maybe, around about now, entropy kicks in and the whole edifice starts collapsing in on itself. Perhaps there simply isn't enough human experience and imagination to fuel a limitless number of narratives and images, or enough human beings to consume them. Once we reach a critical mass, the whole thing will start moving backwards. Every year, less and less culture and art, until finally we get back to a single mono-myth.

Before Luther and the printing press, that mono-myth (allowing for a bit of local folklore) was the word of God. When entropy pulls us back this time, what mono-myth will greet us on our route to forming a black hole? Will it be the Bible once again? Will it be a single Great Truth, or will it be Ross and Phoebe and their Friends, or Simba and the Little Mermaid and the Disney world, that reveal themselves as being at the centre of our universe?

A recklessly optimistic nature won't allow me to believe in the apocalyptic possibility of cultural entropy. Globalisation may well produce a "gold standard" of largely American culture, but there's little evidence that it will stop the production of richer and more diverse work. Around and between the global edifices of American film and television, the big art exhibition exported from capital city to capital city and the festival culture that allows the great directors of European theatre to show each other their Hamlets, diverse cultures will continue to flourish.

And this diversity should be celebrated and protected. Absolutely. Of course. Totally agree. And yet... Why do I feel overwhelmed by cultural choices? Why do I so often wish there was less art?

I don't think I'm alone in this. The marketeers understand how I feel. Order a piece of detective fiction from amazon.com and the website will recommend another detective novel. Ignore that advice and order a cookery book, and you'll be offered another cookery book. They're trying to save you the bother of browsing through all those titles you won't like.

And you needn't look through endless theatre listings in entertainment guides, because if you've booked tickets for an old play in the past two years, you'll be down on a list and will be mail-shotted with classical plays you can go to.

But it's not just business doing this. The reading group (someone selects a book, you all read it, you come together to discuss it) allows us to hand over the difficult task of choosing our reading material to someone else and to share the experience with a group of others. It makes all those piles of books - books that have won prizes, books recommended by people who've written other books, books shortly to be made into major motion pictures - so much less terrifying.

What the reading group does is to formalise and expand that old standby: word of mouth. Anybody who has ever been to the Edinburgh festival will understand what cultural overload means. Within hours of arriving, you are so overwhelmed by press and publicity that you throw it all aside and turn to a stranger in the street and say: "Have you seen anything good?"

I'd like to propose a year-long moratorium beginning on January 1 2001. No reviews, no cultural commentators on radio or television, no profiles of artists in magazines. Stop the presses at Time Out. Pull the plug on Front Row. Ban the Guardian listings. Just a simple sign up outside each gallery or cinema or opera house saying what's on. And let gossip and rumour do the rest. Go on. I dare you.

 Mark Ravenhill's play Feed Me, which he also directs, will be broadcast at 9.45pm tonight as part of Radio 3's new-writing series The Wire.

fields.headline: The wrong type of rain
fields.standfirst: Radio 5 Live |  Tim's Comedy Links | Listen to Your Parents
fields.trailText: A week in radio
fields.body:
Let's be honest: a certain envy always creeps in when you fly into Heathrow. You can hear the people in window seats cooing "Ooh, what a lovely lot of swimming pools!" as they look out over the sumptuous end of suburbia. But coo no more. As reported on Thursday's breakfast show on Radio 5 Live, poolside life in west London is no longer a picnic.

It's a matter of matter - falling matter from planes, to be precise. Chunks of ice, a frozen body (a stowaway who had died a horrible death - but hey, what's that compared with having him land in your postcode?), even chunks of "frozen doo-dah". "It's not very nice," one resident said, "to have doo-dah landing on you as you walk to work." You could feel the 5 Live team clinging to their desks, thinking of famine and drowned kittens to stem the tide of chuckles.

Tim Brooke-Taylor is a man used to people always laughing at what he says, and that's without resorting to doo-dah gags. This is presumably why Radio 4 went for his new series, Tim's Comedy Links , exploring the connections between golf and comedy. What I liked best was the show's barefaced cheek. The format is not, as you might expect, lots of golfy gags or even Tim Brooke-Taylor telling indulgent anecdotes about the game. No, Tim gets to play on some of his favourite courses with comedians you might have (deliberately) forgotten about, in between some very fine clips from other comedians, not many of which have anything to do with golf.

So Tim mentions that he's a nervous golfer, and we get Robin Williams on stage fright. We get Stanley Unwin on ergonomics, saying things like "centimold" for centimetre, just because it makes Tim titter. When the comedy does turn to golf, we have some marvellous P G Wodehouse and some rather less marvellous on-course chat. "Great shot, Jasper," they call to one Mr Carrott. "Tim Brooke-Taylor, he's the last person that should be doing golf and comedy," chortles Kenny Lynch.

And then there are the anecdotes, there to remind us that men who play golf are to be treated like men whose eyebrows meet - from a distance and with suspicion. One chap said he'd like to come back in another life as a lesbian: "Then I'll be able to play off the ladies' tees and still get to sleep with women." I hope he comes back as a ball.

Sport was also one of the threads of Benjamin Zephaniah's play Listen to Your Parents (Radio 4), a moving and lyrical tale of a 10-year-old Birmingham boy, Mark, blessed with a gift for football and poetry ("like Eric Cantona", he says to himself), both of which help him cope with his father's brutal treatment of his mother. Though not totally autobiographical, Zephaniah's tale drew on his own childhood experience of a violent household, and it was here that the play was most chillingly authentic.

His parents' raised voices always a fuzzy backdrop of sound, Mark snuggles under his duvet, hides in the wardrobe, retreats into writing love poems for a girl in his class. His Brummie accent, all lilting, quizzical intonation, was just right for a child unable to make sense of the domestic world around him. "The damp loves this house," he says. Its garden "has outgrown and disowned it". Just behind his voice, the sound of slapping, punching, police sirens wailing.

webTitle: Biographer Adam Simpson discovers his family history

fields.headline: Hard times so near at hand
fields.standfirst: When biographer  Adam Sisman began to use professional methods on his own family history, he uncovered a shocking story of poverty and neglect
fields.trailText: When biographer Adam Sisman began to use professional methods on his own family history, he uncovered a shocking story of poverty and neglect
fields.body:
Writing biographies teaches scepticism. When writing my first book, a biography of the historian AJP Taylor, I was startled to find how many people I interviewed told me stories I knew not to be true, or testified to events from the point of view of a witness on occasions when I knew they could not have been present. Even professional historians were guilty - not of lying but simply as victims of that strange human tendency to believe they had been present at a scene only imagined from a description. The mind rearranges events into what seems a rational progression, making order out of chaos. The historian Sir Lewis Namier wrote that we imagine the past and remember the future.

In researching my book on Taylor, I sensed that much of what I was told was biased or partial. Whenever I came across an interpretation of events or behaviour I tried, wherever possible, to test it against the ascertainable facts. Then I began to apply this method to my own life. I saw that many of the conclusions I had reached rested on shaky foundations.

So much of every family's past is obscure, wilfully or otherwise. To understand what it means to be another person, to make sense of the past, a biographer needs to imagine what it must have been like for his subject, to hypothesise about motives and causes, and then to test these hypotheses against what is known. Like a scientist, like a detective, the biographer proceeds from what is known to explore what is not.

I had a privileged childhood: private education, a large, uncomfortable house in west London, no shortage of toys or holidays, let alone food or warmth, which - as my parents never ceased to remind my sister and myself - many children in poorer parts of the world lacked. As a result, I grew up feeling vaguely guilty about my circumstances. I railed against my parents for sending me to such a good school, and discounted my academic successes on the grounds that with such advantages, to fail was hardly possible. As soon as I was old enough to choose, I decided to deviate from the ordained route by refusing to sit Oxbridge entrance.

In my teens, in the late 1960s and early 70s, I thought myself part of a revolt against middle-class values. I taunted my father with being a bourgeois - as if I had ever been, or ever would be, anything else. He never reproached me. I think of him now with love and slight shame. I try to imagine what his life must have been like: boarding school, sent to sea at 16, the terrifying war years when he served in submarines and on convoy duty, arriving back at Waterloo station with only the clothes he stood up in after his ship was sunk, and later, as a penniless art student, and then a young husband, striving to provide for his wife and babies.

I never knew my grandfathers. There is a picture of my father's father holding me. I later discovered that he was a bigamist and a bankrupt. He died soon after I was born, leaving my father nothing but a disgruntled widow to care for. My mother's father was a more shadowy figure. Nobody seemed to want to talk about him. I assumed he had originated from the same petit-bourgeois background as my mother. I discovered only recently that he too had lived to see me born, dying while I was a baby. I knew only that he had been a surveyor and an engineer, manager of a small factory in Ceylon. I never realised that he had a life in England, that he had been born here and died here. I didn't even know his name.

My mother explained that he had been virtually a stranger to her too; my grandmother had not liked life in Ceylon and had returned to England after a few months with her elder daughter, leaving her husband behind. She was pregnant with my mother, who was born in England several months later, so my grandfather saw his younger daughter for the first time when he came home to Lincoln on leave, when she was already two and a half. He came back to England four years later, and then again after another five years, when my grandmother was dying.

My mother remembers being embarrassed by this stranger who tried to embrace her, and fleeing the room. After my grandmother died in 1937, my mother and her sister were brought up by an aunt, my grandmother's sister. My mother did not see her father again until after the war, when she was a young woman. He was by now married to his second wife, a missionary teacher he had met in Ceylon. Together they retired to the Isle of Wight.

This was all I knew of him until a few months ago, when a package arrived containing copies of letters and photographs unearthed by a distant cousin in Australia. There was a photograph of three urchin boys in flat caps standing behind a stone wall: one of them, my grandfather, caught in the act of throwing a snowball (or perhaps shamming).

Most remarkable was a letter, dated November 28 1896, written from an address in Liverpool in a looping hand by my grandfather's elder sister, Lennie May, then 16. As I read her letter, I realised with a jolt its importance to me. "Dear Uncle John," it read (I had no idea then who Uncle John might be): "I am writing to tell you how affairs stand. Father is not working. We are all bare-footed again for he has pawned our boots, in fact, he has sold everything saleable, we have not even a decent bed to sleep on, and I cannot bear to see the children suffer so, for Mother's sake... the poor children are in a state of semi-starvation... they never have anything in the way of nourishment... your affectionate niece, Lennie." There was a postscript: "Please do not mention me having written to you...

On the back of this letter, in a different hand, were the words: "Should the child be favoured with a reply, let it kindly be addressed to her at 17 Dawsons Grove, Liverpool and the writer will hand it to her. She fears getting into trouble with her father if he knew she wrote."

The letter only hints at the terrible suffering Lennie and her younger brothers and sisters had endured. Six months earlier, their mother had died as the result of a miscarriage, having borne 11 children in 18 years. Three had succumbed to bronchial pneumonia in the space of a few months. It seems that as the eldest daughter, Lennie May was left struggling to look after the other five children. My grandfather, Frederick, was one of these, then aged 11. Lennie's father never gave her money to buy food and often came home very late. He had lost his job, and it seems clear that he was drinking heavily. They were living in a slum in one of the coldest parts of the city, where diphtheria, whooping cough, and bronchial pneumonia were rampant and typhoid not uncommon; the children could not survive much longer unless something changed.

In desperation, Lennie May wrote to her mother's brother, "Uncle John", a prosperous grocer in Broadheath, Cheshire, on the outskirts of what is now Greater Manchester. It seems likely that she was helped by a kindly neighbour, who wrote the note on the back of the letter to protect Lennie from her father's wrath.

This plea for help prompted John to travel to Liverpool to rescue the children. Lennie May and her charges were scooped up and taken to live with their uncle and his family; their uncles, John and his brother Samuel, took steps to become the children's legal guardians. My grandfather was sent to boarding school in Lincolnshire and afterwards apprenticed to Ruston's, an engineering firm in Lincoln. His later life gave no hint of how hard his early life had been, though he always retained a special affection for his older sister who, perhaps unknown to him, had saved the children from almost certain death in that Liverpool slum.

Also in the package were documents which explained much of the background to Lennie May's letter. Her mother, my great-grandmother Sarah Ann Hulme, came from a respectable Lancashire farming family. There is a photograph of her which hints at a certain docile gullibility; and of my great-grandfather, Owen Peake, a handsome man, younger than Sarah Ann, with a reputation as an irresponsible wastrel.

Perhaps he married her for money. Their marriage was very much against the wishes of my great-grandmother's family; in will after will, they specified that money was to be left in trust for Sarah Ann and the children, where Owen could not lay his hands upon it. Owen seems to have worked for his father at first, describing himself as a metal finisher and polisher, and later a journeyman hot water engineer.

He and his new wife lived first near his family in Altrincham, and then moved for a while to London, where Lennie May was born in the shadow of Waterloo station. Afterwards they moved back to Altrincham, where my grandfather was born, before moving once again to Liverpool.

In 1895 the crisis came. Three children died in quick succession, followed by their mother. My great-grandfather had no further contact with his children after they had been rescued by their uncle. It was assumed that he died soon afterwards. On his marriage certificate, my grandfather registered his father as "deceased".

In fact Owen lived for another 35 years, dying in London, one of the last residents of a workhouse before they were abolished in the 30s. A "notification of death" form appealed for relatives to make themselves known. In their absence, it advised that burial would be carried out by the London City Council, with provision being made for two official mourners to attend the funeral. No one came forward to collect the body, and my great-grandfather was buried in a pauper's grave. My Australian cousin headed her account of these events "A Story Reluctantly Written Which Had to Be Told". My mother and her sister were reluctant to read what had been so reluctantly written. For them, their father's past is best forgotten.

I too found this discovery strangely disturbing, but in a different way. Far from being ashamed of my grandfather's humble origins, I felt defiant, almost proud of them. This discovery had moved me deeply, but more than that: it had subtly altered the way I thought about myself. My comfortable assumptions were blown apart; I realised how precarious my existence had been. There is a sense in which each of us is endlessly writing and rewriting our autobiography. We are constantly trying to explain who we are and what we have done. We cling to facts that seem to indicate the direction we have followed. But very occasionally, we stumble across some awkward piece of evidence that forces us to reshape our interpretation of the past. This is what happened to me when I opened that package.

A few months after it arrived, I journeyed up to Liverpool, a city I had never visited before. I spent a morning in the central library trying to find the address where my grandfather and his siblings had lived. The whole neighbourhood had been bulldozed in the slum clearances of the early 1960s. Dawson Grove no longer existed; all the surrounding streets had been levelled to make a park, with views over the Mersey estuary.

I sat down on a bench and tried to imagine Lennie May a century earlier, battling to care for her young brothers and sisters. I marvelled at the courage and the strength of that 13-year-old girl, who defied her brutal father to save the little ones. And I reflected, not for the first time, that she had enabled me to live.

 Adam Sisman's book, Boswell's Presumptuous Task, has just been published by Hamish Hamilton, priced £17.99.

fields.headline: Walk all over me
fields.standfirst: Susana Baca, the Peruvian barefoot diva, works her soothing magic on  Robin Denselow
fields.trailText: Susana Baca, the Peruvian barefoot diva, works her soothing magic on Robin Denselow
fields.body:
The Latin music boom rolls on and becomes ever more varied. In South and Central America, as in Africa, there is a vast array of different styles, and audiences that may have started off listening to the dance music of Cuba or Brazil are moving on check out the slinky rhythmic ballads of the west coast.

Susana Baca, now firmly established as the best-selling exponent of Afro-Peruvian styles, is the Latin answer to Cesaria Evora. Both can now pack Western concert halls while popularising apparently obscure local styles that mix African and Portuguese or Spanish influences, and both have been hailed as "barefoot divas". Apart from that, they are a world apart - Evora is from the Cape Verde Islands, off the West African coast, while Baca was brought up in a coastal barrio outside Lima.

She may have started out as something of a musical scholar, travelling across Peru and learning the songs and music of those descended from the old slave communities, but there is nothing academic about her performance. She comes on in cropped hair, long velvet dress, shawl and (of course) no shoes, looking and sounding as if her natural home is a concert hall. She starts off with exquisite, slinky ballads that soothe or seduce, and eases gradually towards laid-back dance songs in which she glides across the stage almost in slow motion. The songs are a mixture of old and new from Peru, ranging from ballads with European- sounding melodies to upbeat songs with Irish jig-like bass riffs.

But the African influences are there too, both in those pieces where her four-piece band echo the song lines back to her, and in their intriguing, subtle use of rhythm. In a gentle band like this, it at first seems odd that two of the four musicians are percussionists, with one drumming away throughout on the wooden box on which he is perched, and the other hitting anything from congas to a clay pot, a twanging gourd-like instrument, or a hinged wooden device, worn round the neck and repeatedly thumped and banged shut.

On her new album Eco De Sombras, recorded for David Byrne's Luaka Bop label, Susana Baca is joined by such adventurous Western musicians as Mark Ribot and Greg Cohen (both known for their work with Tom Waits) but they were not needed here. She has worked with the same backing musicians for six years now, and they understand her perfectly. Sensitive, inventive accompaniment from acoustic guitar and double bass matched the colourful percussion and provided an intricate setting for her cool ballads or the more up-beat songs like Valentin.

She may have started off with a series of minor key laments, but when goaded by her highly enthusiastic band she eased into her own stately form of party music, sounding even more impressive live than on her albums. Peru can claim a world-class world music diva.

webTitle: Tim Ashley reviews  The Rise and Fall of the City of Mahagonny

fields.headline: City of the damned
fields.standfirst: A car crash, sopranos in undies, mutual masturbation -  Tim Ashley  is astonished by a new version of Brecht and Weill's Mahagonny
fields.trailText: A car crash, sopranos in undies, mutual masturbation - Tim Ashley is astonished by a new version of Brecht and Weill's Mahagonny.
fields.body:
In sexy, affluent Hamburg, the Staatsoper is staging a formidable show about a sexy, affluent city bent on its own destruction. Like the original work itself, this version of The Rise and Fall of the City of Mahagonny is the product of an intense collaboration.

Bertolt Brecht and Kurt Weill wrote the piece in 1930 as an attempt to make Weimar Germany see sense before its collapse began. The Hamburg version, the work of a controversial partnership between the conductor Ingo Metzmacher and the director Peter Konwitschny, reminds us that the essential inhumanity of capitalist self-interest remains an omnipresent danger, particularly now that the altruism of the socialist ideal has been rejected.

Brecht and Weill located their nightmarish paradise in America, opening the work as a gang of no-goods emerge from a broken-down car in the middle of nowhere to found their city with ill-gotten lucre. Konwitschny and Metzmacher bring it closer to home.

We begin with an almighty bang as a vehicle seemingly crashes into the back of the Staatsoper itself. The auditorium doors open to admit Mechthild Gessendorf's alarming Leokadja Begbick, who looks as if she has just screwed every Reeperbahn prowler in sight. A splay-legged madame in red silk and ocelot, she presides over the proceedings with the daring, monumental obscenity that is characteristic of the production.

As Mahagonny is built, the conventional divisions between stage, pit and public buckle and bend. The city's victims scramble through the audience to the stage. Maps of Mahagonny rain down from the ceiling, informing us that it lies some 21,516km west of Hamburg, though the plan of streets and docks leaves no doubt as to where we actually are.

When the city is at its apogee, the orchestra is transported from pit to stage. Metzmacher dons a silver bandleader's jacket, and marches his musicians in triumphal procession round the set. Most productions play the goings-on of Mahagonny's denizens for laughs. Konwitschny, however, just flings everything in our faces with unremitting force.

The glutton Jakob Schmidt decides to eat himself to death and expires in a pool of excretions. When Begbick ups the price of the local girls, the men retaliate with a frenzy of mutual masturbation in the city's public loos. Mahagonny's God is the terminally sick deity of Nietzsche, whose rejection by a whisky-sodden humanity brings about his demise.

It's a place where honesty can't survive. Albert Bonnema's touching Paul Ackermann goes to his pauper's death with a look of unspeakable horror on his face. Jenny, the good time girl who loves him yet betrays him, is Inga Nielsen, one of the few sopranos to look convincing in skimpy undies. Far from the brazen harshness that we usually get, Jenny too is a victim. Musically, the production is staggering, presenting us with a gallery of alarmingly convincing portraits of human viciousness. Metzmacher splits the score open to reveal both its erotic beauty and its terrifying malignancy.

Inevitably, given the production's riskiness, there are occasional flaws. Balance is lost when the performers are in the auditorium. The shifting of the orchestra from pit to stage has to happen in the interval, which means that the first act finale plays itself out in a not very convincing bathhouse or orgy-room. The faults are minor, however.

As the final roll call of capitalism's inhumanity began, I sat there with a lump in my throat, overwhelmed with anger. This is Weill's centenary year and there has never been a more convincing vindication of his work. In London, which is closer to the nightmare of Mahagonny than Hamburg, we haven't produced a Weill tribute to equal it - and I doubt that prudish Britain ever could.

fields.bodyText: In sexy, affluent Hamburg, the Staatsoper is staging a formidable show about a sexy, affluent city bent on its own destruction. Like the original work itself, this version of The Rise and Fall of the City of Mahagonny is the product of an intense collaboration. Bertolt Brecht and Kurt Weill wrote the piece in 1930 as an attempt to make Weimar Germany see sense before its collapse began. The Hamburg version, the work of a controversial partnership between the conductor Ingo Metzmacher and the director Peter Konwitschny, reminds us that the essential inhumanity of capitalist self-interest remains an omnipresent danger, particularly now that the altruism of the socialist ideal has been rejected. Brecht and Weill located their nightmarish paradise in America, opening the work as a gang of no-goods emerge from a broken-down car in the middle of nowhere to found their city with ill-gotten lucre. Konwitschny and Metzmacher bring it closer to home. We begin with an almighty bang as a vehicle seemingly crashes into the back of the Staatsoper itself. The auditorium doors open to admit Mechthild Gessendorf's alarming Leokadja Begbick, who looks as if she has just screwed every Reeperbahn prowler in sight. A splay-legged madame in red silk and ocelot, she presides over the proceedings with the daring, monumental obscenity that is characteristic of the production. As Mahagonny is built, the conventional divisions between stage, pit and public buckle and bend. The city's victims scramble through the audience to the stage. Maps of Mahagonny rain down from the ceiling, informing us that it lies some 21,516km west of Hamburg, though the plan of streets and docks leaves no doubt as to where we actually are. When the city is at its apogee, the orchestra is transported from pit to stage. Metzmacher dons a silver bandleader's jacket, and marches his musicians in triumphal procession round the set. Most productions play the goings-on of Mahagonny's denizens for laughs. Konwitschny, however, just flings everything in our faces with unremitting force. The glutton Jakob Schmidt decides to eat himself to death and expires in a pool of excretions. When Begbick ups the price of the local girls, the men retaliate with a frenzy of mutual masturbation in the city's public loos. Mahagonny's God is the terminally sick deity of Nietzsche, whose rejection by a whisky-sodden humanity brings about his demise. It's a place where honesty can't survive. Albert Bonnema's touching Paul Ackermann goes to his pauper's death with a look of unspeakable horror on his face. Jenny, the good time girl who loves him yet betrays him, is Inga Nielsen, one of the few sopranos to look convincing in skimpy undies. Far from the brazen harshness that we usually get, Jenny too is a victim. Musically, the production is staggering, presenting us with a gallery of alarmingly convincing portraits of human viciousness. Metzmacher splits the score open to reveal both its erotic beauty and its terrifying malignancy. Inevitably, given the production's riskiness, there are occasional flaws. Balance is lost when the performers are in the auditorium. The shifting of the orchestra from pit to stage has to happen in the interval, which means that the first act finale plays itself out in a not very convincing bathhouse or orgy-room. webTitle: Why reality is the lifeblood of theatre

fields.headline: Why reality is the lifeblood of theatre
fields.standfirst: Modern drama may at last be starting to contemplate the world instead of its own navel, says  David Hare
fields.trailText: Modern drama may at last be starting to contemplate the world instead of its own navel, says David Hare.
fields.body:
In a splendidly silly announcement last year, the jury of the Evening Standard drama awards committee ruled that no play presented in the British theatre had met their exacting standards to be adjudged the best of the year. The newspaper rightly came in for a certain amount of black-hearted mockery. Having sat on a few awards committees myself, I know that risible errors of judgment are endemic to the process. No award would be complete without them. But this self-advertising decision seemed particularly insulting in view of the fact that 1999 had offered one of the most memorable evenings most of us had ever spent in a theatre.

Anyone who watched the Tricycle Theatre's compelling adaptation of the Stephen Lawrence inquiry, The Colour of Justice, could sense that the play was important not just for the obvious reason that it anatomised a great public scandal whose complexity could only properly be grasped in the course of a two-hour dramatisation. Guardian journalist Richard Norton-Taylor had also written a play which seemed, in both its ambition and its maturity, to offer a rebuke to more recent trends in its own chosen medium.

Despite the heroic success of Gary Mitchell in telling us about the RUC, or of Neil LaBute in helping us understand the Mormons, it seems that many London plays are working on a narrower and narrower psychological focus. There are times when metropolitan theatre seems to be running off into the distance in a chicken-headed flight from content.

The reluctance of the performing arts to engage with the world around us leaves any objective observer saddened and bewildered. Apart from anything else, so many playwrights are denying themselves the simple pleasure of discovering that the external universe may be richer and more suggestive than the inside of their own heads. When, three years ago, I was first asked by Elyse Dodgson to go to the Middle East, I came back tentatively proposing a monologue which Stephen Daldry aimed to present for six performances only in the Theatre Upstairs.

As the result has passed through all its subsequent mutations - West End, Broadway, Sundance, Guardian supplement, and now film on television - Stephen and I have always known that the turtle-like durability of Via Dolorosa owed little to its author, and still less to its wayward star. At every stage of our progress it became clearer that the play's reach and response was down to the axiom that no evening in the theatre is ever wasted which aims as much to enlighten as it does to entertain.

You would think it was obvious. Audiences flock to Copenhagen because they judge, rightly, that Michael Frayn has something interesting to tell them about nuclear physics. A play by David Edgar about Albert Speer at the National Theatre does not even need to get good notices to attract full houses, because people know that Gita Sereny has devoted her life to understanding the lethal glamour of Nazism.

Yet faced with evidence of the public's hunger for knowledge, producers remain superstitiously convinced that it is commercially dangerous to set your sights too high. Supposedly hard-headed managers ignore people's evident satisfaction in leaving a theatre knowing more than when they came in, and instead prefer to offer the same classic plays, endlessly reiterated, plus embarrassing fluff that dies on exposure to the light.

The delight of Via Dolorosa's appearance on British television, even in the week of Leah Rabin's tragic death, is that it will go out on a channel which habitually addresses subjects that once belonged in an authentic theatre culture. For someone who wants to stop and think before they opine, there's a sense of coming home.

The most radical epic drama of the last few years wasn't even a play. It was a documentary series on BBC2. The Mayfair Set explained how local economies were opened up to the cruelties of the free market at the behest of a group of seedy gamblers from the Clermont Club.

Watching men like James Goldsmith, Jonathan Aitken and Tiny Rowland exhibiting the Savile Row brand of egotism that marks out the truly ruthless, you felt a gamy depth of characterisation which would not have disgraced the Elizabethan theatre. Listening to the programme's formidable alternative analysis of how and why the British government abdicated responsibility for the economy, you experienced the rush of understanding, exhilaration and anger you more usually expect to feel in a playhouse.

Let's hope things change. It may be fun for everyone in the theatre world to pass their time ripping merry hell out of Trevor Nunn and Adrian Noble, but is it germane? Is the practical upshot that we shall all mount more new plays that are actually about something? Or shall we continue our nightly festival of style aerobics and Mamet mimicry?

 Via Dolorosa is on BBC2 tomorrow at 10pm.

fields.headline: Flowers of despair
fields.standfirst: Essayist William Hazlitt was driven to the brink of madness by his unrequited love for a younger woman. But as AC Grayling argues in his new book, it spurred him on to his most brilliant work
fields.trailText: Essayist William Hazlitt was driven to the brink of madness by his unrequited love for a younger woman. But as AC Grayling argues in his new book, it spurred him on to his most brilliant work.
fields.body:
William Hazlitt was England's supreme essayist, and one of the greatest writers of prose in the English language. He was also the best and most important critic of the Romantic period, making original contributions to appreciation of art, theatre, literature and philosophy. And as if that were not enough, he was also a hard-hitting political polemicist who, at the expense of his own chances for worldly advancement, defended a radical stance which was not just unpopular but actively persecuted in the Regency period of the early 19th century - as shown by the fact that some of his friends found themselves in prison for views that he and they shared.

Hazlitt is sometimes labelled a "Romantic" like Coleridge and Wordsworth, who were first his friends and later his enemies. If the label has any value, it is because he was an intensely personal writer, vividly present in everything he wrote. He argued for his opinions without appealing to the authority, or needing the protection, of orthodox ideas or established ideologies.

A good example is afforded by his innovative style of criticism. The critics who came before him attacked Shakespeare for failing to observe the theatrical "unities" of time and place, as prescribed two thousand years before by Aristotle. Hazlitt was not interested in rules and formalities; he reacted to theatre - and to art, literature and ideas - as a man of deep feeling and independent mind, asking only whether he was being presented with truth, and in a manner that was well done of its kind. He demanded honesty in art, not orthodoxy; and he listened to his own responses, which were keen and searching, for the basis of his judgments.

As a result he changed the way people thought and wrote about the arts, and indirectly helped to liberate them from the rule of the past. Hazlitt wrote incessantly, not just because he made his living that way, but because he was impelled to write; it was his way of thinking, and of making sense of things. He thereby transmuted his life and thought into literature, leaving a body of work - 20 volumes' worth, in the standard edition - which continues to delight and instruct. Many of his essays are classics of the English tongue.

He has always had admirers, and his reputation, great and controversial in his own day, has never ceased to grow, though for a time it was clouded by Victorian delicacy, which was offended by his confessional style and most of all by his Liber Amoris, the searingly painful account of his notorious middle-aged passion for the young daughter of his landlady. Hazlitt attracted sharply different responses from his contemporaries. One view is well represented by John Keats and his friend John Hamilton Reynolds, who ardently admired him. They attended his lectures, read aloud to each other from his essays, and formulated their theories of poetry in response to his views. Through their eyes Hazlitt appears at his best, because when he was with such ambitious young men of talent, he was relaxed and expansive, ready to talk endlessly about art and philosophy - not in monologue, as Coleridge did, but as a conversationalist in the same mould as his friend Charles Lamb.

In a letter of April 1817, Reynolds describes entertaining Hazlitt to dinner: "On Thursday last Hazlitt was with me at home, and remained with us till three o'clock in the morning! - full of eloquence, - warm, lofty, and communicative on everything imaginative and intelligent - He is indeed great company, and leaves a weight on the mind, which 'it can hardly bear'. He is full of what Dr Johnson terms 'good talk'. His countenance also is extremely fine: - a sunken and melancholy face, - a forehead lined with thought and bearing a full and strange pulsation on exciting subjects, - an eye, dashed in its light with sorrow, but kindling and living at intellectual moments, - and a stream of coal-black hair dropping around all. Such a face, so silent and so sensitive, is indeed the banner of the mind. I fear you will be tired of this long 'personality', but I remember having read a few papers of his to you, and therefore imagine you are not wholly uninterested in him."

Reynolds' portrait has an air of hyperbole, but it chimes exactly with accounts given by others who enjoyed Hazlitt's friendship. A very different picture is given by Thomas De Quincey, never a friend to Hazlitt, still less so after the detection of his unacknowledged borrowings from Hazlitt's writings (for which he was uncomfortably obliged to apologise).

"His inveterate misanthropy was constitutional," De Quincey wrote. "Exasperated it certainly had been by accidents of life, by disappointments, by mortifications, by insults, and still more by having wilfully placed himself in collision from the first with all the interests that were in the sunshine of the world, and of all the persons that were then powerful in England... A friend of his it was who told me that involuntarily, when Hazlitt put his hand within his waistcoat (as a mere unconscious trick of habit), he himself felt a sudden recoil of fear, as from one who was searching for a hidden dagger."

These two portraits - drawn from a number of either kind - could scarcely be more at variance. For two generations after Hazlitt's death it was De Quincey's portrait which prevailed, for although some thought him the greatest thinker and critical writer of his age, others saw him as a gloomy pessimistic Jacobin motivated by party spleen and personal antipathies. Leaving aside the melodramatic reference to a dagger, chosen to allegorise Hazlitt's fearsome powers as a polemicist, there is some truth in De Quincey's picture, for Hazlitt was indeed at loggerheads with the vested interests of his time, he indeed never courted favour with those "in the sunshine of the world" because he suspected that most of them had got there by dishonest or despicable means, and he indeed suffered much from disappointments in his personal life and insults in his public life.

The disappointments and insults were connected, for this was an age of violent polemic and party strife, in which Hazlitt was the subject of constant attacks by the Tory press, of a kind we could not now tolerate. They called him depraved, blasphemous, malign, a fiend who endangered traditions and proprieties, a blackguard, a quack, a "pimpled coxcomb".

In its most vicious style one of the chief Tory magazines, Blackwood's, was capable of ranting, "Let execrations gurgle in your gullet, distended with the rising gorge of your blackest bile; belch out your bitter blackguardism lest you burst; clench your fists till your fretted palms are pierced with the jagged edge of nails bitten in impotent desperation, stamp with cloven feet on the fetid flags of your sty till the mire mounts to your mouth" - and so on.

More sober journals, recognising Hazlitt's genius, applauded "the spirit and energy of this extraordinary writer, whose work abounds with striking beauties, and with the enlightened spirit of truth and critical discrimination", but they did not wholly cancel the harm done. Hazlitt returned the Tory attacks with interest, but his enemies made ammunition out of his private sufferings, thereby doubling them.

A man who could inspire such different responses, and who could think and write as Hazlitt did - "We think we are very fine fellows nowadays," Robert Louis Stevenson told his contemporaries, "but none of us can write like Hazlitt" - deserves explanation. The explanation is his life, from which all that he felt and thought sprang; so to explain him is to tell his story - and not least one of the most famous (or perhaps infamous) episodes in it, his unrequited love for a woman less than half his age. His account of the affair, the Liber Amoris, is so frank and painful that it destroyed his reputation among his contemporaries and the Victorians who came immediately afterwards.

Hazlitt's disastrous passion began in the summer of 1820. He was 42, and at the height of his fame and powers. He had been separated from his first wife for three years, and was living a bachelor's life in lodgings. The young woman, Sarah Walker, was the 19-year-old daughter of a boarding-house landlady.

The unhappy tale began when, on August 16 - Hazlitt's third day in his new lodgings at Southampton Buildings near Chancery Lane in London - he saw Sarah Walker for the first time. She brought breakfast to his rooms, and he was immediately struck by her manner. He watched as she went away, mesmerised by her walk, for she had a waving, gliding step which he found graceful beyond description. At the door she turned and looked him full in the eye, her strange, dark gaze burning him to the depths of his soul. He was stunned, amazed - and in love in an instant.

It might seem that, for one who suffered frequently from infatuations (his friend Patmore said "he was always in love with somebody or other") and who therefore understood their nature, Hazlitt should have been well armed against his vulnerability to them. But his own views explain why he allowed himself to become besotted in this case. Love and desire, he said, are blessings when mutual (which he thought they rarely were, except in novels), but like the Furies when unrequited. Either way one cannot escape them. They are non-rational, and the will cannot oppose them. They take hold and run their course, and their victim can do nothing but survive as best he - usually, in Hazlitt's view, he - can. Hazlitt accordingly never attempted to resist. He gave in to his feelings at their first impulse, and invariably suffered the consequences. In the case of Sarah Walker, "suffered" is a wholly inadequate word. His obsession with her almost drove him mad.

Hazlitt also therefore believed in love at first sight. More accurately, he believed that what goes by that name is only a recognition of an antecedently cherished ideal; that in a sense it is not "first sight" at all. "I do not think that what is called Love at first sight is so great an absurdity as it is sometimes imagined to be," he wrote soon after meeting Sarah Walker. "We generally make up our minds beforehand to the sort of person we should like, grave or gay, black, brown or fair; with golden tresses or with raven locks; - and when we meet with a complete example of the qualities we admire, the bargain is soon struck. We have never seen any thing to come up to our newly discovered goddess before, but she is what we have been all our lives looking for. The idol we fall down and worship is an image familiar to our minds. It has been present to our waking thoughts, it has haunted us in our dreams."

A few years before, in a review of a book on European literature, Hazlitt had pointedly disagreed with its author's regret that Petrarch and his Laura had not been able to enjoy a longer intimacy. "The whole is in better keeping as it is," Hazlitt wrote. "The love of a man like Petrarch would have been less in character, if it had been less ideal. For the purposes of inspiration, a single interview was quite sufficient. The smile which sank into his heart the first time he ever beheld her, played round her lips ever after, the look with which her eyes first met his, never passed away. The image of his mistress still haunted his mind, and was recalled by every object in nature. Even death could not dissolve the fine illusion: for that which exists in the imagination is alone imperishable." These words struck home to a reader in Paris who felt that they described his own experience exactly. The reader was Stendhal, who, in making a note of this passage, was not for the first time copying out Hazlitt's words. The two met in Paris some years later, and became friends.

Those words - "The smile which sank into his heart the first time he ever beheld her" - could scarcely have been more prophetic, given the beginning and the manner of Hazlitt's passion for Sarah Walker. But she did not impress everyone. Hazlitt's friend Procter described her thus: "Her face was round and small, and her eyes were motionless, glassy, and without any speculation (apparently) in them. Her movements in walking were remarkable, for I never observed her to make a step. She went onwards in a wavy, sinuous manner, like the movement of a snake. She was silent, or uttered monosyllables only, and very demure. Her steady, unmoving gaze upon the person she was addressing was exceedingly unpleasant. The Germans would have extracted a romance from her, endowing her perhaps with some diabolic attribute."

Although this description was written after the event, in pity for Hazlitt and dislike of Sarah Walker - though it is not as unfriendly as the description offered by Hazlitt's first wife: "thin and bony as the scrag end of a neck of mutton" - it tallies exactly with Hazlitt's own descriptions, except that he gave them a different cast. Her walk, her sphinx-like eyes, her demure silence, and her round face and slender figure, all recur in Hazlitt's account as matters for celebration, and as the barbs that snagged his soul and would not let him go.

Hazlitt longed for the kind of romantic love found in novels. He was sceptical about whether it could exist, for such love would amount to something truly metaphysical: to a companionship of hearts and souls that would cure the inexpressible loneliness of being. Yet he hoped for it anyway, and sought it endlessly. By the time he fell in love with Sarah Walker his longing for the realisation of this dream had grown acute. He was ripe for love, and fell hopelessly into it at the first faint, imagined touch of its presence.

For 18 months after Sarah Walker's sinuous movements and meaningful looks captivated Hazlitt, she spent hours every day in his room, sitting on his knee, kissing and fondling him endlessly, and being fondled in return. He did not try to have sexual intercourse with her, because he idealised her and wanted to marry her, and therefore wished to believe her "pure". But their intimacy did not fall far short.

During the first year he was often blissfully happy. She was "the only woman that ever made me think she loved me, and that feeling was so new to me, and so delicious, that 'it will never from my heart' " (sic). She made him think that she loved him without ever telling him so directly - on the contrary, she refused to say that she loved him, nor would she promise him anything for the future. When he asked, "Do you love me? Could you love me?" she merely said, "You should judge by my actions" and "Do I seem indifferent?" Indeed, her actions made Hazlitt hope, and hope was enough at the outset. He showered her with gifts, some of them expensive: an ivory flageolet, a gold heart-shaped locket, a cap and gown, silk cloth, tickets for the theatre, copies of the books he had written, even his most treasured miniature statue of Napoleon.

But one day she told him something he had not known before. The reason she could never feel more than friendship towards him, she said, was that she still nurtured a tenderness for someone else, a former lodger in the house who, because of a "difference of station", had been obliged to leave to prevent their mutual feelings going further. This continuing attachment posed a barrier, she said, to her ever loving anyone else.

This was a severe blow. Instead of answering his questions evasively, she was now, Hazlitt reported, saying, "No, never." He was hurt and troubled by the news, but it did not kill his hope. He thought that his passion must surely one day make her love him in return, so exalted was it, and so profound. And then he found that he was charmed by her fidelity to one she had loved, and he honoured her for it. And still she sat in his lap daily, twining her arms round his neck, kissing him, enjoying his caresses.

But that was before an even more devastating blow precipitated a crisis in their relationship. A new lodger arrived, younger and more handsome, and Sarah Walker discovered for herself what it was like to fall in love. She rejected Hazlitt therefore, and his suffering over the next three years is almost indescribable. He did everything he could to win her back, not least divorcing his estranged wife so that he could be free to marry Sarah; but it only prolonged his agony. Mary Shelley, the daughter of his friend Godwin, having not seen him during those years because she was in Italy, described his appearance when the crisis was nearly over: "I never was so shocked in my life - gaunt and thin, his hair scattered, his cheekbones projecting - but for his voice and smile I should not have known him. His smile brought tears to my eyes, it was like a sunbeam illuminating the most melancholy of ruins."

And yet in the years during and after Hazlitt's great passion for Sarah Walker, he wrote his best works - essays of incomparable power and beauty, exploring the human condition, discussing art and letters, dissecting ideas, offering instruction and wit, insight, controversy, and pleasure - and, in the most famous of his books, The Spirit of the Age, choosing with unerring accuracy those among his contemporaries whose reputations he thought would last into history, and anatomising them in his penetrating and witty way. As with everything he wrote, his genius as a writer of prose takes one's breath away, and leaves a vivid impression of a man whose passionately lived life was turned by great art into literature, and made a lasting monument to the human spirit.

 AC Grayling's The Quarrel of the Age, a biography of Hazlitt, is published by Weidenfeld & Nicolson (£25).

They attended his lectures, read aloud to each other from his essays, and formulated their theories of poetry in response to his views. Through their eyes Hazlitt appears at his best, because when he was with such ambitious young men of talent, he was relaxed and expansive, ready to talk endlessly about art and philosophy - not in monologue, as Coleridge did, but as a conversationalist in the same mould as his friend Charles Lamb. In a letter of April 1817, Reynolds describes entertaining Hazlitt to dinner: "On Thursday last Hazlitt was with me at home, and remained with us till three o'clock in the morning! - full of eloquence, - warm, lofty, and communicative on everything imaginative and intelligent - He is indeed great company, and leaves a weight on the mind, which 'it can hardly bear'. He is full of what Dr Johnson terms 'good talk'. His countenance also is extremely fine: - a sunken and melancholy face, - a forehead lined with thought and bearing a full and strange pulsation on exciting subjects, - an eye, dashed in its light with sorrow, but kindling and living at intellectual moments, - and a stream of coal-black hair dropping around all. Such a face, so silent and so sensitive, is indeed the banner of the mind. I fear you will be tired of this long 'personality', but I remember having read a few papers of his to you, and therefore imagine you are not wholly uninterested in him." Reynolds' portrait has an air of hyperbole, but it chimes exactly with accounts given by others who enjoyed Hazlitt's friendship. A very different picture is given by Thomas De Quincey, never a friend to Hazlitt, still less so after the detection of his unacknowledged borrowings from Hazlitt's writings (for which he was uncomfortably obliged to apologise). "His inveterate misanthropy was constitutional," De Quincey wrote. "Exasperated it certainly had been by accidents of life, by disappointments, by mortifications, by insults, and still more by having wilfully placed himself in collision from the first with all the interests that were in the sunshine of the world, and of all the persons that were then powerful in England... A friend of his it was who told me that involuntarily, when Hazlitt put his hand within his waistcoat (as a mere unconscious trick of habit), he himself felt a sudden recoil of fear, as from one who was searching for a hidden dagger." These two portraits - drawn from a number of either kind - could scarcely be more at variance. For two generations after Hazlitt's death it was De Quincey's portrait which prevailed, for although some thought him the greatest thinker and critical writer of his age, others saw him as a gloomy pessimistic Jacobin motivated by party spleen and personal antipathies. Leaving aside the melodramatic reference to a dagger, chosen to allegorise Hazlitt's fearsome powers as a polemicist, there is some truth in De Quincey's picture, for Hazlitt was indeed at loggerheads with the vested interests of his time, he indeed never courted favour with those "in the sunshine of the world" because he suspected that most of them had got there by dishonest or despicable means, and he indeed suffered much from disappointments in his personal life and insults in his public life. The disappointments and insults were connected, for this was an age of violent polemic and party strife, in which Hazlitt was the subject of constant attacks by the Tory press, of a kind we could not now tolerate. They called him depraved, blasphemous, malign, a fiend who endangered traditions and proprieties, a blackguard, a quack, a "pimpled coxcomb". In its most vicious style one of the chief Tory magazines, Blackwood's, was capable of ranting, "Let execrations gurgle in your gullet, distended with the rising gorge of your blackest bile; belch out your bitter blackguardism lest you burst; clench your fists till your fretted palms are pierced with the jagged edge of nails bitten in impotent desperation, stamp with cloven feet on the fetid flags of your sty till the mire mounts to your mouth" - and so on. More sober journals, recognising Hazlitt's genius, applauded "the spirit and energy of this extraordinary writer, whose work abounds with striking beauties, and with the enlightened spirit of truth and critical discrimination", but they did not wholly cancel the harm done. Hazlitt returned the Tory attacks with interest, but his enemies made ammunition out of his private sufferings, thereby doubling them. A man who could inspire such different responses, and who could think and write as Hazlitt did - "We think we are very fine fellows nowadays," Robert Louis Stevenson told his contemporaries, "but none of us can write like Hazlitt" - deserves explanation. The explanation is his life, from which all that he felt and thought sprang; so to explain him is to tell his story - and not least one of the most famous (or perhaps infamous) episodes in it, his unrequited love for a woman less than half his age. His account of the affair, the Liber Amoris, is so frank and painful that it destroyed his reputation among his contemporaries and the Victorians who came immediately afterwards. Hazlitt's disastrous passion began in the summer of 1820. He was 42, and at the height of his fame and powers. He had been separated from his first wife for three years, and was living a bachelor's life in lodgings. The young woman, Sarah Walker, was the 19-year-old daughter of a boarding-house landlady. The unhappy tale began when, on August 16 - Hazlitt's third day in his new lodgings at Southampton Buildings near Chancery Lane in London - he saw Sarah Walker for the first time. She brought breakfast to his rooms, and he was immediately struck by her manner. He watched as she went away, mesmerised by her walk, for she had a waving, gliding step which he found graceful beyond description. At the door she turned and looked him full in the eye, her strange, dark gaze burning him to the depths of his soul. He was stunned, amazed - and in love in an instant. It might seem that, for one who suffered frequently from infatuations (his friend Patmore said "he was always in love with somebody or other") and who therefore understood their nature, Hazlitt should have been well armed against his vulnerability to them. But his own views explain why he allowed himself to become besotted in this case. Love and desire, he said, are blessings when mutual (which he thought they rarely were, except in novels), but like the Furies when unrequited. Either way one cannot escape them. They are non-rational, and the will cannot oppose them. They take hold and run their course, and their victim can do nothing but survive as best he - usually, in Hazlitt's view, he - can. Hazlitt accordingly never attempted to resist. He gave in to his feelings at their first impulse, and invariably suffered the consequences. In the case of Sarah Walker, "suffered" is a wholly inadequate word. His obsession with her almost drove him mad. Hazlitt also therefore believed in love at first sight. More accurately, he believed that what goes by that name is only a recognition of an antecedently cherished ideal; that in a sense it is not "first sight" at all. "I do not think that what is called Love at first sight is so great an absurdity as it is sometimes imagined to be," he wrote soon after meeting Sarah Walker. "We generally make up our minds beforehand to the sort of person we should like, grave or gay, black, brown or fair; with golden tresses or with raven locks; - and when we meet with a complete example of the qualities we admire, the bargain is soon struck. We have never seen any thing to come up to our newly discovered goddess before, but she is what we have been all our lives looking for. The idol we fall down and worship is an image familiar to our minds. It has been present to our waking thoughts, it has haunted us in our dreams." A few years before, in a review of a book on European literature, Hazlitt had pointedly disagreed with its author's regret that Petrarch and his Laura had not been able to enjoy a longer intimacy. "The whole is in better keeping as it is," Hazlitt wrote. "The love of a man like Petrarch would have been less in character, if it had been less ideal. For the purposes of inspiration, a single interview was quite sufficient. The smile which sank into his heart the first time he ever beheld her, played round her lips ever after, the look with which her eyes first met his, never passed away. The image of his mistress still haunted his mind, and was recalled by every object in nature. Even death could not dissolve the fine illusion: for that which exists in the imagination is alone imperishable." These words struck home to a reader in Paris who felt that they described his own experience exactly. The reader was Stendhal, who, in making a note of this passage, was not for the first time copying out Hazlitt's words. The two met in Paris some years later, and became friends. Those words - "The smile which sank into his heart the first time he ever beheld her" - could scarcely have been more prophetic, given the beginning and the manner of Hazlitt's passion for Sarah Walker. But she did not impress everyone. Hazlitt's friend Procter described her thus: "Her face was round and small, and her eyes were motionless, glassy, and without any speculation (apparently) in them. Her movements in walking were remarkable, for I never observed her to make a step. She went onwards in a wavy, sinuous manner, like the movement of a snake. She was silent, or uttered monosyllables only, and very demure. Her steady, unmoving gaze upon the person she was addressing was exceedingly unpleasant. The Germans would have extracted a romance from her, endowing her perhaps with some diabolic attribute." Although this description was written after the event, in pity for Hazlitt and dislike of Sarah Walker - though it is not as unfriendly as the description offered by Hazlitt's first wife: "thin and bony as the scrag end of a neck of mutton" - it tallies exactly with Hazlitt's own descriptions, except that he gave them a different cast. Her walk, her sphinx-like eyes, her demure silence, and her round face and slender figure, all recur in Hazlitt's account as matters for celebration, and as the barbs that snagged his soul and would not let him go. Hazlitt longed for the kind of romantic love found in novels. He was sceptical about whether it could exist, for such love would amount to something truly metaphysical: to a companionship of hearts and souls that would cure the inexpressible loneliness of being. Yet he hoped for it anyway, and sought it endlessly. By the time he fell in love with Sarah Walker his longing for the realisation of this dream had grown acute. He was ripe for love, and fell hopelessly into it at the first faint, imagined touch of its presence. For 18 months after Sarah Walker's sinuous movements and meaningful looks captivated Hazlitt, she spent hours every day in his room, sitting on his knee, kissing and fondling him endlessly, and being fondled in return. He did not try to have sexual intercourse with her, because he idealised her and wanted to marry her, and therefore wished to believe her "pure". But their intimacy did not fall far short. During the first year he was often blissfully happy. She was "the only woman that ever made me think she loved me, and that feeling was so new to me, and so delicious, that 'it will never from my heart' " (sic). She made him think that she loved him without ever telling him so directly - on the contrary, she refused to say that she loved him, nor would she promise him anything for the future. When he asked, "Do you love me? Could you love me?" she merely said, "You should judge by my actions" and "Do I seem indifferent?" Indeed, her actions made Hazlitt hope, and hope was enough at the outset. He showered her with gifts, some of them expensive: an ivory flageolet, a gold heart-shaped locket, a cap and gown, silk cloth, tickets for the theatre, copies of the books he had written, even his most treasured miniature statue of Napoleon. But one day she told him something he had not known before. The reason she could never feel more than friendship towards him, she said, was that she still nurtured a tenderness for someone else, a former lodger in the house who, because of a "difference of station", had been obliged to leave to prevent their mutual feelings going further. This continuing attachment posed a barrier, she said, to her ever loving anyone else. This was a severe blow. Instead of answering his questions evasively, she was now, Hazlitt reported, saying, "No, never." He was hurt and troubled by the news, but it did not kill his hope. He thought that his passion must surely one day make her love him in return, so exalted was it, and so profound. And then he found that he was charmed by her fidelity to one she had loved, and he honoured her for it. And still she sat in his lap daily, twining her arms round his neck, kissing him, enjoying his caresses. But that was before an even more devastating blow precipitated a crisis in their relationship. A new lodger arrived, younger and more handsome, and Sarah Walker discovered for herself what it was like to fall in love. She rejected Hazlitt therefore, and his suffering over the next three years is almost indescribable. He did everything he could to win her back, not least divorcing his estranged wife so that he could be free to marry Sarah; but it only prolonged his agony. Mary Shelley, the daughter of his friend Godwin, having not seen him during those years because she was in Italy, described his appearance when the crisis was nearly over: "I never was so shocked in my life - gaunt and thin, his hair scattered, his cheekbones projecting - but for his voice and smile I should not have known him. His smile brought tears to my eyes, it was like a sunbeam illuminating the most melancholy of ruins." And yet in the years during and after Hazlitt's great passion for Sarah Walker, he wrote his best works - essays of incomparable power and beauty, exploring the human condition, discussing art and letters, dissecting ideas, offering instruction and wit, insight, controversy, and pleasure - and, in the most famous of his books, The Spirit of the Age, choosing with unerring accuracy those among his contemporaries whose reputations he thought would last into history, and anatomising them in his penetrating and witty way. As with everything he wrote, his genius as a writer of prose takes one's breath away, and leaves a vivid impression of a man whose passionately lived life was turned by great art into literature, and made a lasting monument to the human spirit.  AC Grayling's The Quarrel of the Age, a biography of Hazlitt, is published by Weidenfeld & Nicolson (£25). fields.headline: Wot no president?
fields.trailText: Smallweed
fields.body:
Thomas More has just been enshrined as the patron saint of politicians. But who is the patron saint of disputed elections? Clearly, St Chad (or Ceadda), after whom Birmingham Cathedral is named, not just because chads (pieces of cardboard punched from the ballot paper) have played so conspicuous a role in the US imbroglio, but because St Chad was involved in the 7th-century equivalent of Gore v Bush. Chad was one of four brothers, all of them ordained, two of them bishops, Chad (or Ceadda) succeeding his brother Cedd (or Cedda) as bishop of the East Saxons, which no doubt encouraged all sorts of groundling complaints of cronyism.

The diocese of Lindisfarne having fallen vacant, the nomination went to St Wilfrid, and the seat was moved to York. Wilfrid went over to Gaul for his consecration but failed to come back. In time this provoked all sorts of groundling complaints about absenteeism, to a point where King Oswy of Northumbria resolved that this nonsense must stop. So Chad was despatched to Canterbury to be consecrated in Wilfrid's place. But the Archbishop there (Deusdedit) was found to have popped his clogs, so the ceremony was re-routed to Winchester. For a time Chad ruled very happily over his new province - so much so that when St Wilfrid at last returned, he took the matter no further.

That was how things stood when a new archbishop of Canterbury, Theodore, came cantering on to the scene. Alerted by the usual complainers, he investigated the enthronement of Chad and decided that the result would have to be reversed - partly because Chad's job belonged to somebody else, and partly because two bishops assisting at Winchester had heretical views on the dating of Easter. Without even waiting for CNN to pronounce, Chad conceded defeat and took himself off to a monastery. Later, however, his superiors brought him out of seclusion and made him bishop of the Mercians, a job which, as a man of good taste and discernment, he chose to do from one of Smallweed's favourite English towns, Lichfield, in rarely commended Staffordshire.

It does not need a rocket surgeon or brain scientist here to deduce that this may be a helpful precedent for the Americans. Clearly the man who didn't ought to be president should simply be offered a consolation presidency somewhere else, like Outer Mongolia. All it needs now is some latter-day Theodore to pronounce on whether vice-president Gore is a Ceadda or Chad, or a Wilfrid.

One further word on chads before we leave this pretty kettle of cod (or codda). During the war there used to be little cartoons posted across the country showing a man with a very large nose looking over a wall, with a slogan beneath him bemoaning a shortage: "Wot no bananas"; "Wot no second front", and so on. This character was known as a chad. Some reference books say its origins are unknown, but others ascribe it to a cartoonist called Chat (real name George Edward Chatterton). To mark the solemnity of this occasion, Smallweed has commissioned a 21st-century Chad whose cheerful face brings this disquisition safely to harbour, and allows me to move on to another monosyllabic obsession: clogs.

All week letters and emails and phone calls concerning clogs have been clogging up Smallweed's system. Older readers may recall me asking last week how the expression "popping one's clogs" had entered the English language. It seemed to me vaguely mysterious - in utter contradistinction to the expression "clogging one's pops", which describes what young lads do to their dads during the annual encounter between the school football team and a parents' XI. Almost everyone is agreed that to pop means to pawn and that clogs are what people used to wear on their feet before we all took to trainers. So popping your clogs means taking your clogs to the pawnbroker because you wouldn't need them in future. But even this fails to explain how this usage came to be equated with dying. A man who is dead cannot, I maintain, take his clogs to the pawnbroker. In any case, those who took goods to the pawnbroker usually planned to redeem them later. What was the point of the dying planning to redeem their clogs?

A theologian writes: You are getting into deep waters here, sonny.

Smallweed obediently mumbles: I'm sure St Chad would agree with you. And here is another mystery. One erudite lexicographical source asserts, to his own surprise, that popping one's clogs cannot be traced back in written form any further than the 1970s. However, a Sheffield reader recalls that when King George VI died, his brother arrived back at home with the cheery announcement: "Ah see t' king's popped 'is clogs", at which their mother rebuked him for levity. That, by my calculation, must have been February 1952, but he also thinks he heard tell of a pope popping his clogs - which he says must have been Pius IX in 1939. Please alert me to any much earlier sightings: from the time of St Chad, for instance.

I mentioned other euphemisms for dying - including "pegging out" which I said referred to cribbage. Not so, says a letter from Tewkesbury. "It is the final action after going through the hoops in croquet," I am assured, "when one then has to hit a brighly coloured peg in the centre of the lawn. One has then finished - or pegged out." A former nurse, who should know, has offered me a fat hamper of further euphemisms, said to be used in hospitals, some too tasteless, I fear, to repeat. Gentler versions include: going professional, going private (said to be used only by COHSE members); contracting Beethoven's disease (or insert name of any famously defunct person); contracting subepitaphitis; putting on the eternal nightie; being referred upwards; opting for reincarnation therapy; and joining the Old Conservatives (ie, turning blue).
