fields.headline: North Pembrokeshire
fields.standfirst: A Country Diary
fields.trailText: A Country Diary
fields.body:
The Vikings invaded a few weeks ago, intent on pillage. The first fieldfare was alone, busy on a cotoneaster. In amongst the rain and wind we visited holly trees and rowans before the backup force arrived. Now they are swooping and clattering, each day the holly berries diminish in number. Watching birds during these hard times you cannot help but be impressed by the neat ability of small birds to keep low and vanish into the shelter of any leaved bush. On one particularly lashed-about walk we sought some shelter by creeping under a low holly. Saved from wind and rain, we could catch our breath and look around. The ground was covered in berries torn from the tree: what will eat them down there?

When we emerged we were dazzled by yet another rainbow. Days of non-stop rain become tedious, but the rainbows seen on showery days have been triumphant, soaring arcs of colour. Another delight is the varied hues of the tree leaves in sunshine. Oaks are providing rich marmalade while the beeches flame into gold. Whether the sky is pale blue or dark indigo, behind them the trees sing, "What if this life is full of care..."

Admittedly, if you stand around to stare in some places you may lose your boots. In the gales you can see the under-side of the leaves. Alders and willows are noticeable for their steely grey tones, which gleam when caught in the sun. Both trees need wetness. Sixteenth-century Venice was built on alder piles because the wood does not rot easily in water.

A pertinent tale for current weather conditions concerns the alder and willow. They both attended a great feast for the fertility deities, when all living creatures celebrated together. However, these two were so mesmerised by flood waters that they stood gazing upon them, quite ignoring the mighty gods, who then decided that, if that was what they wanted, that's what they would get. Since then, they have stood by the waters, traditionally holding their banks to maintain the steady flow of water, without which the land dies.

fields.headline: Gore excels at survival game
fields.standfirst:
Democrats take heart from leader who refuses to quit

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Democrats take heart from leader who refuses to quit.
fields.body:
Bill Clinton was always supposed to be the Comeback Kid, but Al Gore has survived so many political near-death experiences this week that he has become the American presidential election's cat with nine lives.

Yesterday morning, when Judge Terry Lewis ruled that Florida's recounts did not have to be counted in the state's election totals, the Gore obituaries were being prepared across Washington. But then in the afternoon, the Florida supreme court took control of the Florida election certification process from the Republican secretary of state Katherine Harris. With one bound, Mr Gore was back in the game.

"The first test of whether either of these two candidates can be the leader of the United States of America is happening right now, not the day after the inauguration," the former White House chief of staff Leon Panetta said yesterday.

Yesterday's highs and lows for Mr Gore were the latest in a series of rollercoaster days for the vice-president since he stopped campaigning in the early hours of November 7. Since then he has seemed to win, then lose, then be out of it, then be back in. On Thursday this week, it seemed likely that the Florida recounts had driven into the sand. Then a court allowed them to go ahead. It must have made the latest switchback events seem like just another day at the office.

Mr Gore is focused on trying to wrest Florida and the White House out of Mr Bush's grasp, aides say. He was much quicker than Mr Bush to seize the implications of the Florida recount on the morning of November 8, sending 70 lawyers and campaigners to the state on the first day.

Mr Gore also made a vital move when he shifted his headquarters back from Nashville 48 hours later. By establishing his "war room" in the Democratic National Committee's national headquarters on Capitol Hill, Mr Gore placed his cause at the centre of the party's agenda, conscripting the party hierarchy behind his cause and ensuring that his challenge became a crusade for the whole Democratic machine, not just for the Gore loyalists.

No one disputes in Washington that Mr Gore is at the heart of the hour-by-hour war for position against Mr Bush. Despite the appearance of normality Mr Gore is trying to project, he has spent several hours each day on the phone. He talks countless times a day to his lieutenant in Florida Warren Christopher, and he has also spent large parts of each day ringing party notables and donors, thanking them for their past support and recruiting them for the current battle.

"He's very thorough, even meticulous, and very comprehensive in the way he approaches each problem," says Mark Fabiani, a key Gore strategist throughout the campaign.

So far, the public has been tolerant of Mr Gore's efforts to ensure that all the votes that were cast for him are properly counted in Florida. Yesterday's legal decision was a vital extra lifeline in that process, enabling the recounts to continue in Palm Beach and Broward counties - as well as possibly Dade county eventually. Yesterday morning, when Judge Terry Lewis ruled that Florida's recounts did not have to be counted in the state's election totals, the Gore obituaries were being prepared across Washington. But then in the afternoon, the Florida supreme court took control of the Florida election certification process from the Republican secretary of state Katherine Harris. With one bound, Mr Gore was back in the game. "The first test of whether either of these two candidates can be the leader of the United States of America is happening right now, not the day after the inauguration," the former White House chief of staff Leon Panetta said yesterday. Yesterday's highs and lows for Mr Gore were the latest in a series of rollercoaster days for the vice-president since he stopped campaigning in the early hours of November 7. Since then he has seemed to win, then lose, then be out of it, then be back in. On Thursday this week, it seemed likely that the Florida recounts had driven into the sand. Then a court allowed them to go ahead. It must have made the latest switchback events seem like just another day at the office. Mr Gore is focused on trying to wrest Florida and the White House out of Mr Bush's grasp, aides say. He was much quicker than Mr Bush to seize the implications of the Florida recount on the morning of November 8, sending 70 lawyers and campaigners to the state on the first day. Mr Gore also made a vital move when he shifted his headquarters back from Nashville 48 hours later. By establishing his "war room" in the Democratic National Committee's national headquarters on Capitol Hill, Mr Gore placed his cause at the centre of the party's agenda, conscripting the party hierarchy behind his cause and ensuring that his challenge became a crusade for the whole Democratic machine, not just for the Gore loyalists. No one disputes in Washington that Mr Gore is at the heart of the hour-by-hour war for position against Mr Bush. Despite the appearance of normality Mr Gore is trying to project, he has spent several hours each day on the phone. He talks countless times a day to his lieutenant in Florida Warren Christopher, and he has also spent large parts of each day ringing party notables and donors, thanking them for their past support and recruiting them for the current battle. webTitle: Bluetac to sell off financial website

fields.headline: Bluetac to sell off financial website
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Mobile-Invest, a financial website that provides investors with international stock market quotes and news, is to be sold off by its parent company Bluetac.
fields.body:
Mobile-Invest, a financial website that provides investors with international stock market quotes and news, is to be sold off by its parent company Bluetac.

Bluetac, which was founded in April last year, wants to capitalise on the technology and branding assets that Mobile-Invest has, to provide the cash it needs to reach profitability in the next two months.

Andres Jugnarain, Bluetac's chief executive said: "We have to turn Mobile-Invest into some money soon, otherwise as a company we don't have very long left."

The announcement comes just after the financial website TheStreet.co.uk closed because it could not get funding to keep it afloat beyond the end of the year. Another financial website, jagnotes-euro.com, which was a leading customer for Mobile-Invest, also closed a week ago.

Mr Jugnarain said: "Following a sharp downturn in international financial markets, in particular technology related issues, the company is no longer in a position to continue operations beyond the end of 2000."

Mobile-Invest provides international financial content and news, written in house, via WAP, website and other mobile devices. The site receives 60,000 page impressions a day and has 5,000 regular users. Mr Jugnarain expects to sell the site for about £100,000 - enough to take the company to profitability, he said.

webTitle: Driver unlocks wheel clamp with matchstick

fields.headline: Driver unlocks wheel clamp with matchstick
fields.trailText: Another of life's certainties was dispatched this week, when a man succeeded in unlocking a clamp from the rear wheel of his car using a matchstick and escaped paying the £58 fine.
fields.body:
Another of life's certainties was dispatched this week, when a man succeeded in unlocking a clamp from the rear wheel of his car using a matchstick and escaped paying the £58 fine.

The man, whose identity has not been revealed, was caught on a security camera in Manchester city centre as he separated the clamp from his Toyota, minutes before a clamping unit turned up to find the car gone and the clamp on the roadside.

The operation took 16 minutes and is thought to be the first anti-clamping manoeuvre not to have involved criminal damage. Greater Manchester police said: "There is no case we are aware of where someone has taken a clamp off the car without damaging it."

It had been believed the clamping device was infallible. When the motorist discovered the clamp he asked Peter Rogers, a security officer working nearby, if he could use his phone to call the clamping unit. Its response appeared to annoy him, however, and after the call he asked to borrow a match. "You could see he was angry," said Mr Rogers. "He reversed the car a fraction with the clamp on, leaving it off-centre of the wheel. He pushed a match into the tyre valve and deflated it. Next, he jacked the car up and took the clamp off and threw it on the pavement."

The man borrowed a jack from a passing motorist. While he was changing the flat tyre a traffic warden walked past, without asking why he appeared to be in possession of a dismantled wheel clamp. After changing the tyre all that remained was for him to drive off to cheers from the crowd.

Control Plus, the clamping company, said cars could be freed in five minutes if drivers paid the £58 by credit card.

"I thought it was wonderful," said Mr Rogers. "He had beaten the system."

webTitle: Body lay in flat for two years

fields.headline: Body lay in flat for two years
fields.trailText: Neighbours considered George Oswald quiet but friendly. They exchanged pleasantries as he walked past on his way to the pub or to meet his girlfriend.
fields.body:
Neighbours considered George Oswald quiet but friendly. They exchanged pleasantries as he walked past on his way to the pub or to meet his girlfriend.

Then two years ago he stopped walking past. His neighbours thought little of it, assuming that as he had been ill he had gone into hospital.

Until, that is, the council came knocking. Seeking to repossess the flat on the Holly Park estate in Crouch Hill, north London, bailiffs battered down the door to be confronted by Mr Oswald's skeletal remains.

It was only after the DSS stopped paying his rent last January that Islington council began making the inquiries which led to the discovery.

Yesterday, following the opening of an inquest into the death, neighbours were asking why they had not thought to check up on Mr Oswald, 38, a French polisher, and painter and decorator. The council said the fact he might have been dead for two years was "regrettable", but added: "These things do happen."

The inquest at St Pancras coroner's court was told it was impossible to ascertain the cause of death because Mr Oswald had died so long ago. His mother, from Scotland, helped with the difficult identification process.

Neighbours said Mr Oswald moved into the ground floor council flat six years ago. He seemed content and liked the estate, which houses several hundred people. He made friends and plied his trades around north London.

He had a girlfriend but neighbours believe they had argued and might have split up. He was particularly friendly with his next door neighbours Adam and Stella Venkiah, with whom he shared a small garden. To go anywhere he had to walk past their front window and through a common gate.

Mr Venkiah, 69, said they had not seen him for about two years. At first visitors would call for him but leave when he did not answer. Eventually they stopped coming.

"One of his friends said he was ill so when he disappeared we thought he had probably gone into hospital," Mr Venkiah said.

Mr and Mrs Venkiah continued to keep his side of the garden tidy for his return.

Another resident, Stephen Jones, questioned why it had taken the council so long to discover what had happened. "Don't they have a duty of care for their tenants? I think they should have found out much sooner that something had gone wrong. It's also dispiriting that he lived here surrounded by people but no one seems to have noticed he had gone."

The council's eviction process began last January when the DSS stopped paying his rent. Council officers visited the flat but left when there was no response. Neighbours told them they thought he was in hospital.

On August 15 a possession order was obtained but still there was a delay until October 31 because the council's bailiffs were so busy. Then the bailiffs and council officials broke into the flat to find Mr Oswald's remains.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Three officers have been suspended at Pentonville prison, north London, after allegations by prisoners.
fields.body:
Prison officers suspended

Three officers have been suspended at Pentonville prison, north London, after allegations by prisoners. One officer was allegedly found in possession of a class A drug, a female officer was accused of having an "inappropriate relationship" with a prisoner, and the third was said to have assaulted an inmate.

Tribunals can hear spies' woes

MI5 and MI6 staff will be able to take their grievances to employment tribunals under long-delayed plans being considered by the Department of Trade. But the agencies will be able to restrict, on national security grounds, information used in court.

Charities board reinvents itself

The National Lottery Charities Board, which gives some £280m annually to voluntary groups, is to reinvent itself in April as the Community Fund to stop it being confused with operator Camelot and other lottery distributors.

Cycle helmets protect busmen

Two late-night bus drivers are wearing cycle helmets to protect themselves on Cheltenham to Tewkesbury routes in Gloucestershire after a spate of attacks on drivers and buses, including air rifles being fired.

Beatles album heads for record

The Beatles' greatest hits album is on track to sell 300,000 copies to win a platinum award by tomorrow and possibly become the biggest selling week one album this year - and could go on to become one of the bestselling albums of all time, according to the music retailer, HMV.

webTitle: Kosovan sex slave ring is smashed

fields.headline: Kosovan sex slave ring is smashed
fields.standfirst: Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: Police in Kosovo, backed by British and Norwegian peacekeeping troops, say they have broken an international trafficking and prostitution ring by raiding bars, hotels and homes in the town of Kosovo Polje, near the provincial capital Pristina.
fields.body:
Police in Kosovo, backed by British and Norwegian peacekeeping troops, say they have broken an international trafficking and prostitution ring by raiding bars, hotels and homes in the town of Kosovo Polje, near the provincial capital Pristina.

Officials of the Nato-led peacekeeping force K-For said the operation had revealed the involvement of both Serbs and Albanians in the province's sex slave trade.

Twelve women, all from the republic of Moldova, were found as the police and troops searched the area.

The K-For spokesman, Flight Lieutenant Martin Perin, said the trade was centred on Albanian-owned bars in the town. Serbs had been identified as controlling prostitutes in private houses and flats.

"There has been a considerable amount of cooperation between Albanian and Serb pimps, with women being exchanged between them."

Teams of royal marine commandos used sledgehammers to smash down the doors of a house and several flats. Sniffer dogs were sent in to search for explosives.

Most of the women were found in the Black Lady bar, on the ground floor of a block of flats. Red velvet curtains covered what used to be a shop window, and a disco ball lit up the centre of the room.

Six women were led away by police officers to a waiting van while three men, the bar's owners, were handcuffed and photographed. Nobody tried to resist arrest. One of the men held the womens' passports.

A Royal Ulster Constabulary officer seconded to the UN said the women were nearly all there against their will.

"Some may be victims of trafficking, others women who got into prostitution but were held against their will. They don't have freedom of movement and they are not being paid," he said.

He said the raids had been made with the support of residents. "The local community are fed up with pimping and prostitution going on in their backyards."

Elsewhere, police officers said they found drugs and syringes. Seven people were arrested and four pistols were seized. A police spokesman said several of the suspects were believed to be former members of the Kosovo Liberation Army.

A senior former KLA commander, Sabit Geci, was detained in Pristina last month, accused of threatening to kill the owner of strip bar.

The sex slave trade has boomed since the UN took control of Kosovo 17 months ago. The women are smuggled into the province from Serbia and Macedonia, and sold for as little as £350.

Many are tricked into leaving their homes, mainly in eastern Europe, by the promise of work in the west.

The arrests follow the creation of 22-strong trafficking and prostitution unit. The UN's police spokesman, Derek Chapelle, said the military's concentration on combating the high murder rate and inter-ethnic violence had left the sex trade to grow largely unhindered.

"This is the first large-scale effort directed against the problem," he said. "Until now people have felt fairly safe here, there has been a climate of impunity. The message now is that we will direct our resources against any aspect of criminality."

The 12 women will be given the opportunity to return to Moldova if they were brought to Kosovo against their will.

fields.trailText: An assault charge against South Africa's top anti-corruption official was abandoned yesterday after the woman who alleged she had been attacked in a hotel room by Selby Baqwa, the public protector, withdrew her complaint.
fields.body:
Charge dropped

An assault charge against South Africa's top anti-corruption official was abandoned yesterday after the woman who alleged she had been attacked in a hotel room by Selby Baqwa, the public protector, withdrew her complaint.

Mr Baqwa had rejected the charge, saying it was not unusual for people to sling mud at a person in his position.
Chris McGreal, Johannesburg

Gunman kills 3

A gunman opened fire inside a Japanese restaurant in the heart of Amsterdam's tourist district yesterday, killing three people, police said.

The attack took place in the early evening as diners settled in for a meal. Police used a helicopter to help search for the assailant, who remained at large last night.
AP, Amsterdam

fields.headline: Death row Texan wins delay
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: The US supreme court has halted the execution in Texas of a man with learning disabilities who was said still to believe in Santa Claus.
fields.body:
The US supreme court has halted the execution in Texas of a man with learning disabilities who was said still to believe in Santa Claus.

The court agreed late on Thursday to a stay of execution so that it could consider more evidence in the case of Johnny Paul Penry, 44, who has an IQ of 56. He was convicted of the 1979 rape and murder of Pamela Carpenter, 22.

Penry would have been the 149th person to be executed in Texas under the governorship of George W Bush.

It emerged in the run-up to the presidential election that the governor spends an average of 15 minutes deciding whether to approve executions. He believes in the measure as a deterrent.

Penry raped Carpenter after delivering appliances to her house. He then stabbed her to death with scissors and said afterwards: "I told her I loved her and hated to kill her but I had to do it so she wouldn't squeal on me." He was on parole at the time, after an earlier rape conviction.

At Penry's trial, the prosecution argued that he knew right from wrong. They support the execution on the grounds that Carpenter's family has waited 20 years "to have the closure they deserve".

The American Bar Association, Amnesty International, and the European Union are among the many bodies that have protested that Penry should not be executed because of his mental state.

The supreme court has said that it is not a "cruel and unusual punishment" to execute a person with learning disabilities, but has ruled that a jury should be aware of someone's mental condition, which the original jury was not.

webTitle: We'll cross that bridge when they finally fix it

fields.headline: We'll cross that bridge when they finally fix it
fields.standfirst: This week £5m plans were unveiled to make the wobbly Millennium Bridge stable. Michael Edmands talked to Tony Fitzpatrick, the embarrassed but defiant engineer who is determined to get it right
fields.trailText: This week £5m plans were unveiled to make the wobbly Millennium Bridge stable. Michael Edmands talked to Tony Fitzpatrick, the embarrassed but defiant engineer who is determined to get it right.
fields.body:
It looked as if London had been the victim of a major earthquake when TV cameras showed people crossing the Millennium Bridge over the Thames. Young and old alike clung to the rails on the kind of ride usually enjoyed at Alton Towers.

The embarrassment of ministers was matched by the humiliation of the engineers who built the design of sculptor Anthony Caro and architect Norman Foster.

But, unlike these two eminent figures, Tony Fitzpatrick has been prepared to face the music following the closure of the bridge. He says his Italian mother taught him to stand up and tell the truth, and that's what he does.

As the engineer at the center of the Millennium Bridge fiasco he might have been forgiven for being a little gun-shy, but he stood tall. Facing the world's media he looked more like a Warner Brothers film noir gangster - sharp, dark suit, silk shirt, steel glasses and designer stubble - but in the real world he's chairman of engineering at Ove Arup and the man responsible for correcting the swaying of the £18m bridge which opened in June and closed after only a few days. "I am an embarrassed man and my company is very embarrassed," he now says, "When I came back from meeting the press I felt like the British Rail spokesman who blamed the delays on the wrong kind of snow."

He was born in the east end of London of an Irish father and an Italian mother. His dad had fought with the Eighth Army all the way up through Italy to Florence, where he met Tony's mother.

Mr Fitzpatrick arrived here in 1951. "I spent my early years in Italy and it gave me a multinational outlook, especially with the Irish connection in London." He did well at school. "My mother taught me many things like beware of limitations but never settle for second best," he says. She also taught him to cook, and he claims to be very proud of the traditional dishes he can still knock out. He read civil engineering at Leeds University and met his future wife in the history department. He then applied to join Arup "because it was the best in the world" and was accepted in 1972. Based in Newcastle, he was mad about the countryside. "I was really enjoying the life," he says, "When a real break came from a phone call - a chance to move to Tehran. I said fine, where is it?"

He spent three years building everything from supermarkets to the Iranian equivalent of the British Museum. "It was a case of swim or drown, so I quickly learned to swim, but when the Shah left I was soon on the next plane to London," he says.

In England he found himself at the back of a long line in the design competition for the new Hong Kong Bank building. Unfazed, and finally successful, he enjoyed another break. "After Iran, the bosses had liked the cut of my jib. They sent me to Hong Kong and the place really worked its magic on me. I stuck around until 1987 doing various projects."

By the mid-80s London was boasting its own excitement and buildings were going up - not as tall as the Hong Kong Bank but with their own quality. He was also climbing the company ladder and, more importantly to him, meeting people like Lord Norman Foster. Next would come sculptor Sir Anthony Caro and then the "blade of light bridge dazzling all who gaze upon her" as the papers had it. Stretching from St Paul's to Southwark and the Tate Modern, and blessed by the Queen - like the Dome and the London Eye - the Millennium Bridge was a major attraction.

When opened it began to lurch as some 100,000 people (10,000 were expected) started to cross. "There were too many people at once. It had never been flagged in the design codes. Pedestrian bridges don't get that many people walking on them at one time." It was closed. "I was responsible and we couldn't run away from it. When I make a mistake I will fix it." And as revealed this week, Arup plans to ease the swaying, if not stop it entirely, with a series of shock absorbers that will cost Arup some £5m with extra costs for ongoing maintenance and close the bridge for six months.

Mr Fitzpatrick says: "In a situation like this there are a few rocks you need to cling on to and the main and only one you really need is 'always keep telling the truth.' " Shakespeare knew what he was talking about - and so did Tony's mother.
fields.bodyText: It looked as if London had been the victim of a major earthquake when TV cameras showed people crossing the Millennium Bridge over the Thames. Young and old alike clung to the rails on the kind of ride usually enjoyed at Alton Towers. The embarrassment of ministers was matched by the humiliation of the engineers who built the design of sculptor Anthony Caro and architect Norman Foster. But, unlike these two eminent figures, Tony Fitzpatrick has been prepared to face the music following the closure of the bridge. He says his Italian mother taught him to stand up and tell the truth, and that's what he does. As the engineer at the center of the Millennium Bridge fiasco he might have been forgiven for being a little gun-shy, but he stood tall. Facing the world's media he looked more like a Warner Brothers film noir gangster - sharp, dark suit, silk shirt, steel glasses and designer stubble - but in the real world he's chairman of engineering at Ove Arup and the man responsible for correcting the swaying of the £18m bridge which opened in June and closed after only a few days. "I am an embarrassed man and my company is very embarrassed," he now says, "When I came back from meeting the press I felt like the British Rail spokesman who blamed the delays on the wrong kind of snow." He was born in the east end of London of an Irish father and an Italian mother. His dad had fought with the Eighth Army all the way up through Italy to Florence, where he met Tony's mother. Mr Fitzpatrick arrived here in 1951. "I spent my early years in Italy and it gave me a multinational outlook, especially with the Irish connection in London." He did well at school. "My mother taught me many things like beware of limitations but never settle for second best," he says. She also taught him to cook, and he claims to be very proud of the traditional dishes he can still knock out. He read civil engineering at Leeds University and met his future wife in the history department. He then applied to join Arup "because it was the best in the world" and was accepted in 1972. Based in Newcastle, he was mad about the countryside. "I was really enjoying the life," he says, "When a real break came from a phone call - a chance to move to Tehran. I said fine, where is it?" He spent three years building everything from supermarkets to the Iranian equivalent of the British Museum. "It was a case of swim or drown, so I quickly learned to swim, but when the Shah left I was soon on the next plane to London," he says. In England he found himself at the back of a long line in the design competition for the new Hong Kong Bank building. Unfazed, and finally successful, he enjoyed another break. "After Iran, the bosses had liked the cut of my jib. They sent me to Hong Kong and the place really worked its magic on me. I stuck around until 1987 doing various projects." By the mid-80s London was boasting its own excitement and buildings were going up - not as tall as the Hong Kong Bank but with their own quality. He was also climbing the company ladder and, more importantly to him, meeting people like Lord Norman Foster. Next would come sculptor Sir Anthony Caro and then the "blade of light bridge dazzling all who gaze upon her" as the papers had it. Stretching from St Paul's to Southwark and the Tate Modern, and blessed by the Queen - like the Dome and the London Eye - the Millennium Bridge was a major attraction. When opened it began to lurch as some 100,000 people (10,000 were expected) started to cross. "There were too many people at once. It had never been flagged in the design codes. Pedestrian bridges don't get that many people walking on them at one time." It was closed. "I was responsible and we couldn't run away from it. When I make a mistake I will fix it." And as revealed this week, Arup plans to ease the swaying, if not stop it entirely, with a series of shock absorbers that will cost Arup some £5m with extra costs for ongoing maintenance and close the bridge for six months. Mr Fitzpatrick says: "In a situation like this there are a few rocks you need to cling on to and the main and only one you really need is 'always keep telling the truth.' " Shakespeare knew what he was talking about - and so did Tony's mother.

fields.headline: Reduced circumstances
fields.trailText: Everyone knows that banking has become the most competitive of businesses, but Dresdner Kleinwort Benson were hammering the point home yesterday, warning their clients not to treat the sector as a "safe haven".
fields.body:
Everyone knows that banking has become the most competitive of businesses, but Dresdner Kleinwort Benson were hammering the point home yesterday, warning their clients not to treat the sector as a "safe haven".

Analysts at the investment bank see margins eroding fast, while cost pressures are rising. "Mortgage and consumer credit volume growth is falling and re-mortgaging is rising, competition from new entrants and mutuals remains intense, and costs are rising with a step increase in IT costs chasing an uncertain reward," a note said.

So DKB has downgraded Halifax from a "buy" to a simple "add" (knocking 5p off the price to 585p). Analysts are sticking to their "reduce" view on Lloyds TSB, which nevertheless managed a 3.5p advance to 678.5p.

Poor Alliance & Leicester, meanwhile, is now rated a "sell." The shares fell 2.5p to 639.5p.

fields.headline: Highway robbery - Russian style
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: One of the axioms of the foreign correspondent's trade - one that I've never quite understood - is that you don't talk to taxi drivers. Or, at least, you don't quote them. Beats me why a taxi driver's views are less valid than, say, a baker's or a secretary's. But such are the mysterious dos and don'ts of foreign correspondency.
fields.body:
One of the axioms of the foreign correspondent's trade - one that I've never quite understood - is that you don't talk to taxi drivers. Or, at least, you don't quote them. Beats me why a taxi driver's views are less valid than, say, a baker's or a secretary's. But such are the mysterious dos and don'ts of foreign correspondency.

Honouring the rule in the breach, I'll quote Sasha, a member of the taxi mafia that controls Sheremetyevo airport. Emerging from the trials of the arrivals hall and the tribulations of passport control, you can't avoid Sasha and his mates when you arrive in Moscow.

They usually demand a ludicrous $60 (£42) for the 40-minute ride into town and, following the compulsory, elaborate bargaining ritual, settle for half that.

Then they'll try and charge you another $10 (£7) for a receipt, mitigating the fraud by offering to leave it blank for you to fill in. It's the market economy, stupid!

"So who's your boss? How does the system work, Sasha?"

"You don't really want to know. The less you know, the better," he replies. "A couple of guys came into the office a couple of weeks ago and shot two people in the head. Something to do with not paying their dues."

Sasha then pronounces the three dread letters that are the bane of Moscow. GAI. Standing for the state car inspection, the GAI are the traffic cops, the ubiquitous corruption of the city made flesh.

The Gaishniki are everywhere on the roads, swaggering, omnipotent, striking fear into the innocent and pocketing a daily fortune in bribes extorted at will. In their own little way, the Gaishniki are the embodiment of the worst of Russia - sleazy, rude, arbitrary, all-powerful, and you can't ignore them.

I've just had to donate 100 bucks to the traffic police retirement fund. En route to play tennis, and stone cold sober, I was flagged down by the arrogant white stick on a pretext. "Documents, please. Mmm, Yan (the clever cop is instantly on first-name terms), very strong smell of beer."

This is a definition of a no-win situation. Protesting is a definition of futility. The alternative to paying up is a very long day away with the traffic cops.

He raises the need for a blood test, which will mean hours standing around a clinic waiting for a reused syringe in a city where HIV is rife. He, of course, knows all this. Besides, he also thinks he's struck lucky by stopping a relatively wealthy westerner.

In the poverty-racked suburbs, the less privileged traffic cops are known to flag down Russians in their Ladas and scream: "Gimme 10 roubles." That's 25p.

But you can't help admiring the chutzpah. A friend was stopped, and shelled out her $20 (£14) for the sake of a quiet life. The policeman then asked for a lift, followed by an invitation to dinner. All with a straight face.

Sasha says, on average, he donates 100 roubles, or £2.50, a day to the traffic cops. He treats it as road tax. But, he explains, in addition to taking the daily levies from the dozens of airport drivers, the traffic cops also control the airport taxi trade.

The cops use middlemen. The middlemen front the firm and hand over half the takings to the police, otherwise they get closed down, have their licences revoked, or get visits from gun-toting goons.

At the other end of the business, the actual drivers get paid a pittance out of what is left over. And out of that they again have to bribe the Gaishniki.

fields.headline: Pregnant branch of law
fields.trailText: I am appalled by the woman who sued the fertility centre whose treatment enabled her to have three children instead of the two she would have preferred (Payout to triplet parents in landmark IVF case, November 17). Many couples who go through months of unsuccessful subfertility treatment would give anything to be able to achieve a ready-made family, as this mother has done. I hope that instead of seeing the triplets as a burden, in time she will come to appreciate how fortunate she really is.
fields.body:
I am appalled by the woman who sued the fertility centre whose treatment enabled her to have three children instead of the two she would have preferred (Payout to triplet parents in landmark IVF case, November 17). Many couples who go through months of unsuccessful subfertility treatment would give anything to be able to achieve a ready-made family, as this mother has done. I hope that instead of seeing the triplets as a burden, in time she will come to appreciate how fortunate she really is.

Pat Pentecost
Maidstone, Kent
pentecost@lineone.net

Since it's now open season for lawsuits, I am wondering whether to seek compensation on a number of issues. We have three children - should we sue for having had one too many or one too few? Should I encourage two of my children to sue us for having had the third, thereby depriving them of the extra pocket money they might have expected? Or should my wife sue me for her two unexpected pregnancies? And would that entitle me to sue the London Rubber Company for prophylactic failure? I'll be more than happy to share the proceeds with anyone coming up with the most profitable route.

Oliver Wingate
Walpole, Suffolk
oliverwingate@lineone.net

Dickens is right, the law is a ass. Quite apart from other considerations arising from the Sheffield judgment, how on earth did the implausible, greedy Thompsons ever obtain legal aid?

Nigel Linford
Brighton

fields.headline: Mr Corbett's successor is not to be envied
fields.standfirst:
Special report: transport in the UK
Special report: the Hatfield train crash
fields.trailText: The replacement of Gerald Corbett as chief executive of Railtrack by fellow director Steven Marshall, an accountant, will not of itself do anything to restore morale on the railways. Passengers everywhere are suffering twice daily from the effects of the massive repair programme in the aftermath of the Hatfield crash
fields.body:
The replacement of Gerald Corbett as chief executive of Railtrack by fellow director Steven Marshall, an accountant, will not of itself do anything to restore morale on the railways. Passengers everywhere are suffering twice daily from the effects of the massive repair programme in the aftermath of the Hatfield crash, which sometimes gives the impression that Britain's aged railway infrastructure is imploding. Mr Marshall will be judged by one thing alone: results. Passengers long for an early end to the disruption, followed by a prolonged period in which the underinvestment of past years and the structural problems created by privatisation are solved without any compromise on safety. To achieve that while satisfying shareholders is a tough assignment. Mr Marshall has not got the operational experience a job of this magnitude needs, but he does have plenty of experienced people under him to call on.

Gerald Corbett's resignation is understandable. He had already offered it after Hatfield only to have it rejected by the board. As head of Railtrack he ultimately carries responsibility for what has gone wrong, even though he had thrown himself into a reconstruction programme with great energy. He has had to cope with the simultaneous wrath of discontented passengers coping with unprecedented disruption and disgruntled politicians who want the railway problem to go away before the next general election. His resignation will at least clear the air and give the impression that a fresh start can be made, even though the rest of the board, all of whom share responsibility, will remain there for the time being.

It remains to be seen whether the system itself is workable or whether it contains systemic faults both in the relationship between Railtrack and the train operating companies and between Railtrack's policy of putting safety first and its duty to maximise profits for shareholders. The board's recent decision to raise its dividend despite the chaotic state of the railways was not encouraging in this respect. One thing in Mr Marshall's favour is that to have brought in someone completely new from outside the industry might at this stage have been even more disruptive. He will have the heartfelt good wishes of travellers everywhere. But if he doesn't bring observable improvements to the railways soon, he too may suddenly find himself with more time to spend with his family.

fields.headline: In praise of inconsistency
fields.trailText: Over the years I have read many letters to you suggesting that there may be a slight inconsistency (dare I say hypocrisy) in the Guardian.
fields.body:
 Over the years I have read many letters to you suggesting that there may be a slight inconsistency (dare I say hypocrisy) in the Guardian. You carry articles underlining the damage caused by the portrayal of women in the media. On the next page you have adverts of stick-thin androgynous women. You carry pieces on the damage caused by high performance cars, followed by starry-eyed reviews of those cars. You talk about the damage to our environment and include thousands of glossy inserts. You say women are institutionally discriminated against and then we find that your letters pages carry letters overwhelmingly from men (Letters, November 14).

Tom Cargill
London

 I have been reading the Guardian since 1970, at which time the standard of letters was extremely high, with soundly reasoned and erudite contributions. It was the page I always read first. Regrettably, over the years, there has been a tendency to publish snide comments from people who might fairly be called smart Alecs, and no doubt in today's world are referred to as "smart arses". These contribute nothing to sensible discussion of anything, but you seem to be publishing an increasing number of them. On November 11, of the 23 letters published, no less than 10 (43%) could justifiably be called smart-arse letters.

E Relton
Ilford,
Essex

 Sad or what? I prefer to enjoy the letters for the different views expressed, rather than to divide the letters into their respective sexes and then count them.

W Waide
Rossendale,
Lancs

webTitle: Letters: the true meaning of success

fields.headline: Our success
fields.trailText:
Congratulations to Thomas Telford school on its 100% A-C grades at GCSE (November 16). However, I think I am more proud of my truly comprehensive school in north Yorkshire which opens its doors to children with Down's syndrome, spina bifida and real learning difficulties. I will celebrate their fine achievements of grades F and G and leave the league tables to mislead the public about the true meaning of success.
Althea Draper
Northallerton, North Yorks

fields.trailText: I only add two points to your linkage of my work for Shandwick and the latest Neill report on parliamentary standards (Lords reform, November 17). I have never discussed the issue with any Shandwick client, nor have I received any payment for championing the cause of greater protection for the creative industries.

webTitle: Child star faces '£4m claim' from ex-manager

fields.headline: Child star faces '£4m claim' from ex-manager
fields.trailText: The biggest cash worry for most teenage girls is petitioning mum and dad for more pocket money, a clothing allowance or help with mobile phone bills.
fields.body:
The biggest cash worry for most teenage girls is petitioning mum and dad for more pocket money, a clothing allowance or help with mobile phone bills.

But next week 14-year-old singing star Charlotte Church will be biting her nails as her former manager Jonathan Shalit sues her in a high court battle that could cost her millions of pounds.

The soprano from Cardiff gets £50 a month in pocket money. But she is one of the top 10 earners in British music - she made more than £6m last year.

Now the man who made her famous is suing her and her parents for breach of contract following his sacking. Neither party is willing to discuss the figures involved, but music industry sources believe he may be hoping for as much as £4m.

Mr Shalit - whose previous clients include Leo Sayer and docusoap celebrity Jane McDonald - discovered Miss Church in 1997. He rapidly clinched a five-album deal with Sony Records, an £800,000 deal for her autobiography and a lucrative advertising contract with Ford.

But last January his contract, which was due to run until 2002, was abruptly ended by a letter from Miss Church's solicitors. He launched his suit shortly after.

The case, which is scheduled to begin on Tuesday, is yet another date for Miss Church to add to her crammed diary. It coincides with the launch of her third album, Dream a Dream, a collection of Christmas songs.

Her last album sold 2m copies worldwide, but Sony Records is taking no chances with the new release. Her heavy publicity schedule kicks off on Tuesday when she switches on the Christmas lights in Oxford Street, London. A couple of weeks later she will fly to the US to do the same at the White House, meeting Bill Clinton for the second time.

Other high profile fans include Michael Jackson, Elizabeth Taylor, the Queen, and even the Pope.

Hollywood producers are keen to cast her in movies and the only restrictions on her workload are imposed by the law and her parents.

Although Miss Church is still without a manager she has a formidable team of legal, financial and entertainment experts on hand to protect her interests. Her mother, Maria, and stepfather, James, who formally adopted her last year, gave up their jobs to work as her personal assistants.

The court case is likely to raise questions about how the Church family has handled her unexpected success. It is believed that Mrs Church and Mr Shalit clashed over who should make decisions on the star's behalf.

Miss Church's press spokesman yesterday said that she had put the court case to the back of her mind.

"She's a 14-year-old girl. She is studying for eight GCSEs. She's thinking about spending Christmas at home and about flying to the States - those are the things that occupy her mind," he said.

"She's obviously aware of her court case, but she's leaving it to her representatives and won't be in court to start with, although she may be called as a witness."

Mr Shalit yesterday refused to comment, saying it would be inappropriate before the hearing.

Backstage rows that end in court

Charlotte Church is the latest star to be involved in a legal case with a former manager. Other cases include:

 Sir Elton John received a £3.4m payout from his former manager and lover John Reid and is currently suing the managing director of John Reid Enterprises Ltd for negligence. But the case will be best remembered for airing details of Sir Elton's luxurious lifestyle. At one point he was spending £1.5m a month.

 Robbie Williams sings when he is winning - but kept rather quieter in March last year when appeal court judges landed him with a £1m bill. Nigel Martin-Smith, who launched the star's career in the boy band Take That, wanted £90,000 in commission. Legal costs, interest and VAT increased that sum.

 Spice Girls manager Simon Fuller received an out-of-court settlement rumoured to be worth up to £15m after he was sacked in a girl power coup. He went on to form another teen band, SClub7.

It coincides with the launch of her third album, Dream a Dream, a collection of Christmas songs. Her last album sold 2m copies worldwide, but Sony Records is taking no chances with the new release. Her heavy publicity schedule kicks off on Tuesday when she switches on the Christmas lights in Oxford Street, London. A couple of weeks later she will fly to the US to do the same at the White House, meeting Bill Clinton for the second time. Other high profile fans include Michael Jackson, Elizabeth Taylor, the Queen, and even the Pope. Hollywood producers are keen to cast her in movies and the only restrictions on her workload are imposed by the law and her parents. Although Miss Church is still without a manager she has a formidable team of legal, financial and entertainment experts on hand to protect her interests. Her mother, Maria, and stepfather, James, who formally adopted her last year, gave up their jobs to work as her personal assistants. The court case is likely to raise questions about how the Church family has handled her unexpected success. It is believed that Mrs Church and Mr Shalit clashed over who should make decisions on the star's behalf. Miss Church's press spokesman yesterday said that she had put the court case to the back of her mind. "She's a 14-year-old girl. She is studying for eight GCSEs. She's thinking about spending Christmas at home and about flying to the States - those are the things that occupy her mind," he said. "She's obviously aware of her court case, but she's leaving it to her representatives and won't be in court to start with, although she may be called as a witness." Mr Shalit yesterday refused to comment, saying it would be inappropriate before the hearing. Backstage rows that end in court Charlotte Church is the latest star to be involved in a legal case with a former manager. Other cases include:  Sir Elton John received a £3.4m payout from his former manager and lover John Reid and is currently suing the managing director of John Reid Enterprises Ltd for negligence. But the case will be best remembered for airing details of Sir Elton's luxurious lifestyle. At one point he was spending £1.5m a month.  Robbie Williams sings when he is winning - but kept rather quieter in March last year when appeal court judges landed him with a £1m bill. Nigel Martin-Smith, who launched the star's career in the boy band Take That, wanted £90,000 in commission. Legal costs, interest and VAT increased that sum.  Spice Girls manager Simon Fuller received an out-of-court settlement rumoured to be worth up to £15m after he was sacked in a girl power coup. He went on to form another teen band, SClub7.

fields.headline: Information war hots up
fields.trailText: I deeply resent the suggestion that those of us involved in the Campaign for Freedom of Information are somehow not as serious about it as the two noble lords (Letters, November 16).
fields.body:
 I deeply resent the suggestion that those of us involved in the Campaign for Freedom of Information are somehow not as serious about it as the two noble lords (Letters, November 16). I was a founder member of the campaign, and the Consumers' Association, of which I am director, has been a major funder for many years. The association is interested in the ordinary information that we need to do our job of protecting consumers. We are not in it for point scoring. We can give you many examples of where consumers are badly served by the proposed legislation.

The amendments Lord Lestor and Lord Goodhart agreed to and are now talking up beyond their importance were always going to be conceded by the government in the opinion of those of us in day-to-day contact with the issues. You bought a pig in a poke, your lordships. Hugo Young got it right and the Liberal Democrats who have supported open government for many years have scuppered the last chance of getting amendments that would mean this bill was a true step towards open government. Your lordships should do the right thing and tear up the deal with the government and put up a fight for what your party and members believe is right for the people of this country.

Sheila McKechnie
Consumers' Association

 Maurice Frankel is naive and Lord Strathclyde disingenuous (Letters, November 17) about the prospects for the freedom of information bill had the Liberal Democrats not negotiated an agreement with the government. In the division to which Lord Strathclyde refers, only 82 Tory peers voted in favour of their own amendment out of a total of 233 Tory peers. They would hardly have turned out in greater numbers in support of Lib Dem amendments. In the last resort the government could not have been forced to concede anything more. Politics is the art of the possible.

Lord Rodgers
Leader, Liberal Democrat peers

webTitle: WTO asked to hit US with $4bn in trade sanctions

fields.headline: WTO asked to hit US with $4bn in trade sanctions
fields.standfirst: Special report: World Trade Organisation
fields.trailText: The European Union has asked the World Trade Organisation to impose $4bn worth of tariffs on American companies, the largest ever sanctions demand made to the body which polices global trade rules.
fields.body:
The European Union has asked the World Trade Organisation to impose $4bn worth of tariffs on American companies, the largest ever sanctions demand made to the body which polices global trade rules.

The row is over tax breaks for American exporters. According to a WTO decision in February they contravene global trade rules by giving US companies an unfair advantage over their foreign competitors. President Bill Clinton signed legislation last week replacing the scheme with a new tax relief system, but the EU says the US is still out of line with WTO rules.

"The new legislation continues to provide a significant illegal export subsidy to more than half of total US exports, to the detriment of European companies," said Anthony Gooch, spokesman for the European trade commissioner, Pascal Lamy.

US authorities said they would submit the new legisla tion to the WTO to prove it complied with trade rules.

The EU and the US have been at loggerheads over infringements of WTO rules since the body was created five years ago. The US is imposing more than $300m of sanctions on EU companies authorised by the WTO in separate disputes over beef and bananas.

Washington has threatened to rotate the list of luxury goods it hits with punitive tariffs, a move which could threaten Scotland's cashmere industry, but intensive behind the scenes lobbying appeared to have achieved a ceasefire.

The EU's latest move is likely to reawaken tensions between the world's largest trading powers. US officials have warned it could spark all-out trade war if the EU actually imposed billions of dollars of sanctions on US goods.

Both sides have promised to abide by WTO arbitration, taken by trade analysts as a sign that the issue could be resolved without punitive tariffs.

fields.headline: The urban renaissance
fields.trailText: As a resident of a deprived inner-city area for more than 20 years, I am waiting to see what effect the government's new plans for urban regeneration will have (New powers to halt flight from cities, November 17). I suspect that it will follow the decades-long government tradition of far too little and far too late.
fields.body:
As a resident of a deprived inner-city area for more than 20 years, I am waiting to see what effect the government's new plans for urban regeneration will have (New powers to halt flight from cities, November 17). I suspect that it will follow the decades-long government tradition of far too little and far too late.

I welcome the efforts to halt the drift to the countryside. However, in the Easton district of Bristol there is little brownfield land left. Nearly all available sites for housing have already been packed with high density dwellings and residents have little open space for recreation.

Whether the policies in the latest white paper will actually solve our problems is another matter. Blatant drug dealing and street crime are rife, as is poverty. Fly-tipping and litter abound. The police are more likely to be seen in their helicopters than on the beat. Public transport is a joke.

It's not as though the area has been deprived of public funds over the years. Millions have been thrown at the district in recent years, mostly on cosmetic projects. We have lots of ornate streetlights and fancy block paving, but what is the point when our streets always look so filthy?

The government is also keen that regeneration and community development are evolved from the bottom up, ie the people they will affect have their say. I did not notice any invitation to be consulted on this white paper drop through my letter box. What happened to it, Mr Prescott?
Steve Woods
Easton, Bristol
woodsy@theunstoppable.com

 David Walker argues that an urban renaissance will never happen until we invest more in repairing older houses (Unsafe as houses, November 17). The fact is that councils and landlords have been reluctant to invest in repairing newer houses too - and when those dwellings happen to be tower blocks, they would much rather pull them down.

The irony is that tower blocks could be the answer to the housing shortage that threatens to engulf Britain. The government predicts that most of those looking for accommodation will be young, single people. Refurbished tower blocks could be the safe, sensible and popular answer for this sector of society.

Tower blocks are secure because they offer fewer points of access, they conserve energy, cut heating bills and help create vibrant communities. They save space, revitalise local economies and stop the exodus from urban to rural areas. Politicians, local authorities and the public must stop equating tower blocks with urban decay and start investing in their future.
Alan Woods
Chief executive, Going for Green

 There is already an urban lobby; it is the Council for the Protection of Rural England. It recognises that a logical way to avoid development and despoliation of the countryside is to restore urban areas. Pressure and incentives for business to develop in run-down urban areas would take the heat off the south-east. There is a real need for joined-up government here that will not be met by changes in tax relief.

There is a danger that the next round of urban renewal will resemble a scorched earth policy. Many good but redundant buildings remain in the inner cities. There is little in any of John Prescott's announcements to suggest that he recognises this.

The new 5% VAT rate for church repairs is welcome, but the white paper has ignored Lord Rogers, the empty homes agency and conservation and preservation bodies in refusing to adopt a rate of 5% for all buildings, on green or brownfield sites. This would protect the countryside and regenerate cities.
Judith Martin
Winchester, Hants

webTitle: Leader: Hackney can sort itself out

fields.headline: Friends in need
fields.standfirst: With help, Hackney can sort itself out
fields.trailText: When a local council fails disastrously to deliver, should government intervene? This is not an academic question but an issue staring ministers in the face. What are they going to do about the London borough of Hackney?
fields.body:
When a local council fails disastrously to deliver, should government intervene? This is not an academic question but an issue staring ministers in the face. What are they going to do about the London borough of Hackney? In the past, for all Whitehall's notorious centralised powers, the right of direct intervention in a district where a local authority had run off the rails was never available. Through 18 Conservative years, local government suffered ever tighter control, saw its taxing capacity capped and surrendered £30bn-worth of services to unelected quangos. Yet even Margaret Thatcher left Lambeth and Liverpool to clear up their own mess. Now this has changed. Under last April's Local Government Act the chief monitor of local councils, the audit commission, can in dire circumstances advise ministers to send in a hit squad to take over a council's services.

And dire is certainly the appropriate word for the state of Hackney today, even given its long history of political in-fighting, managerial incompetence and plain fraud. A succession of recent reports, starting with the audit commission's first local authority performance tables in 1995, has shown a steady decline across most services. Five years ago the borough was at the bottom of the league table, taking 37.4 weeks to let a vacant flat (compared to Knowsley's two weeks) and with 20% of its tenants at least 13 weeks in arrears (compared to Merseyside's 5%). Subsequent Ofsted and social service inspections have added to this picture of gloom. A third Ofsted report, published yesterday, reported that schools had lost faith in the local council.

But it is the audit commission's corporate report earlier this month, warning ministers that the borough was facing an across the board "meltdown", that has become the real catalyst. It disclosed that the council had collected only half its council tax, 17,000 of its poorest tenants were still awaiting housing benefit and the council was facing a budget deficit of £40m. Hackney was given until February to get its finances in order, agree spending cuts and improve council tax collection and housing benefit payments.

Surely, then, if there has been no improvement, a responsible government would send in a hit squad? Local autonomy is important, but so are civil rights. Some of the poorest people in London - 10 of London's 50 most deprived wards are in the borough - are suffering intolerable conditions: uncollected refuse, unswept streets and a catalogue of urgent but frozen house repairs. There are plans to slash early education programmes and cut 48 residential care beds. A tough hit squad, with powers to take over all services, may seem the best solution. Yet that is not going to happen. One obvious reason is that this would make Hackney the direct responsibility of Whitehall, and that is the last thing this government wants.

Hit squads sound fine, but where do you find them? Incompetency cultures become ingrained. Councils take years to turn round. It may sound less dramatic, but the audit commission's approach offers a far better chance of success. It set down in detail the changes which it wanted to see in better financial control, filling gaping management holes and reaching a political settlement. Local Labour and Tory leaders have reached a consensus; new managers are moving in; nearby authorities are lending support. The exercise is being closely monitored by a new team at the commission, headed by Wendy Thomson, who helped turned round neighbouring Newham. Wish her luck: given the problems of Hackney today, she will certainly need it.

fields.headline: Tenors online
fields.standfirst:
Microsoft signs up Christmas special

Net news
fields.trailText: Microsoft signs up Christmas special.
fields.body:
Fans of the Three Tenors will be able to hear their heroes perform a Christmas special via Microsoft's internet portal MSN next month, under a deal signed yesterday.

Microsoft has signed up Online Classics, the quoted internet broadcaster, to provide it with entertainment content, including The Three Tenors - Placido Domingo, José Carreras and Luciano Pavarotti - at Christmas. MSN will pay Online Classics a facility fee and advertise the concert to a total of 3m page impressions.

The event can be seen by visitors to MSN throughout the US, South Africa, the Middle East and many European countries, including the UK.

"It is hard to imagine a better way of introducing Online Classics to a global audience and driving traffic to our site, whilst gaining revenue in doing so," Chris Hunt, chief executive of Online Classics, said. He expects the relationship to continue on a project-by-project basis.

Online's shares jumped 5.5p to 64p on the news.

Analysts said the deal was excellent for Online's revenue potential, especially because half of the advertising for the concert will be in the US, a crucial market.

fields.headline: Reprieve for local post offices
fields.standfirst:
Negotiations about a rationalised urban network delayed until issue of univeral bank is resolved

More about the Post Office
fields.trailText: Plans to close hundreds of urban post offices have been put on hold as a result of the lengthy talks about setting up a PO-based universal bank.
fields.body:
Plans to close hundreds of urban post offices have been put on hold as a result of the lengthy talks about setting up a PO-based universal bank.

The government promised to compensate sub-postmasters who merged their businesses to create bigger, more viable, high street branches.

But Colin Baker, the general secretary of the National Federation of Sub-Postmasters, yesterday said talks about compensation packages could not start until after the resolution of the universal bank issue.

The universal bank, which will provide basic bank accounts for the financially excluded, is expected to restore about £150m of the £400m annual revenue post offices will lose when state benefits are paid directly into bank accounts, from 2003.

But efforts to establish the new bank have been bogged down by the leading banks' opposition to the scheme and by divisions within Whitehall.

Mr Baker said: "Without the universal bank being nailed down, it would be a leap in the dark for sub-postmasters to merge their businesses.

"They need to know whether they will be getting the univer sal bank revenue and they need to know details of the compensation package.

"Without that knowledge, there is no chance of bigger, brighter and better urban post offices. It is time for the government to deliver on its promises," he said.

Two post offices are closing every week - double last year's rate. The government knows closures of branches in rural and deprived urban areas are the most controversial because they usually lead to the closure of the only local shop.

But it accepts there is a strong case for consolidation in commercially stronger urban areas, where there are often several post offices within walking distance of each other.

A single, larger post office for the area would support a bigger shop and would provide the extra space for planned new post office businesses such as wider provision of government services, internet access, basic banking facilities and pick-up point for online purchases of retail goods.

A small trial of an online purchases pick-up scheme started two weeks ago in the west country, albeit with weight limits on the items.

"In the first week there were 48 parcels, in the second 130 parcels, and it will be near 300 parcels in the third week," Mr Baker said.

The Treasury believes paying benefit direct to bank accounts will save about £400m a year. But it is also encouraging banks to develop their own branded no frills accounts.

The Department of Trade & Industry, on the other hand, is backing the universal bank plan, in part because it would offset the impact of bank branch closures in rural areas and in part because it would help post offices survive.

It has also undermined the Treasury stance by promising that people will still be able to receive benefits in cash at post offices.

The banks do not see why they should financially support the universal bank, which they see as part of government social policy. They also believe it will carry the stigma of a "poor people's bank".

"Without that knowledge, there is no chance of bigger, brighter and better urban post offices. It is time for the government to deliver on its promises," he said. Two post offices are closing every week - double last year's rate. The government knows closures of branches in rural and deprived urban areas are the most controversial because they usually lead to the closure of the only local shop. But it accepts there is a strong case for consolidation in commercially stronger urban areas, where there are often several post offices within walking distance of each other. A single, larger post office for the area would support a bigger shop and would provide the extra space for planned new post office businesses such as wider provision of government services, internet access, basic banking facilities and pick-up point for online purchases of retail goods. A small trial of an online purchases pick-up scheme started two weeks ago in the west country, albeit with weight limits on the items. "In the first week there were 48 parcels, in the second 130 parcels, and it will be near 300 parcels in the third week," Mr Baker said. The Treasury believes paying benefit direct to bank accounts will save about £400m a year. But it is also encouraging banks to develop their own branded no frills accounts. The Department of Trade & Industry, on the other hand, is backing the universal bank plan, in part because it would offset the impact of bank branch closures in rural areas and in part because it would help post offices survive. It has also undermined the Treasury stance by promising that people will still be able to receive benefits in cash at post offices. The banks do not see why they should financially support the universal bank, which they see as part of government social policy. They also believe it will carry the stigma of a "poor people's bank".

webTitle: New regime at Railtrack is long overdue

fields.headline: New regime at Railtrack is long overdue
fields.trailText: When Railtrack raised its interim dividend by 5% earlier this week, Gerald Corbett and his colleagues were quick to point out that the move had only cost an extra £2m.
fields.body:
When Railtrack raised its interim dividend by 5% earlier this week, Gerald Corbett and his colleagues were quick to point out that the move had only cost an extra £2m.

It was a premature calculation. That £2m was probably the final drop of poison in the relationship between an exasperated government and a muddled industry. Whether he walked or was pushed, Mr Corbett had clearly had enough.

So what is the new chief executive, Steven Marshall, taking on? Well, on the operational side, he has to condense a 10-year track replacement into only a few months, cut the still ludicrously high level of signals passed at danger, while simultaneously evaluating a new and hugely expensive train protection system.

In his spare time, Mr Marshall will also have to keep the City on side - so that when the inevitable time comes for him to ask them for more cash, fund managers might listen - and the government off his back. Oh, and there is also the small matter of getting passengers to their destinations on time.

This is quite a handful - probably a job for two. So we should be relieved at the accompanying news yesterday that the invisible chairman, Sir Phillip Beck, is leaving next year. The list of those capable of taking on this job is likely to be very short indeed.

Mr Corbett, meanwhile, is taking a holiday in India. The view from there might even make the British rail system look efficient.

Thankless brief

Reactions to this week's statement from Stephen Byers on Britain's mix of energy - lifting the moratorium on new gas-fired power stations and giving the EU-approved go-ahead for £110m of state aid for coal - suggest that, once again, short-term political considerations gained the upper hand over longer term policy objectives.

Is that fair? Certainly, Mr Byers dismayed the green lobby, its eyes fixed on the deadlocked climate change talks in the Hague and the failure of the west to agree on genuine measures to reduce carbon emissions. It sees in the decision to approve six gas-fired plants, with a capacity of 4800MW, an endorsement of a failed technology that does nothing to reduce energy consumption, and the postponement of promised policy guidelines on combined heat and power plants adds grist to its mill.

But the green lobby is only satisfied when government puts all its efforts - and money - into backing renewable sources, and doubts even that UK ministers can deliver on their promise to source 10% of the nation's energy mix from the likes of biomass or wind or waves within a decade. Mr Byers is simply seen as renewing the "dash for gas" after a two-year pause.

However, there is every reason to believe that few - if any - of the six stations will ever be built, because there is no guarantee they will produce the required returns for investors.

The reason is simple: gas prices during the moratorium have trebled to 28p a therm, while forward electricity prices have fallen by at least 10% this year alone. This has much to do with greater competition both in generation and the retail market. Where once there were two power producers - National Power and PowerGen - there are now seven or eight, and generators are selling off plant to escape regulatory price controls and move into retail or overseas. Greater competition, one of the professed goals of Mr Byers' policy, is already being achieved - by the market.

What of coal, then? The £110m aid package is designed to help an industry that employed 1m on nationalisation in 1947 keep alive just over 10,000 jobs and fewer than 18 viable pits; to enable it to adapt to a period of transition; and to ensure a level playing field for an energy source that last year provided 28% of the energy mix. But it lasts only until July 2002, with Blair into his second term, after which - government sources say - it will be left to stand on its own two feet, finally depoliticised af ter more than a century of strife. Richard Budge of RJB Mining, whose 13 pits receive £70m of the aid, may pull more political levers, it is said, but nobody will listen and coal will be granted no state-aided share of the mix. Price will decide its fate.

The real problem with Mr Byers' statement, however, is what it inevitably left out: a long-term view consistent with fighting global warming and maintaining security and diversity of supply. Gas reserves are fast depleting, and the country may have to turn increasingly to unstable countries for supplies.

There remains the nuclear option - if the surmountable issue of waste disposal can be grasped. Now accounting for a quarter of the UK's power, it could fill the gap - and reduce emissions at the same time. But that would be dangerous politics and it is hard to see any minister or shadow minister raising this option. Maybe they should.
