fields.headline: Degraded policy
fields.standfirst:
Children suffering, filthy water, burning villages: these are our sanctions against Iraq

Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: Children suffering, filthy water, burning villages: these are our sanctions against Iraq.
fields.body:
Monday sees the launch of a national petition against sanctions in Iraq. It will probably pass unnoticed. Sanctions aside, Britain and America bomb Iraq whenever they feel like it, and with no news coverage at all. Presumably, the purpose of the bombing and sanctions is to degrade something. The something is ourselves.

I'm sure those who are reinventing world politics in the light of a new-found enthusiasm for western military intervention, are convinced that Saddam Hussein is about to fall at any moment. If he does at least Iraq will be newsworthy. Saddam is getting more press these days anyway because he's sitting on a lot of oil. So are we, if only we had the wit to renationalise it, but since we gave it all away, we rely on oil companies to make nice with dictators and help them to crush internal opposition so that we can keep our hauliers trucking. The oil-for-food programme is one way in which the west has sought to keep the oil coming.

In fact, the amount of oil which Iraq is allowed to export was set higher than its much degraded industry was able to produce. Even then the programme is not as generous as it sounds, because the oil money is held in a UN-managed account with 30% coming off the top in reparations and imports subject to approval by the Security Council. Equipment vital to Iraq's electricity and water supplies are held up. As a result water is frequently contaminated (there's a biological weapon for you) and the national grid could completely pack up at any moment.

The British government line is that medical shortages are the result of stockpiling. Former UN humanitarian co-ordinators, Denis Halliday and Hans von Sponeck, who resigned in succession over sanctions, both dispute this. The infrastructure was degraded by the west and distribution suffered. In addition, some medicines and equipment are useless without others. Much is lost through spoilage during power cuts. In fact, von Sponeck stated, "We have found no evidence that there is a conscious withholding of medicines ordered by the government."

It is possible that such a policy exists. Certainly, Saddam has a cavalier disregard for the suffering of his own people. He boasts to them of how he enjoys his lavish lifestyle, free from the ravages that sanctions and bombs have brought to ordinary Iraqis. He feasts while they suffer. Perhaps he does withhold medicines. But how would that boost the case of the dwindling number of politicians who support the sanctions? It further demonstrates that the 10-year war we have waged against his people, while ostensibly having "no quarrel" with them, is all grist to the mill as far as he is concerned. That is why all the voices for change in Iraq, and all Saddam's opponents in exile, are telling us to stop.

The west certainly has a curious notion of what it is not to have a quarrel with someone. I suppose in the sense of fisticuffs over a Leylandii tree, it is not a quarrel. Perhaps extermination is a better word. According to Unicef, which as a UN agency is forced to tread carefully, sanctions have contributed to the deaths of 500,000 children since the Gulf war, and 800,000 are chronically malnourished. Asked to comment on such figures, Madeleine Albright has replied: "We think the price is worth it." And it is always worth going to her rather than to Robin Cook. The organ grinder doesn't mess about. She plays a simple tune that's easily recognisable. The monkey leaps about all over the place, making a lot of silly noises.

So let's listen to Washington rather than Westminster. Albright told us in 1997: "We do not agree ... that if Iraq complies with its obligations concerning weapons of mass destruction sanctions should be lifted." In 1998, former weapons inspector Scott Ritter said: "Sanctions only punish the people of Iraq, they don't punish this regime." In June this year, the former head of Unscom, Richard Butler, said: "We now know that using economic sanctions to bring about compliance in the weapons area does not work." Deputy US national security adviser, Robert Gates, said back in 1991: "Iraqis will pay the price while [Saddam] remains in power. All possible sanctions will be maintained until he is gone." That year, Colonel John A Warden III, of the US air force, said that the wrecking of Iraq's electricity system "gives us long-term leverage".

According to Mike Horn, who flew F-15s in two tours of duty in the northern no-fly zone, "You'd see Turkish F-14s and F-16s inbound, loaded to the gills with munitions. Then they'd come out half an hour later with their munitions expended." When US pilots flew back over the Kurds whom the no-fly zone ostensibly protects, they would see "burning villages, lots of smoke and fire". Instructions were not to interfere. Someone remind me who this quarrel is with?

comment@theguardian.com

webTitle: Glas Cymru seeks to lower bills at Welsh Water

fields.headline: Glas Cymru seeks to lower bills at Welsh Water
fields.trailText: Glas Cymru, the not for profit company planning an agreed £1.8bn takeover of Welsh Water early next year, wants to cut bills by 5% in 2004 and give annual rebates thereafter, executives said yesterday.
fields.body:
Glas Cymru, the not for profit company planning an agreed £1.8bn takeover of Welsh Water early next year, wants to cut bills by 5% in 2004 and give annual rebates thereafter, executives said yesterday.

Welsh Water customers pay higher bills than those in the rest of England and Wales and, under the present controls imposed by the industry regulator Ofwat, could see their annual bills reach £276 by 2005.

The American owner, Western Power Distribution, has appealed against Ofwat's ruling, which envisages a 10.5% cut this year, a 0.5% reduction next year and small rises in the three subsequent years.

But Glas Cymru, which has no shareholders and would run Welsh Water as a debt financed firm by raising low risk bonds, said it would generate enough cash and reserves to offer significantly lower bills.

Glas expects its initial estimated £150m reserves to rise to around £350m by 2005 on annual turnover of £450m.

Chris Jones, the finance director, said the lower cost of capital brought about by issuing bonds could generate savings of between £40m and £50m, and some of this could be passed back to customers, with an initial cut of 5% likely around 2004-5.

The company, which is aiming for an A credit rating, says it expects its revenues to be so steady that by the time of the next Ofwat review in 2005 that customers could look forward to annual rebates.

"Welsh Water bills are the second highest because of the extensive environmental investment programme," Mr Jones said.

"But by paying rebates we would hope to get them closer to the average - right in the middle of the pack."

Glas Cymru hopes to be given Ofwat approval for its plans in January.

Last week Philip Fletcher, the director general of water services, said that its plans "do not appear to give rise to any insurmountable issues", and is understood to be ready to give them the go-ahead after the formal consultation period.

fields.headline: The knowledge
fields.standfirst: Chicken stock, part 2
fields.trailText: Chicken stock, part 2
fields.body:
The subject
You can make chicken stock with nothing more than chicken and water, as the Knowledge proposed last week. But its pleasure potential waxes if you add a few extras. The basics
First, assemble the essential components: chicken trimmings, abducted from your local butcher at every opportunity and frozen until critical mass is achieved. Pop the pieces in the pot, heat to simmering point, and skim off conspicuous effusions of scum. Now you are ready to add...

The details
...the A-list aromatic accessories, an ounce or so per pound of trimmings. A-list number 1 is literally that: alliums. Garlic and/or onions, topped and tailed; peeling optional. Leeks, thoroughly cleaned.
A-list number 2: parsley, celery (especially leaves), carrots added in extreme moderation, peppercorns, bayleaves, a parsimonious pinch of dried herbs. Use one or all, but don't bother freezing scraps of veg: as Jacques Pépin pithily puts it: 'After a while, you accumulate hundreds of small packages with crystallised ice around them. So one day, you look around the freezer and throw them all away.'
Stock never-nevers: starch, strong-tasting veg, acid.
Stock sometimes-sometimes: preliminary browning of bones for colour and flavour.
Stock always-always number 1: do not turn your back when stock is sitting on a flame that can turn the simmer into a boil. The Knowledge can tell many sad stories about the results.
Stock always-always number 2: comprehensive clarification and de-greasing.
Stock always-always number 3: sound storage.
Send an SAE for tips on all three points.

Where to buy
As we agreed last week, the butcher is your stock stockist.

The easy way out
The Knowledge acknowledges the usefulness of cubist options when B-list stock will suffice.
Top brand: Just Bouillon, widely available. Joubere Fresh Chicken Stock (around £1.15 for 300g) is a good product that costs many, many times more than homemade.

webTitle: Food: Joanna Blythman on Derek Cooper

fields.headline: Voice of reason
fields.standfirst: Joanna Blythman hails a consumers' champion, Radio 4's Food Programme host, Derek Cooper
fields.trailText: Joanna Blythman hails a consumers' champion, Radio 4's Food Programme host, Derek Cooper
fields.body:
The Food Programme on Radio 4 is that rare thing: a national institution that has become essential listening for anyone who loves food and who wants to take an intelligent interest in how it is produced. Since the show first aired in 1979, it has become increasingly authoritative and opinion-forming. So much so, in fact, that whether it's rediscovering the aromatic delights of the ancient pear varieties that make a traditional English perry or raising the spectre of a new and disturbing disease in cattle (as it was first to do with BSE way back in 1987), the programme sets the UK's food agenda.

Integral to the Food Programme are the rich, gravelly tones of Derek Cooper, whose voice is as distinctive and characterful as any peaty Island malt. It's also a voice that strikes fear into the bigwigs in the food industry because he is so adept at tripping them up with those characteristically neutral but deadly questions that manage to elicit information that would not otherwise be volunteered.

Cooper is not afraid of the powerful, nor is he seeking membership of any establishment club. Listeners adore him, and trust what he tells them about food. This is a man with the deeply held conviction that everyone, everywhere, has a right to good food, and that anyone or anything that stands in the way of that needs to be investigated and exposed. Even so, there is a less cerebral side to him, too: Cooper is the Bollinger Bolshevik, a gourmand who loves to eat and drink - the great joke about him is that he is, by his own admission, a non-cook, albeit one who is fortunately catered for by an excellent "natural cook" in the form of his wife, Janet.

Yet even without any hands-on feel for food, he still manages to convey its many fascinating pleasures without recourse to gushing "cherries-on-the-nose" speak or impoverished banalities. You won't hear Cooper describing something as "Delicious!" or "Yummy!"

If there is one thing that is arguably as good as listening to Cooper on the radio, it is reading his prose. Such is his stature as a broadcaster nowadays that it is easy to forget that he is also a formidable writer who has generated a constant stream of articles over the years for publications as diverse as the Guardian, the Listener, Woman's Journal and Saga, the best of which, fortuitously, have now been rescued from newsprint oblivion and collected in a new book, Snail Eggs & Samphire (MacMillan £16.99).

There are few places in the world to which Cooper hasn't travelled, so the collection is an extravagant miscellany. It transports you to the Cathay restaurant in Singapore in the 50s and his (thankfully unsuccessful) search for its speciality - Himalayan bear paw soaked in honey. "Sorry," said the waiter, "bear paw off."

You'll laugh at his tales of snail eggs, originally a Tibetan speciality "more recherché than curdled yak's milk", seized on by top chefs and tasted at a "snailathon" in a smart London restaurant: "'I'm getting almonds,' said the foodie opposite me. I found the eggs moist and unusual, but I was getting nothing," writes Cooper.

His tougher attacks on the food industry, meanwhile, like his radio interviews, are light of touch (he writes, for example, of the Egg Disinformation Service) - and all the more devastating for it. "Reading the pages of the catering press is to be transported into a bleak economy, where time is of the essence, where skilled staff are nonexistent and all food preparation must be accomplished only with cold water and a mixing bowl or microwave."

Cooper subjects products such as "fresh-style frozen turkey" to wry forensic examination. The latter title, he observes, represents "a semantic leap forward in food marketing that has released us, in a poetic and creative burst of imagination, from the tyranny of words".

One of his greatest skills is understatement, which allows readers and listeners alike to reach their own conclusions. His deep sense of injustice at the north-south inequalities of food production in the UK and man-made food poverty is a theme that runs through the book. Recounting his childhood in the 30s, he writes, "The Mercator map on the school wall seemed to be largely red and I knew that much of what we ate came from the Empire where native peoples toiled eagerly with permanent smiles to produce the raw materials on which our wealth was founded."

This is a volume with the attractions of Elizabeth David's An Omelette And A Glass Of Wine: biting, ironic humour, a celebration of simplicity and honesty in cooking, intolerance of industrial processed food, erudite and evocative accounts of splendid meals and precious small-scale foods. In short, a book to have by your bed when you can't listen to the Food Programme.
fields.bodyText: The Food Programme on Radio 4 is that rare thing: a national institution that has become essential listening for anyone who loves food and who wants to take an intelligent interest in how it is produced. Since the show first aired in 1979, it has become increasingly authoritative and opinion-forming. So much so, in fact, that whether it's rediscovering the aromatic delights of the ancient pear varieties that make a traditional English perry or raising the spectre of a new and disturbing disease in cattle (as it was first to do with BSE way back in 1987), the programme sets the UK's food agenda. Integral to the Food Programme are the rich, gravelly tones of Derek Cooper, whose voice is as distinctive and characterful as any peaty Island malt. It's also a voice that strikes fear into the bigwigs in the food industry because he is so adept at tripping them up with those characteristically neutral but deadly questions that manage to elicit information that would not otherwise be volunteered. Cooper is not afraid of the powerful, nor is he seeking membership of any establishment club. Listeners adore him, and trust what he tells them about food. This is a man with the deeply held conviction that everyone, everywhere, has a right to good food, and that anyone or anything that stands in the way of that needs to be investigated and exposed. Even so, there is a less cerebral side to him, too: Cooper is the Bollinger Bolshevik, a gourmand who loves to eat and drink - the great joke about him is that he is, by his own admission, a non-cook, albeit one who is fortunately catered for by an excellent "natural cook" in the form of his wife, Janet. Yet even without any hands-on feel for food, he still manages to convey its many fascinating pleasures without recourse to gushing "cherries-on-the-nose" speak or impoverished banalities. You won't hear Cooper describing something as "Delicious!" or "Yummy!" If there is one thing that is arguably as good as listening to Cooper on the radio, it is reading his prose. Such is his stature as a broadcaster nowadays that it is easy to forget that he is also a formidable writer who has generated a constant stream of articles over the years for publications as diverse as the Guardian, the Listener, Woman's Journal and Saga, the best of which, fortuitously, have now been rescued from newsprint oblivion and collected in a new book, Snail Eggs & Samphire (MacMillan £16.99). There are few places in the world to which Cooper hasn't travelled, so the collection is an extravagant miscellany. It transports you to the Cathay restaurant in Singapore in the 50s and his (thankfully unsuccessful) search for its speciality - Himalayan bear paw soaked in honey. "Sorry," said the waiter, "bear paw off." You'll laugh at his tales of snail eggs, originally a Tibetan speciality "more recherché than curdled yak's milk", seized on by top chefs and tasted at a "snailathon" in a smart London restaurant: "'I'm getting almonds,' said the foodie opposite me. I found the eggs moist and unusual, but I was getting nothing," writes Cooper. His tougher attacks on the food industry, meanwhile, like his radio interviews, are light of touch (he writes, for example, of the Egg Disinformation Service) - and all the more devastating for it. "Reading the pages of the catering press is to be transported into a bleak economy, where time is of the essence, where skilled staff are nonexistent and all food preparation must be accomplished only with cold water and a mixing bowl or microwave." Cooper subjects products such as "fresh-style frozen turkey" to wry forensic examination. The latter title, he observes, represents "a semantic leap forward in food marketing that has released us, in a poetic and creative burst of imagination, from the tyranny of words". One of his greatest skills is understatement, which allows readers and listeners alike to reach their own conclusions. His deep sense of injustice at the north-south inequalities of food production in the UK and man-made food poverty is a theme that runs through the book. Recounting his childhood in the 30s, he writes, "The Mercator map on the school wall seemed to be largely red and I knew that much of what we ate came from the Empire where native peoples toiled eagerly with permanent smiles to produce the raw materials on which our wealth was founded." This is a volume with the attractions of Elizabeth David's An Omelette And A Glass Of Wine: biting, ironic humour, a celebration of simplicity and honesty in cooking, intolerance of industrial processed food, erudite and evocative accounts of splendid meals and precious small-scale foods. In short, a book to have by your bed when you can't listen to the Food Programme.

fields.headline: On the rack
fields.standfirst: Malcolm Gluck's vintage advice: should a wine be left to breathe?
fields.trailText: Malcolm Gluck's vintage advice: should a wine be left to breathe?
fields.body:
The number of readers who have asked this question is so numerous that to list them would exhaust the pages of this issue of Weekend. I have come to the conclusion that, for many people, the question has about it something slightly louche, something secret, as though in asking it an accompanying wink or nudge wouldn't be out of place. Rather as if I was being pumped to provide the name of the dead cert for the 3.30 at Aintree.

Yet there is only a gamble about letting air get to a wine when the bottle is ancient. As when an acquaintance recently, and rather excitedly, revealed that she had been present when a bottle of La Tche 1943, the legendary wine from Domaine de la Romanée-Conti, had been opened. Alas, it went raisiny and sere within minutes of being in the glass. La Tche, like any wine, is anxious to hasten to its inevitable end, which is vinegar (from the French vin aigre or sour wine). The older the wine, the quicker it will reach this condition.

Air is, then, the great enemy of wine, but it is also its great ally. I use it constantly, most especially when I am serving wine at home. It is not enough, though, merely to remove the cork of a wine. This is not letting the wine breathe much beyond the top few centimetres of liquid. Wine - all wine, but in particular red wine - should always be given the chance totally to interact with air. This is achieved most dramatically, yet simply, by using large (three- or four-bottle size) glass jugs into which one or several bottles can be poured - after first having ascertained the wines' perfect state of health (no cork taint, or a variation in quality so as to render a single bottle unfit for marriage).

Whether a red wine is young or old, I always jug it. All wine, whatever self-styled experts may say, is the better for being aerated. Take two of the wines in this week's Superplonk column, the Wolf Blass South Australia Barrel Fermented Chardonnay 1999 and Somerfield's Chilean Cabernet Sauvignon La Rosa 1998. I would jug both, several hours beforehand. With the chardonnay - and I concede the difficulty - you have the problem of keeping the contents cool, but at this time of year I would put muslin or a clean teatowel over the top of the jug and put it outside the kitchen door. The rich acids of the wine will develop and a more exciting wine will emerge. With the cabernet sauvignon, the tannins will soften with the acids and greater perfume and texture emerge.

There is one other interesting side-effect of jugging wine. No dinner guest, invariably male, can pick up a bottle and pontificate over the label for 10 minutes when conversation on more compelling themes is required. Simple jugs add an air of mystery, and indeed great confidence, to any dinner table. Your standing in the community will be greatly enhanced.

fields.headline: Faith, hope, charity
fields.standfirst: At face value, Christianity would seem to have but a peripheral role to play in the cut and thrust of modern life. So how do we explain why this age-old religion is as recognisable and influential today as any multinational brand, asks Cristina Odone
fields.trailText: At face value, Christianity would seem to have but a peripheral role to play in the cut and thrust of modern life. So how do we explain why this age-old religion is as recognisable and influential today as any multinational brand, asks Cristina Odone.
fields.body:
Voluptuous, delicious and mysterious: it's time to uncover the sensual face of Christianity. Tradition paints the churches as goody-goody worshippers of purity, strict adherents to a legacy of hair shirts and denials; but Christianity walks provocatively between the sinful and the celestial, and draws its beauty from rites that please the senses while promising to satisfy the spirit. This is a no-holds-barred religion that speaks easily of "ecstasy" and "adoration", and in superlatives such as "King of kings" and "Holiest of Holies".

Even in our prosaic times, take part in a Christian ritual and you step into a world of wonders that celebrates what God gives rather than what He withholds; abundance, not abstinence, inspires our practices, colours our palette and strengthens our faith. I can shut my eyes and relish memories of certain Christian celebrations. Easter service in the Russian Orthodox cathedral in Washington DC, where the rich brocades of the altar cloth and the scarlet and gold-leaf icons blurred in the sweetly potent clouds of incense that filled my eyes, nose and lungs. A Sunday service in the Comoro Islands, in the Indian ocean, where villagers in boldly coloured cotton turbans and caftans fill the whitewashed, sun-filled church, swaying in the aisles as their voices rise in a joyous rendition of a Ladysmith Black Mambazo gospel song. A holy procession in the backstreets of Naples, where housewives at their windows cast down notes upon the pastel-coloured plaster Virgin that two black-haired altar boys carry between them.

These rituals blend scent and colour, song and texture to celebrate life - not just here on earth, but beyond. Any attempt to define Christians today must pay homage to this rich beauty; to chronicle their world with a collection of black-and-white photographs is to short-change its technicolour brilliance.

In his book The Faces Of Christianity: A Photographic Journey, Abbas, the Iranian-born photographer, does just this. The gently glowing gaze of a Benedictine monk in Fleury and the serene beauty of a young mother, her baby at her breast, dressed up as Madonna and Child in a pilgrimage in Mexico City: these are the images that for Abbas define the Christian aesthetic - an aesthetic he views as rooted, predictably, in serenity and innocence. His "photographic journey" is often one of sombre beauty. The rites he records and the people he depicts are appealing, and often haunting; but to hem in Christianity by duotoned piety is to misrepresent it.

Nothing new in that. Ever since the carpenter's son started agitating for change almost 2,000 years ago, his message has been twisted or manipulated, and his followers have been made into scapegoats. Yet if history is a catalogue of attacks on Christianity, to this day the religion holds us in thrall, informing our laws and social code, our education and the arts. The story of Jesus Christ remains our single greatest narrative; Christian signposts - from Genesis through the Garden of Eden, from his birth to his crucifixion and resurrection - are familiar to believers and unbelievers alike; Christian symbols - the cross, the communion wafer, the fish - instantly recognisable.

In terms of branding, Christianity is up there with Coca-Cola, Walt Disney and Gap - but it will not subside into mood music, or a pair of Mickey Mouse ears we can pick up and wear to entertain. Even today, snug in an atheism that has become commonplace, we come across Christians who give us pause for thought and leave us wondering whether Freud, Nietzsche and Russell really did get it right.

A young volunteer, sitting on the floor of a Catholic home for the disabled, feeding a handicapped child whose head rests in her lap; a middle-aged missionary, who lives and works alongside the villagers in remote Senedongo, Mali, celebrating an al fresco Mass at a makeshift altar of straw; a monk helping Serb refugees in Kosovo load a lorry with their belongings as they prepare to set off on their lives of exile: even two-dimensional and on a page, their wordless sacrifices are unsettling, for the nurses, schoolchildren and farmers, as well as the nuns and priests, whom we see through Abbas's lens, are busy turning our world upside down.

The outcast is embraced, the marginalised moved centre-stage, the voiceless given a megaphone. These subversives are working for a truly "inclusive society": forget the political catchphrase peddled from podiums in Bournemouth and Brighton - theirs is the real thing, an uncomfortable, relentless quest to place others above me-myself-and-I. It's an outrageous message that goes against the grain: don't seek the successful, the A-list celebs, the profit motive or the bottom line; look out, instead, for the weak and the misfit, for the occasion to give everything and to love without bounds.

No wonder Christianity is so unpopular. To paraphrase GK Chesterton, it has been tried, and found too damned difficult. And too damned irreverent. Christians, like the little boy who told the Emperor he was naked, are forever puncturing our self-importance, hinting that, actually, there is something missing from our lives.

That connection with others, the reaching out to the less fortunate, this is their imperative - one that, in the west at least, sounds so foreign now. Foreign, but also alluring, as Abbas - who in the text accompanying his photographs labels himself a "Shiite Muslim sceptic" - clearly shows. He is at once intrigued and impressed by the do-gooders' silent protest at our selfish ways; the heroes of his book are the volunteers who work with the disabled in Lourdes or the malnourished in Mali. His lens rests lovingly on their figures, captures the compassion in their gaze, turns even their pedestrian activities - sharing a meal, packing a lorry - into lyrical statements of a profound humanity.

Onward, Christian soldiers, has always been the churches' marching order - and its Bible-thumping troops have obeyed and colonised the globe. As a result, the world has been transformed; but Christianity, too, has changed its accent, if not its language. From Egypt to Mexico to South Korea, the native communities that have embraced this religion have coloured it with their home-grown rites and rituals - and even superstitions. Thus, in Cape Town you can find a shaman burning money as an offering to the gods in a Baptist church; Christians in South Korea make the pilgrimage to the stone buddhas of Ch'ilburam, near Kyongju; and, in Mexico City, Catholics celebrate the Aztec spirit in a primitive dance.

Its more exotic manifestations will make a vicar in Tunbridge Wells gulp - though, interestingly, Pope John Paul II, who forbids even the discussion of women or married men becoming priests, has no difficulty with some of the pagan practices being incorporated in Christian services. But this liturgical globalisation reveals the appealing self-confidence of a successful and adult religion that can live cheek-to-cheek with local divinities and native devils without feeling threatened.

And yet the marriage of the voodoo doll and the crucifix conveys an ease with multi-ethnicity that the experience in Northern Ireland, say, or Serbia belies. Christianity bestows identity - here I stand, this is what I believe in - but Christian identity has been hijacked by extremists time and again, manipulated to divide and conquer. The tribalism fuelled by Rev Ian Paisley and Slobodan Milosevic finds its impetus in the Old Testament notion of the chosen people - a notion that the New Testament, alas, did not dislodge.

Armed with this mentality, you can promote an us-against-them apartheid of the kind in which factionalism thrives. The ugly Christian, like the ugly American, combines imperial ambitions and a self-righteousness that can justify any abuse - even killing - in the name of their Ideal.

Abbas captures this dark side of Jesus's followers, too, in a succession of troubling portraits: the chin-jutting arrogance of a uniformed member of the Black Order as he steps out of his car in Ulster; the white Seventh Day Adventist family in Ficksburg, South Africa, who attend Saturday service holding a gun and a Bible in the same hand; a demonstrator against abortion in California, eyes closed in pious prayer, while his fellow members sanction the bombing of abortion clinics and the gunning down of doctors who perform abortions. These damning vignettes speak of the intolerance that can pass for authority when the Christian ethic is perverted by bigots. The religion of the powerless here becomes a dangerous weapon in the hands of the power-hungry.

Yet Christian identity can also promote security and order. When their husbands died, my great aunts, then in their 50s, decided to return to their native village and share a house there. In that small Italian village, the two childless women, who had neither a husband nor a fortune to ensure their status, found their identity in their faith. Their Mass attendance (every morning and on Sundays), their membership in the rosary group (which used to pray before the little shrine of San Rocco, the village patron saint, once a month), the endless dinners they offered the parish priest, gave their lives form and substance - and placed them squarely within the village hierarchy (one rung below Signora Gandini, who was married and who had paid for the stained-glass window in the church; one rung above the baker, Rina, who was married and had children, but who never gave more than a few coins to the Sunday collection).

Their religion rooted my aunts in a clearly defined spiritual space as well. They had no doubt that there was life after death, and that they fitted into a divine scheme whose confines were the glorious bliss of heaven and the terrible torment of hell. My great aunts' certainty is echoed in many of the Christians whom Abbas encounters: from the evangelical enthusiasm of the born-agains to the deep-seated calm of the village elders who accept without question all that He brings them, there are endless witnesses to the soothing strength of faith.

I suspect that, like my aunts, these men and women never suffer the existential fears that characterise so many secular lives today. And their example suggests that our state of almost perpetual anxiety stems from our questioning the spiritual order that they accept unblinkingly. We feel vulnerable because we have turned our back on their ancient Christian atlas, which placed us in a universe in which God was firmly in the heavens above; and in the midst of a life that stretched into eternity.

In our harsh new world, instead, we doubt the presence of a guiding spirit, and that our existence goes beyond the here and now. We play out our lives against a backdrop that has been reduced from the eternal to the earthbound. Boxed in this new, man-made landscape, we peer at a world where everything looms larger and more menacing - where talk of a fuel shortage produces chaos, and the sight of a flooded city panic. There is not much room here - as the two young boys who murdered James Bulger have discovered - for forgiveness or the possibility of redemption. And who can blame us? We no longer see ourselves as part of a big picture, or stakeholders in an everlasting community; we are reduced instead to a cluster of individuals wandering aimlessly over a small corner of the universe.

It's a shallow, finite world that we have created, and one that makes us feel precarious as we proceed, terrified of losing our footing. Little wonder, then, that we cast a curious, almost envious eye upon those who, wrapped in their certainties, led by their beliefs, journey forth so determinedly.

In the two millennia since Jesus Christ, theologians and philosophers have devised "proofs" with which to convert the unbeliever. Abbas's book is a small contribution to this tradition - it offers us a glimpse of a people who are not so much chosen as making choices, every day, that bravely reject our so-called truths: that I am at the centre of the universe, that reason is my only guide, and that now alone counts for anything. These Christians' bold conviction animates Abbas's book as it does their lives - and calls our own into question

 Cristina Odone is deputy editor of the New Statesman.
The Faces Of Christianity: A Photographic Journey, photographs and text by Abbas, is published by Abrams on December 1, priced £38. To order a copy at the special price of £34 (plus 99p UK p&p), freephone Guardian CultureShop on 0800 316 6102.

Abbas's book is a small contribution to this tradition - it offers us a glimpse of a people who are not so much chosen as making choices, every day, that bravely reject our so-called truths: that I am at the centre of the universe, that reason is my only guide, and that now alone counts for anything. These Christians' bold conviction animates Abbas's book as it does their lives - and calls our own into question  Cristina Odone is deputy editor of the New Statesman. fields.headline: The lonely princess of bohemia
fields.standfirst: Frustrated that she could not be a writer, an artist or a philosopher, Lady Ottoline Morrell set out to define herself through her wardrobe. And, sure enough, she became one of the most notable and elegant figures of the Edwardian era and beyond. Judith Watt explores the woman and the myth

Perhaps Oscar Wilde lived up to his own dictum: "One should either be a work of art, or wear a work of art." Lady Ottoline Morrell, renowned hostess, muse and patron of artists, pacifist and bohemian, achieved both. Six foot tall, with reams of copper-red hair, turquoise eyes, a long nose and jutting jaw, she wore clothes that had little to do with fashion but everything to do with originality.

So memorable was she that she featured in several works of fiction, including Aldous Huxley's Crome Yellow and DH Lawrence's Women In Love. She also inspired many artists, particularly Augustus John. Her own passion was for clothes - distinctive, sumptuous, relating as much to the baroque styles of her aristocratic ancestors as they did to the Edwardian fashions of her day. The Museum of Costume in Bath recently acquired much of her wardrobe - the archive of her dress and accessories - which illuminates not only her character but also an aspect of the dress of a section of society who made anti-fashion part of their identity.

"Bohemia is the name for the attempt by 19th- and 20th-century artists, writers, intellectuals and radicals to create an alternative world within western society... a social milieu created against the dominant culture," writes cultural historian Elizabeth Wilson in her riveting Bohemians: The Glamorous Outcasts. The Morrell collection now at Bath represents a sartorial attempt to create an alternative world.

"It is very exciting because it has given us the opportunity to study bohemian dress, an important area that has hitherto been rather neglected," says Rosemary Harden of the Costume Museum, who has catalogued the collection and is very enthusiastic about Ottoline. "She was an important figure in cultural life in the earlier 20th century, when bohemianism was more than just a hippy, Thea Porter aesthetic." About 600 pieces of clothing, accessories and miscellaneous textiles and objects were bought from Ottoline's grandson, Adrian Goodman, in March this year, having been carefully preserved for over 60 years by his mother, Julian Goodman.

What emerges from the collection is an indication that Ottoline Morrell was glamorous, idiosyncratic and elegant: not the mad, rather grungy eccentric we have been led to believe. From her death in 1938 until the publication of her biography by Miranda Seymour - Ottoline Morrell, Life On a Grand Scale (1992) - Morrell has been seen through what Seymour calls the "distorting" eyes of the Bloomsbury Group in their copious letters, diaries and memoirs. "Her beauty was forgotten, her religious faith belittled and her generosity derided."

She had sunk from being one of the most remarkable and influential women of her time to the level of caricature: "It is like sitting beneath an arum lily; with a thick golden bar in the middle," wrote Virginia Woolf in 1907, "dropping pollen, or whatever that is which seduces the male bee." She undoubtedly irritated and probably offended people. What is of especial interest now that the collection has come to light is how the clothes are not entirely bohemian. They bear little relation to the Gypsy-style dress of Dorelia John or the arts-and-crafts aesthetic style of Vanessa Bell and Virginia Woolf, and there is only one example from the Omega Workshops of Bell and Roger Fry at Bath. Ottoline did not fit into her own background or adopted milieu so she made herself unique: "An artistic object for display and consumption," as Seymour puts it.

Morrell did not believe that she was beautiful; instead, she became extraordinary. Wearing shoes with two-inch soles and six-inch heels, she exaggerated her height and hennaed her already auburn hair. Only later did she recognise that her compulsion to present such a dramatic appearance made her more isolated: "It's no fun being an oddity for it makes one eternally lonely," she wrote in her diary. "Unfortunately, I combine being an oddity with being very proud, and that makes one aloof."

Ottoline Cavendish-Bentinck belonged to the world of aristocratic privilege, to a family at once conventional and eccentric. Born in 1873, she was the youngest child and only daughter of General Arthur Cavendish-Bentinck, heir to the mysterious fifth Duke of Portland. Her mother Augusta was Irish and instilled in Ottoline a strong religious faith, a love of beautiful clothes and the importance of being an exceptional hostess. Their lives changed when (the general having died) Ottoline's half-brother Arthur inherited the dukedom in 1879 and the family moved to Welbeck, the ancestral home of the Portlands. Aged six, she became Lady Ottoline and entered a world of history and fantasy.

There was a touch of the Gormenghast to Welbeck. The fifth duke had been a recluse. To avoid being seen, he had mined into the foundations of the house, constructing tunnels and rooms, including a magnificent underground riding school lined with chandeliers. There was great excitement as the children explored the place, but what appeared to have the greatest influence on Ottoline was the discovery of family portraits.

"Stacked here were all the pictures belonging to the house - pictures that had come down from generation to generation, but taken out of their frames and set up two or three deep," she wrote. "My love of history was first stimulated by gazing at these old paintings, portraits of the courtiers of James I's court, so elegant and lovely and sentimental, with pearls in their ears and long trailing lovelocks of golden hair hanging over their collars, and of ladies whom they loved, with very low cut dresses, showing pearly breasts, and embroidered skirts and exquisite shoes... portraits of the Countess of Essex who had poisoned Overbury; of Louis XIV... of Charles I... dressed in a green velvet doublet and skirt, with a sad pale face... of pale Arabella Stuart, who had been imprisoned nearby at Bolsover Castle. A small picture of Mary Queen of Scots, who soon became my dearest friend - the exquisite face with a pearl drop on her forehead, and a fine gold cap over her small head - I used to visit very often."

The place was imbued with romance; she found a portrait of the matriarch Bess of Hardwick, Mary's gaoler and the grandmother of the tragic Arabella. The discovery of her ancestor Margaret Lucas, Duchess of Newcastle, the poet, playwright and would-be philosopher whose eccentric appearance fascinated the Restoration court, was not just inspiring: the child identified with her and her later grand style was testament to their connection. "Perhaps, after all, I belonged to the time of hoops and loops and billowing skirts - a rare survival."

Clothes for Ottoline had always been an obsession; her earliest memory is of bursting into tears because her brothers said a dress made her look fat. When she was four, she was given a pair of black dogskin gloves by her father, which she treasured until death. Some 250 years before her birth, the Duchess of Newcastle, as Virginia Woolf wrote in The Common Reader, had been a believer in fairies, pondered the nature of the universe, worried about cruelty to animals, placed intelligence over fashion.

"All I desire is fame," the great lady said - and she got it, primarily through sensationally individual clothes. "I took great delight in attiring, fine dress and fashions, especially such fashions as I did invent myself, not taking that pleasure in such fashions as were invented by others: also I did dislike that any should follow my fashion, for I always took great delight in a singularity, even in accoutrements."

This was a blueprint for Ottoline, and Osbert Sitwell drew the comparison in his Laughter In The Next Room. "With her mass of chestnut hair falling on each side of her face, with her emphatic features, and wearing a yellow gown with a very wide skirt... there was something, too, in her appearance that recalled the portraits of her remarkable ancestress Margaret, Duchess of Newcastle... her way of looking, talking, thinking, her magnificent manner of dressing, her brocades and silks, [were] as natural to her as tweeds to the owner of a fox-terrier."

She married the young solicitor Philip Morrell in 1902. They honeymooned in Italy, and there is a memorable account by Mary Berenson of the bride at Orvieto railway station: "A tall drooping figure in a fur coat and low neck hung all over with jewels and crowned by an immense poke bonnet, on which nodded and trembled an immense array of ribbons and funeral feathers and ends of lace."

Later, Ottoline described herself at this time as "very earnest, full of potentialities, large and unfinished". Morrell became the Liberal MP for South Oxfordshire and later Burnley, shared his wife's pacifism and her interest in art and literature. The Morrells had twins, a boy and a girl, whom they named Julian. The boy died as a baby; the loss of her son was something Ottoline never really recovered from, and it was to create long-lasting difficulties in her relationship with her daughter. Devastated, the Morrells moved to 44 Bedford Square, Bloomsbury, and from 1907 onwards Ottoline threw her energies into a salon, held in two rooms on Thursday evenings.

Her aim as hostess was to invite writers and artists to meet possible patrons, with food and drink, music, talking and dancing. In one room were the artists, in the other the "sedate talkers" such as Henry James and Herbert Asquith. "I rigidly did not invite the smart or fashionable world," she explained. "When one or two stray ones crept in, they upset the harmony and unselfconscious gaiety of the others."

For the next 30 years, at Garsington Manor, Oxfordshire, where she lived from 1915 to 1928, and then at 10 Gower Street, Ottoline was a notable hostess to a variety of people that ranged from James and Asquith to Augustus John and Bertrand Russell, TS Eliot and DH Lawrence to Nijinsky and Diaghilev, Lytton Strachey and Virginia Woolf to Charlie Chaplin. "Conventionality is deadness," she wrote in her diary in 1915. She had found her vocation - "to live," says Seymour, "a life of active benevolence outside the conventions."

Virginia Woolf wrote of Ottoline to her sister Vanessa in 1917 that she had been "so overcome by her beauty that I really felt as if I'd suddenly got into the sea, and heard the mermaids fluting on the rocks". She was an unconventional model for Duncan Grant (who portrayed her as a bird of paradise), Henry Lamb, Simon Bussy, Charles Conder, Augustus John and Dorothy Brett, dressing in clothes inspired by portraits she saw in galleries. "When I see old Italian or Flemish pictures, or modern French or English ones, I know that what they express to me is some individual vision of the world." This individual vision was what she strove to express to the world in dress.

"She was compulsive," Harden, Bath's keeper of collections, believes, "a compulsive hostess, compulsive dresser, compulsive shopper." And compulsive about her appearance - she admitted she looked "rather gorgeous" in 1920 after buying rich yellow fabric to make a dress with a neckline like a "Tudor king's jacket".

Siegfried Sassoon wrote of their first meeting, with Oscar Wilde's friend Robbie Hoss, at Garsington in 1916: "Always original in her style of dress, which was often extremely beautiful, she happened... to be wearing voluminous pale-pink Turkish trousers... It would have made all the difference to me if she had managed to look a bit more like Rossetti's Blessed Damozel."

Although Ottoline belonged to a grand family, she and her husband were not rich but "comfortable". As time went on, they became less so. Almost from the start of the Ottoline myth, she could not afford the couturiers, like Fortuny and Poiret, who would have particularly appealed to her. Instead, her clothes were homemade, a collaboration with her maid, Miss Brenton. Ottoline would have an idea, often inspired by portraits she had seen, and a postcard would be presented to "Brenty". Fabrics were often antique silks bought on bargain- hunting expeditions, exotic material from the east or ecclesiastical fabrics that had the right historical look. She had excellent taste in colour and would choose beautiful muted pinks, golds and yellows, inspired by the colours of Bolsover.

Brenty was no pushover, however, and seems to have exerted some control. "I think the postcard very quaint and pretty but not the style for you," she said on one occasion; and on another, "It is so difficult to keep out of the fashions as the narrow frocks do suit you so much, but we must make our things quaint and unusual by the colouring or embroidering."

The intention was therefore not to be fashionable, but original. In 1913, Ottoline visited Joseph Conrad, wearing a blue Persian jacket over a lavender silk dress having been told that the writer would appreciate a note of "fantasy". "How beautiful your wife looks in her colours against the green," Conrad told Philip Morrell. Yet she kicked against her own creation, saying that she struggled to express her "wild artistic bohemian side" to a world that only noticed her dress and colour sense.

So while she enjoyed creating an image, she was also deeply frustrated - that she was not a writer, artist, philosopher or politician, a person without a vote for more than half a lifetime. This frustration was explored by DH Lawrence in her most famous literary appearance as Hermione Roddice in Women In Love, published in 1920.

His portrayal was perceptive and not entirely hostile: "Now she came along, with her head held up, balancing an enormous flat hat of pale yellow velvet, on which were streaks of ostrich feathers, natural and grey... She wore a dress of silky, frail velvet, of pale yellow colour, and she carried a lot of small, rose-coloured cyclamens. Her shoes and stockings were of brownish grey, like the feathers on her hat; her hair was heavy; she drifted along with a peculiar fixity of the hips, a strange unwilling motion. She was impressive, in her lovely pale-yellow and brownish-rose, yet macabre, something repulsive."

Ottoline felt that it was a devastating betrayal of friendship, but interestingly was specifically angry with him for casting her as an ubiquitous "Liberty mannequin... an awful aesthetic Grosvenor Gallery woman". By representing her as a clotheshorse, however aesthetic, he had made her seem useless. Ottoline was a consummate stylist and Lawrence understood that her inspiration was from a romantic past: "So to the steps up the porch... and into the interior, fragrant with all the memories of old age, and of by-gone, remembered lustiness," he wrote to her of Garsington in 1915.

Augustus John noted perceptively in Chiaroscuro that, "in spite of a dull and conventional upbringing, this fine woman was always prepared to do battle for Culture, Freedom and the People".

Harden admits that she was surprised the first time that she saw the collection: "I'd read about her and knew her to be an eccentric with an extraordinary dress sense," she says. "But however unique one of her dresses might be, it always relates in some way to a contemporary fashion system."

In the museum's collection, the wedding dress in ivory satin is conventional. There is a dress in muted pink damask that could be inspired by quattrocento painting yet reflects the work of the then fashionable Fortuny. Her trademark puffed sleeves, not Edwardian "leg of mutton" but of the mid-17th century, appear in the early 20s, but all the dresses have the dropped waists of the period.

There is a bias-cut frock, very Gertrude Lawrence, in silver lamé brocade from the 30s, which would have been absolutely conventional bar the sleeves. A saffron 19th-century silk bodice and skirt that was worn in her portrait by Cecil Beaton for Vogue seems a homage to her forbear, the Duchess of Newcastle. But there is evidence of her conventional side in a mid-30s blue dress from Peter Jones and, importantly, there is a black satin evening dress by Neil "Bunny" Roger, the couturier, dandy and very grand homosexual, from late in her life.

As she grew older, Morrell became less extreme; returning home from George V's Jubilee celebrations in 1930, she told her friend Robert Gathorne-Hardy brightly, "Did you know? They mistook me for a maypole. They tried to dance round me." It is not that all the dresses look peculiar, says Penelope Ruddock, the museum's curator, "it was the way that she put things together and wore them".

Most exciting is to discover that some of the clothes she wore in portraits painted of her are in this collection. There is a black silk velvet dress with a square neckline edged with seed pearls and beads, for instance. Dress historian Professor Aileen Ribeiro of the Courtauld Institute of Art believes it to be the dress worn in the Augustus John of 1919, held by the National Portrait Gallery. "The artist was - understandably perhaps - worried about his sitter's reaction to the portrait, hoping that she would not find it ill-natured," writes Ribeiro in the excellent Gallery Of Fashion.

It has the Tudor neckline that Ottoline favoured at the time, and the hat in the painting is thought to be one of the big slouch hats on show at Bath. It can, of course, be compared to the broad-brimmed, plumed hats worn by stylish members of the court of Charles I; the Duchess of Newcastle was lady-in-waiting to the Queen. Ottoline has the bravura of a pre-Commonwealth courtier from the "time of hoops and loops and billowing skirts".

The historian David Cecil, a friend to Ottoline, described her as "a princess of the Renaissance risen to shame our drab age". In a postscript to the 1998 edition of the biography, Seymour has written of a sexual element to her relationship with her half-brother, the sixth Duke of Portland, that became evident in her diaries in 1932 and may have lasted until her death in 1938. "It is degrading," she wrote. Also extraordinary, and unpublished, is the fact that the duke would get her to dress up in his wife's gowns by Worth. He had always been embarrassed by Ottoline's "old clothes".

Was this now a final humiliation, to make her "look presentable" in couture, or did she tolerate his foibles, knowing only too well the power of dress to inspire and arouse?

"Ought I always to keep my eyes from looking at kingfishers and dragonflies and peacocks, and rest them only on jackdaws and crows?" she wondered. With her courage, her dragonfly yellows and kingfisher greens, Ottoline was never a mere fashion victim. She deserves to be reassessed as a pioneer in the development of original style - Leigh Bowery, Vivienne Westwood, Isabella Blow and John Galliano are her descendants.

 The Museum of Costume at the Assembly Rooms in Bath is currently preparing an exhibition of the Morrell collection, which is still being catalougued and researched. In the meantime it can be viewed by appointment, tel 01225 477789.

By representing her as a clotheshorse, however aesthetic, he had made her seem useless. Ottoline was a consummate stylist and Lawrence understood that her inspiration was from a romantic past: "So to the steps up the porch... and into the interior, fragrant with all the memories of old age, and of by-gone, remembered lustiness," he wrote to her of Garsington in 1915. Augustus John noted perceptively in Chiaroscuro that, "in spite of a dull and conventional upbringing, this fine woman was always prepared to do battle for Culture, Freedom and the People". Harden admits that she was surprised the first time that she saw the collection: "I'd read about her and knew her to be an eccentric with an extraordinary dress sense," she says. "But however unique one of her dresses might be, it always relates in some way to a contemporary fashion system." In the museum's collection, the wedding dress in ivory satin is conventional. There is a dress in muted pink damask that could be inspired by quattrocento painting yet reflects the work of the then fashionable Fortuny. Her trademark puffed sleeves, not Edwardian "leg of mutton" but of the mid-17th century, appear in the early 20s, but all the dresses have the dropped waists of the period. There is a bias-cut frock, very Gertrude Lawrence, in silver lamé brocade from the 30s, which would have been absolutely conventional bar the sleeves. A saffron 19th-century silk bodice and skirt that was worn in her portrait by Cecil Beaton for Vogue seems a homage to her forbear, the Duchess of Newcastle. But there is evidence of her conventional side in a mid-30s blue dress from Peter Jones and, importantly, there is a black satin evening dress by Neil "Bunny" Roger, the couturier, dandy and very grand homosexual, from late in her life. As she grew older, Morrell became less extreme; returning home from George V's Jubilee celebrations in 1930, she told her friend Robert Gathorne-Hardy brightly, "Did you know? They mistook me for a maypole. They tried to dance round me." It is not that all the dresses look peculiar, says Penelope Ruddock, the museum's curator, "it was the way that she put things together and wore them". Most exciting is to discover that some of the clothes she wore in portraits painted of her are in this collection. There is a black silk velvet dress with a square neckline edged with seed pearls and beads, for instance. Dress historian Professor Aileen Ribeiro of the Courtauld Institute of Art believes it to be the dress worn in the Augustus John of 1919, held by the National Portrait Gallery. "The artist was - understandably perhaps - worried about his sitter's reaction to the portrait, hoping that she would not find it ill-natured," writes Ribeiro in the excellent Gallery Of Fashion. It has the Tudor neckline that Ottoline favoured at the time, and the hat in the painting is thought to be one of the big slouch hats on show at Bath. It can, of course, be compared to the broad-brimmed, plumed hats worn by stylish members of the court of Charles I; the Duchess of Newcastle was lady-in-waiting to the Queen. Ottoline has the bravura of a pre-Commonwealth courtier from the "time of hoops and loops and billowing skirts". The historian David Cecil, a friend to Ottoline, described her as "a princess of the Renaissance risen to shame our drab age". In a postscript to the 1998 edition of the biography, Seymour has written of a sexual element to her relationship with her half-brother, the sixth Duke of Portland, that became evident in her diaries in 1932 and may have lasted until her death in 1938. "It is degrading," she wrote. Also extraordinary, and unpublished, is the fact that the duke would get her to dress up in his wife's gowns by Worth. He had always been embarrassed by Ottoline's "old clothes". Was this now a final humiliation, to make her "look presentable" in couture, or did she tolerate his foibles, knowing only too well the power of dress to inspire and arouse? "Ought I always to keep my eyes from looking at kingfishers and dragonflies and peacocks, and rest them only on jackdaws and crows?" she wondered. With her courage, her dragonfly yellows and kingfisher greens, Ottoline was never a mere fashion victim. She deserves to be reassessed as a pioneer in the development of original style - Leigh Bowery, Vivienne Westwood, Isabella Blow and John Galliano are her descendants.  The Museum of Costume at the Assembly Rooms in Bath is currently preparing an exhibition of the Morrell collection, which is still being catalougued and researched. In the meantime it can be viewed by appointment, tel 01225 477789.

fields.headline: Pilgrims' progress
fields.standfirst: Pumpkin may be indigenous to the continent, but I doubt the settlers were making pies with it
fields.trailText: Pumpkin may be indigenous to the continent, but I doubt the settlers were making pies with it.
fields.body:
Sometimes I think that Thanksgiving is an event conjured up by Hollywood in lavish, homely mode - somewhere between Meet Me In St Louis and Little Women. It is staged every year, ostensibly to banish all ill will and allow peace to prevail. It seems a day made up almost entirely of quaint ritual and food - lots and lots of food. And such food, too: roast turkey, a month before Christmas; corn bread; sweet potatoes cooked with marshmallow. Frankly, it all seems most odd. Charming, but odd.

But then I am just a Brit, one of a dull crowd who do Christmas and, God help us, New Year under duress. Christmas is crabbed by guilt, commercialism and general excess. It has become shorn of its emotional trappings. But to an American, Thanksgiving Day is a complete surrender of hearth, home and hooch to kith and kin from any and all points of the compass. It is an event that travels in the heart and soul of Americans - wherever they may be, the fourth Thursday in November is dedicated to celebrating the survival of the Pilgrim Fathers through their first year on the continent in 1621.

But it hasn't always been the fourth Thursday in November. In fact, the first ever Thanksgiving was in October, when the pilgrims sat down to a feast that they had prepared for their native American benefactors, without whose kindly aid they might well all have perished. Indeed, in Canada, Thanksgiving is still celebrated on the second Monday of October.

Most of the implements, seeds and experience that the pilgrims brought with them were redundant in this new world, and the huts that they built were scant protection against a climate that was savagely cold and relentless compared with the mild, damp English winters they were used to.

Thanksgiving then disappeared off the official agenda for some 200 years, until 1863 when Abraham Lincoln was persuaded to set aside the last Thursday in November for celebration, at least in part due to a campaign orchestrated by the formidable Sarah Josepha Hale, editor of Godey's Lady's Book.

The date was changed to the fourth Thursday in November (you may well ask how many Thursdays can there be in a single month) by President Franklin D Roosevelt in 1939, when he succumbed to the arguments of Federated Department Stores boss, Fred Lazarus Jr, who pointed out that Thanksgiving Day ushered in the Christmas season, and that a longer Yuletide shopathon would be good for the economy.

As we can assume that what was good for the economy was also good for Federated's stores, the story of the changing dates of Thanksgiving Day neatly encapsulates the American belief that you can worship God and Mammon at the same time - even that they are synonymous in many instances.

Curiously, turkey does not seem to have been on the menu of that first-ever Thanksgiving feast. Today, however, it is an established part of the ritual. As at Christmas, it is the smaller ones - weighing 5-6kg - rather than the thunder-thighed behemoths that perform best in the oven. Ideally, they should be free range, as the mass-produced varieties overcook dramatically and become as sawdust.

I think that we must include the sweet-potato-and-marshmallow affair because such a barking-mad confection is a culinary marvel in its own right. The pumpkin, meanwhile, is obligatory - it is indigenous to the continent, even though I doubt that the native Americans or the settlers used them in pies.

Despite this, both dishes cannot be ignored because they play an essential role in what is the embodiment of American unity, bonhomie, camaraderie and contentment. The most potent element of Thanksgiving Day, fittingly, is food - and plenty of it. So let the celebrations begin.

All recipes serve six.

The turkey
The bird is central to the feast, so buy a splendid one - organic, free-range and bronze, hung in the feather a few days before plucking, if possible - and eschew the massed ranks of frozen, bagged matter that has more in common with a morgue than with a kitchen - you and your guests will be all the merrier for a sound investment.

A bird weighing no more than 5-6kg
250g unsalted butter
1 glass white wine

For the stuffing
250g white breadcrumbs
2 large lemons
2 handfuls of picked flat-leaf parsley
1 tsp dried marjoram
1 tsp dried thyme
250g unsalted butter
3 eggs
Sea salt
Fully charged pepper mill

Begin by making the stuffing. Cut the crusts from the bread and lay the slices out on a baking sheet to dry. If you decide that it would be better to complete this part of the operation more easily and speedily in the oven, then by all means do so, but take care not to allow the bread to colour, as this will render the resulting product useless for our purposes. Wash and chop the parsley. Finely zest both of the lemons, and remove the juice from only one of them. Soften the butter, finely crumb the dried bread and mix together with the herbs, lemon and eggs, then season with some salt and pepper.

Pre-heat the oven to 160°C/320°F/ gas mark 3. Push the stuffing inside the bird and tie or skewer to seal the mixture inside the cavity. Liberally butter the bird, lay it on its side on a roasting tray, then cover it with foil and place in the oven. After 90 minutes, turn the bird on to its other side, ensuring that it remains covered with foil, and roast for a further hour. Remove the foil, sit the bird on the roasting tin, and pour over a small glass of white wine before returning it to the oven for a further 30 minutes or so, until it is a deep golden colour.

When your bird displays a rich hue, remove it from the oven and, most important, allow it to sit for at least half an hour before carving, in order to allow the juices to settle.

Sweet potatop with marshmallow
This is Grandmother Tillman's recipe, lifted straight from the pages of the American food bible, Saveur.

60g raisins
40ml sherry
3 medium sweet potatoes
80g soft dark brown sugar
125g unsalted butter
30ml orange juice
1 tsp finely chopped orange zest
tsp ground cinnamon
tsp ground ginger
Pinch ground nutmeg
Pinch ground allspice
40g coarsely chopped pecan nuts
50g pineapple (yes, tinned!)
2 handfuls marshmallow

Pre-heat the oven to 185°C/365°F/gas mark 5. Soak the raisins in sherry until they are soft, about 30 minutes. Drain the raisins, transfer them to a large bowl, and discard the sherry.

Meanwhile, place the sweet potatoes in a roasting tin and bake until tender, about 40 minutes. Allow the potatoes to cool, peel them, purée with a food mill or food processor, and add the raisins. Then add the brown sugar, butter, orange juice, orange zest, spices and mix.

Fold in the pecans and pineapple, then transfer the mixture to a 20cm baking dish. Bake the casserole for 20 minutes, then cover with marshmallows and return to the oven until the marshmallows are golden.

Pumpkin pie
The sublime filling could only come from Chez Panisse, another great standard-bearer of American cuisine. This recipe comes from the wonderful Chez Panisse Desserts, by Lindsey Remolif Shere.

For the pastry
200g flour
100g unsalted butter
1 tsp icing sugar
1 egg yolk
1 tbsp ice-cold water
Pinch of salt

For the filling
1 butternut squash
30g soft dark brown sugar
1 tsp granulated sugar
1 tsp ground cinnamon
tsp ground ginger
tsp ground cloves
A few grinds of white pepper
2 tsp brandy
3 good eggs
1 egg yolk
20ml whipping cream

Mix the butter, flour, salt and icing sugar to a fine crumb, then add the egg yolk and water, and knead lightly to form a dough. Wrap the dough and refrigerate overnight. Roll out the pastry as thinly as possible, and use it to line a 23cm tart case. Leave the case to rest for at least an hour and then line this, in turn, with silicon paper and weight with uncooked beans, rice or somesuch. Bake at 150°C/300°F/gas mark 2, until the pastry turns pale golden in colour and is cooked through.

Split the squash in half, scoop out the seeds and lay it, cut sides down, on a baking sheet with sides to prevent the juices spilling. Bake in the same hot oven for an hour or so, until it is soft. Scoop the flesh from the skin and purée in a food processor.

Pre-heat the oven to 170°C/338°F/gas mark 4. Weigh out 300g of squash flesh (any remaining could be used for ravioli or soup). Whisk in the sugars, spices and brandy. Whisk in the eggs, egg yolk and whipping cream. Pour the mixture into the cooked pastry case and bake for 45 minutes, until it is set. The tart is best eaten when just warm and accompanied by a spoonful of whipped double cream.

Corn bread
Tradition in the southern US demands the use of a quantity of bacon fat to coat the inside of a cast-iron skillet when cooking this bread. It is unlikely that a household in the British Isles has such a thing to hand, so use either duck fat or just good butter instead.

70g plain flour
2 tsp baking powder
325ml full fat milk
1 tsp sea salt
220g coarse corn meal
1 large egg
6 spring onions
1 red chilli pepper
70g butter, melted and cooled

Pre-heat the oven to 210°C/410°F/gas mark 6. Rub a generous amount of butter/fat on the surface of a deep cast-iron pan. Finely chop the pepper and spring onions and put to one side.

In a large bowl, place the flour, corn meal, baking powder, salt, and mix thoroughly. In a separate bowl, beat the egg together with the milk. Pour the milk and butter into the dry ingredients, and mix just enough to bring the ingredients together (over mixing gives a heavier result).

The brave may wish to heat the pan in the oven with the fat before pouring in the batter - this is not really necessary, but I'd recommend it for optimum results. Bake the mixture in the oven for 30 minutes, until the edge turns a pale golden brown and the bread springs back when touched. The best time to enjoy the bread is when it is fresh and warm.
