fields.headline: The child in time
fields.standfirst: At 18, Liesel Evans left the family home in which she'd grown up. Years later, she bought it and moved back. Great memories or what, asks Sophie Radice
fields.trailText: At 18, Liesel Evans left the family home in which she'd grown up. Years later, she bought it and moved back. Great memories or what, asks Sophie Radice.
fields.body:
Have you ever found yourself standing on the outside, looking in at the home you were brought up in? Go on, admit it: many of us find the places that shaped our childhoods completely fascinating.

Some of us have taken this a stage further. Once, I knocked on the door of the home I lived in as a child and explained to a puzzled woman that I was one of the daughters of the couple from whom they had bought their house, and wondered if I could quickly look around. I can't imagine doing that sort of thing now, but at the time I was in my late teens and much more prone to melancholy and self-indulgence.

The poor family gave me a brief tour while I kept a fixed grin and tried to swallow almost overwhelming feelings of longing and sadness - not only because in some ways it was unbearably familiar (there was still the same pink floral shiny wallpaper in the children's bedroom), but also because of the seemingly unnecessary and callous changes that had been made. Why on earth would anyone want to get rid of the perfect 60s kitchen and, God forbid, make the ground floor open-plan? And the garden, the lovely little Eden where so much happened, was blandly redesigned with fancy sunken brickwork and water features.

As if asking for an impromptu tour is not enough, some people actually decide to stay in or move back to the very same house they lived in as a child. For the first-born sons of the aristocracy, it is part of the deal to have the expensive honour of inheriting the familial pile. Most are forced to embark on a desperate financial tightrope between maintenance and radical change: turn it into a conference centre, and you may well incur the wrath of family ghosts and ancient relatives; but if you just continue to leave the north wing open for a handful of visitors a year, you risk it falling into the hands of a pop star - with plans for a recording studio, swimming pool and, horror, central heating.

Nearly nine years ago, Liesel Evans, 34, moved back into the large house in Stoke Newington, London, that she first knew as a two-year-old in the late 60s. She had lived there until she was 18, when she left home for university. Though the house remained in the family, it was rented out to students for several years. Eventually, Liesel's mother began toying with the idea of selling the place when Liesel, who had recently started looking for a house for herself, offered to buy it. "It would be hard to find a lovelier house, and so it just seemed the natural thing to do."

Liesel has painstakingly transformed the place from a memory-sodden home with the William Morris wallpaper, deep-red carpets and 70s furniture of her childhood into somewhere that is indelibly stamped with her personality and taste. The colour scheme is bold, while large pieces of furniture are mixed with a collection of knick-knacks and trinkets, shoes and photos from around the world. It all goes to make the home feel striking and dynamic, rather than depressingly nostalgic.

Liesel's obvious need to make her mark has sometimes brought disapproval from the rest of her family: "Every time I do something new there are raised eyebrows, because if there was already a perfectly good bathroom it is difficult for them to see why on earth I would want a whole new one. I took the garden on in a way it had never been taken on before, conquering the 'jungle' that my brother and I used to take such delight hiding in, and making a beautiful, lush but fairly orderly garden. As for the new kitchen, it was considered grossly extravagant."

It was not only Liesel's family who found it difficult that she had taken over the family home, but also friends who had known her since childhood. "They seemed to find it a bit awkward at first, as if they couldn't quite relax because they thought my mum might walk in and ask what they were doing smoking in the sitting-room." The neighbours, too, seemed slightly confused to begin with, as very few of them had moved away since Liesel had originally lived there. "At first, I could tell that they thought it odd that they now had to view me as a responsible homeowner, whereas only a few years earlier I had been the errant teenage daughter. In fact, it has made me feel even more secure having pretty much the same neighbours as I always did, even though the surrounding area has changed so much. It is so much more gentrified now."

There was a natural and respectful pause of about six months or so before Liesel could bring herself to start redecorating, and she needed to have a couple of lodgers in order to finance any changes, anyway. Not surprisingly, one of the first things she decided was that her rather sumptuous and ladylike bedroom would be the one room that had been out of bounds to her and her brother as children. "The house was always very lively because not only did we always have lodgers but it became a place where my brother and my friends would always congregate before they went out, and my mum must have needed a bolt-hole," she explains. "I was being quite daring by truly staking my claim and making that room my bedroom."

Liesel took in her own lodgers. One of them, Leo Burley, she found particularly irritating because he was messy and did not seem to have any respect for her home and what she was trying to do with it. One week, she was complaining to friends about him; the next, she found that they had fallen in love. "It took us both completely by surprise. We thought we loathed each other and then discovered that the mutual feeling was actually something else."

They married a year later and have lived in the house ever since. "At first, Leo really wanted us both to move out and start again because it didn't feel it could really be ours. That is why the kitchen extension became so important, because it was a major work that we had decided upon together."

The extension is impressively modern, contrasting with the elegant and rather traditional living room - with its Patrice Butler chandelier and chaise longue - which it leads on to. Though they had to lose some of the garden to build it, they were able to to create a large dining area as well. As always with such projects, building the kitchen was a nightmare, reminding me of an architect friend who once said that the most emotionally fraught of all architecture is the extension and that it is "often a compensation for not moving, spreading your wings just a little bit".

Elsewhere in the house, Leo's personality is there, too, moving it away even more from its past into its new identity. Now, there is little left to connect it with its former life - except, that is, for the stair carpet. "I found myself unable to deviate from having a red stair carpet, just like my mum had chosen," says Liesel. "So that is my tribute to the house as it was."

fields.headline: Make mine a...
fields.standfirst: Leapfrog
fields.trailText: Leapfrog
fields.body:
Okay, here's a party game. Think of a whisky beginning with L and ending in G, and that tastes of seaweed, iodine and peat. Laphroaig? Got it in one. Except the bottler of these particular casks, Murray McDavid, has not been allowed to use the L-word, so it has to call it Leapfrog instead. If you're hooked on the distinctive, almost medicinal, flavour of Laphroaig, you won't be disappointed. This is textbook Islay malt: 12 years old, 46%, uncoloured, unfiltered, with a reek of peat.

So who drinks it? Clearly not the directors of Allied Domecq, which owns the original brand name and is still peeved about the whole business. Sophisticated malt drinkers, says Murray McDavid, and it has a point, because this is hardly a beginner's dram. Other admirers are canny speculators, who realise that the name Leapfrog may well disappear once the dispute is finally settled, no doubt increasing the value of any remaining bottles astronomically. In fact, I might just pop to Oddbins,which sells it for £27.99, and buy one.

fields.headline: Superplonk
fields.standfirst: Macolm Gluck tries out supermarket wines
fields.trailText: Macolm Gluck tries out supermarket wines.
fields.body:
Even though the number of wine merchants and off-licences has shrunk dramatically in the past 30 years, the wine market as a whole has enjoyed a spectacular boom. The supermarkets dominate proceedings, with well over 70% of drinkers buying their wines there, while the high-street wine chains have either merged or have been swallowed up by bigger operators.

The latest get-together, which no one could have predicted, is Sainsbury and Oddbins. Not that the former has swallowed the latter, but the two have announced a joint venture, to be launched next year, selling via mail order and the internet.

Now, you might think that all this activity has led to restriction of choice and more homogeneity among wine ranges. Not a bit of it. It has even encouraged other players, such as Unwins, Asda and Somerfield, to be more ambitious. Unwins gobbled up Fuller's wine shops, and Asda let itself be consumed by Wal-Mart, which has only increased the opportunities to find high-rating bargains on both of these retailers' shelves. Somerfield continues to remain competitive by offering wine at crazy prices.

Unwins, for example, has a rich choice of exotic merlots. La Palmeria Merlot 2000 (16.5 points out of 20, £4.99), from Chile, has a biting leather-lush richness with a cassis and coffee undertone - this is a lovely merlot for a fiver (and the no less tasty 1999 vintage is said to be at Sainsbury and Oddbins). Vina Porta Limited Edition Merlot 1999 (16 points, £4.99), also from Chile, is throatily dry and generously textured with a touch of leathery cheroot. Valdivieso Merlot 1999 (16.5 points, £4.99), from Chile, too, parades terrific tannins to back up the chocolate-drop richness, and the result is a warmly textured mouthful. This wine is also at Victoria Wine, Thresher and Sainsbury. Casa Donoso Merlot 1999 (16.5 points, £4.99), likewise from Chile, has marvellous, tobacco-edged richness and fruity aplomb. This is a superbly textured wine with a melt-in-the-mouth scrumptiousness.

On the white side, Unwins (and also Waitrose) has Canepa Semillon Colchagua Valley 1999 (16.5 points, £3.99), from Chile, which has nutty richness and elegance. Gently crisp gooseberries, a hint of melon, a touch of lemon - for such style the price is fantastic. Bright Brothers Argentine Dry White (15.5 points, £3.49) is also great value. This is a dry wine of demure fruit and assured manners.

At Asda there is Porcupine Ridge Sauvignon Blanc 2000 (16 points, £4.98), from South Africa. This is disarmingly prickly and classically styled in everything except the lingering hint of creamy pineapple and peach. Danie de Wet Chardonnay 2000 (16 points, £3.99), also from the Cape, is elegant and well tailored. It's a stunning bargain of delicacy and fruity stealth. Casas del Bosque Chardonnay 1999(16.5 points, £5.49), from Chile, has touches of yoghurt to the ripe melon and lemon, but these are not overdone and so the extreme reached is poised between charming concentration and fresh fruitiness. Villa Maria Private Bin Chardonnay 1998 (17.5 points, £6.97), from New Zealand, has gentility of woodiness allied to delightful fruit with beautifully balanced acids. A superb example of Kiwi chardonnay at a price that is world-beating, this is a captivating wine of panache yet subtlety. This wine is also at Waitrose.

Wolf Blass South Australia Barrel Fermented Chardonnay 1999 (16.5 points, £6.92) has always been a big, deep wine, but in this vintage it exhibits a finesse to the acidity often missing in previous vintages. Oddbins and Victoria Wine have this wine also. But they don't have Chateau Gigault Côtes de Blaye 1998 (Asda, 16.5 points, £8.99), a claret to force a fancy left-banker, at three times the price, to blush with embarrassment. It has lovely blackcurrant spiciness and earthy richness backed up by delightful tannins. Very elegant, fruity and deep, this is a hugely attractive wine for rich food.

However, you can spend £2.99 and get a 16.5-point beauty. Somerfield's Chilean Cabernet Sauvignon La Rosa 1998 is going for a song until November 28, and its cassis, plum and coffee fruit, backed by graceful tannins, make for a marvellous treat.

fields.headline: Give yourself a break
fields.standfirst: There are 37 shopping days left to Christmas. But should you worry? This week Jobs & Money sets out to find the alternatives - such as donating cash, buying    green gifts and volunteering to help others - to the annual spending binge in the high streets and shopping malls of Britain. We look at charity Christmas cards and check out how much of the cover price actually reaches needy causes. And what if your presents turn out to   have come from a grotty grotto? And then we examine your rights, and the best ways to avoid a financial hangover
fields.trailText: There are 37 shopping days left to Christmas. But should you worry? This week Jobs & Money sets out to find the alternatives - such as donating cash, buying green gifts and volunteering to help others - to the annual spending binge in the high streets and shopping malls of Britain. We look at charity Christmas cards and check out how much of the cover price actually reaches needy causes. And what if your presents turn out to have come from a grotty grotto? And then we examine your rights, and the best ways to avoid a financial hangover.
fields.body:
Charities need your help

Bereft of Christmas present ideas? £20 will buy a couple of book tokens, but the same amount will pay for literacy classes for 10 adults in Angola. Two Christmas chart-topping CDs will set you back £30, but could instead provide a medical kit to care for the healthcare needs of a Vietnamese village.

The idea of skipping Christmas presents and giving the money to worthy charitable causes instead will hardly appeal to children. But it is catching on among adults - neatly sidesteping the horror of traipsing through shopping malls during the pre-Christmas rush.

In the US and Australia, it has become common for charities to supply Christmas gift cards showing that "A gift has been made in your name towards ... maintaining a school/providing medicine/digging a well, etc" and the concept is now beginning to appear in Britain.

Trocaire, a sister charity to Cafod in Ireland, this week launched its Global Gift Campaign, where it gives individual donors Christmas cards with a gift certificate enclosed, detailing where the money has been spent, to post on to friends and relatives.

Help The Aged is also encouraging people to join its Adopt a Granny scheme, costing from £15 per month.

The Inland Revenue can help too. The government's Gift Aid scheme is financially the most effective way to donate cash at Christmas. Any charity receiving a donation from a UK taxpayer can reclaim basic rate tax, currently 22% on the gift. In cash terms, that means that a £50 donation is actually worth £64.10 once the charity has reclaimed the tax, at no extra cost to the donor. Higher rate taxpayers can reclaim the difference between higher and basic rate tax, currently 18% for themselves.

Gift Aid is remarkably simple; donors don't have to sign a form to make the donation - all they have to do is tell the charity their name and address and confirm they are a UK taxpayer.

Another easy way to give at Christmas is to open a CharityCard Account. Card holders can nominate any charity for their donation, and the organisers, the Charities Aid Foundation will arrange for the charity to receive the basic rate tax.

Oxfam has 840 shops selling a wide range of Christmas gifts sourced from Fair Trade, which promotes goods made in the Third World. Its top seller is Christmas Crackers at £9.99 for six "family" crackers or £12.99 for the luxury version. Each contains a Fair Trade gift.

By Patrick Collinson

 Charities Aid Foundation, www.caf.org or www.charitycard.org, tel 0345 626655; Help The Aged, www.helptheaged.org.uk, tel 0207253 0253; Cafod, www.cafod.org.uk, tel 020 7733 7900; Trocaire, www.trocaire.org; Oxfam, www.oxfam.org.uk, tel 01865 311311. Fair Trade's on-line shop is at http://store1.europe.yahoo.com/oxfam-uk

Animal attraction

There are no shortage of environmentally friendly, socially responsible and energy efficient gift options.

The Natural Collection boasts one of the more eclectic selections of eco-friendly gifts. The Bath-based company, a trading partner of Friends of the Earth, is offering unisex T-shirts made from 100% organic cotton (£10), handcrafted forest vine table mats from the Philippines (from £9.95), and plant-based candles derived from natural sources including coconut oil and scented with pure aromatherapy oils (from £3.50).

Or what about giving a growing tree? From £18 including postage and packing, Shropshire-based Trees Direct will send a friend or relative a carefully-packed tree complete with planting instructions. There are more than 30 trees on offer from English oak, walnut and silver birch to eucalyptus, olive and monkey puzzle.

If you would rather support up-and-coming young businesses than hand your cash to the high street giants, try a new website set up to promote the wares of some of the UK's newest designers who were helped on their way by The Prince's Trust. Gifts on sale at its website and at the shop in the King's Road, London, include funky handbags, briefcases and rucksacks made from recycled rubber by Inner Tube (prices start from £35); contemporary and colourful freeblown decanters and other glassware by Loco Glass (from £25).

Animal lovers can help to save endangered species and fund vital research by adopting an animal. Typically with the zoo schemes the adoption lasts a year and the recipient gets a photo, certificate, complimentary tickets and their name up on one of the "thank you" boards. At London Zoo you can adopt everything from a piranha (£25) to a pygmy hippo (£3,000). A "share" of an animal costs £35. At Whipsnade you pay one price - £40 - whatever animal you choose, from alpaca to zebra, while at tropical bird haven Paradise Park in Hayle, Cornwall, home of the World Parrot Trust macaws and flamingoes are just two of the species you can take under your wing (cost: £30-£100).

If you'd prefer to sponsor a creature living in the wild, you can adopt a Moray Firth dolphin or a Canadian whale via the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society which offers four categories of adoption ranging from junior (£15.95) to adult friend (£24.50).

There are seven dolphins and five orcas (killer whales) to choose from, each of which is profiled on the website.

By Rupert Jones

 The Natural Collection, www.naturalcollection.com tel 01225 404010; Trees Direct, www.treesdirect.co.uk tel 01588 680280; The Prince's Trust, www.princestrustshop.co.uk tel 020 7823 8292; London Zoo (www.londonzoo.com, tel 020 7722 3333), Whipsnade, www.weboflife.co.uk/whipsnade tel 0870 520 0123; World Parrot Trust, www.paradisepark.org.uk tel 01736 753365; Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society, www.wdcs.org.uk, tel 0870 870 5001.

The gift of time

If the thought of impersonating Jim Royle this Christmas appals you, slumped in your seat watching usual recipe of blockbuster films and TV specials, there is another option. It has never been easier for busy workers to volunteer their time over the festive period to support the less well off.

The National Association of Volunteer Bureaux is at the apex of some 360 individual volunteer bureaux scattered about the country. The national centre will identify a local office that can in turn put the caller in touch with community projects or charities in their area.The beauty of the system is that people who have had little contact with local groups can find a quick and easy way to get in touch.

The network runs in parallel with a new initiative run by the New Economic Foundation and the charity Fairshares and supported by the government's active community unit. It's an import from the US where over 250 schemes operate. It is a kind of Lets scheme that allows people to perform tasks when they can to build up "time credits" to buy care and support from other community members. Anyone can join who feels they, a friend or a relative might benefit.

Most of the charities that offer support for the elderly, homeless and disabled hold one-off functions or projects at this time of year, including Barnardo's, National Children's Homes and Age Concern. At the Salvation Army's 800 centres nationwide, volunteers are asked to cook and serve dinners both in the run up to Christmas and on the big day itself, take dinners out to house-bound people, transport elderly people around and make up hampers.

Crisis at Christmas, run by homelessness charity Crisis, is an obvious choice for volunteers repelled by groups with a religious bent. It runs a net work of shelters for the homeless that need thousands of volunteers.

Business in the Community is a not-for profit organisation supported by hundreds of businesses (The Guardian is a member).

It is rolling out a scheme called Cares Incorporated, where it acts as a broker matching community groups with businesses. For example, pensioners in a care home will request a trip to see a pantomime and CaresInc will allocate the job to a company. Currently there are established centres in London, Leeds, Manchester, Cardiff, Liverpool and many other towns and cities.

Kevin Cowdell, manager of Liverpool Cares, says over Christmas its Secret Santa scheme is supported by the likes of Barclays, Swiss Life, Littlewoods, Manweb, Royal & Sun Alliance and the City council. PricewaterhouseCoopers has agreed with Leeds Cares to put on a kids party for the charity Women's Health Matters targeted at single mums with children between 9-11 - one of many similar projects.

Comic Relief is gearing up for day of mirth and mayhem when its television special hits the screens on March 16 2001 and is looking for volunteers to join in.

By Phillip Inman

 National Assoc of Volunteer Bureaux, www.navb.org.uk, tel 0121 633 4555; Timebank,www.timebanks.co.uk, tel 0870 702 7428; Cares Incorporated, wwwcaresinc.org.uk; Crisis at Christmas, www.crisis.org.uk, tel 020 7655 8300; Salvation Army www.salvationarmy.org.uk tel 020 7367 4500; comicrelief.co.uk tel 020 7820 5555.

The organic option

Fancy an organic Christmas? All the major supermarkets are stocking organic versions of all the usual food, but for many people buying from the big chains defeats a part of the object of organic - getting as close to the source of food as possible.

A spokesman from the Soil Association, the body which grants organic certification in this country, says: "Buying from farmers' markets, farm shops and box schemes means that you are supporting the local producers in your area. It is a great way to give financial support at the same time as getting to know more about where your food is coming from."

The first farmers' market was set up in Bath in 1997 and the concept has grown fast: there are now more than 200 throughout the UK. Producers come from a 20-30 mile radius to sell their (mostly) organic foods - the official definition for the markets is a place selling food "reared, caught, brewed, pickled, baked, smoked or processed by the stallholder" - and are charged just a small stall fee.

Most of the country is now covered by a fruit or vegetable box delivery scheme. Some are nationwide, although this again removes the buying locally element, and they tend to be cheaper than supermarkets for organic produce as overheads are lower. The Soil Association has voted Organic Connections International of Wisbech near Cambridge as top box retailer this year. Organic Connections charges £13.50 per box, which will contain core fruit and vegetables for a Christmas lunch as well as seasonal variants and some produce from co-operatives in France, Italy and Spain. It also sells organic pet food.

Also on the Soil Association website is a list of organic retailers specialising in Christmas food, from turkeys to more esoteric fare such as Boxing Day game and port pies. Providence Farm in north Devon will send its meat, lamb, beef, chicken, duck and guinea fowl anywhere in the UK. A 10kg beefbox is £79.50 or a 12kg mixed poultry box costs £75 plus postage and packing. Pimhill Farm in Shrewsbury sells mostly from its farmshop, but will send goods by mail order. Produce includes organic turkeys at £8.35 a kilo, Christmas pudding, iced Christmas cake made by the farm's chef, mince pies and chocolate truffle roulade soaked in organic brandy.

Sedlescombe Vinyard in Sussex sells a dry and medium organic white wine for £7.75 and a dryish sparkling white for £14.95. For alternative Christmas drinks, Broughton Pastures sells organic mead and ginger, blackcurrent and elderflower wines, all at £5.50 a bottle.

fields.bodyText: Charities need your help Bereft of Christmas present ideas? £20 will buy a couple of book tokens, but the same amount will pay for literacy classes for 10 adults in Angola. Two Christmas chart-topping CDs will set you back £30, but could instead provide a medical kit to care for the healthcare needs of a Vietnamese village. The idea of skipping Christmas presents and giving the money to worthy charitable causes instead will hardly appeal to children. But it is catching on among adults - neatly sidesteping the horror of traipsing through shopping malls during the pre-Christmas rush. In the US and Australia, it has become common for charities to supply Christmas gift cards showing that "A gift has been made in your name towards ... maintaining a school/providing medicine/digging a well, etc" and the concept is now beginning to appear in Britain. Trocaire, a sister charity to Cafod in Ireland, this week launched its Global Gift Campaign, where it gives individual donors Christmas cards with a gift certificate enclosed, detailing where the money has been spent, to post on to friends and relatives. Help The Aged is also encouraging people to join its Adopt a Granny scheme, costing from £15 per month. The Inland Revenue can help too. The government's Gift Aid scheme is financially the most effective way to donate cash at Christmas. Any charity receiving a donation from a UK taxpayer can reclaim basic rate tax, currently 22% on the gift. In cash terms, that means that a £50 donation is actually worth £64.10 once the charity has reclaimed the tax, at no extra cost to the donor. Higher rate taxpayers can reclaim the difference between higher and basic rate tax, currently 18% for themselves. Gift Aid is remarkably simple; donors don't have to sign a form to make the donation - all they have to do is tell the charity their name and address and confirm they are a UK taxpayer. Another easy way to give at Christmas is to open a CharityCard Account. Card holders can nominate any charity for their donation, and the organisers, the Charities Aid Foundation will arrange for the charity to receive the basic rate tax. Oxfam has 840 shops selling a wide range of Christmas gifts sourced from Fair Trade, which promotes goods made in the Third World. Its top seller is Christmas Crackers at £9.99 for six "family" crackers or £12.99 for the luxury version. Each contains a Fair Trade gift. Fair Trade's on-line shop is at http://store1.europe.yahoo.com/oxfam-uk Animal attraction There are no shortage of environmentally friendly, socially responsible and energy efficient gift options. The Natural Collection boasts one of the more eclectic selections of eco-friendly gifts. The Bath-based company, a trading partner of Friends of the Earth, is offering unisex T-shirts made from 100% organic cotton (£10), handcrafted forest vine table mats from the Philippines (from £9.95), and plant-based candles derived from natural sources including coconut oil and scented with pure aromatherapy oils (from £3.50). Or what about giving a growing tree? From £18 including postage and packing, Shropshire-based Trees Direct will send a friend or relative a carefully-packed tree complete with planting instructions. There are more than 30 trees on offer from English oak, walnut and silver birch to eucalyptus, olive and monkey puzzle. If you would rather support up-and-coming young businesses than hand your cash to the high street giants, try a new website set up to promote the wares of some of the UK's newest designers who were helped on their way by The Prince's Trust. Gifts on sale at its website and at the shop in the King's Road, London, include funky handbags, briefcases and rucksacks made from recycled rubber by Inner Tube (prices start from £35); contemporary and colourful freeblown decanters and other glassware by Loco Glass (from £25). Animal lovers can help to save endangered species and fund vital research by adopting an animal. Typically with the zoo schemes the adoption lasts a year and the recipient gets a photo, certificate, complimentary tickets and their name up on one of the "thank you" boards. At London Zoo you can adopt everything from a piranha (£25) to a pygmy hippo (£3,000). A "share" of an animal costs £35. At Whipsnade you pay one price - £40 - whatever animal you choose, from alpaca to zebra, while at tropical bird haven Paradise Park in Hayle, Cornwall, home of the World Parrot Trust macaws and flamingoes are just two of the species you can take under your wing (cost: £30-£100). If you'd prefer to sponsor a creature living in the wild, you can adopt a Moray Firth dolphin or a Canadian whale via the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society which offers four categories of adoption ranging from junior (£15.95) to adult friend (£24.50). There are seven dolphins and five orcas (killer whales) to choose from, each of which is profiled on the website. The gift of time If the thought of impersonating Jim Royle this Christmas appals you, slumped in your seat watching usual recipe of blockbuster films and TV specials, there is another option. It has never been easier for busy workers to volunteer their time over the festive period to support the less well off. The National Association of Volunteer Bureaux is at the apex of some 360 individual volunteer bureaux scattered about the country. The national centre will identify a local office that can in turn put the caller in touch with community projects or charities in their area.The beauty of the system is that people who have had little contact with local groups can find a quick and easy way to get in touch. The network runs in parallel with a new initiative run by the New Economic Foundation and the charity Fairshares and supported by the government's active community unit. It's an import from the US where over 250 schemes operate. It is a kind of Lets scheme that allows people to perform tasks when they can to build up "time credits" to buy care and support from other community members. It runs a net work of shelters for the homeless that need thousands of volunteers. fields.headline: The questionnaire
fields.standfirst: Ruben Gonzalez
fields.trailText: Ruben Gonzalez
fields.body:
Ruben Gonzalez was born in Santa Clara, Cuba, in April 1917. By 1941, he was a full-time musician. Recognised as one of the greatest Cuban piano players, he retired in the mid-80s having played with major orchestras and the pioneering band leader Arsenio Rodriguez. In 1996, Gonzalez began to play professionally again, making now legendary recordings with the Afro Cuban All Stars band and then the Buena Vista Social Club. His new album, released on the World Circuit label, is called Chanchullo.

What is your idea of perfect happiness?
Playing the piano - that is what I like most in my life - and sex. What is your greatest fear?
Not being able to play piano any more.
With which historical figure do you most identify?
Arsenio Rodriguez and Enrique Jorrin - they taught me all I know about music and life.
Which living person do you most admire?
Arsenio Rodriguez - in my mind, he lives for ever.
What is the trait you most deplore in yourself?
When I make a mistake.
What is your favourite journey?
Walking every morning in Old Havana.
What or who is the greatest love of your life?
My wife, Eneida - she gave me my son and we've had very happy times.
What vehicles do you own?
I used to have a lot of cars, but now other people drive me.
What objects do you always carry with you?
An image of Jesus.
For what cause would you die?
I'm 83, so I don't like to think about it.
Which living person do you most despise?
Nobody, I don't think like that - I prefer to think of my music.
Have you ever said 'I love you' and not meant it?
Maybe when I was young and on the road. Anyone in the band would easily say 'I love you' to a lovely lady - we were young and discovering the world, so why not?
What is your greatest regret?
Not training to be a doctor.
When and where were you happiest?
Having been retired for so long and then to be part of the Buena Vista phenomenon has made me very happy.
How do you relax?
Playing piano.
How often do you have sex?
I would like to say every day, but this would be a lie, right?
What single thing would improve the quality of your life?
Being young again.
How would you like to die?
I'll outlive you all.

fields.headline: Aiming High
fields.standfirst: He was dismissed as a drunk for being too convincing in Fear And Loathing. Now with Way Of The Gun, Benicio Del Toro takes a sobering look at violence
fields.trailText: He was dismissed as a drunk for being too convincing in Fear And Loathing. Now with Way Of The Gun, Benicio Del Toro takes a sobering look at violence
fields.body:
Benicio Del Toro's mumbling hood, Fenster, was killed off early in The Usual Suspects, but the actor made enough of an impression for critics to complain about his lack of screen time. To show there are no hard feelings, Del Toro has reteamed with Suspects writer Christopher McQuarrie for his directorial debut, The Way Of The Gun. It marks part of a return to form for Del Toro, who has hardly been seen since Terry Gilliam's Fear And Loathing In Las Vegas. He's also coming up in Ken Loach's Bread And Roses, and Steven Soderbergh's eagerly awaited Traffic.

So, how did you and Chris get together on this?

We were in some coffee shop, talking about the pros and cons of doing films for the big studios, and at some point we said, "Hey, why don't we do our own little movie?" I've always thought Chris was a natural-born director.

But wasn't he considering leaving the movie business because he was unable to get a movie made?

Yeah, he was having one of those days where you feel like you're completely disconnected from the world. He definitely wanted to make a comment about where he stands with The Way Of The Gun. There is a lot of stuff in it about how he feels about people in Hollywood and the big studios. Like there's a scene where my character is sitting down with Jimmy Caan, and they talk about how criminals today are all for the posture. That's like saying film-makers, studios, and movies today are all about the package and not about substance.

Is that how you also feel? Until your cameo in Snatch, we hadn't seen you for a while.

After Fear And Loathing I got turned down a couple of times because people said I was a drunk. I even heard from a friend of mine that people thought I was in rehab. They looked at the performance and thought, "The guy's gone crazy. Look how fat he got, and how fucked up he is in the movie." I think that influenced people in the industry to make certain decisions.

The Way Of The Gun is one of several crime films you've done. What attracts you to the genre?

I'm not necessarily attracted to crime films, I think it's just the way the cookie crumbles. Hunter [S Thompson] said I have a guilty face. One thing I was interested in doing with The Way Of The Gun, though, was making a crime film where nothing's glamourised. It would be painful and more realistic. Kinda old school.

Despite the violence, the film appears to be offering an anti-gun message.

I think it does. The way we handle guns in the film, we wanted to treat them serious. I went to school in weapons for that film, and I think anyone who's going to own a gun should do the same. Then you decide whether you want to get one or not.

The message of the film seems to have been missed by a lot of American critics.

Yeah, completely. All they saw was a violent movie, and they didn't like it. But I think it's a smart film, too, for a more mature audience. In America it was marketed like it was for early-20s/teenagers but it's kind of like a film for an older generation. It's straight to the point. It's not flashy and I'm very proud of that.

So, what do you think about guns in movies generally?

We've done a lot of films with weapons that make people laugh, like Pulp Fiction, and they're fun. But now I think you should teach something. Those things have the power of God. You can just turn the lights off any time you want. I think the law should say: "If you want to play with guns in the movies, show me the horror."

fields.headline: Halo Boys
fields.standfirst: Those three little girls who went to police academy are back, but thankfully they haven't grown up too much. Joe Queenan enjoys a cartoonishly camp send-up of the hit 70s TV series
fields.trailText: Those three little girls who went to police academy are back, but thankfully they haven't grown up too much. Joe Queenan enjoys a cartoonishly camp send-up of the hit 70s TV series
fields.body:
The past month has been very kind to moviegoers who like to see beautiful young women dressed in preposterous outfits. First, Elizabeth Hurley ran through the usual gamut of male fantasies - policewoman, nurse, cheerleader, schoolgirl, Satan - in Bedazzled. Now Cameron Diaz turns up as a belly dancer, Lucy Liu does a brief turn as a charismatic dominatrix, Drew Barrymore lights up the screen as a car mechanic literally bursting out of her overalls, and all three femmes fatales surface as members of an unlikely hot-pants-clad Alpine oompah band in Charlie's Angels.

For the past few years, Hollywood has repeatedly tried to repackage popular old television programmes into profitable movies, and the results have generally been disastrous. The Wild, Wild West, The Flintstones, Inspector Gadget, Dragnet and The Mod Squad were all unwatchable, and The Avengers was even worse. To date, only the Mission: Impossible franchise has passed muster in this genre. To its ranks can now be added Charlie's Angels, an often cartoonish but none the less entertaining film.

To its credit, Charlie's Angels is not merely a campy send-up of the brain-dead 70s cop show starring Farrah Fawcett's hair, Jaclyn Smith's breasts, Cheryl Ladd's rear, Kate Jackson's winning smile, Shelly Hack's legs and Tonya Roberts. Instead, it is an equal mixture of campy send-up and good-natured action flick. In the end, it comes across as an all-girl Jackie Chan movie. With fewer stunts but a lot more T&A.

It must be pointed out that although Charlie's Angels was a beloved TV programme, it wasn't actually any good. The plots were idiotic: any excuse to get the girls into swimsuits. None of the actresses on the show ever transferred their success to the big screen; this may be because they were not very good actresses, though that certainly never hurt Demi Moore's career.

By contrast, Charlie's Angels, the movie, can draw on the estimable resources of Cameron Diaz, the most appealing young actress working today. A natural clown with unconventional good looks, Diaz brings to this project the same engaging daftness that worked so well in My Best Friend's Wedding and There's Something About Mary. Goofy, vivacious, not at all reluctant to shake her moneymaker - in fact, all of her moneymakers - Diaz has quietly emerged as the film industry's Anti-Gwyneth. Thank God somebody did.

Charlie's Angels also stars the intense, seductive, but somewhat monochromatic Lucy Liu and the game, if slightly miscast, Barrymore.

As was the case in the TV show, the Angels are three multi-faceted young women who work as private detectives/crimebusters for a man they have never met. They learn of their assignments via an intermediary called Bosley, here played by Bill Murray. Murray has recently made a habit of giving stellar performances in supporting parts (Ed Wood, Rushmore), but this is not one of them. Charlie's Angels is all about the Angels, which is just as well because they look a lot better in those Alpine outfits than he does.

As the film begins, the Angels have been hired to find a kidnapped billionaire known as a brilliant software designer. This brings them face to face - or, in this case, cheek by jowl - with Tim Curry, delivering his stock performance as the cheeky rogue. Curry's right-hand man is Crispin Glover, a sadistic, chain-smoking stick figure who seems to be marking time while waiting for Dick Tracy III to start shooting. A decade ago, with films like Back To The Future and River's Edge under his belt, Glover appeared to have a promising future ahead of him. Now he pops up in movies where, by my calculation, he does not deliver a single line. Oh well, at least he's working.

In due course, the Angels learn that the kidnapping may be a hoax, that the target of the crime may not be the missing billionaire, that they themselves are being cunningly manipulated. While they are being cunningly manipulated, they have many pleasing costume changes. Generally speaking, the lanky Diaz and the petite Liu attend to the A portion of the T&A show, while the somewhat better-fed Barrymore concentrates on the T segment. Kelly Lynch also does a fine turn as the villainess; it's always nice to see this fetching veteran back in a leather sheath. Or two. Or three.

Most of the humour in Charlie's Angels derives from Diaz's adorable klutziness plus her frantic attempts to balance career and personal life. Although she can speak Japanese and is capable of instantly pinpointing a phone caller's location by identifying the rare bird tweeting in the background, she is basically a total airhead. She also has trouble getting dates because today's young men generally opt for more cerebral, serious women and hate females who get dressed up in microscopic shorts and see-through blouses. I know that look was always a turn-off for me.

The martial-arts sequences in Charlie's Angels are very good, with the bad guys ultimately getting stomped to smithereens. One might even argue that the film has an artfully concealed feminist subtext, since the three women not only outmuscle the men in the movie but outact them (Matt LeBlanc is invisible, Bill Murray wasted, Tim Curry his usual ham self, Tom Green completely useless, and Sam Rockwell, the kidnap victim, entirely one-dimensional.)

Alas, the scene where Diaz lovingly studies her gyrating derriere in a wall-to-ceiling mirror and the numerous sequences where the twin peaks of Mount Barrymore seem to be erupting from her blouse, gown, swimsuit or blanket make it difficult to advance such a theory. Having had an entire paragraph to reconsider the matter, I don't know why I even bothered.

 Charlie's Angels is out on Friday

To date, only the Mission: Impossible franchise has passed muster in this genre. To its ranks can now be added Charlie's Angels, an often cartoonish but none the less entertaining film. To its credit, Charlie's Angels is not merely a campy send-up of the brain-dead 70s cop show starring Farrah Fawcett's hair, Jaclyn Smith's breasts, Cheryl Ladd's rear, Kate Jackson's winning smile, Shelly Hack's legs and Tonya Roberts. Instead, it is an equal mixture of campy send-up and good-natured action flick. In the end, it comes across as an all-girl Jackie Chan movie. With fewer stunts but a lot more T&A. It must be pointed out that although Charlie's Angels was a beloved TV programme, it wasn't actually any good. The plots were idiotic: any excuse to get the girls into swimsuits. None of the actresses on the show ever transferred their success to the big screen; this may be because they were not very good actresses, though that certainly never hurt Demi Moore's career. By contrast, Charlie's Angels, the movie, can draw on the estimable resources of Cameron Diaz, the most appealing young actress working today. A natural clown with unconventional good looks, Diaz brings to this project the same engaging daftness that worked so well in My Best Friend's Wedding and There's Something About Mary. Goofy, vivacious, not at all reluctant to shake her moneymaker - in fact, all of her moneymakers - Diaz has quietly emerged as the film industry's Anti-Gwyneth. Thank God somebody did. Charlie's Angels also stars the intense, seductive, but somewhat monochromatic Lucy Liu and the game, if slightly miscast, Barrymore. As was the case in the TV show, the Angels are three multi-faceted young women who work as private detectives/crimebusters for a man they have never met. They learn of their assignments via an intermediary called Bosley, here played by Bill Murray. Murray has recently made a habit of giving stellar performances in supporting parts (Ed Wood, Rushmore), but this is not one of them. Charlie's Angels is all about the Angels, which is just as well because they look a lot better in those Alpine outfits than he does. As the film begins, the Angels have been hired to find a kidnapped billionaire known as a brilliant software designer. This brings them face to face - or, in this case, cheek by jowl - with Tim Curry, delivering his stock performance as the cheeky rogue. Curry's right-hand man is Crispin Glover, a sadistic, chain-smoking stick figure who seems to be marking time while waiting for Dick Tracy III to start shooting. A decade ago, with films like Back To The Future and River's Edge under his belt, Glover appeared to have a promising future ahead of him. Now he pops up in movies where, by my calculation, he does not deliver a single line. Oh well, at least he's working. In due course, the Angels learn that the kidnapping may be a hoax, that the target of the crime may not be the missing billionaire, that they themselves are being cunningly manipulated. While they are being cunningly manipulated, they have many pleasing costume changes. Generally speaking, the lanky Diaz and the petite Liu attend to the A portion of the T&A show, while the somewhat better-fed Barrymore concentrates on the T segment. Kelly Lynch also does a fine turn as the villainess; it's always nice to see this fetching veteran back in a leather sheath. Or two. Or three. Most of the humour in Charlie's Angels derives from Diaz's adorable klutziness plus her frantic attempts to balance career and personal life. Although she can speak Japanese and is capable of instantly pinpointing a phone caller's location by identifying the rare bird tweeting in the background, she is basically a total airhead. She also has trouble getting dates because today's young men generally opt for more cerebral, serious women and hate females who get dressed up in microscopic shorts and see-through blouses. I know that look was always a turn-off for me. The martial-arts sequences in Charlie's Angels are very good, with the bad guys ultimately getting stomped to smithereens. One might even argue that the film has an artfully concealed feminist subtext, since the three women not only outmuscle the men in the movie but outact them (Matt LeBlanc is invisible, Bill Murray wasted, Tim Curry his usual ham self, Tom Green completely useless, and Sam Rockwell, the kidnap victim, entirely one-dimensional.) Alas, the scene where Diaz lovingly studies her gyrating derriere in a wall-to-ceiling mirror and the numerous sequences where the twin peaks of Mount Barrymore seem to be erupting from her blouse, gown, swimsuit or blanket make it difficult to advance such a theory. Having had an entire paragraph to reconsider the matter, I don't know why I even bothered.  Charlie's Angels is out on Friday

fields.headline: Skullandbones, cloakanddagger
fields.standfirst: The Skulls is based on the secret Yale society George W Bush joined as a student. Andrew Mueller examines our fascination with conspiracy theories
fields.trailText: The Skulls is based on the secret Yale society George W Bush joined as a student. Andrew Mueller examines our fascination with conspiracy theories
fields.body:
We are all members of secret societies: close-knit groups whose rules of admission seem arbitrary or bizarre to outsiders, who express their solidarity with peculiar rituals and phrases, whose members look out for each other's interests and keep each other's secrets. For most of us, these societies are known as Me And My Mates, and they general pose little threat to humanity at large.

In Rob Cohen's initially intriguing, eventually annoying and finally completely baffling new film The Skulls, his central protagonist, Luke McNamara, played by Joshua Jackson - the bloke off Dawson's Creek you don't want to smack in the mouth with a railway sleeper - is, at the outset, a member of just such a workaday cabal. It comprises him and two fellow students at a posh American college: a girl he doesn't realise he loves (Chloe, played by Leslie Bibb) and his best friend and room-mate (Will, played by Hill Harper). The tension on which the film attempts to perch its plot is created when Luke is extended membership of a secret society of the more sinister sort: The Skulls.

The Skulls in The Skulls are transparently modelled on the Yale University society Skull And Bones. The film's opening titles inform us that "three American presidents" are alumni of this ostensibly fictional club - back in the real world William Taft, George Bush and George W Bush are all alleged Bonesmen, as members are known. We are also told that "the CIA was created within its walls" - and it is axiomatic that the CIA's second world war-era forerunner, the Office of Strategic Services, was stuffed to the gunwales with Yale graduates. When Luke is selected by The Skulls, he is rewarded with a Breitling watch, $20,000 and a vintage sports car. Those chosen for Skull And Bones are reputed to be welcomed aboard with a slightly less grandiose $15,000 and a grandfather clock.

Had The Skulls continued in this vein, musing on the conflicts that arose from Luke trying to maintain his new life alongside his old, it might have made an interesting human drama, as well as a provocative meditation on class division on campuses in notionally egalitarian America. Unfortunately, either or both director Cohen or writer John Pogue - who claims membership of a Yale secret society - lose their grip shortly after the opening half -hour. The Skulls spends the rest of its span trying to figure out whether it is a matinee thriller, teen romance or action romp, and the climactic scenes are as baffling as they are preposterous, something like Beverly Hills 90210 rewritten by John Woo, and not half as much fun as that might sound.

This is a shame, and not just for the usual reasons that ill-focused movies are a shame. The idea that the world is run by secretive, ruthless and unaccountable elites is becoming more and more popular, both on the fringes (countless internet sites burble about the pernicious influence of one group or another) and in the mainstream - what have the recent protests against the World Trade Organisation in Seattle and Prague been, if not a demonstration of this?

There are two principal reasons why such beliefs are gaining currency. The first is that the sole unarguable constant of human history is our inability to accept that life is an essentially meaningless sequence of random occurrences. At a time when God is widely perceived as perhaps less omnipotent than previously, and no grand, global ideological struggles are being waged, we all want a Nato or a WTO or a UN or a Skull And Bones or a looser fraternity of back-scratching comrades to kick against or reassure us - even if it's at the trivial level of an embittered failure persuading himself that his problem is his lack of a Cambridge tie, rather than his absence of talent.

The second reason is that what may once have been a healthy scepticism about our governments is now a near-total conviction that nothing our leaders do is as it appears, that the only real agenda is the hidden one. When we take it as read that we're being lied to, all day every day, by people seeking only to further their own interests, we are only a short step from believing it possible that our fates are, indeed, dictated by cliques of champagne-swilling frat boys whose induction rites for the class of 2000, according to the Yale Herald, included "humping a pole while being fed wafers and exclaiming "Scooby Snacks!'".

Though The Skulls is ultimately nothing more than a mildly entertaining and somewhat silly movie, it should at least serve the purpose of confirming our culture's determination to see the subtext at the expense of the simple explanation. We shouldn't have to wait too long for the books and websites examining the film for revelatory traces of the writer's professed inside knowledge; these will doubtless be followed, in due course, by counter-claims that The Skulls is itself part of some vast and malignant plot to divert us from the scent.

 The Skulls is out on Friday

webTitle: Pick of the week:  Crumple Zone by Nick Barlay

fields.headline: Good, innit?
fields.standfirst: Nicholas Lezard  on Nick Barlay's  fictional voice of the street in Crumple Zone
fields.trailText: Nicholas Lezard on Nick Barlay's fictional voice of the street in Crumple Zone
fields.body:
Crumple Zone
Nick Barlay
(Sceptre, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

When publishers tout a new voice from the streets, a narrative that accurately reflects contemporary urban life as lived by people who wear trainers and puffy jackets, the results are almost always depressing. Either the details of the lives described are manifestly false, or the writing sucks. This is hardly anyone's fault, as living life on the edge and honing one's prose style are, in this country at least, goals at odds with each other.

So it was very nice to pick this up and find a writer who is not only in command of his technique but seems to be have his finger on the city's pulse. The story is about Cee Harper, a part-time teacher who lives in Trellick Towers, that modernist slab of a tower block at the top end of Notting Hill which so beguiles some of the middle class (but which is convincingly portrayed in this novel as a toilet). She comes back to find her flat broken into and trashed; which, as it is 30 floors up, seems to indicate an inside job, and besides, there is a hole under the floorboards that she did not know was there.

Now it seems to be axiomatic that, unless the author is Tony Parsons, Nick Hornby or an unmarried woman worried about her weight, the contemporary, not-overly-literary urban novel has to contain some kind of criminal element to keep itself going, and this is no exception; but this would appear to be more about having one's own fears addressed than a nasty little fantasy excursion into a semi-pornographic tableau of baseball bats and crack cocaine. All right, this novel does feature those things, but it also features what goes through the mind of a savvy but internally anxious teacher when she is confronted by four of her hardest, most routinely disrespectful pupils on her way back home. And that is what makes this novel: its creation of Cee Harper's voice, the monologue of an intelligent, alert and thoughtful person to whom bad things start happening.

There's another interesting thing Barlay does, or does not do: and that is tell you what his characters look like. In other words, while a detail might slip out here and there, he makes you work a bit before you twig which characters are black. This is not so much colour-blindness as a discreet aversion of the head; and one of the reasons you might do that would be to hear better. You don't have to be a genius to work out what race Georgio Georgianou, the novel's hard man, would describe himself as; but his speech - as is almost everyone's in the novel - is very much supercharged Ali G. Most dialogue closes with the word "innit" or "y'na mean", which is how "you know what I mean" comes out most of the time these days.

So what? Well, as Empson said, one of the things, or should I say tings, literature does is to give us sympathetic access to systems of value and belief that are not our own; or, if you prefer, not to look in a mirror but out of the window. I can't completely vouch for Barlay's veracity - but his ear certainly does sound trustworthy. And there are some good jokes here too, such as the one about baklava.

webTitle: The Best a Man Can Get by  John O'Farrell

fields.headline: Desperately seeking jokes
fields.standfirst: James Hopkin on John O’Farrell’s patchy novel The Best a Man Can Get
fields.trailText: James Hopkin on John O’Farrell’s patchy novel The Best a Man Can Get
fields.body:
The Best a Man Can Get

John O'Farrell

271pp, Doubleday
£10 Buy it at BOL

In this age of disposable literature, it's refreshing to find a novel that is wittily aware of its own ephemerality. John O'Farrell is a writer of satirical sketches, both political and comic, and his first novel is a quick-fix gathering of domestic funnies that's more New Lad than New Labour.

The narrator, Michael Adams, 32, is yet another male lost in the limbo between youthfulness and middle-age. With a wife and two children to support, the freelance jingle writer is disillusioned with work, and distracted by the demands of family life. Under the excuse of needing somewhere else to work, he gets himself a flat south of the river with a bunch of bachelors - a double life that creates great scope to contrast a life of male bonding, flirtation, drinking and trivia with the endless negotiations necessary to keep the peace at home.

There are some clever ideas here, conveyed in prose that registers somewhere between lifestyle columns, the musings of a wickedly ironic agony uncle, and the confessions of a middle-aged man who hasn't yet grown out of his trainers: "I had spent my childhood doing what my parents wanted to do and now my adulthood seemed doomed to be spent doing what my children wanted to do."

O'Farrell's style is to stumble on a joke, and then run with it for a page or two: why can't humans hibernate? Why can't we score sleep like drugs? He does occasionally try to write in a story behind the gags: we learn that Adams's philandering father walked out on his five year-old son and that his mother died in a car accident. If this doesn't quite vindicate Adams's later behaviour, then it does at least give the novel a more solid core, albeit an increasingly sentimental one. But like a stand-up working through his material, O'Farrell is always on the look-out for easy-fill linking gags, which is why the novel is not so much driven by a narrative as propelled by a restless energy. And, as with any venture that seeks to entertain at every turn, some of the jokes miss their mark.

fields.headline: Big in SF
fields.trailText: A round-up of what's out of this world: Paradox | Dervish is Digital | The Voyage of the Jerle Shannara | Thraxas and the Elvish Isles | Crescent City Rhapsody
fields.body:
Some time in the future, in a vast underground world where events are pre-told by oracles and society is rigidly static, a market boy called Tom Corcorigan is given a cheap memory chip by a mysterious woman. A day later, Tom watches in horror as she is gunned down by guards, leaving him with what turns out to be a cross between an IQ test and a history of a different world: our world. Echoes of science fantasy, hard SF and post cyberpunk abound in Paradox (Bantam Press, £17.99). With some good writing, John Meaney subverts what might easily have become clichéd. Not every plot strand holds up, but this is pulp SF with class.
Buy it at BOL

Also busy subverting old tropes is Pat Cadigan, twice winner of the Clarke Award, who is back with Dervish is Digital (Macmillan, £9.99). For Cadigan, virtual reality becomes artificial reality, and AR is where the gamers hang out, where nothing is real and every statement a lie. Which should make policing it a problem. Except for the fact that Konstantin, Chief Officer of TechnoCrime (AR Division) is back, this time chasing cybercrim Hastings Dervish. Locations dazzle, sleights of hand abound, and - as ever with Cadigan - nothing is quite what it seems.
Buy it at BOL

Terry Brooks's new novel, The Voyage of the Jerle Shannara (Simon & Schuster, £16.99), begins with a drowning elf. Unfortunately, nothing else in the novel quite lives up to that burst of promise. There is much hanging around in grubby taverns until a motley band of elves, innocents abroad and heroes gather together to make a quest across the oceans in the airship of the title.
Buy it at BOL

In Martin Scott's Thraxas and the Elvish Isles (Orbit, £5.99), elves don't just nearly drown, they take drugs, win fights by hitting people with chairs or fall out of their trees, usually under the influence of something illegal. Not traditional behaviour for elves, but then Martin Millar, who wrote some of the best urban fiction of the late 1980s/early 1990s, has - as Martin Scott - invented a new genre: pulp fantasy noir. Blindingly funny, deeply subversive - at least to anyone who takes fantasy seriously - and completely improbable, this is the fourth book to star Scott's drunken, obese and foul-mouthed private detective, Thraxas.
Buy it at BOL

Far more serious is Crescent City Rhapsody (Millennium, £6.99), the third book in Kathleen Ann Goonan's Nanotech cycle, which is set back near the beginning of the story, when the "biological" cities are only just being created and computers, cars and the web have been brought to a halt by a burst of electro-magnetic energy from outer space. Based around mob boss/voodoo queen Marie Laveau, manic-depressive astrophysicist Zeb Aberly and a group of hyper-intelligent humans created when the pulse changed the genetic structure of a small number of embryos, Crescent City Rhapsody begins clumsily, gets slightly flabby in the middle but builds up a head of steam to end in a crescendo of jazz music, mayhem and miracles. With a decent edit and 100 fewer pages it could have been truly excellent.
Buy it at BOL

webTitle: Review: Saul Bellow  by James Atlas

fields.headline: The unzipped ego
fields.standfirst: Hywel Williams  charts the triumph of Saul Bellow in James Atlas's biography
fields.trailText: Hywel Williams charts the triumph of Saul Bellow in James Atlas's biography
fields.body:
Saul Bellow
James Atlas
701pp, Faber
£25
Buy it at BOL

He was Solomon before converting to Saul, but worldly wisdom was never his trade. "Was meinst du - a writer?" asked exasperated and commercial Abraham of his introspective son. Many years later Herzog could reply: "Consciousness is his line of work."

The young Bellow was precocious, but no prodigal. When it came to the mind and the spirit he discovered that his inheritance was a real Klondike affair. And so he mined away - the artificer of the American-Jewish consciousness. Saul's brothers followed the windy city's winding ways and made money. But Junior exploited the cultural side of his heritage. It took time but he got the ultimate local accolade. "Hey Solly," said a Chicago gangster, embracing the Nobel Laureate of 1976 at the Riviera Club, "I hear you won the big one."

James Atlas's biography of Saul Bellow combines scholarship with empathy. No life can "explain" art, but the fiction of the "dangling man" has been so insistently biographical that it cries out for an account as lucid as this. The making of Bellow is a many-layered thing, and it's all here: the Talmudic ancestors in Tsarist Russia; Abraham reading Chekhov's stories in Yiddish to his sons; Montreal, where the child of the immigrant family spoke French on the streets and read Genesis in Hebrew at home. And - of course - Chicago, where the family finally settled.

It was his kind of town, if only because it wasn't New York. Bellow has always needed his willed sense of exclusion. Chicago was mid-western, raw and heterodox, where New York was too obviously sophisticated. The local university was no Ivy League conspiracy of gentlemen whose highest cultural aspiration was to join Eliot and James on the boat back to the old country. Chicago alone could nurture Bellow's mythic sense of the American writer's selfhood.

The university's Great Books Program immersed Bellow in an eclectic European tradition: Proustians mingled with Thomists and Plato met Tolstoy. In Chicago - as the local joke had it - Jewish professors taught Roman Catholicism to Protestant students. Anthropology afterwards at Northwestern University gave him an even wider base. The result is Bellow the cultural commentator as well as Bellow the novelist. His characters play with ideas - even, at times, belabour them with a provincial neediness to show off.

A succession of wives and girlfriends - as well as grants, scholarships and part-time jobs - emerged from the university system to support Bellow on the way up. Campus characters populate his novels, most movingly in Ravelstein, his effectively biographical study of the late Allan Bloom. But Bellow's are not Bradbury-like novels of "academic life". In all their rage and rampage, they are the most accurate imaginative record of the 20th century's American destiny - for good and ill.

Henderson the Rain King shows a millionaire explorer unleashed on a continent populated by Uncle Remus-style Africans. It is the unconscious literary reflection of 1950s American colonialism. Mr Sammler's Planet is an angry defence of the "great tradition" of rationality and objectivity. Here Bellow embraces the values of those he once rejected - the debilitatingly Anglo-Saxon goyim who used to run American English departments. Atlas shows the range of Bellow's women problems both in life and in art, where the unzipped fly has been a constant companion to the neo-Biblical moralism. His novels offer machismic accounts of fractured egos - protective of their sensitivity, but ready to destroy. The female characters seem vengeful attacks on the women whom he has failed and who have failed him: the Eumenides as viragos. (A one-sided lunch with Margaret Thatcher, who lectured him on Chicago blacks, was an appropriate punishment.)

But Bellow's selfish gene is also a thing of genius. He is the explorer of an industrial society that can't accommodate a Prometheus because it limits people to an alloted function. He bemoans the lack of a unified self in modern literature while exploring the consequences of its absence. Haunted, like Allan Bloom, by a dream of the unified western past, he has used that fiction of consensus to castigate a decadent, relativist present. The sensitive eyes and the sensuous lips now sail with rare serenity into another millennium accompanied by another female: his daughter, Naomi, born to an 84-year-old father. To this fertility there seems no end. But there is one explanation - Bellow's own: "Practice, Practice, Practice".

webTitle: Review: Hans Christian Andersen: The Life of a Storyteller by Jackie Wullschlager

fields.headline: The animator of worlds
fields.standfirst: Paul Binding  on fairy-tale life and art in  Jackie Wullschlager's biography of Hans Christian Andersen
fields.trailText: Paul Binding on fairy-tale life and art in Jackie Wullschlager's biography of Hans Christian Andersen
fields.body:
Hans Christian Andersen: The Life of a Storyteller
Jackie Wullschlager
528pp, Penguin/Allen Lane
£20
Buy it at BOL

'You certainly do your best to wear out your friends ... and all because of the ceaseless concern with YOURSELF - YOUR OWN EGO - THE GREAT POET YOU THINK YOU WILL BE." Andersen was 21 when he received this letter from a well-wishing but exasperated patron, but it remained true throughout his life. An unmarried man, without family of his own, he was dependent, emotionally and physically, on others until the day of his death, demanding assurance, consolation, praise and home comforts. In his sixties, he was described by an English visitor to one of his surrogate families as "a child ... entirely egotistical, innocently vain, the centre of life, interest, concern and meaning to himself". And after his death the great Danish critic, Georg Brandes, perhaps the first to appreciate quite how extraordinary and innovative his stories were, wrote that "Andersen's mind was wholly filled by himself".

And yet this self-obsessed man's contribution to literature lies not in the domain of confessional poetry or autobiographical fiction, but in the most objective of forms, the fairy-tale, drawing (at first, directly) from vast reserves of folk-culture, and later fashioning his own archetypal characters and predicaments. True, some of Andersen's most famous stories - "The Ugly Duckling", "The Steadfast Tin Soldier", even "The Little Mermaid" - are dramatisations or sublimations of his own dilemmas, but they would not work on us as they do if they did not transcend the personal - in language, in observation and detail, and in intricate but unobtrusive structure - to stand on their own as perfectly wrought artefacts of universal appeal.

Andersen's work is not the preserve of sophisticated introverts (as, say, outside the German-speaking world, Rilke's poetry largely is), but has been from the first admired and loved by readers of all ages, all social classes, all countries, all degrees of education.

It could be said that inordinate egotism was needed for Andersen to elevate himself at all from the harsh circumstances of his early years. As Jackie Wullschlager observes in this scrupulous and intensely intelligent biography, Andersen's background was humbler, more deprived than that of any comparable writer. He was born in 1805 in Denmark's second city, Odense. His father, a shoemaker and something of an autodidact, was the son of an inmate of the local madhouse and himself not altogether mentally stable. Hans Christian (as the son should always be called) was devoted to him, but lost him when only 11 years old. His mother, Anne Marie, who was older than his father, illiterate but very practical, was left poor; she had a daughter, six years older than Hans Christian, fathered by a married man. Anne Marie's sister ran a brothel in Copenhagen, and Karen-Marie, Hans Christian's half-sister, almost certainly worked as prostitute for some years.

Andersen was haunted by these relations of his: he came to view his mother's family as a paradigm of promiscuity and had a terror of them erupting into his own carefully arranged life. As a boy in Odense he was largely left to his own devices. Effeminate and clumsy, as he was to remain his life long, he kept out of the way of other children, and amused himself with his toy theatre and his own imaginings. But ambition, and day-dreams of the great success his unusual personality and gifts surely deserved, also governed his young life, and when he was only 14, he saved up enough money from performance and recitals at middle-class houses to leave Odense for Copenhagen.

Denmark - and a major feature of Jackie Wullschlager's book is its rich study of the country during Andersen's life, culturally, sociologically, politically - appears at this time to have been an extraordinarily cohesive society. Copenhagen's upper crust probably consisted of no more than 1,000 people, closely interconnected. After defeat in the Napoleonic wars, Danes seem to have turned away not just from the world arena but from politics altogether, and the arts (especially the theatre) were valued particularly highly. Andersen was thought promising enough to be nurtured and provided with an education.

The family who took particular responsibility for him was to remain important to him for the rest of his life - indeed, at his request, two of its members were buried in the same cemetery plot as himself. Jonas Collin was director of the Royal Theatre, "court official, senior civil servant and well-known philanthropist", and Andersen never lost either his affection or his awe for the man whom he would call "Father".

The most important relationship of his life was with Collin's son Edvard. Young Hans Christian adored Edvard and expected from this clever, successful, yet rather cold and conventional person a reciprocation it wasn't in his nature to give. It is hard to warm to Edvard Collin, however great the trouble he took over the business side of Andersen's subsequent literary life. His snootiness towards the vulnerable Hans Christian was at its most conspicuous in his written refusal to permit the use the familiar "du" between them.

The insecurities of Andersen's start in life permeated his entire career. He always needed the support of those born into a high social sphere - his circle would later include the Danish Royal family - and he never could resist adopting a fawning tone to his hosts and a boastful one to his friends. His craving for fame and approbation was insatiable, and he was assiduous in securing both, though for years Denmark lagged behind other countries (including Britain) in its appreciation of him. Sadly, even the Collin family seem to have lacked a proper appreciation of the gifts of their friend and protégé; to the end they rated other Danish writers above him.

The young Andersen had a kind of free-floating creativity. Determined to succeed, no matter in which artistic domain, he produced poems, plays, novels, and regular self-preening, self-bowdlerising autobiographies. He was 30 years old when his first book of fairy-tales appeared. It was very short, only 61 pages long and three of the stories - "The Tinderbox" "Little Claus, and Big Claus", and "The Princess and the Pea!" - derived from stories Hans Christian had heard back in Odense. A second volume of tales came out seven months later. Before long both Andersen and his public understood that it was such tales that showed his imagination and his artistry at their most intense and original.

Wullschlager writes with extraordinary clarity and perspicacity about Andersen's productions, relating them to his life and to the culture of the age, but also standing back to reveal their universal, timeless qualities. She shows how revolutionary Andersen's use of objects was. He would animate toys, kitchen utensils, furniture - the entire monde visible - enabling us to perceive every aspect of our lives as metaphoric. Wullschlager also emphasises what too many translators failed to render: the marvellously colloquial language Andersen always employed (even Edvard Collin admired this). It was an emotionally flexible instrument used with unfailing subtlety and power.

She also shows us a progression within the fairy-tale oeuvre itself; after the trauma of the Denmark-Prussia wars of 1849-1851 and personal disappointments, the stories darkened and became more artistically adventurous - heralds of modernism (his last story, "Auntie Toothache", was his darkest and most modernist). Andersen, for all his folk roots and naivety, always saw himself in the European vanguard, and was as enthusiastic about technical experimentation in the arts as he was about technological progress in society.

This outstanding book enlarges our understanding not just of Andersen and his times, but of literature and its relation to the individual and the collective mind. It offers an almost Goya-like portrait of its central figure, yet presents a fuller and more satisfying account of socio-cultural strata than any I have encountered in a literary biography. I do feel, however, that Wullschlager nails Andersen rather too definitely to the mast of homosexuality. Women, pre-eminently the great singer Jenny Lind, obsessed him, and quite patently erotically so. But his was essentially a virginal temperament.

Andersen once boasted that while the British Dr Livingstone was a great man, "he was not loved in the hearts of the world as I am". Almost 200 years after his birth, we can see how right he was.
