fields.headline: How zero became a hero
fields.standfirst: Jon Turney  goes into the void and finds that the boffins, John D Barrow, Charles Seife and  David Bodanis,  have spun gold from nothing
fields.trailText: Jon Turney goes into the void and finds that the boffins, John D Barrow, Charles Seife and David Bodanis, have spun gold from nothing
fields.body:
The Book of Nothing
John D Barrow
395pp, Jonathan Cape
£16.99
Buy it at BOL

Zero: The Biography of a Dangerous Idea
Charles Seife
248pp, Souvenir Press
£18.99
Buy it at BOL

E=MC2
David Bodanis
324pp, Macmillan
£14.99
Buy it at BOL

Nothing will come of nothing, King Lear reproves his tongue-tied daughter. Nowadays, physicists routinely extract entire universes out of nothing - on paper, anyway. Once, multiplying or dividing by zero had terrifying results, reducing orderly arithmetic to instant nonsense. Today, it is a simple trick to recover all the numbers from nothing again. Zero, once a symbol of the void, of absence, of non-being, is now just a location on a number line, an innocuous entry in a string of binary code.

The history of how humans learned to love zero involves startling shifts in metaphysics, mathematics and science. These are hard for us to recover. Childhood rhymes are the nearest we moderns get to Platonic knowledge. When the last green bottle accidentally falls, there are no green bottles hanging on the wall. It feels as if we have always known this. So surely everyone else has, too? But the struggle to develop the idea, and the fact that entire civilisations got by without it, attests that zero is a deeply non-obvious notion.

The first cultures of counting had no need for zero because numbers were used for recording presence rather than absence. Five thousand years ago, if a victorious Pharaoh captured 100,000 goats, that was worth carving into rock. The fact that no slaves were seized this time did not detain the stonemasons. But the number symbols in Egyptian hieroglyphics, like other ancient numerals, were cumbersome. Ever more complex combinations were needed to denote larger and larger numbers. And each symbol meant the same, wherever it was put. They lacked the elegant economy of place value.

That idea, now familiar as the numbers, tens and units on which Mr Blunkett will probably soon be testing three-year-olds, was an extraordinary discovery. What was needed, as the Babylonians first realised, was an extra sign. If a numeral has a different value depending on where it appears in a list, there must be a symbol for an entry in the list which is empty. Enter zero. Not to stand on its own, but to write, say, 1,001, keeping the ones in their place.

Eventually, through the Arab numerals we still use, zero became part of the global language of arithmetic. But not without a fight. While eastern cultures had long been comfortable with the idea of nothing as a something, the Greeks, for all their learning, could not countenance it. Their cosmos was both filled out and finite. Embrace zero, and the twin threats of the void and infinity might undermine the foundations of an Aristotelian universe. Not until the European renaissance and the scientific revolution did zero and the infinite come into their own in the west: in perspective drawing, in the infinitesimal divisions of Newton's and Leibniz's calculus, in the recognition that space might extend for ever but need have no content.

In some senses, we now know the Greeks' fears of the void to have been unfounded. Since the advent of set theory, a mathematician starting with a representation of nothing can rebuild all the other numbers. The trick is to begin with the empty set, which has no members. Then you can define the number one as the set which contains the empty set as a member - like thinking about a thought. And so on, to infinity. Generated this way, zero nestles at the heart of things inside the endlessly embedded sets, a bootstrap that can pull out an endless ribbon of numbers even though it is tied to nothing. If you buy that, you may also be ready to contemplate modern physicists' notion of the vacuum. They did away with the ether 100 years ago or so, and settled for empty space. They have now repopulated the void with a sea of "virtual particles". Quantum mechanics depicts space as a seething foam of uncertainty, with unimaginably short-lived elementary particles continually appearing and disappearing. Contemporary cosmology even suggests that the whole universe might have appeared out of the quantum vacuum: the ultimate free lunch.

As these few highlights suggest, there is a lot more to nothing than meets the eye. So perhaps it is not surprising that, in one of those coincidences that amuse readers more than publishers, John Barrow and Charles Seife choose to tell the whole story in almost identical terms. Both are trained mathematicians and gifted popular writers, and both run through pretty much the sequence I have just sketched. Few people will have time for both, but choosing which to read is largely a matter of taste. Seife, in his first book, is breezier, more journalistic, occasionally preoccupied with the personal quirks of great men - as though he is not quite convinced the ideas alone will keep our attention.

Barrow, whose previous books include one on theories of everything, is very much at home with his new topic, from his splendid title onward. He is also a professional cosmologist and delves further into the physics, while Seife is mainly preoccupied with mathematics, especially the links between zero and infinity. Both tell a good story, from the Babylonians to Big Bang theorists. Barrow's book is, to my mind, more satisfying, not just because he covers more ground. He has a firmer grasp of the deep metaphysics of being and non-being - though he balks at Sartre, and Heidegger hardly gets a look in. But readers of popular science are well served by Barrow's apparently effortless range of reference. When it comes to explaining the trickiest ideas he often goes the extra mile, which helps you feel you really understand what is going on (while you have the book in your hand, anyway).

A telling comparison comes when he and Seife discuss the consequences of the zero-point energy of the vacuum, a property linked with the birth of all those virtual particles. Both are convinced that this is an amazing idea. The zero-point energy is, in theory, infinite. As Seife puts it: "According to the equations of quantum mechanics, more power than is stored in all the coal mines, oil fields, and nuclear weapons in the world is sitting in the space inside your toaster".

Very striking, but why should we be convinced? Well, although the zero-point energy normally disappears in real life - particles and their twinned anti-particles constantly annihilate each other - it does, in some special circumstances, leave a faint residue that can be measured on an atomic scale. Siefe and Barrow both explain how this registers as a force between microscopically separated metal plates, in an experiment first suggested by the Dutch physicists B G Casimir and Dik Polder. Both explain the origin of the Casimir force in terms of the wavelength of particles. Move the plates close enough together and only some wavelengths will fit between them, creating a kind of pressure from an excess of waves outside that tends to push them closer together still.

Barrow, though, fishes a splendid trophy from the physics journals, and points out that a problem in handling sailing ships is just like the Casimir effect. Old nautical manuals warn that two sailing ships positioned side by side in a heavy swell will move toward each other and may collide. The reason turns out to be the same as the cancelling out of wave motions that impels atoms in a vacuum to move closer. This kind of link between the everyday world and the microworld is just what popular-science writers need to help one visualise the strange phenomena they report. Seife is pretty good at spotting them, but Barrow looks further and finds more. Some of the cosmological speculation is still hard to follow, but at least you do not feel that he is holding back from dealing with the most demanding stuff.

The same can hardly be said of David Bodanis's E=MC2. Like Seife, Bodanis presents his book as a "biography", in this case of Einstein's famous equation. For both this means a sprinkling of personal anecdotes about people who worked with the ideas they write about. But in Bodanis's book the anecdotes all but drive out the ideas. The result is a popular-science book in which the science is present in near homeopathic dilution. More seriously, the celebrated equation makes little sense by itself. As Bodanis says, it is simply a small part of the special theory of relativity, which in turn gave way to the general theory some years later. There is a good deal of history in his book, but little sense of the rich interconnection of a web of ideas that pervades Barrow and Seife's narratives. fields.bodyText: The Book of Nothing John D Barrow 395pp, Jonathan Cape £16.99 Buy it at BOL Zero: The Biography of a Dangerous Idea Charles Seife 248pp, Souvenir Press £18.99 Buy it at BOL E=MC2 David Bodanis 324pp, Macmillan £14.99 Buy it at BOL Nothing will come of nothing, King Lear reproves his tongue-tied daughter. Nowadays, physicists routinely extract entire universes out of nothing - on paper, anyway. Once, multiplying or dividing by zero had terrifying results, reducing orderly arithmetic to instant nonsense. Today, it is a simple trick to recover all the numbers from nothing again. Zero, once a symbol of the void, of absence, of non-being, is now just a location on a number line, an innocuous entry in a string of binary code. The history of how humans learned to love zero involves startling shifts in metaphysics, mathematics and science. These are hard for us to recover. Childhood rhymes are the nearest we moderns get to Platonic knowledge. When the last green bottle accidentally falls, there are no green bottles hanging on the wall. It feels as if we have always known this. So surely everyone else has, too? But the struggle to develop the idea, and the fact that entire civilisations got by without it, attests that zero is a deeply non-obvious notion. The first cultures of counting had no need for zero because numbers were used for recording presence rather than absence. Five thousand years ago, if a victorious Pharaoh captured 100,000 goats, that was worth carving into rock. The fact that no slaves were seized this time did not detain the stonemasons. But the number symbols in Egyptian hieroglyphics, like other ancient numerals, were cumbersome. Ever more complex combinations were needed to denote larger and larger numbers. And each symbol meant the same, wherever it was put. They lacked the elegant economy of place value. That idea, now familiar as the numbers, tens and units on which Mr Blunkett will probably soon be testing three-year-olds, was an extraordinary discovery. What was needed, as the Babylonians first realised, was an extra sign. If a numeral has a different value depending on where it appears in a list, there must be a symbol for an entry in the list which is empty. Enter zero. Not to stand on its own, but to write, say, 1,001, keeping the ones in their place. Eventually, through the Arab numerals we still use, zero became part of the global language of arithmetic. But not without a fight. While eastern cultures had long been comfortable with the idea of nothing as a something, the Greeks, for all their learning, could not countenance it. Their cosmos was both filled out and finite. Embrace zero, and the twin threats of the void and infinity might undermine the foundations of an Aristotelian universe. Not until the European renaissance and the scientific revolution did zero and the infinite come into their own in the west: in perspective drawing, in the infinitesimal divisions of Newton's and Leibniz's calculus, in the recognition that space might extend for ever but need have no content. In some senses, we now know the Greeks' fears of the void to have been unfounded. Since the advent of set theory, a mathematician starting with a representation of nothing can rebuild all the other numbers. The trick is to begin with the empty set, which has no members. Then you can define the number one as the set which contains the empty set as a member - like thinking about a thought. And so on, to infinity. Generated this way, zero nestles at the heart of things inside the endlessly embedded sets, a bootstrap that can pull out an endless ribbon of numbers even though it is tied to nothing. If you buy that, you may also be ready to contemplate modern physicists' notion of the vacuum. They did away with the ether 100 years ago or so, and settled for empty space. They have now repopulated the void with a sea of "virtual particles". Quantum mechanics depicts space as a seething foam of uncertainty, with unimaginably short-lived elementary particles continually appearing and disappearing. Contemporary cosmology even suggests that the whole universe might have appeared out of the quantum vacuum: the ultimate free lunch. As these few highlights suggest, there is a lot more to nothing than meets the eye. So perhaps it is not surprising that, in one of those coincidences that amuse readers more than publishers, John Barrow and Charles Seife choose to tell the whole story in almost identical terms. Both are trained mathematicians and gifted popular writers, and both run through pretty much the sequence I have just sketched. Few people will have time for both, but choosing which to read is largely a matter of taste. Seife, in his first book, is breezier, more journalistic, occasionally preoccupied with the personal quirks of great men - as though he is not quite convinced the ideas alone will keep our attention. Barrow, whose previous books include one on theories of everything, is very much at home with his new topic, from his splendid title onward. He is also a professional cosmologist and delves further into the physics, while Seife is mainly preoccupied with mathematics, especially the links between zero and infinity. Both tell a good story, from the Babylonians to Big Bang theorists. Barrow's book is, to my mind, more satisfying, not just because he covers more ground. He has a firmer grasp of the deep metaphysics of being and non-being - though he balks at Sartre, and Heidegger hardly gets a look in. But readers of popular science are well served by Barrow's apparently effortless range of reference. When it comes to explaining the trickiest ideas he often goes the extra mile, which helps you feel you really understand what is going on (while you have the book in your hand, anyway). A telling comparison comes when he and Seife discuss the consequences of the zero-point energy of the vacuum, a property linked with the birth of all those virtual particles. Both are convinced that this is an amazing idea. The zero-point energy is, in theory, infinite. As Seife puts it: "According to the equations of quantum mechanics, more power than is stored in all the coal mines, oil fields, and nuclear weapons in the world is sitting in the space inside your toaster". Very striking, but why should we be convinced? Well, although the zero-point energy normally disappears in real life - particles and their twinned anti-particles constantly annihilate each other - it does, in some special circumstances, leave a faint residue that can be measured on an atomic scale. Siefe and Barrow both explain how this registers as a force between microscopically separated metal plates, in an experiment first suggested by the Dutch physicists B G Casimir and Dik Polder. Both explain the origin of the Casimir force in terms of the wavelength of particles. Move the plates close enough together and only some wavelengths will fit between them, creating a kind of pressure from an excess of waves outside that tends to push them closer together still. Barrow, though, fishes a splendid trophy from the physics journals, and points out that a problem in handling sailing ships is just like the Casimir effect. Old nautical manuals warn that two sailing ships positioned side by side in a heavy swell will move toward each other and may collide. The reason turns out to be the same as the cancelling out of wave motions that impels atoms in a vacuum to move closer. This kind of link between the everyday world and the microworld is just what popular-science writers need to help one visualise the strange phenomena they report. Seife is pretty good at spotting them, but Barrow looks further and finds more. Some of the cosmological speculation is still hard to follow, but at least you do not feel that he is holding back from dealing with the most demanding stuff. The same can hardly be said of David Bodanis's E=MC2. Like Seife, Bodanis presents his book as a "biography", in this case of Einstein's famous equation. For both this means a sprinkling of personal anecdotes about people who worked with the ideas they write about. But in Bodanis's book the anecdotes all but drive out the ideas. The result is a popular-science book in which the science is present in near homeopathic dilution. More seriously, the celebrated equation makes little sense by itself. As Bodanis says, it is simply a small part of the special theory of relativity, which in turn gave way to the general theory some years later. There is a good deal of history in his book, but little sense of the rich interconnection of a web of ideas that pervades Barrow and Seife's narratives. In fact, they both explain more about relativity than Bodanis. For it turns out that in order to write convincingly about nothing, you really do have to explain just about everything.  Jon Turney teaches science communication at University College London.

webTitle: Review: Get Happy by Gerald Clarke

fields.headline: Forever young
fields.standfirst: Gaby Wood  on the infantile appeal of Judy Garland in Gerald Clarke's biography, Get Happy
fields.trailText: Gaby Wood on the infantile appeal of Judy Garland in Gerald Clarke's biography, Get Happy
fields.body:
Get Happy: The Life of Judy Garland
Gerald Clarke
510pp, Little, Brown
£20
Buy it at BOL

In his new biography of Judy Garland, Gerald Clarke quotes his subject complaining about the sex appeal of her co-stars. "I don't like myself," she moaned to her drama coach on Ziegfield Girl in 1940. "When Lana walks onto the set, all the guys whistle until she gets across. When Hedy walks on, there's a sigh of I don't know what. And when I walk on, they say: 'Hi, Judy!'" Garland was later to revise her opinion of Lana Turner's merits, saying that "talking to her is like talking to a beautiful vase", but for that moment, on the edge of womanhood, the child star Judy Garland was not content to be someone people could talk to - she wanted to be precisely the kind of girl no one felt they could talk to.

Every movie fan must now have their own immediate, free-associative view of who Judy Garland was - not because she was such a stalwart at MGM (she was fired a number of times), but because she had been with the starry studio since her youth. She grew up in the movies, too fast and not at all, retaining both a childlike energy and a childlike frailty, even as she sabotaged her body with adult weapons. Which Judy Garland first comes to mind? Is it the girl-next-door of the Andy Hardy films, the pigtailed innocent of The Wizard of Oz? Is she the sweet-voiced sister from Meet Me in St Louis or the complicated, gutsy heroine of A Star Is Born? Is she, perhaps, the drug-addled singer who made thousands weep? Is she overweight in your memory or gauntly thin? Is she, only, Liza Minnelli's mother?

Her story has been told in countless books and documentaries since her death from a drug overdose in 1969, and one imagines this might create difficulties for the biographer, but Gerald Clarke has his own take on Garland's life. The legend begins with an attempted abortion: Ethel Gumm, the future Judy's mother, already had two children and could not afford or cope with more. She tried to get rid of the child, but a friend told her it could cost her her own life. If she kept the baby, the friend said (with an irony forever lost on Ethel), she would have "the happiest baby in the world". When the girl was born, Ethel pinned all her hopes on her - not because she wanted her to be happy, but because she was Ethel's best chance of a ticket out of the sticks and onto the stage. Frances, or Babe, as the youngest was called for many years, had an extraordinary gift: she looked like a child and sang like a woman.

The Gumm sisters (sometimes called the Gumdrops, and later changed to the Garland sisters) started out as a trio, with Frances on stage by the age of two, but they ended up leaving Babe, the most popular by far, to give solo performances. Ethel, a wildly pushy, unaffectionate woman, took the role of stage mother to heady new heights. She drove her daughter around the country, accompanying her on the piano. She had her sights set on Hollywood, but her daughter was rejected by everyone there until she changed her name. In the end, it was not Frances Gumm or Frances Garland but Judy who was welcomed with open arms, and by 1935 her mother's stubborn design had been fulfilled.

Gerald Clarke brings to the story something that might account for Ethel's disillusioned desperation: her husband, Frank Gumm, was, Clarke writes, "basically homosexual".

It's a rather casual phrase for such a dramatic revelation - indeed, the revelations are so dramatic that one is inclined to disbelieve Clarke, to think him the sort of biographer who sets out to dredge up scandal or abuse. But he does cite his sources, and after a while, the sources themselves become part of the excitement: Clarke, the author of a bestselling biography of Truman Capote, appears to have an ingenious knack for seeking out the extras in Garland's life. He has spoken to the boy who took the tickets at her father's old movie theatre, to her best friend down the street in the small desert town of Lancaster, California, to a boyfriend from her teenage years; he has consulted local lawyers and barbers, dredged up letters and recorded reminiscences - in short, he has assembled a small army of marginal storytellers, and there seems no reason to suspect the account he gives.

The theme continues: Not only was Judy's father servicing boys in the back row of his cinema, but her husband, Vincente Minnelli, was also gay - or, according to Clarke, "at least largely so". He would dress up in drag, at least two male actors claimed to have had flings with him, and Clarke gives evidence of one "almost certain" other. When colleagues at MGM told Judy they were under the impression that her future husband was not, as they put it, "marrying material", she insisted that it was "just his artistic flair". Many years later, their daughter Liza discovered her husband Peter Allen in bed with another man - not only that, but, Clarke claims, unbeknownst to either Liza or her mother, Allen was also sleeping with Judy's husband Mark Herron.

The story has an almost too-perfect circularity to it, and what, in the end, can we do with this information? Conclude that, since the loves of her life had been gay, Garland became a gay icon, and that the feelings of her fans were reciprocated in ways we could not have known? Clarke makes no connection between husbands and fans, suggesting that her gay following is to do with her audience's affinity with the public abuse she had suffered. The only thing the sexuality of her father and lovers seems to indicate is that she wanted to be loved by men who could not really love her, or that she was afraid of men who might. Feeling unloved is, in any telling, the story of Judy Garland's life; she always dreamed of something better. She said that when she sang "Over the Rainbow" it always made her cry, and even the most hardened cynic might, on hearing the cracking voice of late recordings of that song, wonder what had happened to the little girl who first sang it.

Although much of Get Happy is taken up with what will for many be a familiar account of loves and losses of self-control, perhaps the most arresting part is the section on Garland's late youth and early adulthood. Through the studio's difficulties in casting her - "they didn't know what to do with me because they wanted you either five years old or eighteen, with nothing in between," she said - something about her can be clearly seen.

Garland doesn't seem to have experienced the change from child to adult as a transition, she seems to have carried both extremes within her all her life. This is not merely because of her experiences - the fact that she was singing at the Cocoanut Grove at the age of nine, for instance - it was a strange and unique fusion she possessed. When she was twelve, Garland (then Frances Gumm) performed an act in which she sat on stage covered in a shawl so that only her face was visible in the spotlight. She sang a melancholy torch song with a deep, womanly voice. Only when the applause had started did she throw off the shawl and reveal her childish form; it was this uncanny factor that had audiences raving. But it wasn't always so successful - she tried singing love songs straight, her child's body unhidden, and had to stop, because people thought it just too weird.

The studio never really stopped treating her as a child, so much so that it is difficult to think of her as a mother. When she was pregnant with Liza, Louis B Mayer protested, "we simply can't have that baby have a child!", and it's as if she made herself unable to deal with adult life, or parental life, by abusing her grown-up body. After several drying-out programs, Garland was sent to a hospital in Boston, where she was particularly popular on the children's ward. "If I was cured at Peter Bent Brigham," she said of the hospital, "it was only because of those children." Clarke writes that she became very close to one girl, who had been so badly abused she had been catatonic for two years. Garland, who had got through her own childhood by singing, spent a good deal of time with the silent girl. At the end of her three-month stay, she went to say goodbye. As Garland bent down to kiss her, the child spoke for the first time.

"Judy!" she shouted, "I love you! I love you! Don't leave!" Perhaps only now did the glamour of the MGM stars seem less significant than being Judy - the person everyone felt they could speak to.

 Gaby Wood is writing a book about dolls and automata for Faber.

fields.headline: Smoking jacket
fields.trailText: • To the Groucho Club, where the usually libertarian regime was severely tested by a party to celebrate The Faber Book of Smoking, edited by James Walton. Such was the fug created by eager puffers that smoke-alarm mayhem was only narrowly averted. That relations between staff and guests remained cordial might be ascribed to the Walton Effect, a peculiar aura of calm and reassurance that led the publisher to relax its deadlines. It was, an employee of Faber remarked, the first time they had seen a manuscript delivered in a crate; neither was there usually so much evidence of scissors and paste, Walton being less than enthusiastic about modern technology.
fields.body:
 To the Groucho Club, where the usually libertarian regime was severely tested by a party to celebrate The Faber Book of Smoking, edited by James Walton. Such was the fug created by eager puffers that smoke-alarm mayhem was only narrowly averted. That relations between staff and guests remained cordial might be ascribed to the Walton Effect, a peculiar aura of calm and reassurance that led the publisher to relax its deadlines. It was, an employee of Faber remarked, the first time they had seen a manuscript delivered in a crate; neither was there usually so much evidence of scissors and paste, Walton being less than enthusiastic about modern technology.

 Meanwhile, Faber has just signed up another author with an unmistakable aura - Paul McCartney, whose collection of lyrics and poetry will be edited by Adrian Mitchell. According to Mitchell's agent, about three-quarters of the material has never been seen before. Fans of the Beatles and the Frog Chorus need only wait until next March.

 Always keen to celebrate literary milestones, the Loafer notes that November 18 is the day - albeit only in alternate years - that Edward Gorey's celebrated fictional creation Mr Earbrass traditionally begins his new novel. Gorey's The Unstrung Harp, recently reissued by Bloomsbury, is a cautionary tale for any would-be author, particularly in its treatment of celebrity. When Mr Earbrass attends a party at Le Trottoir Imbecile, the talk is of "disappointing sales, inadequate publicity, worse than inadequate royalties, idiotic or criminal reviews, others' declining talent, and the unspeakable horror of the literary life". Quite.

 At least Nick Hornby is up-front about cronyism in his latest venture, a collection of stories in support of the Treehouse Trust for autistic children. "Robert Harris is the editor's brother-in-law," reports the Editor's Notes, adding of John O'Farrell: "He went to the editor's school, funnily enough." Meanwhile, Helen Fielding nestles beneath Colin Firth, aka Mr Darcy, and reports herself to be obsessed by him (Mr Darcy, that is). "Boringly, everyone lives in London," the notes end.

 Booker finalist Brian O'Doherty can console himself with his inclusion on another august shortlist. The Literary Review's annual Bad Sex Prize has alighted on the special relationship between man and sheep in O'Doherty's The Deposition of Father McGreevy - alongside squelchy offerings from John Updike, Candida Clark and Jerry Hall's former date Edward St Aubyn. Much to the dismay of booksellers, Margaret Atwood has not been nominated.

fields.headline: Was he human?
fields.standfirst: Phil Baker  explores the weird world of Wyndham Lewis through Paul O'Keefe's biography, Some Sort of Genius, and Paul Edwards's Wyndam Lewis: Painter and Writer
fields.trailText: Phil Baker explores the weird world of Wyndham Lewis through Paul O'Keefe's biography, Some Sort of Genius, and Paul Edwards's Wyndam Lewis: Painter and Writer
fields.body:
Some Sort of Genius: A Life of Wyndham Lewis

Paul O'Keeffe

697pp, Jonathan Cape

£25

Buy it at BOL

Wyndham Lewis: Painter and Writer

Paul Edwards 583pp, Yale

£40
Buy it at BOL

Wyndham Lewis was the hard man of modernism. He presented himself as "The Enemy", and society took him at his word. Of all the great modernists, Lewis is the one who has stayed out in the cold, despite his double genius as both painter and writer. Walter Sickert called him the "greatest portraitist of this or any other time", and T S Eliot described him as "the greatest prose master of style of my generation".

Lewis wrote like no one else: "hairy, surgical, and yet invisible" is a not uncharacteristic Lewis description, while modern society was "the moronic inferno". Lewis's punky-looking 1914 publication Blast dished out the praise and blame with deliberately erratic typography and all the aggressive energy that was Lewis's stock in trade. Its blasting and blessing read like a prototype of all those glossy magazine "In/Out" lists. "BLESS the HAIRDRESSER" runs a typical entry: "He attacks Mother Nature for a small fee."

Unfortunately, an enthusiasm for short haircuts - excellent though they are - is not irrelevant when it comes to Lewis's politics. Legions of point-scoring bores know that Lewis once wrote a book called The Jews: Are They Human?, although they don't always know that this book - from the calculated obscenity of the title onwards - is a tract against anti-semitism. As Paul O'Keeffe points out in his impressive biography, it not only takes its title from a forgotten humorous bestseller called The English: Are They Human?, but it got a bad review in the Mosleyite British Union Quarterly and a good one in The Jewish Chronicle .

That doesn't let Lewis off the hook completely. His Jewish book (and his anti-Nazi book, The Hitler Cult) were part of a damage-limitation exercise, an attempt to undo the gaffe he'd made with his 1931 book Hitler ("This celibate inhabitant of a modest Alpine chalet - vegetarian, non-smoking, and non-drinking ... the most unassuming of men ..."). But the inter-war years were a strange time, and Lewis was hardly alone in his extremism: T S Eliot wrote to the Daily Mail to praise the paper's pro-Mussolini stance, George Bernard Shaw hero-worshipped Stalin, and Graham Greene's books had to be re-edited after the war to take the anti-semitic bits out. You can't help feeling there is a touch of scapegoating with Lewis, and a kind of inverse McCarthyism: both the New Statesman and the aptly named Partisan Review spiked pieces on Lewis for not being negative enough.

Lewis's political fascination lies not so much in his declared views - perhaps not even in his conscious views - but in the intrinsically political aspect of his sensibility or temperament. Lewis had a strong aesthetic preference for stylisation, and for clean lines and hard surfaces. He liked dynamic stasis and machine-like forms, and he disliked time and flux and subjectivity (which stood him alone against the prevailing 20th-century current of Bergson, Freud, Proust and Joyce).

He didn't like messy interior monologues or messy internal organs; instead, he was a man for the carapace. In fact, Wilhelm Reich's hoary old psychosexual idea of "character armour" seems oddly appropriate to Lewis. For all its energy, there is often something alienating about Lewis's sensibility. Despite his violent perfection at the level of the phrase, his writing can be unreadably arid over the longer haul of a book. When you realise his comment on W H Auden - "all ice and wooden-faced acrobatics" - is intended as praise, it gives you a suspicion that life out there on Planet Lewis might not be quite as we know it.

Lewis could be intensely paranoid and prickly, and he seems to have been almost physically incapable of not being rude to people. He had been a great drinking buddy of Joyce (O'Keeffe gives a nice account of them sitting in a Paris gutter together), but he still attacked Joyce's work - brilliantly - in Time and Western Man, then stitched up the Sitwells (and virtually everyone else he'd known, including friends and patrons) in his satirical novel The Apes of God. Editors handled Lewis at their own risk. Times Literary Supplement editor Alan Pryce-Jones (a "Tory pansy" anyway, as far as Lewis was concerned) once made some changes to a piece that Lewis had written. Lewis hit back with an almost psychotically sarcastic commentary on the alterations, then threw in a homophobic dig about Pryce-Jones's editorial "fairy wand" for good measure. As Anthony Powell puts it, in his wonderfully ponderous High Court judge style: "The impression ... that all was not well with the balance of Lewis's mind could not be avoided."

Lewis wasn't all venom. The death of a pet dog would bring out the human being in almost anybody, but instead of just wallowing in sentimentality, Lewis's reflections on the death of his terrier quickly slide to his long-suffering wife, who shared what Lewis felt was ostracism by the envious. "The death of our hirsute gremlin has left an ugly gap," he wrote to a friend. When it came to the world's malice, "my wife has had to pay as well as myself. So this small creature, which stood for all that was benevolent in the universe, sweetened the bitter medicine for her. Like the spirit of a simpler and saner time, this fragment of primitive life confided his destiny to her, and went through all the black days beside us. She feels she has been wanting in some care ... Such are the reflections that beset her. Whereas I am just another human being - by no means a well of primitive joie de vivre ..."

Lewis ended his life blinded by a slow-growing brain tumour. His eyesight had been going for some time, and he once tried to hail a hearse instead of a black cab, which must have been a pregnant moment. Finally he had to give up his post as art critic: as he politely explained in the "unseemly autobiographical outburst" of his last piece, he could no longer see the pictures. "Pushed into an unlighted room, the door banged and locked for ever, I shall then have to light a lamp of aggressive voltage in my mind to keep at bay the night."

Paul O'Keeffe has had a difficult task with Some Sort of Genius: A Life of Wyndham Lewis, because he has had to avoid retreading the steps of Jeffrey Meyer's excellent 1980 biography, The Enemy, which remains the best life of Lewis. O'Keeffe opens with a three-page consideration of a brain tumour, deliberately not saying whose it is, and this is characteristic of a book so packed with circumstantial detail that it sometimes feels as if it should be called Some Sort of Laundry List: A Life of Somebody or Other. Along with an occasional dry wit, O'Keeffe's deadpan deployment of his material makes his book into a literary experiment in its own right. His penchant for giving data on groceries, diphtheria, meteorology and dry rot (or Merulius lacrymans, which even becomes a chapter title) is probably meant to be objectively materialist and impersonal in a way that is appropriate to Lewis, but a stronger sense of form and outline would have been equally appropriate.

Like Some Sort of Genius, Paul Edwards's Wyndham Lewis: Painter and Writer has clearly been years in the making. It is not a life but an intensely detailed study of the work, and it is a very handsome book, with several hundred of Lewis's pictures integrated into the dense text. It consolidates Edwards's position as probably the world's leading Lewis scholar, if not his most readable critic, and at least the nitty-gritty closeness of Edwards's discussion does justice to Lewis's own complexity. Edwards's superior factual knowledge allows him to take trenchant issue with other critics and their axe-grinding agendas, including the celebrated American Marxist, Fredric Jameson, who is himself the author of an exceptionally interesting short book on Lewis.

Lewis hated mass culture and feared what we would now call "dumbing down", but Edwards also brings out his anticipations of pop art, postmodernism and globalisation. Lewis was a genius of multiple self-contradictions, who deserves to be nobody's ideological Aunt Sally. To quote another not quite fashionable figure, Harold Bloom, great writers are subversive of all values, both ours and their own.

webTitle: Review: The Truth by Terry Pratchett

fields.headline: Speaking truth to power
fields.standfirst: Terry Pratchett's The Truth  is as good as ever, says  Helen Falconer
fields.trailText: Terry Pratchett's The Truth is as good as ever, says Helen Falconer
fields.body:
The Truth
Terry Pratchett
424pp, Doubleday
£16.99
Buy it at BOL

Terry Pratchett is famous for writing comic fantasy, but there is more to him than that - he has developed into a scathing political satirist. Thus, despite there being plenty of wizards around in Discworld adept at turning one element into another, in this 25th novel in the series those conjuring gold from lead are messing with reality in a far more dangerous way - they are producing Ankh-Morpork's first daily newspaper.

Young, earnest William de Worde is proud of his one-sheet, hand-engraved newsletter. He is proud that it always gets its facts right (as far as he can tell). And he is proud of its impressive circulation (six copies, at five dollars a copy). But after running into the dwarfs' new printing press (actually it runs into him), he pushes his print-run up, halves the price and starts hiring staff ... and then discovers that a surprising number of people want him dead, or at least very ill indeed.

William's biggest mistake? Well, that depends on who you talk to. As far as the Guild of Engravers is concerned, it's his sacrilegious use of moveable type. As for as those plotting a right-wing coup, it's that annoying habit he has of writing down the things that people say to him. And as far as his readership is concerned, it's his tendency to drone on about coups and other boring political issues and to leave out the really important stuff carried by his tabloid rival, like that story about the man-eating goldfish.

Willam can understand why the guilds want to do him down (by getting their own press and churning out the dreadful Ankh-Morpork Inquirer ). He can even understand - if not forgive - the reasons behind the attempted coup (a nasty racist backlash against the increasing numbers of dwarfs, trolls, vampires etc living in Ankh-Morpork).

But what William just can't understand or forgive is his readers' total lack of interest in The Truth, and their tendency, when told about crucial affairs of state, to say things like "they're all the same".

Pratchett has found his own way of turning lead into gold, and by that I don't just mean that he's written 25 bestsellers in 17 years, but that every one he has written is a treasure.

webTitle: Review: biographies of Berlioz and Pope Pius XII

fields.headline: Beautiful music and dirty politics
fields.trailText: John Dugdale on a biography of Berlioz by David Cairns and The Secret History of Pius XII by John Cornwell
fields.body:
Berlioz: Servitude and Greatness 1832-1869
David Cairns
(Penguin £12.99)
Buy it at BOL

Why the French disdain to pen biographies of their own artistic greats is baffling, but their reluctance has made possible Hilary Spurling's Matisse, Graham Robb's Balzac and Cairns's award-winning study of Berlioz. Covering a period that includes Benvenuto Cellini, the Requiem and The Trojans, and the composer's marriages to the actress Harriet Smithson and the singer Marie Recio, the second volume depicts the post-Romantic musical scene in Balzacian detail, with walk-on appearances by Liszt, Meyerbeer, Mendelssohn, Rossini and Wagner. Its analysis of the works is as acute as that of the subject's moods and relationships.

Hitler's Pope: The Secret History of Pius XII
John Cornwell
(Penguin £7.99)
Buy it at BOL

John Paul II plans to canonise Pius XII. But as a Vatican diplomat in the 1930s, the then Eugenio Pacelli masterminded a concordat with Hitler, extending the church's power over Germany's 23m Catholics in exchange for its withdrawal from politics and the disbanding of the Catholic Centre Party. And after becoming Pope in 1939 he refused to condemn Nazism and the Holocaust, failed to protect Rome's Jews, and formed links with Croatia's fascist Ustashe. Rather than a simple indictment, Cornwell's superb biography is a complex study of self-delusion, resembling Gitta Sereny's life of Albert Speer.

fields.headline: The House
fields.trailText:
That house had taken us
Into its dusty arms...
fields.body:
That house had taken us
Into its dusty arms,
And after some years
Of apprenticeship
In all its obscurities
We left it, much wiser.

There were others in our place,
Some Lolita-like girls
With acrobats' eyes,
Fallen into the law's ditch:
One had 'married' her father,
Another, with a parsnip smile,
A slave to the sex of a woman.
Both still smarting
As disciples of love.
A third, thin girl
With a refugee face,
A wire-cage head of hair,
Dark as burnt grass,
Could not refrain from stealing.
She wanted to cram herself
Full of precious objects,
Be pregnant with possessions.

The house tried its best
With corridors and corners
Declaring protection,
A barricade to fence off
'thou shalt not'
To point them towards
A new existence -
For a short while only.

webTitle: Review: Abyssinian Chronicles  by Moses Isegawa

fields.headline: Into the heart of grunge
fields.standfirst: Maya Jaggi  dissects a lively first novel from Uganda - Abyssinian Chronicles  by Moses Isegawa
fields.trailText: Maya Jaggi dissects a lively first novel from Uganda - Abyssinian Chronicles by Moses Isegawa
fields.body:
Abyssinian Chronicles

Moses Isegawa

480pp, Picador

£16
Buy it at BOL

'It is a great irony of history and geography," wrote Chinua Achebe, "that Africa, whose land mass is closer than any other to the mainland of Europe, should come to occupy in European psychological disposition the farthest point of otherness, should indeed become Europe's very antithesis." Like Edward Said, Achebe saw the cause not in ignorance but in concerted invention. He was among the first to rehumanise the "dark continent" for its neighbours through fiction that told its story on its own terms.

Moses Isegawa's sprawlingly ambitious first novel, Abyssinian Chronicles, pulls off something of the same feat amid the carnage and chaos of post-independence Uganda. Its title has nothing to do with ancient Ethiopia, but puns on a country that was "a land of false bottoms where under every abyss there was another one".

First published two years ago in the Netherlands, where Isegawa lives, the novel was hailed as a Ugandan The Tin Drum or Midnight's Children. Günter Grass and Salman Rushdie are indeed spectral presences. Yet it has African precedents, too, in perhaps more assured novels of the past 15 years that meld history with myth and metaphor, entwining personal fates with those of nations and communities - from Nuruddin Farah's Maps (1986) and Kojo Laing's Search Sweet Country (1986) to Moyez Vassanji's The Gunny Sack (1989) and Ben Okri's The Famished Road (1991).

Nor does Abyssinian Chronicles rely on the "magical realism" of Rushdie and Gabriel García Márquez, or the so-called spiritual realism of Okri and his Yoruba forebears. Its mode is gritty, even grungy realism, despite extravagant imagery and an omniscient narrator, Mugezi, who is able to recount the faraway deaths of his father, Serenity, in the jaws of a colossal crocodile, and his mother, Padlock, gored by a bull and tossed "like a Korean trapeze artist".

Mugezi's watchful, sly intelligence and acerbic, sometimes lacerating tone dominate the novel, in which his coming of age keeps pace with the country's. Born in 1960, with independence, he witnesses the 1966 state of emergency, the rise and fall of Idi Amin and the ousting of the returned dictator Milton Obote in 1986 after renewed civil war. This freewheeling history is grounded in the lives of Mugezi's family - united only when watching Muhammad Ali fights - in coffee-growing swampland festering with illicit passions and religious rivalries. It reaches back to the sectarian battles of the 1950s, as Protestantism and Catholicism vie with Islam and traditional beliefs.

Christianity proves a target, notably in Mugezi's parents - Serenity, a "benevolent dictator" who takes his wife's aunt as his lover, and Padlock, a disrobed nun who regards semen as "holy snot" and is given to "beating children like drums". Her aim is to break Mugezi, a "free spirit with piratical proclivities", not least through the latrine duties he performs for his younger siblings - unerringly referred to as "the shitters". From the urban dystopia of Kampala, where his family settles in the "red-roofed pretention of a big Indian bungalow" after Amin's expulsion of Ugandan Asians, Mugezi is banished to a seminary run by tyrants "programmed to obey and be obeyed".

The novel lingers unduly on Mugezi's swashbuckling run-ins with parents and priests, drawing forced parallels with national authority (he is seduced into adopting Amin as his "guardian angel" before adulthood brings an end to the "flirtation"). More compelling is the depiction of the apocalyptic legacy of Amin's 3,010 days in power, Tanzanian intervention, and the renewed bush war that follows Obote's return. While Mugezi searches for his dead grandfather, near-skeletons rise from Amin's torture chambers, his henchmen are "necklaced", and child guerrillas spread terror.

As the decades pass and Mugezi, a corrupt anti-corruption agent, finds his village overrun by coffee-smuggling youths in bell-bottoms, platform shoes and Afro wigs, Isegawa observes how history "wrote, erased and rewrote itself". The rebels capture Kampala on the 15th anniversary of Amin's coup; the expelled Indians return under IMF fiat; and war gives way to plague, "Slim" or Aids claiming the survivors as surely as Spanish flu did after the first world war.

His village - and by implication a whole country-destroyed, the final chapter shifts to Amsterdam, as Mugezi directs his vengeful and war-scarred vision at a European heart of darkness, its aid agencies purveying "the worst in international beggary, image pillage and necrophilic exploitation", its red-light cages like slaves' auction blocks. Reborn with a false British passport, Mugezi is a "rebel on a vague mission", who finds his metier where "words were beaten into weapons".

Unsurprisingly given the novel's breadth (Mugezi's affairs with Dutch women perhaps warrant a book in themselves), there is an unevenness in pace and tone. The humanity in the depiction of Mugezi's aunt's death from Aids, and the sympathy for African women as "olympic medallist camouflagers of pain" are replaced by a cold misogyny towards Amsterdam prostitutes, and a perfunctory effort to humanise Indian shopkeepers, otherwise seen as "pirates" with their "curried curses".

While the prose can be overwritten ("vengeance remained sealed in the kaleidoscopic casket of euphoria"), Isegawa's talent lies in his mordant perspective, his imagery and freshness of language: the Indian community is said to split "like a jackfruit dropped on concrete", while the puritanical Padlock, allowing herself to flirt, laughs "discreetly, as if she were straining a precious liquid through cotton cloth". Abyssinian Chronicles may lack the sedate control of distance, but it has a momentum and energy that derive from the trauma it tells from the inside.

Nor does Abyssinian Chronicles rely on the "magical realism" of Rushdie and Gabriel García Márquez, or the so-called spiritual realism of Okri and his Yoruba forebears. Its mode is gritty, even grungy realism, despite extravagant imagery and an omniscient narrator, Mugezi, who is able to recount the faraway deaths of his father, Serenity, in the jaws of a colossal crocodile, and his mother, Padlock, gored by a bull and tossed "like a Korean trapeze artist". Mugezi's watchful, sly intelligence and acerbic, sometimes lacerating tone dominate the novel, in which his coming of age keeps pace with the country's. Born in 1960, with independence, he witnesses the 1966 state of emergency, the rise and fall of Idi Amin and the ousting of the returned dictator Milton Obote in 1986 after renewed civil war. This freewheeling history is grounded in the lives of Mugezi's family - united only when watching Muhammad Ali fights - in coffee-growing swampland festering with illicit passions and religious rivalries. It reaches back to the sectarian battles of the 1950s, as Protestantism and Catholicism vie with Islam and traditional beliefs. Christianity proves a target, notably in Mugezi's parents - Serenity, a "benevolent dictator" who takes his wife's aunt as his lover, and Padlock, a disrobed nun who regards semen as "holy snot" and is given to "beating children like drums". Her aim is to break Mugezi, a "free spirit with piratical proclivities", not least through the latrine duties he performs for his younger siblings - unerringly referred to as "the shitters". From the urban dystopia of Kampala, where his family settles in the "red-roofed pretention of a big Indian bungalow" after Amin's expulsion of Ugandan Asians, Mugezi is banished to a seminary run by tyrants "programmed to obey and be obeyed". The novel lingers unduly on Mugezi's swashbuckling run-ins with parents and priests, drawing forced parallels with national authority (he is seduced into adopting Amin as his "guardian angel" before adulthood brings an end to the "flirtation"). More compelling is the depiction of the apocalyptic legacy of Amin's 3,010 days in power, Tanzanian intervention, and the renewed bush war that follows Obote's return. While Mugezi searches for his dead grandfather, near-skeletons rise from Amin's torture chambers, his henchmen are "necklaced", and child guerrillas spread terror. As the decades pass and Mugezi, a corrupt anti-corruption agent, finds his village overrun by coffee-smuggling youths in bell-bottoms, platform shoes and Afro wigs, Isegawa observes how history "wrote, erased and rewrote itself". The rebels capture Kampala on the 15th anniversary of Amin's coup; the expelled Indians return under IMF fiat; and war gives way to plague, "Slim" or Aids claiming the survivors as surely as Spanish flu did after the first world war. His village - and by implication a whole country-destroyed, the final chapter shifts to Amsterdam, as Mugezi directs his vengeful and war-scarred vision at a European heart of darkness, its aid agencies purveying "the worst in international beggary, image pillage and necrophilic exploitation", its red-light cages like slaves' auction blocks. Reborn with a false British passport, Mugezi is a "rebel on a vague mission", who finds his metier where "words were beaten into weapons". Unsurprisingly given the novel's breadth (Mugezi's affairs with Dutch women perhaps warrant a book in themselves), there is an unevenness in pace and tone. The humanity in the depiction of Mugezi's aunt's death from Aids, and the sympathy for African women as "olympic medallist camouflagers of pain" are replaced by a cold misogyny towards Amsterdam prostitutes, and a perfunctory effort to humanise Indian shopkeepers, otherwise seen as "pirates" with their "curried curses". While the prose can be overwritten ("vengeance remained sealed in the kaleidoscopic casket of euphoria"), Isegawa's talent lies in his mordant perspective, his imagery and freshness of language: the Indian community is said to split "like a jackfruit dropped on concrete", while the puritanical Padlock, allowing herself to flirt, laughs "discreetly, as if she were straining a precious liquid through cotton cloth". Abyssinian Chronicles may lack the sedate control of distance, but it has a momentum and energy that derive from the trauma it tells from the inside.

fields.headline: New information about aunts
fields.standfirst: Claire Tomalin tells Nicholas Wroe why she gave up poetry for biography
fields.trailText: Claire Tomalin tells Nicholas Wroe why she gave up poetry for biography
fields.body:
Biographer and literary editor Claire Tomalin was obviously a strong candidate when she applied for her first job as a secretary and editorial assistant in a publishing firm. She was just out of Cambridge with a first in English, she was a published poet and a French speaker, and she could type.

But it wasn't entirely her CV that won her the job. Tomalin's career was launched after she was awarded 7 out of 10 for her looks by one of her future colleagues. "This is how things were done in 1954," she writes in Several Strangers: Writing From Three Decades, her absorbing collection of memoir and journalism that is out in paperback this month.

The book opens with Tomalin coming down from Cambridge. But her path into writing had been set much earlier. Her mother had been a songwriter who read a lot of poetry to her daughter. "Poetry was one of the things that interested me most as I was growing up. I used to write it in my head all the time. I still think the very greatest pleasure in life is to write a poem. When something comes to you, apparently out of nowhere, but only a bit of it so you have to work for weeks to build the rest of the poem."

Her work had been published at Cambridge, but when some of her poems were rejected by the London Magazine she stopped writing verse. "I just thought 'That's it'. I think I had realised when I came down from Cambridge that my poetry wasn't really good enough. And looking who came after me" - Sylvia Plath was in the year below her at Cambridge - "I was absolutely right. But I do think that all that writing and all that struggling with words has been invaluable. I re-write and re-write endlessly now, and I say it all aloud to myself."

Though Tomalin was good at publishing, she was aware of the glass ceiling in the industry. "While women could work for publishers, there was never any question that they would have any power in the firm." She reasoned that as she was reading new books and recommending them for publication, it wouldn't be such a great step to become a reviewer. She moved over to journalism and was appointed assistant literary editor of the New Statesman. Her own move into hard covers came when she was on maternity leave from the Statesman in 1971. She sat down with her husband - the journalist Nicholas Tomalin, who was killed in 1973 reporting from the Golan Heights during the Yom Kippur war - and they wrote down all the pros and cons of writing a book. The credit side out-weighed the debit side and so she wrote her first biography. It was of Mary Wollstonecraft, the 18th-century pamphleteer and novelist, and it won the Whitbread first book prize in 1974.

Shortly after her husband's death, she was offered the job of literary editor at the Statesman. Her daughter has said that this was the time Tomalin recognisably became the woman she is today. "I loved running my family and I loved running my department," she says. "I was able to be responsible and I really enjoyed that. And it's also a creative thing running the back half of the New Statesman. You can make judgments about books and promote them. You can find writers. It was terrific." She also acted as a one-woman finishing school for a new generation of British fiction writing, and her deputies over the years included Martin Amis, Julian Barnes and Timothy Mo.

Tomalin went on to write acclaimed biographies of Shelley, Nelly Ternan, Dora Jordan, Jane Austen and Katherine Mansfield (about whom she also wrote a play). She was asked, too, to write a biography of Sylvia Plath, and she agreed - but Ted Hughes vetoed the project. "My husband" - she has been married to the novelist and playwright Michael Frayn since 1976 - "said it was a lucky escape. But that's not quite how I feel about it even now."

Several Strangers includes Tomalin's review of Janet Malcolm's controversial 1994 biography of Plath. "It is not really much concerned with Sylvia Plath and not at all with her poetry." she wrote. "It is deeply concerned with the nastiness of biography, and with interviewing and the impossibility of objectivity." Tomalin defends biography as a form, saying: "Janet Malcom was naughty. People who attack biography choose as their models vulgar and offensive biography. You could equally attack novels or poems by choosing bad poems or novels."

She says that finding the right tone for the autobiographical sections of Several Strangers was difficult - "other people are involved; children, friends, family" - but she hopes one day to write a full-scale memoir. In the meantime she has plenty going on. She is currently "deeply absorbed in the 18th century", working on a biography of Pepys. "He's one of the great writers in the English language, but he has never been studied as literature in the universities so he's wonderfully fresh. The writing of the diary is terrific. It is so flexible and vivid and concise. He gives an anatomy of himself and of the world."

A paperback edition of her Jane Austen biography, with new information about Austen's aunts, is also published this month. "I continually get more information about a subject after the book has been published. But with Jane Austen I didn't really think this would be the case, so I am delighted to have been sent something new. It's the most wonderful aspect of biography that these books can have lives after they are published."

webTitle: On Histories and Stories by A S Byatt

fields.headline: Directing traffic
fields.standfirst: Ian Sansom  enjoys A S Byatt's engaging essays, On Histories and Stories
fields.trailText: Ian Sansom enjoys A S Byatt's engaging essays, On Histories and Stories
fields.body:
On Histories and Stories: Selected Essays

A S Byatt

212pp, Chatto & Windus

£16.99
Buy it at BOL

If, as one suspects, the only reason for our existence is approbation, then most literary criticism is a waste of time, since most literary criticism concerns itself only with disapprobation. A book of criticism is usually like a long plumber's whistle, or an irritated shake of the head, and reading it is about as much fun as sorting nails or sifting thistles.

A S Byatt's On Histories and Stories is another kind of criticism. Byatt is no grumbler. In her discussion of works of fiction, rather than judging weaknesses she sets out to account for strengths. She talks things up. You get the impression that she actually enjoys reading. On Histories and Stories is therefore criticism as it used to be written, before critics toned up on theory and pigged out on cultural studies, and before what Byatt calls that "gladiatorial antagonism" developed between writers and critics.

Byatt discusses contemporary fiction but ignores pulp. She engages with ideas but avoids jargon. The book probably contains fewer niggles and prickles than the average work of polemics or scholarship, but more than the average weight of subtleties and insights. In seven chapters - on "Fathers", "Forefathers", "Ancestors", et cetera - Byatt sets out to explore the various uses and meanings of historical fiction, and discusses her own methods in composing novels, novellas and short stories. The essays are, she claims in her introduction, "a writer's essays".

Many of them are also, it should be said, lecture notes, and there is a certain tone, both authoritative and casual, that indicates their true origins. "I shall come back to the the opposition of probability and chance, both as subject and as form of the novel later," Byatt announces to her empty auditorium. She waves and signposts, with a rather aristocratic and proprietorial air, directing the traffic and attention like the lady of the manor who has opened up the house for the summer. "Come on, hurry up, please, into the library. Chop chop. Now, look! Look over there. Yes, look at all this terrific literature!"

In discussing and enthusing about writers and their works - from The Arabian Nights to Lawrence Norfolk - Byatt summarises neatly and quotes wonderfully. The quotations are often lengthy, and there are many of them. This matters. "Next to the originator of a good sentence is the first quoter of it," wrote Emerson ( Journals , volume 16). "My quotations", Byatt claims, "are like the slides in an art historical lecture." They are in fact nothing like so dull and flat. It's more like listening to someone humming arias - pleasant, but occasionally irritating. Her embellishments can be rather artless.

The Irish, apparently, "argue beautifully and passionately" and "are happy to suppose that English writing can be dismissed". This is caricature. She is also prone to digression and doodle. "It is interesting to compare Free Fall with Earthly Powers." "It is interesting to compare Hawksmoor with William Golding's The Spire , which is also about the building of churches." "It is interesting also to compare Ackroyd's thresholds between past and present with a recent novel by a young Scottish writer, A L Kennedy." The comparisons and intuitions are often stimulating, but sometimes insubstantial: as with a flirtation, the expression of interest becomes the interest itself.

The book contains, nonetheless, some important insights. Her reading of contemporary fiction as a series of plays on certain Darwinian plots is illuminating. For example, it allows her to read Penelope Fitzgerald's novel The Gate for Angels through Ian Hacking's book about probability, The Taming of Chance, and her summary of Fitzgerald's book reveals exactly what is surprising and disturbing about its apparent simplicity - that sense that "there is more here, more significance, than the sheer pleasure of elegant prose and the satisfactory storytelling". Fitzgerald, she concludes, is "playing lightly with the random and haphazard, in the form of her novel and in life".

What Byatt won't admit about historical fiction, though, despite all her talk of such subtle plottings, is its determined thrust and ambition. The historical novel may throw light upon modern sensibilities, and may often be an example of considerable ingenuity, and even an expression of great moral seriousness, but it is also an example of the will to power. "Playing lightly" it is not. The historical novel is always boasting about its knowhow, whether it's by Penelope Fitzgerald or Norman Mailer. It loves to display its credentials. It preens. It knows how to sell itself. And above all, it desires success. One suspects that Byatt, author of the bestselling Possession , knows more about this - the real secret of histories and stories - than she is letting on.

fields.headline: Chewing-gum and chocolate
fields.trailText: Isobel Montgomery on how Iceland got from the Vikings to Björk in Devil's Island, plus The Edge Of Europe, Black Girl in Paris and Beware Of Pity
fields.body:
Devil's Island
Einar Karason
(Canongate, £9.99)
Buy it at BOL

Few of us can plot how Iceland got from Vikings to Björk, but this is an entertaining way to fill in part of the story. Tomi, fisherman turned hand-cart trader, and Lina, the fortune teller, are indirect beneficiaries of the Allied invasion of Iceland. While they and their neighbours get hold of vacuum cleaners and three-piece suites for beaten-earth floors, the grandchildren Baddi and Danni get to taste the American dream for real. Novels about the chewing-gum-and-chocolate aftermath of the second world war are almost as universal as apple pie and the US army, but Einar Karason's sprawling narrative is a welcome addition: a familiar story with a new topography.

The Edge Of Europe
Angela Bianchini
(Bison, £9.95)
Buy it at BOL

This novella's lengthy afterword would help nicely with an essay on Italian fiction of the holocaust. Bianchini is not quite another Primo Levi or Georgio Bassani, but her heroine, whose ignorance of the racial politics of world war is punctured when she leaves Italy via Lisbon for America, is a symbol for the attitudes of Italy's assimilated Jewish middle class. Bianchini's Lisbon, Europe's last stop, is cousin to Casablanca: hemmed in by armies, afraid of strangulation. Ruben, through whom the girl will get her safe passage, has the magnetism of Bogart plus left-wing credentials. Atmosphere and emotion are Bianchini's strengths; history lessons with subtlety, unfortunately, are not.

Beware Of Pity
Stefan Zweig
(Pushkin Press, £10)
Buy it at BOL

Zweig, essayist and biographer, wrote only this one full-length novel before he committed suicide, a refugee from Nazism, in Brazil in 1942. Beware of Pity has an army officer as narrator and the Austro-Hungarian Empire as setting. It is infused with a feverish young man's notions of honour. Through his encounter with the crippled daughter of a provincial landowner, Hofmiller learns when pity is disguised selfishness and when it becomes a disinterested act of charity. The lesson is rammed home and the contrast between now (1937) and then (1913) made inescapably obvious. It is a curiously 19th-century response to the 20th-century nightmare.

Black Girl in Paris
Shay Youngblood
(Women's Press, £9.99)
Buy it at BOL

Almost any American going to Paris in a novel has to pause for a moment's consideration of Stein and Miller, 1920s jazz and cocktails. A young black girl thinks of Baldwin and Hughes. She must also find room for Josephine Baker, negritude, freedom and equality somewhere in her hand baggage. It is a tight squeeze for any author, but Youngblood deals admirably with the symbolism of the city while letting her heroine, Eden, get on with her own journey. Angelou and Walker have laid the trail for this kind of feel-good odyssey but Youngblood gets you behind Eden all the way.

fields.headline: What's selling in popular-science
fields.trailText: The top ten pop-science books
fields.body:
Popular-science publishing, like the universe, is ever expanding - and not just with more of the same, but with more of anything that could possibly be pulled to this lucrative association. So, at the top of this chart, we find not a science book at all but narrative non-fiction: Dava Sobel's follow-up to her bestselling Longitude. Simon Singh makes two appearances with what is basically the same book (The Science of Secrecy is The Code Book dolled up for TV).

Some books never age, and Stephen Hawking's A Brief History of Time remains the standard peephole onto the arcane world of physics. Martin Rees and Steve Jones bring a similar authority to, respectively, astronomy and genetics. Meanwhile, books about zero may be newly fashionable, but Robert Kaplan got there first with his cultured pop-maths meditation, The Nothing That Is, now deservedly riding high in paperback.

fields.bodyText: Popular-science publishing, like the universe, is ever expanding - and not just with more of the same, but with more of anything that could possibly be pulled to this lucrative association. So, at the top of this chart, we find not a science book at all but narrative non-fiction: Dava Sobel's follow-up to her bestselling Longitude. Simon Singh makes two appearances with what is basically the same book (The Science of Secrecy is The Code Book dolled up for TV). Some books never age, and Stephen Hawking's A Brief History of Time remains the standard peephole onto the arcane world of physics. Martin Rees and Steve Jones bring a similar authority to, respectively, astronomy and genetics. Meanwhile, books about zero may be newly fashionable, but Robert Kaplan got there first with his cultured pop-maths meditation, The Nothing That Is, now deservedly riding high in paperback. fields.headline: Prince eyes Sky Global
fields.trailText: Prince Alwaleed Bin Talal, the Saudi businessman, has met Rupert Murdoch in New York to discuss an investment in Sky Global, the satellite television business being spun out of News Corporation, the media empire.
fields.body:
Prince Alwaleed Bin Talal, the Saudi businessman, has met Rupert Murdoch in New York to discuss an investment in Sky Global, the satellite television business being spun out of News Corporation, the media empire.

The Saudi prince, one of the world's wealthiest men with an estimated net worth of $20bn (£14bn), is understood to be keen to invest in the new business, which includes British Sky Broadcasting and other assets.

A financial vote of confidence from the prince would help Mr Murdoch fulfil his ambitions of creating a leading global satellite platform.

The business was expected to list on the Stock Exchange by the end of this year, a move which would enable it to make further acquisitions, but these plans have been postponed.

The group is now considering several alternatives to the IPO because of weak market conditions for high-tech shares. Outside investors could help the group realise its ambitions to buy other companies as well as value the overall business.

Mr Murdoch has made no secret of his interest in buying DirecTV, the largest satellite business in the US. he already has one Sky Global backer in the form of Liberty Media, run by John Malone. He is also thought to be in discussions with Microsoft with a view to the software company paying about $1bn for a stake in Sky Global.

In comments made to the Financial Times, Prince Alwaleed said: "If you look at the empire Mr Murdoch has built across Europe, Asia, the Middle East and Australia, DirecTV sits very well in that strategy."

The prince, aged 43, and Mr Murdoch, 69, are understood to have a good working relationship. The royal portfolio includes a 3% stake in News Corp. On Thursday, the prince spent several hours talking with Mr Murdoch.

Prince Alwaleed has been an enthusiastic investor in hi-tech shares in the US and Europe, but he has suffered in the recent turmoil in the technology sector.

In April, at the start of this year's downturn, he spent about $2bn on internet companies such as America Online, Amazon and eBay. His investment in Priceline.com, the online ticketing business which has lost more than 90% of its stock market value since the spring, is among his least successful investments.

webTitle: Jobs rise: Graduates should look at SMEs

fields.headline: Embark on a little adventure with your first job
fields.standfirst: Size matters when it comes to gaining experience fast
fields.trailText: Size matters when it comes to gaining experience fast.
fields.body:
If size matters, big might not always be best - sometimes small or medium can offer you more. That's the message from a whole sector of graduate recruiters who want you to consider a future with small to medium enterprises (SMEs) instead of pinning all your hopes on hitching up to the Big Boys.

Recent research by online recruiters Top Jobs on the Net revealed that half of all graduates want to work for a blue chip firm, while only one in eight had ever thought about a career in an SME.

"It's about visibility," says Bob Gelworth, head of careers services at Huddersifeld University. SMEs account for 99% of all UK businesses and they are a big growth sector. Yet SMEs can't afford to advertise widely or set up shop at the careers fairs so few people will have heard of them. Simple as that.

"As big businesses downsize, the global economy is increasingly made up of small firms and graduates need to realise that more employment opportunities with small businesses can lead to greater responsibility at an earlier age for able graduates. In contrast, in larger corporations these same graduates are made to feel anonymous," says Donald Martin, UK policy unit chairman for the Federation of Small Businesses.

The trend for outsourcing areas of business like marketing, public relations and even human resources is bringing more small companies into being. And most of the exciting start-ups and dot.coms are also SMEs.

But how do you find a job with a small or medium company when you've never even heard of them. Needle in a haystack, or what?

One starting point is STEP, a programme that offers eight-week student placements with SMEs. Your careers service can put you in touch.

And university careers services are getting proactive in the SME recruitment area too. Huddersfield, along with 11 other universities, has set up Graduate Jobs in Yorkshire which is creating a database of available jobs and students who are interested in SMEs, then helping to match them. You might catch it at some of this season's recruitment fairs.

"If our graduates didn't take jobs with SMEs we wouldn't have such a strong employment record as we have," says Bob Gelworth. Nearly half of Huddersfield's graduates work in the Yorkshire region, mostly in small and medium companies.

Meeting the needs of SMEs is more important to some regions than others, and Scotland is proving a market leader in the field.

Graduates For Growth was set up two years ago by the four Edinburgh universities careers services, the Chamber of Commerce, Scottish Enterprise and CBI Scotland. Scottish Enterprise provides the funding and plans to roll out the programme across the country.

Bob Porrer, student services director at Edinburgh University, explains: "Graduates for Growth acts as an intermediary. It gets the vacancies from SMEs and keeps a database of graduates looking for jobs. Half of the jobs are new jobs.

"Graduates can grow a business. They can get stuck in pretty fast and make a difference to a business within months.

"It is difficult for students to find out about career opportunities with small companies, although some of them are now recruiting through the web."

The advantages of working for an SME are clear. "You are closer to what is happening and you can very definitely see the outcome of your work," says Bob Porrer. He says he knows of one graduate who is in line to take over a business when the owner retires.

But what about support once you start work with a small company? Graduates for Growth offers general business skills training and other graduates act as mentors. Huddersfield has a downloadable training package, so both schemes aim to offer the type of support that is given to graduates in big companies during their early career.

For graduates who don't have access to schemes like these to help them find jobs, the advice is to try online recruitment or contact chambers of commerce and local Training and Enterprise Councils to find out which companies are recruiting.

Don McIntosh, UK general manager of Top Jobs on the Net, believes that SMEs can level the playing field by increasing their online presence. Graduates who register only have to fill in one application form for all. They also get careers advice, help with CVs, a diary of forthcoming events and useful website links.

But specialists in the SME field say it is still difficult to crack the graduate recruitment market. Don Martin at the Federation of Small Businesses, believes the Department of Trade and Industry could do more to raise the profile of smaller organisations and offer them a means for entering the recruitment game.

Profiles

Ken Hughes

Aged 30, events co-ordinator for Edinburgh Chamber of Commerce

Ken has a BA in communications from Napier University. He found his present post with the assistance of Graduates For Growth.

"There is no question that an SME was the right option for me given my age and previous experience. In an SME you are hands-on and you have early responsibility."

Emma Freeman

Aged 24, account manager for The Dialogue Agency

Emma has a business and marketing degree from Greenwich. She got her job through the internet.

"All work is valued at an SME and you can be rewarded accordingly. From the experience gained at an SME, I can imagine starting a company of my own within 10 years."

Chris Blundell

Aged 23, works for August One PR agency

Chris has a history degree from Durham. He got his job through a personal contact.

"August One is a progressive company in a fast-growing sector. I have a role which has huge potential and I can climb the ladder more quickly than if I was with a larger organisation."
