webTitle: How to... become a political animal

fields.headline: How to... become a political animal
fields.standfirst: Working in the House is increasingly common
fields.trailText: Working in the House is increasingly common
fields.body:
Looking for a prospect-enhancing way to spend that year out of a vocational course? Look no further than the House of Commons. And if going to work for the former Conservative prime minister Ted Heath for nothing sounds like an unusual career move, not to say somewhat beyond the call of duty, think again.

Doing unpaid work for an MP not only represents a shot in the arm for your CV but it could be just the ticket for that first job.

For years, American students have been working unpaid for politicians both at home and abroad. You only have to look at the vast numbers of staff accompanying the presidential candidates around the US election mayhem to realise how many students ally themselves to politicians of all levels. If you need convincing that doing unpaid work for politicians gets you into the right places, look no further than Monica Lewinsky - even if she came to a sticky end.

But while few get as close to the action as she did, there is increasing evidence that growing numbers of UK undergraduates are realising the benefits of allying themselves to an MP - professionally at least.

According to Stephen Adam, principal lecturer in politics at the University of Westminster, those who put themselves out and find placements at the Commons get a huge amount out of it.

"On the first day the students arrive, I explain that they have a golden opportunity on their doorstep and they should make the most of it. I was talking just yesterday to one of my students currently working at Conservative Central Office, who reported he was having a fascinating time."

Despite his department's proximity to Parliament, Adam says the University does not formally place students with an MP, but the brightest ones do it for themselves.

"MPs are always looking for people to staff offices, carry out research, answer the phones etc -the range of skills that they can pick up are all things employers are looking for. Besides, in the past some of our students have gone on from there to work for lobbying firms on the basis of experience gained with MPs, and have ended up being offered jobs."

On the question of political allegiance, Adam says his students tend to work with the party they are sympathetic towards, but it's not always the case.

One graduate who worked for a Tory MP, even though he describes himself as politically "neutral" is account executive Jay Dossetter. He now works for London PR firm Biss Lancaster on the Eurofighter project but came to it via a four-year degree course in politics at Leeds.

"Politics is a bit of a general degree, unless you want to become a civil servant or a political journalist. One of the things that attracted me to the course was the year out working within politics."

For reasons even he now has difficulty recalling, Dossetter chose to work for Ted Heath.

"Someone on the same course had worked for him and it seemed like a great opportunity - even if we didn't exactly have the same views on many things.

"He has a reputation for being a bitter old man but I found him anything but. He could even be quite charming at times."

Dossetter spent most of the six months he was working for him undertaking research and working on briefings. It was at a time when an election was approaching and he worked on the rebuttal work that came to characterise the last election.

"The phone would ring and it would be a high profile former minister wanting some information. There was no time to become flustered or anxious - it was just a case of getting on with it."

Dossetter spent the second six months working for Canadian MP Sheila Finestone in Montreal.

"In many ways this was the more demanding experience. I arrived at Ottawa University with nothing set up and had to go out and find an MP to aid. Whereas I was one of five in Ted Heath's office, there were just two of us helping Finstone. The experience in London had given me an insight into the political process and I was able to put some of that into practice in Montreal.

Asked what he got out of the year, Dossetter suggests the most valuable thing was self-confidence. "Just to get the job with Ted Heath I had to get through two pretty tough interviews, and dealing with some of the country's leading politicians on a daily basis was invaluable experience. Besides that it was fun. Sitting in the bar at the House of Commons after a long day, you'd look round and think, wow, this is where it all happens."

webTitle: Jobs rise: Help: This guy is raining on my parade!

fields.headline: Help: This guy is raining on my parade!
fields.standfirst: One of my team is always raising objections which slow down projects and make others feel uncertain. How can I get him to cut down on the number of protests he makes?  BF, deputy art director, London
fields.trailText: One of my team is always raising objections which slow down projects and make others feel uncertain. How can I get him to cut down on the number of protests he makes? BF, deputy art director, London.
fields.body:
Compulsive objectors see things differently. Their world view casts them as the voice of reason. Surrounded by impetuous fools, they alone have the analytical ability to foresee dire consequences and prevent disaster.

Either that or they're just mischief makers who enjoy winding everyone up. The latter can largely be ignored, although a workplace full of yes men is in danger of self-congratulating itself out of existence.

The ability to evaluate critically rather than accept unquestioningly is something worth nurturing, annoying though it can be. If the concerns raised have some validity, to dismiss them because their originator is a bore is risky.

However, if you're trying to keep a team working you need to protect others from the frustration one such person can cause. It's easy to make criticisms that damage the morale and coherence of a group if you don't have to do anything about it. So, move him to a position of greater responsibility that exploits his nit-picking characteristics.

Arrange things so he has to present detailed information on potential problems at an early stage. Feeling valued and heard may reduce his need to continually draw attention to himself.

If you also make him responsible for suggesting solutions, he'll soon learn to focus on the most pressing problems.

Irene Krechowiecka
ijk@excite.com

webTitle: Moving on up: An ABC guide to surviving poor managers and bad bosses

fields.headline: Moving on up
fields.standfirst: An ABC guide to surviving poor managers and bad bosses
fields.trailText: An ABC guide to surviving poor managers and bad bosses
fields.body:
A. Winning combinations

You won't see it in job descriptions, but the ability to cope with poor management is one of the key skills for a successful working life. Perhaps you'll be lucky and never have to take orders from those who are incompetent, lazy or plain wicked. But it's not unusual to find yourself working for someone who combines all three characteristics with ease. If that's your situation don't allow yourself to be defeated by it. The only expertise you need to sort it is the conviction that because you deserve better, you will be able to find it.

B. Change management

Some managers may be susceptible to intelligent argument about why things should be done differently; others to concerted pressure to alter their style and attitudes. But it's generally easier to just find yourself another boss, or become your own - although internal transfers are worth investigating. Unfortunately, poor managers don't always come in ones. Some places have whole teams.

C. Dangerous exposure

Resigning yourself to living with conflict and frustration can turn you into an institutionalised misery with limited appeal to anyone else. If you're up against mass mediocrity the only solution is to leave. It's not as difficult as you might think. Don't let fear or inertia cause you to stay in a poisonous environment.Bad bosses retain control by undermining confidence and making you feel there are no alternatives. Don't you believe it!

fields.headline: Sixty seconds in: Psychiatry
fields.standfirst: Massimo Riccio, psychiatrist and medical director of the Priory clinic, talks to Miles Brignall
fields.trailText: Massimo Riccio, psychiatrist and medical director of the Priory clinic, talks to Miles Brignall
fields.body:
Although we have a reputation among the media for treating the rich and famous, the vast majority of the people we see are very ordinary, are referred to us by their GP and have their costs paid for by health insurance.

Famous or not, everyone who arrives through the doors is given an hour-long consultation where I try to assess what's wrong with them while getting to know them a little, to establish their background and to uncover any emotional "baggage" they are carrying.

Although a large proportion of our patients are clinically depressed we also see a range of other illnesses, from addictive disorders right through to schizophrenia.

Assuming I am able to diagnose the problem, the opening session gives me a chance to explain how we'll treat them. I take the view that for them to get better, we have to form a partnership - if that's not possible because they are deemed too ill, our first priority is to get them to a position where they are able to take an active role in their treatment.

For most people we see with clinical depression, we usually prescribe medication combined with cognitive therapy. I very much favour this two-pronged approach. If a patient said he didn't want to go down the medication route I would work within that. However if I felt that things would not get better without medication I would make the case for its use.

Once a patient has been seen by me I oversee the rest of their treatment. I firmly believe that we are treating the whole person and the therapy is a hugely important part of the treatment. Most of it is carried out by our therapists, either on a one-to-one basis or as part of a group. I am lucky to have a very committed team made up of psychologists, therapists and even social workers. On average, our patients stay with us for around three weeks, but there are no rules to this -yesterday someone left us who had been here for seven months - although they often return for several weeks as out-patients.

As well as treating patients, I also manage the running of the hospital and deal with a mountain of correspondence from GPs. We also have a teaching programme linked to Imperial College and I'll often be teaching as I go round the building. Although it can be a long day - often 7.30am to 8pm - the patients expect me to be doing my best for them.

The beauty of the job, if beauty is the right word, is taking a complex human being whose symptoms defy what your training suggests is wrong, and still managing to find a way to make them better.

fields.headline: Bottom rung
fields.standfirst:
Tara Mitchell
Aged 26
Detective constable
Kent police
fields.trailText: Tara Mitchel, Aged 26, Detective constable, Kent police
fields.body:
Tara Mitchell was probably destined to join the police. At 16 she was a police cadet in Surrey and at 18 she was a special constable. "I was involved with recruitment campaigns and training," she explains.

After graduating in social psychology from the University of Kent, Tara applied direct to the county constabulary. "Policing appeals because I am interested in what people do and why they do it."

How to join: Graduates can enter either by the Home Office's Accelarated Promotion Scheme for Graduates (12 each year, nationwide) or by approaching an individual force and applying to join the APSG. Kent police also runs a development scheme for officers with potential.

CV to date: Fifteen weeks intitial training forms the first part of a two-year probationary period which includes attachments to various sections. Tara's experience has included spells in the intelligence and uniform response patrol units.

Training involves residential courses and annual appraisals.

Ambitions? Tara is working towards her inspectors exam next year.

Tip for entrants: "Go to your local police and find out directly what the job's like."

 For more career details visit the website www.kent.police.uk.

webTitle: Is the fair about to leave town?  Pre-select events are just the ticket

fields.headline: Is the fair about to leave town?  Pre-select events are just the ticket
fields.trailText: Go to a fair, choose an employer, apply, do some tests, have an interview, get the job. That was how the system worked. Granted, the employer controlled most of the process, but at least the decision to apply was in your hands.
fields.body:
Go to a fair, choose an employer, apply, do some tests, have an interview, get the job. That was how the system worked. Granted, the employer controlled most of the process, but at least the decision to apply was in your hands.

Not any more.

Such is the competition for graduates, employers are no longer content with merely marketing their opportunities and then selecting the applicants. They are pushing themselves to the very beginning of the process by influencing the decision to apply in the first place.

This technique is called pre-selection and its aim is to minimise the number of unsuitable applicants (so cutting administration costs) while maximising the number of those best-suited to the job (so giving the companies more choice).

Pre-selection can be achieved in a number of ways. But at its simplest it means an employer attempts to supply quality information only to those students most likely to benefit the organisation.

In this context, quality information means the opportunity to listen and speak to well-informed company representatives. Anyone can log on to a company website, but we all know that there is nothing more truly interactive than another human being. The trouble for the company is that providing this quality information is both very expensive and was until recently very difficult to target effectively.

In the past, there was only one way to contact students: the milk round. But for recruiters, the difficulty with careers fairs and other on-campus events is that they are literally and figuratively a free-for-all. Anyone can go and ask anything. Lots of valuable time is wasted on unsuitable candidates which leaves less for those who genuinely need their questions answering.

What companies needed was a way of pre-selecting the students who come to their fairs or presentations, so enabling them to target their provision of quality information much more effectively. The internet has provided the solution.

Careers services and companies can now use online databases to pre-select the students they want to come to their events. Indeed, instead of having to attend the career fair free-for-all, companies can now virtually sidetrack the careers service entirely by hosting off-campus events to which entry is restricted.

This term for example, Nortel Networks is holding a series of ten road shows at key universities throughout the UK. The road shows include lunch with Nortel Networks employees, presentations, facilities for immediate online application, independent career advice, and even a Scalextric for those more relaxed moments. Entry is, however, strictly by invitation.

Students attending the road shows will be able to make a highly informed decision about whether or not to apply: they will either treat their application very seriously or not trouble the company at all. This, for the company, is the perfect result. Of course anyone can still apply, but if this approach accounts for the majority of a company's recruitment marketing then the number of less well-informed speculative applications falls dramatically.

"The trend is away from the milk round," claims Leyla Bozdogan, publishing manager of Hobsons, the education and recruitment company which is organising the Nortel Networks road shows. "By participating in invitation-only events, companies can target their expenditure on those students who are both genuinely interested and who are on the modules and courses that are developing the skills the company needs. A company like Nortel Networks would traditionally have gone to 30 or 40 individual career fairs, but despite this massive investment of time and money, they might only see a few dozen suitable applicants out of the thousands who approach their stand."

By using Hobsons' large student database (which, by the end of the recruitment year, contains details of up to 50,000 final year students) as well as inviting applications for tickets by other means, Nortel Networks is able to select only those students it is interested in meeting, so bypassing the traditional milk round completely.

Some career services have not been slow to realise the advantages of ticketed events. For the last three years, the University of London has held a ticketed finance fair. Students have to fill in an online application form before being allocated tickets according to careers service criteria. This approach has enabled the university to attract increasing numbers of prestigious city firms to the fair who come confident in the knowledge that their time will not be wasted by unsuitable candidates.

Smaller universities are also using limited-numbers events as a means of attracting companies. This year London Guildhall University abandoned its autumn fair in favour of a week-long series of ticketed careers activities. Although not based on selection, places at these events were limited, and this approach led to the university being visited by several top recruiters such as KPMG.

"I am not sure if we were having our normal careers fair that we would have attracted these companies," says Eric Whittington, head of careers at London Guildhall. "Careers fairs can often be a melee, and so it is difficult for companies to know how many people they will be seeing and of what quality. By pre-booking the places on presentations and mini-courses, the companies know the participant numbers and their commitment."

But at highly-targeted places such as Manchester (which has the largest concentration of students in Europe), the walk-in fair is not only holding its own, but appears to be increasing in popularity with students.

"Students expect a just-in-time service like the rest of society," argues Jane Ratchford, director of Manchester and UMIST careers service. "They want a one-stop shop where as many career options as possible are gathered together. The fair concept is definitely changing, but this is because students are using the employer and career service websites to better prepare themselves for the event. The reality for the recruiters is that students like fairs because they can speak directly to a range of employers."

Employers will always want cost-effective pre-selection while students will always prefer the one-stop employment shop. What has changed is the introduction of the internet. It is already starting to transform the milk round, but as yet nobody quite knows how it will end.

webTitle: Top rung:  Jim Barker-McCardle, Assistant chief constable Kent police

fields.headline: Top rung
fields.trailText: Jim Barker-McCardle, Assistant chief constable Kent police
fields.body:
Jim Barker-McCardle Aged 39 Assistant chief constable Kent police

On leaving school in 1981 with three A levels, Jim Barker-McCardle headed straight for his local police station. "I wanted to work in public service and policing also seemed like a job with limitless variety."

A career path which began with initial training at Ashford has since included posts as detective constable, sergeant, inspector, chief inspector, superintendent and chief superintendent. A year ago he took over the second top post in Kent.

Stats and facts: Kent police employs 5,000 people covering a population of 1.5m.

Current role: Jim combines his operational responsibilities in the chief officer team with a specific brief in personnel and training as well as a national role in the Association of Chief Police Officers specialising in criminal justice issues.

The buzz? "When carefully-laid plans come off and operational successes make a real difference on the streets."

Must-have qualities: "Integrity, an ability to think and apply it as well as teamwork and communication skills. In return, graduates have the chance to join a force which has pioneered intelligence-led policing, where specialist skills are encouraged and where our geographic position gives the work an international feel."

fields.headline: Labour of love
fields.standfirst: David Lammy
fields.trailText: David Lammy
fields.body:
Status: At 28, he's one of Britain's youngest MPs.

Past: Studied law at London University and Inns of Court School of Law. Worked during holidays for Amnesty International in Jamaica and Prisoners Abroad in Thailand. Practised as a barrister before taking a sabbatical to gain a masters in law at Harvard. Became a member of the Greater London Assembly.

Present: Holds a surgery in Tottenham constituency on Fridays and Saturdays. Meets with local school, hospital and council reps to hear views and support campaigns. In parliament five days a weeks from 2.30pm "until late".

Future: "I want to be a catalyst for change in my constituency."

Strengths: "Practising law has given me the ability to be a powerful and articulate advocate."

Weaknesses: "When you come from a poor background, raised by a single mother it makes you impatient for change. I want to address many issues too quickly."

Wisdom: "You can push and prod people into something better than mediocrity, but you have to encourage excellence."

References: www.open.gov.uk

webTitle: Video glitch leaves third umpire in the dark

fields.headline: Video glitch leaves third umpire in the dark
fields.standfirst: New Zealand upset at machine failure as South African series gets underway
fields.trailText: New Zealand upset at machine failure as South African series gets underway.
fields.body:
New Zealand were not best pleased on the first day of the first Test against South Africa in Bloemfontein yesterday, when the television-replay system, which assists the third umpire, failed to do its job and left the official unable to adjudicate.

Jacques Kallis was 76 not out at the time when a straight drive from his batting partner Daryll Cullinan was deflected on to the non-striker's stumps by the New Zealand bowler Shayne O'Connor.

Replays supplied to Rudi Koertzen, however, could not help the official to make a conclusive decision on a run out, and Kallis went on to make an undefeated 153 as South Africa reached closed on 270 for three. A replay included in a subsequent television highlights package showed that Kallis had made his ground.

However that was not the issue as far as the New Zealand coach David Trist was concerned. "It was disappointing that they didn't have the technology available to the third umpire when he required," he said. "If the technology is going to fail, it does make the game very frustrating, not only for the players but for the public as well."

Trist was asked whether the incident had annoyed his team. "No," he replied, "because once it's gone, it's gone and you've got to press on. You can't carry that kind of baggage with you because the next ball's the major issue."

The executive producer of the broadcast, Vince Gibbons, later explained: "The video-tape operator rewound the tape to play the incident back and the machine indicated that it had a reel error. It kept on rewinding to a point where he couldn't identify the tape any longer.

"Rudi [Koertzen] was calling for the angle from that camera, and while the video-tape operator was try ing to find it, the delay was longer than normal and the decision was taken in the favour of the batsman.

"The operator couldn't find the footage and the machine jammed the tape. It got chewed up. We went back and found that section of the tape and we've gone to air with it and proved that Kallis was, in fact, not out."

It was the second time that the system has failed on the present tour of South Africa, the country which pioneered television umpiring. The first occurred in Kimberley last month, when a power failure prevented the third umpire from deciding if Jonty Rhodes threw down Roger Twose's stumps with the Kiwi yet to score. He went on to make 89. - Reuters

"No," he replied, "because once it's gone, it's gone and you've got to press on. You can't carry that kind of baggage with you because the next ball's the major issue." fields.headline: Atherton has the inside story
fields.standfirst: Jim White reports on how batting for two teams at once puts Mike Atherton on a sticky wicket
fields.trailText: Jim White reports on how batting for two teams at once puts Mike Atherton on a sticky wicket.
fields.body:
Michael Atherton has been on top form during the tour to Pakistan: careful, considered, giving absolutely nothing away. And he has not been batting badly either.

Anyone picking up the Sunday Telegraph last weekend will have been treated to the new model Atherton. The former England captain has turned into a sports journalist. Not lending his name to a ghosted column, not offering an overview of England's latest tour, but doing the nitty-gritty, dirt-under-the-fingernails, real work: he has filed a match report.

Clearly Atherton is not the first cricketer to work in the business (our own Mike Selvey heads a distinguished roster of former Test players in the press box, including Derek Pringle of the Independent and Vic Marks of the Observer). But he must be the first to assault the word processor before he has even retired. And just to add extra flavour to his journalism, his was a report of a match in which he was actually playing.

As might be expected from a man as intelligent and well read as Atherton, there is nothing wrong with his copy. Nevertheless, it is a worrying piece of casting by the Telegraph, raising all sorts of questions about objectivity. Would the paper recruit Gordon Brown to write its economic comment column, for instance, or get David Blunkett to spin off a couple of hundred words about the National Union of Teachers' conference? Of course not. But then, being the Telegraph, they don't need to. They have Chris Woodhead to do that sort of thing. But how about getting Lennox Lewis to deliver the only piece the paper carried about his fight with David Tua? Or asking Gareth Southgate to write the definitive report when England lost to Germany in last month's World Cup qualifier?

As it happens, Atherton and his new employer were lucky with his first piece. England won the pre-Test final warm-up match, so there was no need for any critical response. Plus they did so without much of a contribution from their reporter, who could thus maintain an illusion of distance. But what would have happened if, say, England had batted as they did in the early stages of their most recent tour to South Africa and one of their own was obliged to comment on abject capitulation? In such circumstances it is inconceivable that Atherton - always careful to respect his colleagues' feelings - would have been appropriately judgmental.

Perhaps the paper's editors thought that the compromise of allowing a player to fudge criticism in a match report would be offset by insider titbits. In which case they should have asked somebody other than Atherton. He is far too canny, far too experienced, far too aware of the consequences on team morale to give a single thing away. In 900 words, the only deep-throat insight he delivered was a comment from Graham Thorpe so bland it is not worth repeating.

But the most entertaining possibilities of the Telegraph's recruitment drive are offered up when their new employee is obliged to report on himself. When I was at school, I had a contemporary called Michael Bennett, who used to provide hilariously egocentric running commentaries on every football match. On one occasion, one of our team-mates won the ball in defence and proceeded to dribble through the opposition before scoring a solo barnstormer. The commentary on this wonder goal provided by the wannabe John Motson, a spectator at right-back, was: "And Bennett lurks . . ."

This was at the same school Atherton attended, and maybe he played with Bennett's younger brother. Certainly his own reporting style eschews all ego, preferring instead shoulder-shrugging self-deprecation, as might be expected from someone who is not exactly the Naseem Hamed of cricket.

Referring to himself as Marcus Trescothick's opening partner, the Sunday Telegraph's man reserves the only critical comment of his piece for the way "a long hop was cut to cover point for the second time on the tour". This before adding: "I hope the habit of gifting my wicket to the opposition comes to an end before the first Test." It is a style which would have been in trouble if he had been reporting on the first day of this Test match, a day summed up in the Guardian's headline: "England fall in a heap after Atherton heroics". Self-criticism would be as inappropriate then as excuse-making is in defeat.

But ultimately there is one overriding reason why I object to Atherton writing match reports for the Telegraph. Simple jealousy. I have none of the resources of concentration, skill and bravery to do his job. Yet he seems to be able to do mine with consummate ease.

webTitle: Saqlain twirls away for eight out of eight

fields.headline: Saqlain twirls away for eight out of eight
fields.standfirst: The off-spinner toils through 74 overs for his hard-earned reward, writes  Paul Allott in Lahore
fields.trailText: The off-spinner toils through 74 overs for his hard-earned reward, writes Paul Allott in Lahore.
fields.body:
At the post-match press conference last night entries to the most-obvious-answer competition closed early with Saqlain Mushtaq's response of "tired". The question wasn't too smart either, a fairly bland "How do you feel?" Try bowling 74 overs of finger-snapping off-spin over 2 days and see how you feel.

Saqlain's effort so far in this Test has been phenomenal. On a desperately slow pitch which looks like a dust bowl but refuses to turn sharply or quickly, he took all the England wickets to finish with eight for 164, his best performance in Tests and the second best against England on this ground.

He also, for good measure, bowled more overs in an innings than ever before.

"My fingers are sore and swollen and my right shoulder is aching, but I am pleased with my performance and not too disappointed I didn't get the chance to take all 10 wickets. It's not important for me to get 10, it's important for the team to get a result and play well," Saqlain added.

With just a bit more luck he could easily have taken all 10. Graham Thorpe was dropped on two, at first slip by Qaiser Abbas, one of six Pakistan fielders to occupy that essential position, and Saqlain himself dropped two return catches, the one area of his game that he needs to improve dramatically.

Obviously Saqlain is not afraid of hard work. His determination to perfect his top-spinning delivery that zips away towards slip took as much as 10 hours out of a day when he was 16.

He used to practise at his home with an old tennis ball wrapped in insulation tape, endlessly throwing the ball against a wall and watching it spin different ways out of his fingers.

It took him four years before he had the confidence to bowl that delivery in a match. Now it is his most lethal weapon and he can use it at will, and it is so well disguised that even Moin Khan, his captain and wicketkeeper, has difficulty picking which way each ball will turn.

Saqlain is an aggressive individual on the field as well and, surprisingly for a spinner, his heroes were both quick bowlers. Imran Khan and Waqar Younis were his role models because of their typical fast bowler's approach, always at the batsman and in his face.

It is often forgotten that spin bowlers, too, need an element of fight as well as flight, though it is not an attribute which is missing in Saqlain, nor does his attitude leave the batsman in any doubt as to who is the aggressor.

His performance here was all the more devastating when you consider that on his own admission the pitch was too slow for him, as it has been for every other bowler.

Far from seizing the advantage over England, Pakistan may feel that they have shot themselves in the foot by producing such a surface. They have allowed the tourists precious time in the middle to assess Saqlain's spin and nullify the effect of the leg-spinner Mushtaq Ahmed.

Saqlain provided a telling assessment of England's effort when he said: "England batting for 2 days will have encouraged them and boosted their confidence. We [Pakistan] will have to think up new ideas and theories of how to bowl to them."

Maybe that is true but Pakistan would still love to get England on a faster and bouncier pitch to see if they have really learnt anything over the past three days.

When the match ends, moreover, it would be more than worthwhile for the England camp to look at all the spinners' figures for both sides just to put into perspective how good Saqlain has been.

If, as England expect, the pitch does continue to deteriorate then they will have had the best of the conditions both with bat and ball. They are still in a good position to force a win but if they fail to do so it will help them realise that Saqlain's spin may be the determining factor in the series.

Saqlain may still have the last word in this series, there are two more Tests to come, but he certainly put his performance into his own clear perspective last night with his final statement. "When I play cricket I always play to enjoy myself, to smile and to thank God."

fields.headline: England crack the whip
fields.standfirst:
England 480 for 8 dec
Pakistan 119 for 2
fields.trailText:
England 480 for 8 dec

Pakistan 119 for 2
fields.body:
For three days now, barring one session on the first evening when Saqlain Mushtaq threatened to lay waste their batting, England have dominated the first Test against Pakistan almost to the point of disbelief. A turning pitch, albeit a slow one, and Asian spinners - not just any old spinners but great ones, among the finest in the world - would on the face of it amount to a recipe for defeat and probably an embarrassing one at that.

Instead it was England who went into today's fourth day cracking the whip, dictating the terms and putting pressure on the opposing batsmen; it was they whose spinners had a coterie of predatory fieldsmen lurking and smirking round the bat while the Pakistanis tried to find a happy medium between studious defence and outrageous hitting.

Patience was a virtue exhibited with great merit by England's batsmen and if it is transferred to the bowlers it could yet hold the key, if not to winning the match then to sending Pakistan to the second Test in Faisalabad with a thought or two about pitch preparation, selection and strategy.

Play ended eight overs early because of poor light once more, despite the fact that spinners were operating at both ends (not dark enough either to prevent Pakistan batsmen immediately taking to the outfield and knocking up against the advertising boards). But by then England had taken the wickets of both openers, including that of the dangerous and high-class left hander Saeed Anwar, an lbw victim of the Australian umpire Darrell Hair's intense and well publicised impatience with players - notably the West Indies captain Jimmy Adams - who tuck their bat in behind their front pad against the spinners and pretend they have played a stroke.

So Pakistan resumed this morning on 119 for two, with Salim Elahi, a batsman of little experience or record who has not played Test cricket for 3 years, on 15 and Inzamam-ul-Haq, who can be exceptional, on 11.

Earlier England had extended their first innings from 393 for six overnight to 480 for eight by lunch, Craig White missing out on his first Test century by seven runs. Ian Salisbury and Ashley Giles, though, added 70 for the eighth wicket before Nasser Hussain declared midway through the traditional long Friday lunchbreak, extended to allow Muslims time to attend to their devotions.

It is a moot point whether England became too entwined in the euphoria of getting a large total and might in fact have been better off pulling the plug half an hour or so earlier and having a bowl. Instead they batted for 196 overs in all, the most they have spent at the crease since they played India at Trent Bridge four years ago.

One person who left the arena with mixed feelings was Saqlain Mushtaq, who had taken both wickets to fall yesterday as well as those on the previous two days and had his sights set on all 10, something achieved only twice in Test history.

As his side embarked on their immediate task of scoring 281 to avoid the prospect of following on (162 still needed, then) he sat, pondered his swollen right index finger and declared himself "tired". He thought he had bowled 63 overs once at Khettarama in Colombo (he was right) but could not remember sending down more than the 74 he delivered in this innings to take eight for 164.

Saqlain's ambitions had gained a boost in his third over of the morning when White, who had begun by slashing Wasim Akram fiercely to the extra-cover boundary, pushed forward, flicked his bat a little where soft defensive hands might have been a better option, and edged on to his pad whence Yousuf Youhana, leaping high to his right at short leg, held a snappy catch. With White's disappointment, however - and it would have been a hugely popular century among his team-mates - came encouragement in that the ball certainly appeared to have turned with more pace than hitherto.

Salisbury and Giles, though, played with good sense and no little skill, hitting a boundary each and selecting their shots wisely until Salisbury became Saqlain's final victim, lbw to the faster ball, as his Surrey team-mate Alec Stewart had been on the first day. Andy Caddick made it plain that the declaration was imminent.

Quite how Pakistan would approach their reply became evident in the fifth over when Afridi - the scorer, let us not forget, of the fastest century in limited-overs internationals when he hit Sri Lanka for 102 from 40 balls - first flicked Caddick behind square for four and then threw not so much the kitchen sink as the entire Armitage Shanks stockroom at an open-mouthed Darren Gough and blasted him straight back over his head.

By the ninth over Hussain had Giles bowling and by the 16th Salisbury as well. The first wicket in the match not to go to Saqlain went to Graeme Hick, however, Saeed offering no shot in the final over before lunch and paying the price.

Neither could Afridi carry on as he was and, having made 52 from 68 balls, he heaved a massive skyer in the direction of long-off where Gough fell backwards to hold a fine catch.

 Alec Stewart has no case to answer over match-fixing allegations, according to the England and Wales Cricket Board chairman Lord MacLaurin. He said yesterday that he was convinced Stewart was "absolutely clear" of involvement. Meanwhile the International Cricket Council president Malcolm Gray said that the council's anti- corruption unit, headed by the former London police chief Paul Condon, had a £2.8m budget to investigate wrongdoing in the game.

webTitle: Prime suspect in mole hunt laughs off link to leak

fields.headline: Prime suspect in mole hunt laughs off link to leak
fields.trailText: November 18 2000: Former Downing St civil servant refuses to deny being source of Sunday newspaper report about the cabinet's 1997 decision to back the Millennium Dome.
fields.body:
A former Downing Street civil servant said yesterday that he was flattered to be considered "the prime suspect" in the Whitehall inquiry into how detailed conversations about the cabinet's 1997 decision to back the Millennium Dome were leaked to a Sunday newspaper.

Mark Adams, who remained a high-flying private secretary at No 10 for three months after Tony Blair's landslide victory over John Major, refused to confirm or deny the substance of rumours in government circles that he may have been the person who briefed journalist Simon Walters.

Told that he is under suspicion in Downing Street, Mr Adams replied: "So I am the prime suspect?" He later joked: "It's nice to have advance warning. I'll decide what to say if and when the leak inquiry catches up with me. I will have no problem, as an ex-public servant, if they do come my way to chat with me."

He joked that such notoriety "might be good for business" in his work as a lobbyist seeking to influence government. "One of my clients might easily ask 'Are you the mole in No 10?'. I can tap my nose and do not have to break any confidences, the client can go away and say 'I just met the mole at No 10'."

The circumstantial reason why Mr Adams's name is circulating in Whitehall as a possible source of the detailed account published by the Mail on Sunday is twofold.

Though Alastair Campbell, Mr Blair's spokesman, denies that any official cabinet minute or notes appeared in the paper, the verbatim account of how 12 ministers attacked the dome project is, ministers present admit, broadly accurate despite some errors.

"The Mail on Sunday didn't publish an official document, but it wasn't bonkers either. It got the drift right," said one official. "There's quite a bit of head-scratching going on about what to do."

Some sources claim that Mr Adams left Whitehall shortly after the election because he was disappointed at the lack of promotion. Such a career profile would fit the timing of the dome leak and an earlier one to the same newspaper about alleged cabinet discussions in July.

He told the Guardian: "I used to sit in occasionally on cabinet, when it was prime minister's question's day, to get the line right. Whether or not I was there on that particular day [of the dome discussion] I don't remember. I sort of stopped doing anything very active in the summer recess [after the 1997 leaks] and was hanging around as a sort of consultant to my successor."

But Whitehall officials also spotted that he was one of 32 friends (including Lord Archer) to be thanked for help in the foreword of Simon Walters' first novel - Second Term, "a story of spin, sabotage and seduction" - published in September. "We think he may be the man," said one official.

Pressed to say categorically whether he was the source, Mr Adams, who got an OBE for his civil service work in John Major's years, said: "I am quite excited that it might be me. It seems a shame to categorically deny it."

Officials who worked with him then call him "very smooth". Some say he was apolitical, others a Tory and a third source called him Blairite.

In a telephone interview, Mr Adams, now managing director of the political unit for the Westminster-based Communications Group, confirmed that he had been present in his capacity as one of Mr Blair's private office staff during some cabinet meetings in the early months of Labour's new government.

"I cannot remember what bits I was present for," he said, adding later: "I do not know how to check whether I was there at the crucial moment [when the dome was discussed on June 19 1997]. I am not inclined to do so to make some public comment." He added last night: "I rang No 10 to seek advice on what was happening. I was assured there was no leak inquiry and that no such official [leaked] documents existed."

Mr Adams was Mr Major's private secretary (parliamentary affairs) for nearly four years, the Tory prime minister rewarding him with an OBE in his resignation honours' list. He joined his present consultancy from the Apco group, also lobbyists.

Mr Adams was said to have supplied much of the colour for the Simon Walters novel, especially for scenes set in Downing Street, such as the colour of wallpaper and details of paintings hanging in various rooms. His own explanation is that Mr Walters "came to me two days before the proof deadline after suddenly realising there was not enough colour about No 10. 'Will you have a quick read?' he asked. On a train to Newcastle I gave it a quick skim and told him about the timing of things, the fact that the people who bring the tea to prime ministers are the messengers, harmless descriptions like that."

One former colleague described him as "chippy" and claimed Mr Adams quit Downing Street when Mr Blair failed to promote him. "He was not politically minded at all, very much a career civil servant," said the former colleague. "He did not get the promotion he was looking for, so decided to leave."

Mr Adams had a fairly low public profile in government but in 1993 was drawn into the row over allegations made under parliamentary privilege that Roger Windsor, former chief executive of the National Union of Mineworkers, had been an undercover MI5 agent.

Mr Windsor, now living and working in France, denied the allegation and wrote to Mr Major asking him to make a public statement clearing his name.

On July 21 that year, Mr Windsor re ceived a reply from Mr Adams referring him to a parliamentary answer given by the prime minister in June 1991.

Asked by Labour MP George Galloway whether Mr Windsor had "ever been employed by her majesty's government", Mr Major had simply replied: "No."

Mr Adams told the Guardian he had refused TV opportunities as a pundit after leaving No 10, preferring to work behind the scenes.

He said he had last met Mr Walters in the street at Brighton during the Labour conference in September. He added that he knew many political journalists.

fields.headline: George polishes off Diamonds
fields.standfirst: Luton Town 1 - 0 Rushden & Diamonds
fields.trailText: Luton Town 1 - 0 Rushden & Diamonds
fields.body:
Rushden & Diamonds performed their accustomed role as the first round swung into action last night, which is to say they worried the life out of their Football League opponents before being forced to accept that giantkilling heroics must be the preserve of others this time around.

The team who have imposed Nationwide Conference strengths on Leeds and Sheffield United in the past two seasons should have won this tie because they twice saw headers come back off the woodwork before half-time.

Then at the start of the second half Jean-Michel Sigere failed to make two gilt-edged opportunities count.

But Brian Talbot's men grew a little too adventurous for their own good, leaving Liam George unattended in the 56th minute as Matthew Spring launched a long through ball. George's finish was calmness, itself unlike so much of a Luton performance designed to impress their new manager.

This week's appointment of Lil Fuccillo to succeed Ricky Hill might have been seen as yet another infiltration of the managerial ranks by foreign opportunists except that this "newcomer" hails from Bed ford and has known only English football.

Fuccillo has come in promising hard work from everyone and he got that last night. But at times effort and determination were all that the Second Division strugglers had to offer against a visiting side who regularly sliced them apart.

Quite how Rushden failed to put the ball in the net is a puzzle that will exercise Talbot's mind all through this long weekend of Cup football. It will be sometime before Sigere is allowed to forget the two glorious invitations he passed up.

Rushden's diminutive creator Gary Mills served him with a neat sidefooted volley which deserved better than the shot hit hastily and high.

Then Mills' low forward pass to Justin Jackson produced a cross that should have been meat and drink for a confident goalscorer but Sigere headed wide from only five-yards.

At the start Rushden launched a succession of corners but they had to absorb pressure in which Mark Stein headed against the bar. Later Rushden twice met the same fate, firstly through a Sigere header and then as Mark Peters attempted to convert a corner.

webTitle: 'It wasn't about how we played but about how we stopped them playing'

fields.headline: 'It wasn't about how we played but about how we stopped them playing'
fields.standfirst: Alex Stepney and Tony Book, stars of many a passion play of yesteryear
fields.trailText: Alex Stepney and Tony Book, stars of many a passion play of yesteryear
fields.body:
"I don't care who they are, where they are from or what they have done," the former Manchester United goalkeeper Alex Stepney says. "When those players walk out at Maine Road they will know that this is a massive game".

Tony Book, who spent three decades at Maine Road as player, manager and coach, agrees. "The atmosphere will just drag them in."

Some recurring events seem forever trapped in a single period of time. For many the words "heavyweight title fight" will always conjure up black-and-white footage of Muhammad Ali, arms raised above his head, feet double-shuffling across the canvas. Likewise for football fans of a certain age, mention of the Manchester derby is likely to call forth images of strikers in red or sky-blue shirts wheeling away from the goal with a single arm raised in celebration, of bare-handed goalkeepers and pitch invasions by fuzzy-haired hordes wearing scarves as bracelets.

That was Book and Stepney's time, an era when the two Manchester clubs were both major forces in European football. Both men arrived in Manchester in 1966 with City newly promoted and they first experienced the momentous fixture on the same September Saturday.

The Surrey-born Stepney, who finished on the winning team that afternoon, went on to make 535 appearances for United. A rangy, agile figure, he kept those in front of him firmly in order. Peter Schmeichel was unlikely ever to win a prize from the Noise Abatement Society but at St Andrews in 1976 Stepney set a benchmark for custodial loudness that is never likely to be surpassed, dislocating his jaw while shouting at Martin Buchan. These days he is the goalkeeping coach at Maine Road while, with pleasing symmetry, the one-time City keeper Tony Coton fulfils the same role at Old Trafford.

Book, meanwhile, has a good claim to be a unique player of the modern age. Snapped up for £15,000 from Plymouth Argyle by Joe Mercer, the elegant full-back did not make his First Division debut until he was 31.

From their first day in the city neither man was left in any doubt about the importance of the game. "There were the supporters, of course," Book recalls in the west country burr that 30 years in the north-west have barely altered. "But more than that it came from the other players. Our side had a lot of local lads: Glyn Pardoe, Alan Oakes, Neil Young and Mike Doyle. They let you know what it was all about; Mike Doyle especially. It meant a lot to Doyley to go out for a drink on the Saturday night after winning the derby."

"In those days," Stepney says, "you didn't have a lot of people coming in from outside. The TV crews and reporters tended to be local so everything was focused on Manchester. You were stuck right in the middle of it and all week it just built up and built up."

For Stepney, the intensity inevitably affected the players' attitude. "Matt Busby would give his usual team talk - 'play your game, enjoy yourself' - but when you walked down that tunnel inwardly you felt the opposite. It wasn't about how we played but about how we stopped them playing. It was about who you were going to cancel out."

With two teams boasting players of the calibre of Denis Law, Colin Bell, Bobby Charlton, Francis Lee and Mike Summerbee there was plenty for defenders to fret about. And then there was George Best. "Funnily enough, I never had much trouble off Bestie," Book says. "I stuck close by him. I used to run along beside him shouting, 'Pass it, you beggar, pass it!' Because once he'd released it he couldn't do you any damage." The tactic proved so successful Doyle later said the City players never worried about Belfast Boy because they knew Book would nullify him.

Unsurprisingly the tension sometimes spilled over into violence. During the 1974 clash at Maine Road a fight broke out between Lou Macari and the ever-feisty Doyle, whose contempt for all things United was not entirely a media creation.

The referee, Clive Thomas, sent both off. When they refused to go the idiosyncratic Welshman led both sides off instead. After five minutes two 10-man teams returned to the field and played out a goalless draw. "Things could get a bit heated," Book observes with a wry smile.

Though neither man regards the encounter as ever being particularly dirty, the casualty list is alarming. In his two dozen derby appearances Stepney saw Bell's career finished when a Buchan tackle broke his leg, and Best shatter Pardoe's tibia, an injury that reportedly came close to ending with amputation.

In the days before the team physio, healthcare was often in the hands of a retired pro armed with a bucket and sponge whose prescription to everything from a calf strain to concussion was to soak the wounded part in hot water. The result was sometimes gruesomely comic.

"When John Aston broke his leg in the derby it happened a few minutes before half-time," Stepney recalls with the grim relish of one for whom pain is an occupational hazard. "When he came off he said to our trainer, Jack Crompton, 'There's something the matter. My leg's all numb.' Jack told him to stamp up and down a few times to get the circulation going. You could hear the bone jarring together."

In the stands things were often just as bloodcurdling. "The atmosphere was definitely hostile," Book remembers. "The team coach would always be showered with spit when you travelled to Old Trafford." Games on the last day of the season in 1973 and 1974 both ended prematurely with mass pitch invasions, the latter in an attempt to stop a match in which, traumatically, the former Old Trafford idol Law's instinctive back-heeled goal for City sent the Red Devils down.

Book was manager of the City side that day and, though he enjoyed the win, the relegation of United saddened him. "To our fans it was maybe a big thing but it gave me no satisfaction, none whatsoever."

To many City fans it sometimes appears that United have set out almost deliberately to rob them of glory, typically trumping the Maine Road club's 1967-68 league championship by winning the European Cup. To Book, though, the motivation for beating United was never resentment. "They had this aura of being the bigger club and we just wanted to change that. When we went to Old Trafford in the early days Malcolm Allison used to take us out on to the pitch before we'd got changed. We'd go down to the Stretford End and applaud United's fans. It was his way of showing that we weren't going to hide away. We were going to take them on and turn things around."

And they succeeded, too. Book played in 16 derbies and finished on the losing side in only three. Stepney, on the other hand, played in 24 and won only eight. "The first few of my games against them we did pretty well," the keeper concedes, "but then at the end of the 67-68 season they came to Old Trafford and won 3-1. To me that was the turning point."

It is also the game of which Book has the fondest memories. "I played sweeper," he recalls. "Bestie scored early and I thought we were really up against it. But we played our way out of it. That was the thing to me. Because our philosophy was that first off you wanted to get the result and after that you wanted to get it with style. And that's what we did that day."

Today, in the first Manchester derby since April 1996, a repeat may seem unlikely. United have won their last eight games, City have lost their last three. Book, however, remains convinced that form is immaterial. "In a big game anything can happen," he says, "and this is the big one, make no mistake about that."

£#149;In all United have won 53 derbies to City's 36, with 46 draws. For City fans too young to remember seeing them win, here is the proof that they once did - and in style.

September 23 1989

Man City 5 Man Utd 1

City: Oldfield (2), Morley, Bishop, Hinchcliffe

United: Hughes

City's only win since 1981, but what a win. Both clubs were looking shaky, City newly promoted and with only four points from their first six games, while United were in the middle of Michael Knighton's attempted takeover. Alex Ferguson, whose Old Trafford future seemed precarious, claimed he had never seen a worse defensive performance. "It was like climbing a glass mountain," he said.

November 12 1975

Man City 4 Man Utd 0

City: Tueart (2), Hartford, Royle

City could not stop scoring (22 in all) on the way to winning the League Cup, their last major trophy. Three goals up after half an hour in this fourth round tie, they ripped Tommy Docherty's young side to shreds with what the Guardian called "football of classical dimensions, fluent, imaginative, decisive, at times breathtaking". The only black spot for City was the injury to Colin Bell, which effectively ended his career.

April 27 1974

Man Utd 0 Man City 1

City: Law

The famous day when the backheel from United's old boy Denis Law five minutes from time sent his former club into the Second Division, although in fact a draw would have been no use to them either. Law's goal sparked a pitch invasion which ended the game prematurely, prompting calls for the erection of fences at English grounds.

March 27 1968

Man Utd 1 Man City 3

United: Best

City: Bell, Heslop, Lee (pen)

The season is better remembered for United's European Cup victory, but it was City who won the league. With 10 games to go, City were two points behind Manchester United and Leeds. This win turned the tide. By the end, the attractive side built by Joe Mercer was so firmly in command they "committed the unforgivable sacrilege of toying with United".

September 23 1989 Man City 5 Man Utd 1 City: Oldfield (2), Morley, Bishop, Hinchcliffe United: Hughes City's only win since 1981, but what a win. Both clubs were looking shaky, City newly promoted and with only four points from their first six games, while United were in the middle of Michael Knighton's attempted takeover. Alex Ferguson, whose Old Trafford future seemed precarious, claimed he had never seen a worse defensive performance. "It was like climbing a glass mountain," he said. November 12 1975 Man City 4 Man Utd 0 City: Tueart (2), Hartford, Royle City could not stop scoring (22 in all) on the way to winning the League Cup, their last major trophy. Three goals up after half an hour in this fourth round tie, they ripped Tommy Docherty's young side to shreds with what the Guardian called "football of classical dimensions, fluent, imaginative, decisive, at times breathtaking". The only black spot for City was the injury to Colin Bell, which effectively ended his career. April 27 1974 Man Utd 0 Man City 1 City: Law The famous day when the backheel from United's old boy Denis Law five minutes from time sent his former club into the Second Division, although in fact a draw would have been no use to them either. Law's goal sparked a pitch invasion which ended the game prematurely, prompting calls for the erection of fences at English grounds. With 10 games to go, City were two points behind Manchester United and Leeds. This win turned the tide. By the end, the attractive side built by Joe Mercer was so firmly in command they "committed the unforgivable sacrilege of toying with United".

webTitle: 'Muddied oafs' of England need only nurture

fields.headline: 'Muddied oafs' of England need only nurture
fields.standfirst: In contrast to popular opinion, England's problem is not a question of brightness
fields.trailText: In contrast to popular opinion, England's problem is not a question of brightness.
fields.body:
According to Francis Maude, the shadow foreign secretary, English footballers are not very bright. And this from a member of the "stupid party".

Apparently Maude, addressing sixth-form pupils in Swindon, was asked to comment on the Football Association's decision to appoint a foreigner, Sven-Goran Eriksson, to coach the England team. "There are too many thickos in English football" was his reported reply.

This drew a swift response from the Professional Footballers' Association, whose deputy chief executive Brendon Batson, a former defender with Arsenal and West Bromwich Albion, said Maude was just showing his ignorance. Batson also went to Cambridge, well to the Abbey stadium anyway.

Maude's off-the-cuff remark need not raise too many hackles but does reveal a depressing tendency in some quarters still to regard professional footballers (and the managers some become) as muddied oafs, even though the amount of mud clinging to them has been considerably reduced by the improved quality of the pitches.

Nobody who listened to David Beckham describing what it felt like and what it involved to be England captain in Turin this week would have been left with the impression of a dullard. For the best part of 20 minutes he gave clear, thoughtful answers and did not say "y'know" once. Yes, he has been coached in dealing with the media, but why not?

The truth about English footballers is that, like MPs, some are brighter than others. The Nevilles, Gary and Phil, come into this category along with Michael Owen, Gareth Southgate, Graeme Le Saux, Martin Keown, Joe Cole and the recently retired Ian Wright, now a chat-show host. Stan Collymore's behaviour may at times be perverse but he is an intelligent conversationalist.

All right, there will always be anecdotes about the dumb things some footballers do. Such as the time when Derby County agreed to meet a prospective signing at the Midland Hotel and, when he did not turn up, scoured the town centre and eventually found their man waiting outside the Midland Bank.

But to play Premiership and Nationwide football, not to mention Champions League and international matches, requires a high degree of mental dexterity as well as good physical shape. England's recent performances might not have suggested that the country's representatives have the same level of intelligence as France, Brazil or Argentina's but that has been more to do with unintelligent team selection and tactics.

Maude has claimed that the intellectual calibre of continental footballers is higher than those produced in this country. It might appear that way when watching Dennis Bergkamp or Paolo Di Canio bewitch opposing defenders with their skills. But players such as Bergkamp are what they are because their natural ability has benefited from an intelligent coaching input at an early age. If naturally gifted English players fail to fulfil their potential it is not because they lack intelligence but because the teaching they required was not available when it was most needed.

When Eriksson does take over the England squad he should not want for intelligent application from the players. He may even find himself turning, as Howard Wilkinson did, to Teddy Sheringham, a cerebrally astute footballer who even at 34 is not only a prolific striker in the Premiership but links the play as well as anyone.

If English footballers as a breed lack anything it is not intelligence but imagination. Some may feel the two are indivisible but, with proper coaching, players who would never pretend to be world class do play highly imaginative football.

Look at Ipswich Town, for whom the likes of Matt Holland, Mark Venus, Titus Bramble and Marcus Stewart are bewildering seasoned Premiership opponents with the imagination of their passing and movement.

The West Ham United academy, pioneered by Malcom Allison and Dave Sexton and brought to fruition by Ron Greenwood, found depths of intelligence in such players as Bobby Moore, Martin Peters and Geoff Hurst and did more than any other club to win England the 1966 World Cup.

For years Dario Gradi has been turning out bright young footballers at Crewe, such as Seth Johnson, who made his England debut this week. Manchester United's youthful core of players - Beckham, Paul Scholes, Ryan Giggs and so on - would not be the players they are now without a reasonable degree of erudition even if it did take the footballing brain of Eric Cantona to switch on the lights in the first place.

English football is a bit like the English education system and not best designed to make the most of talent crying out for development. When, for example, did one of the big public schools produce an outstanding professional footballer? All that the game has had from Harrow is David Elleray.

Even now there is a tendency to regard football as a career for non-academics; a strange attitude given the millions which successful players can now earn. It is this attitude which separates England from countries such as France, Holland, Germany, Brazil, Italy or Argentina, where the game is rated as highly as a career in one of the established professions.

Here it is not so much a question of intelligence as opportunity.

fields.headline: Derby go West for salvation
fields.standfirst: Adrian Milledge  meets the man with a Pride Park pledge
fields.trailText: Adrian Milledge meets the man with a Pride Park pledge.
fields.body:
Taribo West, a man who does much to save Africa's lost souls, today embarks on what many see as a lost cause - keeping Derby County in the Premiership - when he tackles bottom-of-the-table Bradford City, Stan Collymore and all.

And not just at the behest of Derby's chairman Lionel Pickering and manager Jim Smith: for the religious Nigerian defender, who has joined the club on loan from Milan, an altogether more senior authority is involved.

"Whenever I fall into a situation where there is darkness, it means God is about to use me for something," said the 26-year-old as he surveyed Pride Park for the first time. "I have never been at a club which is fighting to survive in the league and although Derby is down, something is about to happen.

"I believe that from this day Derby will be witnessing something different."

Whether that means West, who has also played for Internazionale, will wear the trademark club-colour ribbons in his hair at Pride Park today is unknown. "At Milan I do red and black, with Inter I do blue and yellow and now I will do black and white. I don't know whether I will do it against Bradford but I will do it while I'm with Derby."

The central defender, who won a gold medal with Nigeria at the 1996 Olympics, has no plans to abandon the decorative practice.

"I will still tie ribbons in my hair because it's fun and it's fashionable and I want to get my own style," added West, whose conversation is punctuated by biblical references.

What the 60-year-old Smith, the ever genial but dyed-in-the-wool Lancastrian, makes of all this has yet to be revealed. Ditto his new assistant Colin Todd, a player schooled by Brian Clough.

Of more importance to Derby's management is that West's presence should help plug the leaks in what was the Premiership's most porous defence until Todd's contentious switch from Swindon Town two games ago.

Since then County have not conceded a goal, the second clean sheet coming against the free-scoring Arsenal side that included West's Nigerian team-mate Nwankwo Kanu.

Thanks to Kanu and personal experience, West knows about the healthy end of the Premiership but has had to undergo a crash course in Derby's history.

"I have played against good teams from England like Arsenal and Manchester United. That is why I am so happy to be here in the Premiership and I hope I can give my best because I have been close to coming for years now.

"I have to admit that, apart from the name, I didn't know much about Derby but I know a bit more about the history now. I've been reading about the club and learning and looking at programmes. I feel happy, I feel at home, especially with a coach as good as Jim Smith, and it is a good challenge to lift them in the league."

West, who has played little Serie A football in the past year, is due to spend three months at Derby before returning to Milan, but he has not ruled out the possibility of extending his stay. As always, though, the final decision is not his.

"If that is God's will, it will be done," he confirmed. "And if God wills it, I will set up a church here."

With Pickering already warning that relegation from the Premiership will be financially ruinous for County, the chances are that the club's multi-millionaire owner will build West a church himself if he helps keep the Rams in the top flight.

In which case it would become West's second church: he has already set up one in Milan and tirelessly raises funds for the underprivileged, especially in Africa.

"There are a lot of people who are going through misfortune in life and and I think God has a purpose for them and a purpose for me," he explained.

"Because I am well known they listen to me. And I think God is using me to do something in their lives which makes me very happy.

"I have always felt that way, since I was a child. In Italy we released two songs with players and raised nearly £2m for Unicef.

"Income from Taribo West shoes, shorts and vests also goes to the poor in Africa and while I'm in England I would like to mobilise a few players and do something similar. That is my essence of having my church.

"People think I had a rough upbringing, but that's not right. What I have said is that we don't have the same opportunity as Europeans. They can start in a school of football; in Africa we play on the road. And when you play on the street you become very tough."

Stan Collymore, for one, has been warned.

webTitle: Curbishley ready to bid for Hartson

fields.headline: Curbishley ready to bid for Hartson
fields.standfirst: Charlton interested in Wimbledon's £5m-rated Welshman while Fulham bolster their squad
fields.trailText: Charlton interested in Wimbledon's £5m-rated Welshman while Fulham bolster their squad.
fields.body:
The Charlton manager Alan Curbishley admitted yesterday that his club are interested in signing Wimbledon's £5m-rated striker John Hartson. Curbishley said he had asked his Wimbledon counterpart Terry Burton about Hartson's availability after Burton inquired about taking the Charlton striker Kevin Lisbie on loan.

"I've had a couple of conversations with Terry Burton," he said. "We know each other very well. He asked after Kevin, and I told him I had a load of problems myself with strikers and if he wanted Kevin I would take John."

Wimbledon are understood to be prepared to sell Hartson to reduce their wage bill but Curbishley said they would not consider taking the 25-year-old on loan. "They have got to sell," he said. "There are agents involved who are trying to help it along."

Fulham have signed the Latvian international striker Andrejs Stolcers, subject to the player getting a work permit. The First Division leaders have paid £2m for Stolcers, who joined Spartak Moscow from the Ukrainian runners-up Shakhtar Donetsk a few months ago.

Blackburn Rovers will return to the past with an old-fashioned shirt to celebrate their 125th birthday today. The First Division club have been granted permission to wear a shirt which dispenses with squad numbers and sponsorship logo.

Rob King, the Star's football correspondent, died suddenly yesterday. He was 46. King collapsed a day after returning from Turin where he had been reporting on England's friendly against Italy. Prior to joining the Star, King reported on football for the Press Association for 20 years, rising to become the wire service's chief football writer.

webTitle: Jefferies stands by to take control at Bradford

fields.headline: Jefferies stands by to take control at Bradford
fields.standfirst: Scot ready to take the reins just a fortnight after leaving Hearts
fields.trailText: Scot ready to take the reins just a fortnight after leaving Hearts.
fields.body:
Jim Jefferies will watch Bradford City in today's Premiership relegation battle with Derby before being confirmed as the club's new manager.

Jefferies admits there are still "one or two things to be finalised" but, following a second interview with Geoffrey Richmond at Valley Parade yesterday, the Bradford chairman said: "I am confident he will be unveiled as the manager of Bradford City on Monday."

Jefferies succeeds Chris Hutchings, who was sacked after only one win in his 12 games in charge. "This has come really quickly so you have to jump at it," Jefferies said. "I have been given an opportunity in the Premiership, and that doesn't come too often.

"One of the reasons that attracted me to Bradford was the likes of Stan Collymore and Benito Carbone. You've only got to look at the quality in the squad.

"It will be a great challenge. It was terrific last year when they stayed up and that is their aim in the short term."

It is only a fortnight since Jefferies left Hearts, where he spent five years and led the club to the Scottish Cup, their first major trophy for 36 years.

Jefferies, who will become City's fifth manager in seven years, represents something of a gamble for Richmond, since he has never managed in England. He emerged as the victor from what boiled down to a two-horse race between himself and another Scot, Stuart Baxter, the former coach of AIK Solna of Stockholm.

Jefferies will be little more than an interested onlooker at Pride Park this afternoon. First-team affairs will remain in the hands of the Bradford captain Stuart McCall until Monday.

Jefferies made it a condition of his employment that he be allowed to bring in Billy Brown, his No2 at Tynecastle, but McCall also has management aspirations and may be found a role.

It is believed Jefferies has been offered a deal which would net him the relatively small sum of £5,000 a week but with the promise of a bonus worth up to £1m should he ensure the West Yorkshire club again plays Premiership football come August.

webTitle: Talisman Dickov enjoying taste of the top

fields.headline: Talisman Dickov enjoying taste of the top
fields.standfirst: Slow-burning Scot is ready to set today's derby ablaze
fields.trailText: Slow-burning Scot is ready to set today's derby ablaze.
fields.body:
Paul Dickov is not entirely certain whether it is fame of infamy, but either way he is certainly a man in demand. At his home in a picture-book corner of Cheshire, he has more than 30 interview requests to sift through. How, he wonders aloud, has every bugger got his number?

When Manchester City dusted down their red carpet for George Weah at the start of the season, Dickov was swiftly touted as favourite for the guillotine, the overwhelming consensus being that he would be shipped out, best wishes and all, to the backwaters of the Nationwide League.

Instead, it has been a triumph for the little man. Weah, the one-time world footballer of the year, who has been there, done that and could set up a market stall with all the T-shirts, has disappeared in a huff after being left to collect splinters on the bench. And Dickov, having failed to command a regular place in the Second Division two seasons ago, has established himself as City's talisman in attack.

Today, in the first Manchester derby for four years, the only reminder of Weah at Maine Road will be the queue of fans who have been offered refunds on the replica shirts with his name on.

Dickov, by contrast, is settled with his family in Bowdon, the footballer's enclave populated by, among others, Roy Keane, Fabien Barthez and Teddy Sheringham - "I'm all right," he says, "the paparazzi don't usually recognise me" - and having acquired a taste for the Premiership he clearly intends to be around for some time yet.

"Two years ago we were going to Chesterfield, Colchester and Lincoln. I wasn't always playing and we were losing to the likes of Wycombe. When you look back at that season, it's impossible for me not to be enjoying this now.

"They were desperate times for a club of this size and, as a player, it was embarrassing. People say I'm part of the squad that has taken us up to the Premiership, but I was also part of one that took us down to the Second Division. During those days it was best to keep a low profile around Manchester. You certainly couldn't have imagined us taking on United."

Dickov has always been an important piston in the machinery but it is only now, after a career that flickered without truly igniting at Arsenal, that he seems comfortable in the higher echelon. Where he once shuffled, he now has a swagger to his play. And his updated curriculum vitae not only incorporates an impressive assist in precipitating Weah's departure from Maine Road but, at the age of 28, the green shoots of an international career with Scotland.

For all his powers of longevity, however, his route back to the Premiership has been anything but uncomplicated. When he left Arsenal for City four years ago he called his Highbury team-mates together and confidently predicted he "would see them soon". Not since Michael Fish swatted rumours of a hurricane can there have been a more rickety promise.

"City had just been relegated to the First Division so I was thinking to myself: 'We'll be promoted this season and I'll be back in the Premiership next year'" he says. "You could say it has taken a bit longer than I hoped."

Joe Royle's men have been to hell and back (and very nearly Hull and back) but, for Dickov, the stomach-jolting highs and lows began long before that when, having signed for Alan Ball on a Friday, his new manager was promptly sacked on the Sunday.

Along the way, there have been plenty of other troubled times, too. "There were spells when I wasn't playing and I thought I might have to move on but the gaffer has always given me the incentive to stay by saying he wants me to stick around.

"Sometimes it makes you feel like one of the cleaners, but even when I have been out of the side I could never have slagged him off. He's always been honest with me and that's all you can ask for. And look, I'm still here."
