fields.headline: Boulding returns to old racket
fields.standfirst: Mansfield striker given second service
fields.trailText: Mansfield striker given second service.
fields.body:
When Mansfield visited Bristol City in last season's FA Cup first round, a handful of British tennis players made the trip to Ashton Gate to watch an old colleague try to stick the ball into the back of the net rather than over it.

"I'd not seen them since I was on the circuit," says Mick Boulding, a half-time substitute for the visitors in a 3-2 defeat that day. "They thought it was hilarious to see me running around in a football kit."

Boulding, winner of a tournament in Dubai as a junior and a couple of money events on the tour, is now a 24-year-old striker in his second season at Field Mill, where today Mansfield will attempt to reach the second round at the expense of Peterborough.

"We're playing a team from a league above us and Barry Fry's teams like to attack, that's his way," says Bill Dearden, the manager. "But we like to get forward too, so I can see there being a few goals."

For Boulding, who played for Sheffield Boys from age nine to 13, an overdue first in the FA Cup, be it a lob, a volley or a tap-in, would be more than pleasing after a chance meeting over 10 years ago with Tony Pickard, then coach to the two-times Wimbledon champion Stefan Edberg.

"Tony lives in Nottingham and we met at a football match," says Boulding. "We got on well, he offered me a few free tennis lessons and I really got into it. I ended up on the national squad when I was 16 or 17. He even brought Petr Korda up to Sheffield to practise with me for a couple of weeks.

"It was an exciting time for me and I made it to the senior tour. I played in India, America, Mexico, Japan, Indonesia, about 40 countries in all. But I always felt I was a footballer who happened to play tennis."

There was some scope for the big-ball game, however, and he used to play in LTA matches at Christmas. "A lot of the lads were not that great," he says, "but Tim [Henman] played in goal and was pretty good. In my last match he even went up front and got a hat-trick. Some people are naturals and can turn their hands to most sports."

At the age of 22, though, after six years on the tour, Boulding decided to channel his energies back in the direction of football.

"Playing tennis is a bit like being on a treadmill and I was very weary with it. The help I got from the LTA was quite limited, really. I didn't have a coach at tournaments like a lot of the others did, and if you lose early one week it's very difficult to keep mentally strong for the start of the next week. I just thought there were a lot more opportunities for me as a footballer."

A season in non-league with the Hallam club followed before, in the summer of 1999, Mansfield invited him for a trial and later gave him a one-year deal. "Micky was recommended to us and we played him in a reserve match," recalls Dearden. "I saw that he had pace and we brought him in. He was a left-winger but we played him up front and he's converted well. He knuckled down, learned a lot and now he's getting the benefit of the last 12 months."

A new contract and four goals in six starts is testimony to that in a season which has been disrupted by a couple of un-tennislike injuries, a broken nose and a broken metacarpal, but Boulding is delighted to be back in the team game. "The biggest switch was coming from a sport with a lot of total introverts to one with a lot of extroverts. I was a bit shy at first but footballers have a way of bringing you out of it."

Barry Silkman was never backward at coming forward in his 10-club, 14-season career and today the players' agent hopes to make an appearance from the Harrow Borough bench at Wycombe, managed by the 1988 FA Cup winner Lawrie Sanchez. If he does, aged 48 and 142 days, the former striker will be the oldest man to appear in the Cup since Sir Stanley Matthews, then 49.

Kidderminster host Burton Albion of the Dr Martens Premier in a tie which will see much of the attention focused on dugouts dominated by the former Liverpool players Jan Molby, twice an FA Cup winner, and Nigel Clough, like his dad only ever a finalist. And the Conference club Kingstonian make the short trip along the Thames to Brentford.

Tomorrow Radcliffe Borough, with Bernard Manning junior as chairman and his unfunny father as president, face York in a tie which has been moved to Bury's Gigg Lane; Canvey Island, top of the Ryman Premier, host Port Vale; and Millwall play Leigh RMI, new to the Conference, in a tie switched to the Den from Hilton Park. There is also an appealing game at Cardiff, a city still hoping to get the go-ahead to stage the final, who face Bristol Rovers.

webTitle: We have the man to stop the Aussies

fields.headline: We have the man to stop the Aussies
fields.standfirst:
Australia has an eye on the last bastion of British sporting pride.
We must act fast
fields.trailText: "Australia is, slowly, surely, inevitably, closing in on the one area of sporting superiority we Britons have left." There's only one thing for it, says Jim White.
fields.body:
The ultimate nightmare grows ever nearer. Already world champions at cricket, rugby union and rugby league, not to mention boasting the world's finest swimmers and a clutch of tennis champions, Australia is, slowly, surely, inevitably, closing in on the one area of sporting superiority we Britons have left: football. On Wednesday, the Socceroos hammered Scotland, not only winning 2-0 but playing what was once the most skilful of European nations off the park. And this without their three most valuable players: Mark Bosnich, Mark Viduka and Harry Kewell. Before the horror unfolds, before it becomes impossible to go into a London pub without the barman sneering at our national lack of prowess, something has to be done. Since it is quite simple not to schedule any friendlies between the two countries, the problem will only arise at the next World Cup. To prevent such a clash, the FA needs to develop a strategy which goes beyond its existing one of sidestepping embarrassment by ensuring England don't qualify.

As it happens there is a solution, and it has the added benefit of, at the same time, solving a more local problem. We need the services of the most patriotic of operators to act as a fifth columnist and mess up the Socceroos' qualification. And the one I have in mind has done the job before, presiding over their comical failure to make France 98. Plus, he's at something of a loose end at the moment. Help is at hand for us all: send them Terry Venables.

webTitle: Stage set for a slog on the Tyne

fields.headline: Stage set for a slog on the Tyne
fields.standfirst: North East bragging rights are at stake like never before at St James' today
fields.trailText: North East bragging rights are at stake like never before at St James' today.
fields.body:
When Alan Shearer and Michael Gray lead their teams out of the St James' Park tunnel this afternoon, local rivalries will rarely have been fiercer.

Newcastle and Sunderland meet for the 121st time and, in the cosmopolitan Premiership, a Geordie will captain the black and whites, a Mackem the red and whites. Not since before the second world war have two such fiercely local partisans competed for bragging rights.

The clarity is in stark contrast to last season when, in the apocalyptic evening deluge on Tyneside, the Newcastle manager Ruud Gullit muddied the water further by selecting a Mackem, Paul Robinson, to lead his line ahead of Shearer. When the club captain was called upon, Niall Quinn had cancelled out Kieron Dyer's first-half opener. By the end, Kevin Phillips's smart finish in the mud left Gullit wallowing under the weight of a gamble that had horribly backfired.

"When I saw their team I thought we'd have a chance," recalls the Sunderland manager Peter Reid. "It looked like a resignation teamsheet and it clearly deflated St James'. If I had Alan Shearer in my squad he would probably be the first name on the sheet, with the possible exception of Kevin Phillips.

"You have got to have the players on your side as a manager but, judging by the team he picked, I don't think he did. I looked like a drowned rat when I passed him on the stairs after the match. He was like Giorgio Armani, but that was our night."

"Ruud maybe didn't understand the importance of the match," says Bobby Robson, who answered his boyhood heroes' call to succeed the crestfallen Dutchman. "Feyenoord against PSV Eindhoven is not Sunderland versus Newcastle, is it? They're not on each others' doorstep. The loss of that match was the last straw.

"Gullit said himself that he had made a slight blunder. He left out Alan and Duncan Ferguson, who he had bought, and it hadn't come off. But there was also no Rob Lee and he knows what this match means. I think Rob and Alan may get a game this time."

Robson, as black and white as they come, was actually courted by Sunderland while manager of Ipswich in the mid-70s. "Had it been a different team I would have changed pits," he chuckles. "My father would be jumping with joy to know I'm managing Newcastle against Sunderland. He was at the 1932 Cup Final and I grew up with him telling me about that game."

"The loyalty up here is frightening," adds Reid. "They've been starved of success in terms of trophies, but that just puts more emphasis on the derby. I went to my first Old Firm recently and that was tasty, but they don't come any keener than this."

fields.headline: Outstanding sax appeal
fields.standfirst:
Queen Elizabeth Hall,
London
****
fields.trailText:
Queen Elizabeth Hall,
London
****
fields.body:
David Murray, the sturdy, box-built, 45-year-old saxophonist from Berkeley is joined in the London Jazz Festival by Sonny Rollins and a tiny handful of others in preserving the massive, statuesque sound of pre-second world war swing players within a contemporary repertoire. It's an effect that creates the remarkable illusion of formidable torsos being the organ-pipe in which music is formed, and the sax being merely the escape route.

You might expect this of Rollins, who was a young man when swing giants such as Coleman Hawkins and Don Byas were in their prime, but in the much younger Murray it's come about through research, heart and an ear for fundamentals over details.

The saxophone giant brought his octet to London to perform the John Coltrane repertoire that features on the new Murray CD, Octet Plays Trane. This is a fine improvising band with a rhythm section of fierce intensity. Its momentum is unflagging and its soloing inventive, but the strongest features are Murray's own tenor and bass clarinet playing and the jaw-dropping agility and counter-melodic vivacity of the ensemble arrangements which all sound like seamlessly interwoven solos of their own. Murray's achievement has been to reflect the onrush of Coltrane's typhoon of a solo approach through a larger group often all playing hell-for-leather at once, but without losing the plot.

The opening Lazy Bird set that mood, with a fast and complex, multi-layered arrangement setting off a powerful Murray tenor solo that grew louder, looser and more slippery in phrasing as it progressed. Lafayette Gilchrist, Murray's Baltimore piano discovery, delivered fascinating kaleidoscopes of the vigorous, the delicately preoccupied and the harmonically ambiguous.

Murray's own playing became more majestically painterly and loose as the gig progressed, his passionate sound at its most urgent on Announcement, from A Love Supreme. Gilchrist exquisitely previewed Naima, like a minimalist George Gershwin with a distant Thelonious Monk playing Well You Needn't in the background, and Murray expanded it with a soliloquy of ruggedly lustrous sounds, impassioned multiphonics, complex phrasing astonishingly extended by circular breathing. One of the outstanding events of the festival.

fields.headline: Good ol' Kinky Friedman
fields.standfirst:
Underworld,
London
****
fields.trailText:
Underworld,
London
****
fields.body:
A hefty proportion of the sold-out audience have seen Kinky Friedman perform once for every gallon in his hat, and it's immediately obvious why they keep coming back for more. The country singer meets dime-a-crime novelist is a crowd-pleaser of the highest order, the kind of old-fashioned entertainer who thinks lighting a cigar should be played for laughs. His eyes twinkle cheerily and that huge moustache twitches with pleasure as he knocks out the same songs he's been playing since the 1970s with an infectious enthusiasm and enjoyable, only slightly ironic, appreciation of his own brilliance.

This isn't so much a gig as a variety show: a little music, a little stand-up, a literary interlude as Friedman swaps his guitar for a copy of his latest novel, The Mile High Club. His banter is so honed you could slice cheese with it; the daft gags linking each song are old as his hometown of Texas, but Friedman knowing this just makes them more amusing.

Friedman has Little Jewford, the only remaining member of his 1970s band, the Texas Jewboys, a man who looks like a hybrid of Jeremy Clarkson and Matthew Kelly, and whose main talent (apart from deliciously cornball synth and kazoo skills) is an ability to sound like he's on helium. He happily plays Friedman's foil, recoiling as Friedman mimes bashing his head with a guitar, even falling off his chair at the end of a chromatic scale. You can't but laugh at such stupidity.

It's not all tomfoolery, however. Friedman radiates a burnished reverence both for country music and for fine writing, so that, even at their silliest, his songs and prose are impeccably designed and a delight to hear. The show is bookended with Friedman playing solo, and the tunes he chooses - Western Union Wire at the start, Sold American and Rapid City, South Dakota to close - are as honest and affecting as anything by his heroes Gram Parsons or Hank Williams. It's hard to reconcile this Friedman with the chauvinist of Get Your Biscuits in the Oven and Your Buns in the Bed, who doesn't care if his jokes are homophobic as long as they're funny. But watching him bounce from person to larger-than-life persona is part of the fun.

His eyes twinkle cheerily and that huge moustache twitches with pleasure as he knocks out the same songs he's been playing since the 1970s with an infectious enthusiasm and enjoyable, only slightly ironic, appreciation of his own brilliance. This isn't so much a gig as a variety show: a little music, a little stand-up, a literary interlude as Friedman swaps his guitar for a copy of his latest novel, The Mile High Club. His banter is so honed you could slice cheese with it; the daft gags linking each song are old as his hometown of Texas, but Friedman knowing this just makes them more amusing. Friedman has Little Jewford, the only remaining member of his 1970s band, the Texas Jewboys, a man who looks like a hybrid of Jeremy Clarkson and Matthew Kelly, and whose main talent (apart from deliciously cornball synth and kazoo skills) is an ability to sound like he's on helium. He happily plays Friedman's foil, recoiling as Friedman mimes bashing his head with a guitar, even falling off his chair at the end of a chromatic scale. You can't but laugh at such stupidity. It's not all tomfoolery, however. Friedman radiates a burnished reverence both for country music and for fine writing, so that, even at their silliest, his songs and prose are impeccably designed and a delight to hear. The show is bookended with Friedman playing solo, and the tunes he chooses - Western Union Wire at the start, Sold American and Rapid City, South Dakota to close - are as honest and affecting as anything by his heroes Gram Parsons or Hank Williams. It's hard to reconcile this Friedman with the chauvinist of Get Your Biscuits in the Oven and Your Buns in the Bed, who doesn't care if his jokes are homophobic as long as they're funny. But watching him bounce from person to larger-than-life persona is part of the fun.

webTitle: The heavy cost of seeing double

fields.headline: The heavy cost of seeing double
fields.standfirst: Getting duplicates of home loan statements for borrowing or tax needs is very expensive. Patrick Collinson and Kate Harvey report
fields.trailText: Need a copy of your bank statements or mortgage payments for your tax return or for a remortgage application? You could be in for a shock when you discover how much it costs to obtain simple duplicates.
fields.body:
Need a copy of your bank statements or mortgage payments for your tax return or for a remortgage application? You could be in for a shock when you discover how much it costs to obtain simple duplicates.

A Jobs & Money survey this week reveals that Woolwich charges £25 for each mortgage statement requested, in sharp contrast to other lenders such as Halifax and Nationwide, where duplicate statements are free.

The increasing numbers of people remortgaging are always asked by their new lender for a copy of past mortgage payments made. Usually a lender will want to see two or three years' records, so the total cost for somone remortgaging out of Woolwich can be £75, while at Abbey National and Northern Rock the figure is £45.

A similar picture emerges if you need copies of bank statements. While Barclays and HSBC make no charge, Lloyds TSB demands £5 per sheet - so a couple of month's statements could set you back £30-£40.

How can some banks and lenders justify charges, while others offer copies for free? Woolwich is tight-lipped about its charge, the highest in the survey. In a terse statement it said: "We feel this is a realistic charge."

However, according to other lenders such as Nationwide, asking £25 for a single piece of paper outlining your payments is no longer acceptable in an age where computers mean that the true cost of a print-off is in reality a matter of a few pence.

Nationwide dropped a wide range of fees in June 1998, including charges for stopping cheques or for production of a mortgage deed. At the time, it said: "Every bank and building society has customers who are irritated by one service fee or another. As a building society we are not driven to maximise the profit we make out of our customers at every turn."

Yorkshire building society is now following Nationwide's lead, although two years' late. It currently charges £5 for a copy of a mortgage statement, but will drop the charge from next year. "It's all part of our ongoing commitment to mu tuality," says a spokeswoman.

However, while it is fair to say that non-mutuals (such as Woolwich, Abbey National and Northern Rock) tend to be the high chargers, there are non-mutuals which have dropped fees. For example, neither Cheltenham & Gloucester (part of Lloyds TSB) or Halifax make charges, even though both are quoted companies.

Cheltenham & Gloucester's largesse is all the more suprising considering that its parent company is the highest charger for copies of duplicate bank statements, at £5 per statement. A Lloyds TSB spokesman says: "There is quite a lot of work involved in obtaining statements which are archived and not available by a simple click of a computer mouse." It adds that its charges are currently "under review."

However, HSBC says it has no problems sending customers duplicate copies for free at the click of a mouse. Spokeswoman Victoria Lee says: "We have spent an awful lot of money in modernising our systems, whereas other banks may still be using old microfiche records which will make it more time consuming for them."

But if you are a user of a bank's internet services, do not rely on your web account as your filing system. Lloyds TSB on-line bank statements currently go back six weeks, while First Direct's on-line service holds your statement going back four months.

However, it is expected that on-line records of bank statements going back further than just a few months will be available to account holders as the web services develop and expand their technology.

webTitle: The hedge nuisance that keeps growing

fields.headline: The hedge nuisance that keeps growing
fields.standfirst: Unruly foliage left to run wild by neighbours can make your life a misery and, as Elizabeth Langton reports, there's little you can do
fields.trailText: Unruly foliage left to run wild by neighbours can make your life a misery and, as Elizabeth Langton reports, there's little you can do.
fields.body:
Next week the Tree Council wants to set a new world record for the number of trees planted in three days. At the same time the House of Lords will be debating nuisance hedging and government plans to police them.

There are an estimated 17,000 problem hedges in England and Wales. Hedge blight has driven Britons to the courts and in a small number of cases even to violence. In July, a retired civil servant in Wales was reported to have been shot dead after arguing with a neighbour over a boundary dispute and a hedge dividing their gardens.

Campaigning group Hedgeline has lobbied the government for almost three years for legislation to control the height and spread of Leylandii and other monster trees and hedges. At the forefront of the campaign is founder Michael Jones, from Birmingham, whose problem began 20 years ago and whose case has cost thousands of pounds in court fees. It even led judges to struggle with the definition of a hedge.

Hedgeline president Clare Hinchliffe is boxed in by hedging including Leyland and Laurel varieties. She is negotiating with her neighbours to keep the hedges trimmed. The main hedge culprit is as loathed by its victims as any criminal - the Leyland Cypress (Cupressocyparis leylandii). The plant, the result of a chance cross of two other varieties of Cypress in 1888, is the most widely used conifer for hedging and screening. The reason behind its popularity is its vigour. It grows at a rate of four feet a year and withstands windswept conditions. It is a very useful plant in the right environment. However, the speed of its growth and it height (up to 100ft) has also attracted homeowners searching for an instant barrier to screen their garden from their neighbours. Before long, the hedges are out of control.

Unchecked, the trees can suck the life-blood out of nearby flowerbeds and shrubs as well as damage buildings and fences. As Ms Hinchliffe points out: "Seven foot of nuisance hedge can cut out the light completely in a small garden".

Unruly hedges are also expensive to maintain and can make a property difficult to sell. The stress of dealing with a neighbour's monster hedge takes its toll on homeowners mental health, she says. "We want a law whereby nuisance hedging can be identified by some means and growers can be forced to reduce it in height" Ms Hinchliffe says.

At present the power lies with the person who grows the hedge. The only rights neighbours have is to cut off overhanging branches.

The government has acknowledged the need for new laws to keep the problem in check following a public consultation last year. In August environment minister Michael Meacher announced that, when legislative time allowed, local authorities in England would be given new powers to settle hedge disputes if the matter could not be solved amicably. It is up to Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland to introduce their own legislative changes.

The problems faced by mandarins at the Department of Environment, Transport and the Regions (DETR) charged with drafting new rules is defining what constitutes a "nuisance". Hedgeline recognises the problems of definition and is anxious that any new laws do not follow in the steps of the Dangerous Dogs Act. Above all, says Ms Hinchliffe, new laws need to be workable.

Among Hedgeline's 3,000 members, there are those who have had their lives ruined, lost thousands of pounds and almost their sanity in disputes over hedges. So what drives homeowners to dig their heels in and refuse to trim a nuisance hedge. Ms Hinchliffe says usually the disputes build up gradually.

"It starts off civilly with a victim asking their neighbour to trim the hedge. They'll cut it a bit, but before long it will grow again. The victim will have to go round again and again to ask them to cut it further. Before long the relationship between the neighbours will have deteriorated."

She also believes it is no coincidence that many Hedgeline members are elderly widows who having lost their husbands and are too worn out from grief to tackle bullying neighbours. Perhaps people who grow high hedges take more care when their neighbours are younger and more able to fight their corner, she says.

People see it as their right to grow a hedge and the law is on their side at the moment. "So if it's causing you a problem you have to screw on a smile and ask nicely."

Hegdeline advises people, no matter how great the temptation, not to take an axe to the offending growth. The organisation also urges victims to stay away from courts and solicitors unless absolutely necessary. When disputes escalate and lawyers are involved, victims rarely end up any better off - the law is on the side of the hedge grower, says the organisation.

The DETR publishes advice on how to choose a hedge, called The Right Hedge for You. The pamphlet reminds householders that all hedges need trimming at least once a year, some need to be cut more often. Growers should also resist the temptation to plant a fast growing variety because it will continue to grow after it's reached the desired height. Keeping it in check thereafter could be costly and time consuming.

webTitle: House buyers left high and dry

fields.headline: House buyers left high and dry
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The floods that have devastated much of Britain reveal that standard surveying and conveyancing processes do little to assess the risk that buyers are taking on.
fields.body:
The floods that have devastated much of Britain reveal that standard surveying and conveyancing processes do little to assess the risk that buyers are taking on.

Most domestic property surveys are done on a standard form devised by mortgage lenders. These rarely make any reference to flooding or other environmental hazards.

There is, though, nothing to stop a diligent surveyor advising on the question and, for instance, pointing out the proximity of a river. However, as failure to do even that would be in accordance with current standard practice, it is unlikely to lead to a successful negligence claim.

Similarly, the standard form of inquiries that are raised by solicitors before contracts are exchanged do not ask about flooding, though conscientious solicitors could add an extra inquiry of their own as to whether the property has ever been flooded.

Another surprising omission from these inquiries is about the property's insurance. Asking whether cover has ever been refused or only offered on special terms could bring any potential difficulties to light.

A Law Society spokesman asks in this week's Gazette: "Why should this be the responsibility of solicitors? Why not estate agents and surveyors?"

While others involved in the house buying process may also have a role to play, solicitors are uniquely able to pin down sellers to revealing what they know. Someone who falsely denied there had been a flooding problem would face a substantial compensation claim if it recurred.

The Law Society also pointed out that anyone concerned about such a problem would be well advised to contact the Environment Agency's Floodline, which should be able to provide the most comprehensive information.

 Richard Colbey is a barrister

fields.headline: Bent
fields.body:
We're heading for the silly season. For the next month or so, the TV companies will dig out those old episodes of Top of The Pops that are banned for the rest of the year. Bizarre but loveable creatures (well, OK, Roy Wood) will stalk our screens in five feet of hair and make-up, while at least every third band will have a guitarist dressed as a gorilla.

Meanwhile, people of all generations will be entitled to sigh wistfully and wonder when, exactly, pop's sense of humour was finally stifled by the age of mass marketing. Well, as Bent are determined to demonstrate, it isn't dead.

One of them (Simon Mills) has blue hair; the other (Nail) looks like Norman Bates, and they both model sideburns Elvis would have declared over the top. Arriving onstage to the Theme From Tin Tin and flashed up logos of 20th Century Fox, they soon take what sounds suspiciously like an old Simple Minds tune and mangle it out of shape - hence their moniker, Bent.

Often compared to Air (much to their chagrin), Bent's Mills and, er Nail are in fact impossible to pin down. Between songs, they amuse themselves with end-of-the-pier country and western, stilted 50s public information soundtracks and the repeated loop of the word "toilet".

It's exceedingly silly but you can't help laughing with them. However, after tickling the audience into submission, they deliver the unexpected twist: these madcaps are creating some extraordinarily beautiful music.

Although fascinated with old-fashioned notions of the future - weedy synths, Tomorrow's World and astronaut cartoons - Bent have combined this with 80s pop and 90s rave to construct music full of character. The ancient drum machine from OMD's Electricity is just as likely to appear as what sounds like Ofra Hazra put through a blender, along with only scarcely recognisable echoes of everyone from the Cocteau Twins to Orbital to the Beloved.

In keeping with their humour, singer Zoe is introduced like a pub turn but her ethereal, slightly Julee Cruise vocals inspire things further. By the end, they've attained a stunning, trancelike, headline-at-Glastonbury magnificence.

One day, Bent will have to decide whether to abandon the laughs and go more seriously for the jugular. But for the moment they're having a fabulous time.

As they leave the stage laughing, their hi-tech film show flashes up: "Happy birthday to my girlfriend, Claire."

fields.headline: CBSO/ Segerstam
fields.standfirst:
Symphony Hall,
Birmingham
*****
fields.trailText:
Symphony Hall,
Birmingham
*****
fields.body:
As an entrance it was unbeatable. The Finnish conductor Leif Segerstam is impressive enough just to look at - nearly as wide as he is tall, with a magnificent mane of hair, voluminous beard and eyes that twinkle halogenically. On reaching the podium he opened the score of his Symphony No 35 wide to the auditorium and flicked through the first few pages. Of course, none of us could see a note from that distance. But that wasn't the point. The score, Segerstam explained, was open to us in another sense. This symphony required no conductor. It was chamber music on a massive scale. We were to relate directly to the City of Birmingham Symphony Orchestra as a creative collective of musicians, while he went off to the side of the stage to play the second piano part.

There was something hallucinatory about the experience. The symphony - subtitled Flashbacking Backwardsly - is mostly a dense collage of sounds. Surging string lines, blazing brass chords, shrill woodwind birdsong and a host of other noises struggle for prominence then fall back into the general melee.

Some of it was baffling, but it was rarely long before some new, striking detail caught the ear. It was hard to believe the orchestra was directorless. Everything seemed to happen on cue; whole sections played as one; intensity and concentration never flagged.

As for that title, Flashbacking Backwardsly, Segerstam's note told us, was written at the turn of the millennium and looked back at recent works (symphonies 26-34, all composed in 1999) as though "experiencing an ending backwards". However confusing the experience may have been from time to time, there was no denying that it was alive, not a bizarrely anachronistic Dada-ist experiment.

There was life in abundance too in Segerstam's performance of Mahler's Ninth Symphony - Segerstam very much the conductor this time. In some ways it was a typical composer's interpretation, bringing out details one might not have noticed before, reconsidering tempo-relations.

The sense of shape Segerstam brought to the long, structurally problematic work was remarkable - as though Mahler had taken lessons in organic logic at work from Segerstam's countryman Sibelius. It was also very moving, in a strangely unsentimental way.

Segerstam may be spectacularly eccentric, but he's a lot more as well. This evening there were more than glimpses of something close to genius.

webTitle: Theatre review: The Witch of Edmonton

fields.headline: The Witch of Edmonton
fields.standfirst:
Southwark Playhouse,
London
***
fields.trailText:
Southwark Playhouse,
London
***
fields.body:
As you enter the theatre, the smell of something rank hits your nostrils. Maybe the scent of human frailty? Underfoot it is soft, the floor covered in bark. You feel you could sink down into it right up to your neck.

Erica Whyman, who will shortly move to the Gate, ends her reign at Southwark with another distinctive production: Simon Cox's racy and intimate account of Ford, Dekker and Rowley's 1621 play about witchcraft. Inspired by the real trial and execution of Elizabeth Sawyer, it became something of a cause célèbre.

Cox's production takes quite a little while to get into its stride, but as the play gets darker and the comic gives way to the charnel house it gains in confidence. The final 30 minutes have real power, combining text and physicality to considerable effect.

The acting gets better and better too, with Paul Panting's Dog making the Devil seem an immensely likable cur, Naomie Harris - sweet-voiced and sweet-faced - giving some bite and fire to doomed Susan and, best of all, Chris Garner's Cuddy, whose love of dogs, innocence and sheer good humour render the devil completely harmless.

One of the striking things about the evening is the way the play posits a view of the devil that seems less 17th century than completely modern. Evil is not innate, but merely takes its chance to flourish through the weakness of human nature and circumstance. It is like an old dog that suddenly views through the open butcher's door the possibility of a stolen bone.

Deirdre Doone's Mother Sawyer would not deal with the devil if she had not been driven to do so by the torments of those who have already labelled her as a witch; young Frank Thorny lets greed and filial duty get the better of him, turning him into a bigamist and murderer. Circumstance may lead them, but they make their choices and they pay the price.

There are a couple of things that jar: the accompanying music is initially too filmic in style and the way it is used, and while the simple, non-time-specific costumes provide a blank canvas, too often they look as if they are a money solution rather than a design solution.

But this is a genuinely invigorating production of an interesting play that is rarely performed and is all the fresher for it. Like so much work at this venue under Whyman's tenure, it is fully alert to the possibilities of this most flexible of spaces.

 To December 2. Box office: 020-7620 3494.

webTitle: Jobs for the boys?  Not any more

fields.headline: Jobs for the boys?  Not any more
fields.standfirst:
It's still tough for women in the workplace. But, as Liz Stuart reports, many are breaking through to take on occupations which were previously a male preserve

Work Unlimited
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: It's still tough for women in the workplace. But, as Liz Stuart reports, many are breaking through to take on occupations which were previously a male preserve.
fields.body:
This week the rumbustious columnist Jeremy Clarkson wrote in the Sunday Times about the BBC. "On Wednesday night, I went to a throughly enjoyable dinner, hosted by the head of factual documentaries at the BBC, who is a woman," he starts.

"Also in attendance were her two deputies, who are women, the head of daytime television, who is a woman, the new controller of BBC1, who is a woman, the woman in charge of regionally made television and Ray Mears."

He goes on to list many of the women who hold senior positions in the Beeb in his usual bloke-ish fashion. The addition of an acerbic, bitter ending to his story is missing, however, because he concludes that women are just as capable as men at doing these high-powered jobs and good luck to them. Thanks Jezzer.

Yet the BBC, with its positive policies towards childcare, flexible working and the long-term career prospects of women, remains an anomaly in the business world rather than the foretaste of female power Clarkson seems to hint at.

Women still face huge levels of sexism in the workplace. Last week the Industrial Society urged big businesses to stop living in the past when it reported that just 5% of directors of FTSE 100 companies are female. Most in need of a shake-up is Standard Chartered Bank, which has a board of 17, all of whom are male.

There is plenty of other evidence: the New Earnings Survey just pub lished by the Equal Opportunities Commission shows that at this rate it will be 20 years until the gap between men and women's earnings is closed. Women who work full time are still earning on average £8.98 an hour, compared with £11 for men. In Scotland the situation is more acute: average hourly wages for women are around 22% less than men's.

Also last month, the Institute of Management released its National Management Salary Survey 2000. While it showed that important progress has been made in the number of women managers, it is still the case that just 22% can claim the title of manager.

Next, look at some of the cases going through the courts. This year Judy Owen won a battle against the Professional Golfers' Association, earning the right to wear trousers at work. A female stationery clerk who had been ostracised by senior managers because she was pregnant won her sexual discrimination case. And a former City analyst brought a case against her employers, Schroder Securities, claiming that she was being paid less than two male colleagues working in a similar field.

Rebecca Miller is a stockbroker in the City. She is one of thousands of women breaking into jobs previously reserved for men. She agrees that the most noticable instances of sexism within the industry are in the recruitment process itself.

"You definitely have to be more able than a man; if you looked at a number of CVs I'm sure you would find that the women had far better qualifications than the men. And the City is still very much an old boy network," she says. "Clients are mostly old money and want to be treated as such, preferably by someone who went to a school with which they are familiar."

Once in position, Ms Miller says the sexism becomes more subtle. "In my previous job you could not get above a certain level - you had to change firms to get up the ladder, although maybe this is the case for men as well. I would not say that women are held back, but I would say that women have to be more aggressive in the job. You can also find that as a woman you are locked out of the office information flow."

Most of the problems stem from the attitudes of men who are not used to working with women who are their equals or seniors.In extreme cases women are subjected to innuendo, harrassment and potentially offensive pornographic material which circulates around many workplaces.

"And," says Ms Miller, "There are instances of positive discrimination. This makes for resentment between the men and women in the office because they feel that the females get a fairer deal than them. When I got my first job, I had long brunette hair. When I turned up on the first day, I found that all the other women had too. I don't want to think that I have been taken on for reasons of positive discrimination - half the brokers may think that, but I'm just going to carry on and prove myself."

The EOC has told the government that women could be the answer to its problem of a shortage of 6,500 trained soldiers in the Army. But the services hardly have a good record with female employment, even if the army has now introduced what it calls a "gender-free" physical fitness selection test. The Commission is calling for a lifting of the ban on women serving in combat regiments, which at the moment effectively bans them from one third of the jobs in the Army.

The chairwoman of the EOC, Julie Mellor, says: "Many women in the forces have told us they were not happy with the way their complaint of sexual harassment was dealt with and while women are not longer routinely dismissed when they become pregnant, attitudes towards women with children remain a problem.

"Rather than automatically excluding women from certain posts, it makes sense to judge each on the basis of their ability to carry out the job. We believe that special measures, such as training initiatives to equip women to work in certain jobs which have traditionally been done by men, would help boost the number of women applying," she says.

But she admits it is not easy to change attitudes: "If those women are to be retained, the culture within the services still needs to change."

webTitle: B&B and Barclays: Should I keep my shares or sell them?

fields.headline: What happens next?
fields.standfirst:
Should I keep my shares or sell them? That's the choice currently facing almost 4m people as a result of the imminent Bradford & Bingley building society flotation and the recent takeover of the Woolwich by Barclays, writes Rupert Jones

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Should I keep my shares or sell them? That's the choice currently facing almost 4m people as a result of the imminent Bradford & Bingley building society flotation and the recent takeover of the Woolwich by Barclays, writes Rupert Jones.
fields.body:
Bradford & Bingley is due to convert to a bank on December 4, unlocking windfalls of 250 shares each to almost 2.7m members. They received letters outlining the payouts a few weeks ago, and must make their decision about what they want to do with their shares by next Friday.

Meanwhile, around 1.2m Woolwich shareholders have just received a mixture of cash and Barclays shares following the takeover of the former building society by the banking giant. Quite a few of these people will never have held any shares before other than those of the Woowich and will be wondering whether to keep their Barclays shares or sell them via the low-cost share-dealing service that has been specially set up.

Here we look at what's happening and canvass the opinions of some experts as to what people should do.

Bradford & Bingley

With little more than a fortnight to go until Bradford & Bingley floats on the stock market, many B&B members will have already made their decision - they're taking the money.

But thousands of others are still unsure about whether to hold on to their shares or cash them in. You must return the relevant form saying what you want to do by next Friday.

If you opt to sell immediately, you'll get a cheque for the proceeds (minus a £10 selling fee) on around December 12. If you decide to keep them, you'll receive a "welcome pack" and confirmation of your shareholding within a few days of the conversion.

Unfortunately, you've got to make your decision without knowing what you could get for the shares if you sold them. The official estimate of a value of 259p-326p per share would spell windfalls of between £647 and £815, the mid-point of which is £731.

Last week, though, stockbroker Teather & Greenwood announced that its prediction for the share price at flotation was just 240p, which would mean windfalls worth only £600.

We asked three experts what they thought. One advised selling, another also indicated that for most people selling was probably the best bet, while the third advised holding on to the shares.

Jeremy Batstone at NatWest Stockbrokers says: "We are recommending people sell. The fact is that 250 shares is not an economic number of shares to hold. They will be worth £700 maybe if you're lucky - possibly a bit less." He adds that if you decide to go for the shares, you will be exposing yourself to the vagaries of the stock market, which has been fairly turbulent of late.

Ian Hodges at Barclays Stockbrokers, on the other hand, is recommending that unless members have a need for the cash now, they should retain the shares and see how things go once we have got the flotation out of the way. The price the members who sell immediately receive will be determined by the demand among institutional investors at the special City auction on December 3-4, and they are unlikely to bid aggressively for the shares because B&B will not be big enough to enter the FTSE 100 index of Britain's largest companies.

As a result Mr Hodges believes the shares may not open particularly strongly - perhaps at around 250p-260p each - but ultimately he thinks the business fundamentals and B&B's plans to become the leading independent distributor of financial and property services will make it an attractive stock. "I think ultimately they are worth somewhat more than that - certainly 300p and possibly up to 320p. It's a wait and see as opposed to a sell and regret later."

Fred Robinson at stockbroker Killik & Co indicates that for those people who aren't seasoned investors with already-established share portfolios, selling may be the best option, but he also advises people to think about the timing of when they sell.

He believes the combination of two factors - the large number of carpetbaggers receiving windfalls and the nearness to Christmas - mean a lot of people will choose to sell immediately and take the money, and there is therefore an argument for hanging on in the hope that the share price will improve once this initial batch of shares have been snapped up. But you have to ask yourself how long are you prepared to wait to see an improvement, and you also have to consider what your selling costs will be (while there's a £10 fee for selling immediately, it will probably cost you more than this to sell at a later date).

All things considered, if you're a novice investor with no other shares, holding those of just one company probably isn't a good idea, and you should perhaps consider selling. And if you're a carpetbagger it's pretty simple - you should take the money and run, he adds.

Barclays

The takeover of Woolwich by Barclays was officially completed on October 25, and 1.2m Woolwich shareholders received their new share certificates and cash last week.

Under the terms of the deal these people received £1.64 in cash and 0.1175 of a Barclays share for each Woolwich share they held.

Someone who held 657 Woolwich shares (the average windfall payout back in 1997) would have received a cheque for £1,081.23 plus 77 Barclays shares, which this week were worth around £19.40 each - well up on this summer, when the share price dipped below £15.

Someone who had 450 Woolwich shares (the basic allocation) would have received a cheque for £754.63 and 52 Barclays shares.

However, there was a mix and match option allowing people to opt for more cash or more shares if they wish. Perhaps surprisingly, far more people opted for all Barclays shares and no cash than opted for all cash and no Barclays shares, which meant those who wanted more Barclays shares saw their applications scaled back dramatically.

Many people will now be wondering what to do with their newly-acquired Barclays shares. If you want to sell yours (or buy more), a low-cost sharedealing service has been put in place and runs until December 29. It charges a flat fee of £8.50 per transaction.

So what do the experts think - keep those Barclays shares or ditch them?

Jeremy Batstone at NatWest Stockbrokers suggests the best advice for those people who own no other shares other than the Barclays ones may be to bail out and take the cash. "I think the answer is that for those type of people who are not cut out for the volatility that is associated with stock market investment, the forthcoming rocky ride may not be to their liking."

There are risks associated with holding Barclays shares, he adds - it's been a turbulent time for bank shares this year and with the internet forcing banks to completely rethink their traditional structures and new entrants continuing to pile on the pressure, this is likely to continue.

Fred Robinson at stockbroker Killik & Co says Barclays shares have been performing pretty well lately - they hit £20.10 on November 10. He suggests that for those people who don't own any other shares, this might be a good time to sell.

"If you have got Barclays as part of a larger portfolio, fine. If it is your only investment, it is probably not for you."

Alternatively, some people might want to consider developing a portfolio around their newly-acquired shares - but investing directly in shares is a risky business, and you need to have deep pockets and be prepared to take a long-term view.

webTitle: Theatre review: The Body of a Woman as a Battlefield

fields.headline: Rape as a weapon of war
fields.standfirst:
The Body of a Woman as a Battlefield
Young Vic Studio,
London
***
fields.trailText:
The Body of a Woman as a Battlefield
Young Vic Studio,
London
***
fields.body:
It is rare on a British stage to find a play dealing with contemporary Europe. But this work by Matei Visniec, the exiled Romanian writer, is an impassioned two-hander that encompasses the Bosnian war, victimised women, Balkan man and the Freudian nature of resurgent nationalism. Even if you can sense Visniec ticking off his list of chosen topics, you emerge both intellectually informed and emotionally moved.

The setting of The Body of a Woman as as Battlefield in the Bosnian War is a Nato medical facility on the German border where two women come together in the aftermath of the war.

Dorra, from the former Yuogoslavia, is suffering traumatic neurosis as a result of rape. Kate, a 35-year-old Bostonian who has been working as team pyschologist to a mass-graves commission, is also suffering a nervous crisis.

At first Dorra is deeply suspicious of Kate, imagining she wants to subject her to clinical enquiry. But the two women are drawn together by post-war stress and offer each other healing support. It is only when Kate seeks to adopt Dorra's expected baby that we are reminded of the gulf between American guilt and European experience.

Visniec covers a vast amount of ground in his 105-minute play. In one scene the two women get drunk and play tapes of European music while Dorra catalogues the vices and virtues of all the respective nationalities.

It may be highly contrived but, as female drunk-scenes go, it is 10 times more interesting than the acrobatic display of inebriation in Coward's Fallen Angels.

Visniec's central idea, however, is the one contained in his title: that, in the Balkans, rape is a form of military strategy and that resurgent nationalism is often a form of infantile sadism. Given the horror-stories that came out of Bosnia, it is a perfectly tenable thesis. My only cavil is that Visniec announces it journalistically and then proceeds to illustrate it dramatically.

But Alison Sinclair, who has directed and translated the play for Reality Productions, engages you with the plight of these two women and turns then into something more than symbolic victims.

Sladjana Vujovic as Dorra beautifully charts the conflict between physical revulsion at carrying a child of war and the growth of a defiant maternalism. And Gina Landor, through alertly expressive features, captures the American observer's harrowed identification with European female suffering.

It starts as a thesis-play but it ends by showing theatre's rare capacity to give emotional reality to reported fact.

 Until December 2. Box office: 020-7928 6363

But Alison Sinclair, who has directed and translated the play for Reality Productions, engages you with the plight of these two women and turns then into something more than symbolic victims. Sladjana Vujovic as Dorra beautifully charts the conflict between physical revulsion at carrying a child of war and the growth of a defiant maternalism. And Gina Landor, through alertly expressive features, captures the American observer's harrowed identification with European female suffering. It starts as a thesis-play but it ends by showing theatre's rare capacity to give emotional reality to reported fact.  Until December 2. Box office: 020-7928 6363

fields.headline: A thrilling take on Berlioz
fields.standfirst:
OAE/Rattle
Royal Festival Hall,
London
*****
fields.trailText:
OAE/Rattle
Royal Festival Hall,
London
*****
fields.body:
Period performances of the 19th-century repertory are still far from the norm in the concert hall. But Berlioz benefits from that approach more than any of his contemporaries, making the freewheeling imagination of his scoring seem even more remarkable.

In a pair of concerts at the Festival Hall this week, Simon Rattle and the Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment presented a marvellously rich and comprehensive Berlioz portrait: in the first the Symphonie Fantastique was prefaced by the Carnaval Romain overture and the solo cantata La Mort de Cléopatre, while the second was given over to the dramatic symphony, Roméo et Juliette.

It has been done before. Roger Norrington led the way, and he and John Eliot Gardiner have recorded both the Symphonie Fantastique and Roméo et Juliette with period bands. But hearing that music in all its spangled glory in the concert hall as near as possible to the way in which Berlioz must have imagined it still brings a special thrill.

In one way, though these performances were decidedly inauthentic, for the technical mastery of the performances that the OAE delivered for Rattle surely went far beyond Berlioz's wildest dreams.

Every detail was tinglingly precise - the first and second violins were antiphonally seated to right and left, the double basses lined up at the back of the platform, and the sound took on a transparent, three-dimensional quality. Coupled with the sheer drive and dramatic grip of Rattle's conducting, the vividness of every gesture gave these performances a heightened, almost surreal intensity: there was the cor anglais solo in the central movement of the Symphonie Fantastique sounding far more haunted than it does on its fatter-toned modern equivalent, while hand-stopped natural horns are far more menacing in the opening bars of the March to the Scaffold than conventionally muted ones.

In Roméo et Juliette the tiniest effect, such as the magical combination of four harps and antique cymbals in the Queen Mab Scherzo, or even the tambourine and triangle at the end of the second movement, seemed exactly right, and Rattle consistently caught the work's unique hybrid nature, see-sawing between narrative and commentary, and between opera, oratorio, and symphony, just as in La Mort de Cléopatre he had laid bare Berlioz's debt to 18th-century opera seria in general and to Gluck.

Small points: in La Mort de Cléopatre, the soloist Anne Sofie von Otter was sometimes overwhelmed by the orchestra - for all the passion that she invested in every line the scale of her singing was occasionally misjudged - while, in Roméo et Juliette, Friar Laurence's final pronouncements really need a more lyrical and beneficent bass tone than John Tomlinson's.

In the context of such a thrilling and superbly realised pair of concerts, though, with von Otter and Barry Banks the other soloists in Roméo, and fine choral contributions from the BBC Singers and Symphony Chorus, they hardly mattered at all.

 Roméo et Juliette is repeated at Symphony Hall, Birmingham, tomorrow. Box office: 0121-780 3333

fields.headline: Hornby
fields.trailText: In return for its early Christmas present to the City yesterday, Hornby will now be hoping stockbrokers rush out to buy trainsets in time for the real festivities to keep sales on an upward track.
fields.body:
In return for its early Christmas present to the City yesterday, Hornby will now be hoping stockbrokers rush out to buy trainsets in time for the real festivities to keep sales on an upward track.

Buying a toy is one thing. Buying shares is quite another, and for investors to decide whether it is back on track, they will need to believe the plans of outgoing chairman Peter Newey can be sustained by his successor.

Mr Newey, combined chief executive and chairman for the past four years, took action on Hornby's costs by outsourcing the production of train and Scalextric model car racing sets to China.

While this has reduced overheads, it means the group may be vulnerable to continued sterling weakness against the US dollar because of the latter's influence on the Chinese currency. But Hornby is hoping to overcome any currency disadvantages on the strength of the "competitiveness" brought about by outsourcing.

Mr Newey's decision to leave the firm next month is a signal of the completion of the restructuring he has undertaken. He had started talks to improve the lot of his investors, whose shares hit 156p after yesterday's 25p rise compared with 250p two years ago; but he concluded last month that the correct terms could not be agreed.

He is handing over to Frank Martin, who knows about selling toys, albeit the rather smaller Airfix models sold by his present employer, Humbrol. He also worked at toy group Hasbo.

Taking over the chairman's responsibilities is Neil Johnson, a non-executive director and former chief executive of the RAC. Scalextric sets will appear small to him as Mr Johnson once sold Jaguar cars around the world.

The fresh management will have to keep up the momentum on sales, which showed a 10% rise in the first half and helped double profits to £524,000. It seems unlikely things can get much worse, so for that reason alone it may worth giving Hornby a try.

webTitle: Drugs pick up with Bush hopes

fields.headline: Drugs pick up with Bush hopes
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: There were hopes, albeit mild, that the US presidential impasse might be overcome this weekend, and it showed through in a mildly firm London stock market. Yet business was relatively thin and the FTSE 100 ended the day just 9.7 points higher at 6440.1.
fields.body:
There were hopes, albeit mild, that the US presidential impasse might be overcome this weekend, and it showed through in a mildly firm London stock market. Yet business was relatively thin and the FTSE 100 ended the day just 9.7 points higher at 6440.1.

The sense that Al Gore's chances are slipping away showed through most markedly in the drugs sector, where SmithKline Beecham perked up 18p to 928p and its putative merger partner Glaxo Wellcome gained 31p to close at £20.40. A Bush victory would lead to lighter regulation here.

AstraZeneca , meanwhile, gained 97p to £33.32 after a statement saying a Swedish court had ruled in its favour in a patent infringement case involving its best selling ulcer remedy Losec.

In the insurance sector, Prudential caught a few dealers' eyes, adding 49p to £10.87. Followers pointed to a series of analyst briefings focusing on the group's Asian operations. The Pru has also benefited from a series of broker up-grades over recent weeks.

A flurry of bid speculation around internet service provider Freeserve left the shares 13p higher at 160p, with the shares changing hands from 176p apiece at one stage during the day. The latest rumoured suitors are Italy's Tiscali and France's Wanadoo.

Sale talks with Germany's T-Online collapsed in June. Back in March, when its became clear that 80% parent Dixons was ready to offload its holding, the shares were trading at close to £10. Earlier this week, however, the price hit an all-time low of 124p.

Certain other technology-related issues also did well on the day. Spirent was in demand, climbing from 587p to 641p - up almost 9% - after this week's news that it is splashing out £1.1bn on Hekimian Laboratories, a US telecoms network monitoring specialist.

Analysts at investment bank UBS Warburg decided to up-grade software group Sema from "hold" to "strong buy", sparking a 19p recovery in the price to 695p.

Warburg reckons the recent bout of selling has been badly overdone and believes some strong newsflow over the coming weeks will support the price.

The stock has been under a cloud since early September, when Sema reported a fall in underlying profits and found itself under fire from analysts over the inclusion of a £14m Swedish pension refund in its profits.

But Automomy fell 203p to £29.97 and Turbo Genset gave up 75p to £20.22 as the sector generally followed the downward trend set on the Nasdaq on Thursday. Bookham Technology , for example, gave up 45p to £14.25.

IQE , which makes components for semiconductors, fell 75p to 310p - its lowest level since joining the London market in May. Elsewhere, British Vita , the chemicals group, dived from 177p to 152.5p after issuing a profits warning at yesterday's extraordinary general meeting, originally called to vote on plans for a share buy-back.

The company said that since its interim report in September "trading conditions have deteriorated due to reduced demand and continued upward pressure in polymer prices."

"The weakness of the euro continues to affect UK trading with the translational effect also hitting group profits," chairman Jim Mercer added.

British Airways was untouched by news that commercial director Carl Michel is leaving the airline. The company played down suggestions that Mr Michel's departure might herald a wider management restructuring. The shares held steady at 377p.

Shares in Clinton Cards went up 18p to 114.5p after news that a private company called UK Greetings, which was described in a statement as "the holding company of Carlton Cards Limited," has increased its stake from 8% to 11%.

webTitle: Keep the family jewels intact after the deluge

fields.headline: Keep the family jewels intact after the deluge
fields.standfirst:
It can be difficult to get back the full value of treasured possessions lost or hurt in disasters like the recent flooding. But there is a company which specialises in insuring precious items. Stewart Dalby reports

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: It can be difficult to get back the full value of treasured possessions lost or hurt in disasters like the recent flooding. But there is a company which specialises in insuring precious items.
fields.body:
I spend most weekends in Lewes, East Sussex, a town severely hit by flooding during the recent storms. Although I live on a hill I am not immune to storm damage. But it was after I went to the bottom of town and saw the sodden stores - some of them antique shops - that I got to wondering about insurance.

There has been a crop of newspaper stories saying what the storms are likely to cost and that insurance companies do not like paying up. But it is the difficulties attending "contents policies" which really made what is left of my hair stand on end. It is not that I own a bunch of Picassos or anything. But I do have some old books which have personal and some material value, and these are covered by my personal contents policy.

An insurance broker friend tried to explain some of the problems waiting to ambush me. First, insurers do not like providing large overall contents cover. You can specify particular items, like my books, for £10,000, but once you get beyond an overall total of £50,000 they begin whacking on the premiums.

Secondly, most people forget to update their policies so the insurance companies refuse to pay for any appreciation. Say I bought an LS Lowry painting 10 years ago for £2,000, and it is now worth £10,000, it would be the devil's own job getting the insurance company to cough up the ten grand.

Thirdly, the companies want to replace like with like. If, for example, my CD collection was washed away, I might have to itemise each title so that the company could replace them.

For collectors, even of low-value items, a specialised insurer is the best option.

Axa Nordstern Art Insurance now reckons to be the world's leading high net-worth insurance company specialising in art and antiques. Clare Pardy, the chief client manager, reckons that it can be as cheap if not cheaper to insure art and antiques through a specialised company than through the composites. Nordstern, which estimates it covers 30% of British Antique Dealers Association (Bada) members, starts its charges 0.20%. The minimum is £500, which will get you cover of £150,000.

Nordstern's experts agree on valuation and assess the risk before the insurance is taken out and not afterwards. They are prepared to value each book in a collection, for example, and monitor the values each year so there can be no disagreement later. They then pay out in cash if a claim is accepted.

Two innovative products they offer are the Defective Title Cover, extending to all policyholders, that will protect the owner of a work of art that may become the subject of an ownership dispute. The cover may also extend to the cost of legal fees.

The other new policy is the insurance of wine stocks. The increasing prices of wines at auction poses a potential risk which Nordstern now covers as part of its standard policy wordings.

The most attractive product it offers for people like me, though, is its depreciation costs policies. They work like this. Supposing my Jack Yeats painting gets affected by damp because of the flooding. It costs £6,000 to repair. But the value might have dropped from £50,000 to £25,000. Nordstern would pay not only the £6,000 but also the £25,000 loss in value.

 For further information telephone Axa Nordstern Art Insurance, 0207-626-5001.
